HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH: JOSEPH GRAVES; 
Beyond Black and White in Biology and Medicine

BYLINE:  By LINDA VILLAROSA 

 BODY:
Despite the American obsession with race, growing numbers of experts believe that it is a meaningless concept, at least as far as medicine goes. Dr. J. Craig Venter, the president of Celera Genomics, which recently completed a sequence of the chemical letters in the human genome, has said it bluntly: "It is disturbing to see reputable scientists and physicians even categorizing things in terms of race."
 But some still see a place for race in medicine, including a number of African-American scientists and medical experts. 
 Dr. David Satcher, the surgeon general, who is black, has said that "compelling evidence that race and ethnicity correlate with persistent, and often increasing, health disparities among U.S. populations demands national attention."
Under his leadership, the government has directed millions of dollars toward eliminating racial health disparities by 2010. More recently, the Association of Black Cardiologists agreed to sponsor a clinical trial enrolling blacks only, to test a heart medicine designed for African-Americans. 
In his new book "The Emperor's New Clothes: Biological Theories of Race at the Millennium" (Rutgers University Press), Dr. Joseph L. Graves Jr., a professor of evolutionary biology and African-American studies at Arizona State University, argues that races do not exist and that race is simply a social and political construct that the world would be better without.
Racism, he says, is fueled by the idea that human beings can be separated by genetics into races.
Dr. Graves, who is 46 and lives in Glendale, Ariz., discussed genes, race and health recently while in New York City to be on a panel sponsored by the Gene Media Forum, a nonprofit organization promoting dialogue about genome research. 

Q. What prompted your interest in race and genetics?

A. The catalyst was the success of the book "The Bell Curve," which claimed that there was a genetic basis for differences in I.Q. scores between blacks and whites. Most disagreeable was the way it characterized individuals into discrete racial categories they identified as "black" and "white."
This simplistic categorization was not defensible by what we know about human genetic diversity and the amount of shared genes between people of European and African descent in the United States.

Q. You're questioning the existence of racial categories like black and white?

A. Biologically, yes. Only an incredibly small percentage of genes in human beings are involved in skin color. Possibly only six genes determine the color of a person's skin out of between 30,000 and 40,000.

Q. There may be only six genes involved in skin color, but don't they still separate people by race?

A. You have to understand that what biologists mean when they say race is different from what the common person or even society means. There are two parts to the biological definition: first, a race is a population that has significant genetic differences from other populations such that it can be considered a subspecies. A subspecies is a group that is on the way to becoming a new species. Second, a race is a population whose lineage can be considered sufficiently distinct from other lineages.

Q. Aren't the different groups of humans that most people think of as races different subspecies, and therefore different races?

A. Even though we are anatomically different from each other, there is no subspecies in our group. In fact, there are far more genetic differences within a population of humans than between them. For example, there is only about 3 to 7 percent genetic divergence between groups, compared to 20 percent in subspecies of drosophila fruit flies. It doesn't compare.
As far as distinct lineages, throughout history, we have had too much gene flow between so-called races. If sub-Saharan Africans only mated with sub-Saharan Africans and Europeans only mated with Europeans, then there might be unique lineages. But that hasn't occurred, particularly in America. Here, because of our history of chattel slavery, individuals are still classified as black by means of the "rule of hypodescent," whereby one drop of black blood makes one black. However, there is no biological rationale for this rule.

Q. Doesn't race, in the social and cultural definition, have an impact on health? For instance, isn't sickle cell disease much more common in blacks than whites?

A. Contrary to popular belief, sickle cell anemia is not a black disease nor did it originate in West Africa. The gene responsible for sickle cell provides protection against malaria, so it is present wherever we find malaria. That includes Greece, Yemen, India, East and West Africa and the Middle East, where it originated. The only reason we think of it as a black disease in America is because the slaves came from West Africa. If the slaves who worked the cotton fields of America had come from Yemen or Greece, then we would have seen it as a Yemeni or a Greek disease.

Q. You're opposed to raced-based research, like the recent study published in The New England Journal of Medicine, which showed that some heart medications do not work as well for blacks as whites. Why?

A. Present day thinking about pharmacogenetics is that there is genetic variability that relates to how a drug acts in different people. But the genes for drug activity and response don't seem to be localized in the socially defined races. What is more important is to use an experimental design to find out what the genes are. We need to know which genes are responsible for a drug given to someone, and that is not going to be limited by a person's socially constructed race.

Q. Enalapril, a blood-pressure medication, worked less well for African-Americans than whites. How do you explain that?

A. I think there were other variables at play in this study. It is entirely possible that there was some underlying physical cause to explain the different action of the drugs, coded by the social construction of race, but not genetic.
It could have been stress. Blacks and whites were matched by supposed levels of stress, but that was defined only as financial distress. African-Americans in this country face different forms of stress because of racism than whites. It could have also been diet, which was uncontrolled in the study. Since African-Americans and European-Americans don't eat the same diets, before you can explain why the drugs acted differently, you'd need to control for diet. 
Q. Is there no genetic explanation for high rates of hypertension in blacks?
A. Yes, there is a gene linked to hypertension, but we do not as yet have a clear understanding of how genetic variation and environmental differences interact to cause hypertension. For example, the gene for increased risk for hypertension is very high in Nigerians and very low in African-Americans. Yet, African-Americans in Chicago, for instance, are 2.5 times more likely to suffer from hypertension than Nigerians, though you'd expect the opposite to be true.

Q. What is the harm, particularly for physicians, in knowing racial differences in risk for disease?

A. When doctors think in terms of race, they say, "Oh, you're black" and start ticking off what you might have. But what's important to know is a person's family history. You are treating individuals, not races.

Q. What kinds of problems occur when doctors think in terms of race?

A. A student of mine came to talk to me because her husband was having trouble with his doctor. She suggested that her husband might have scleroderma, but the doctor said, "No, African-Americans don't get that disease; it's a Caucasian disease."
I explained to her that that wasn't true because we have significant amounts of European genes, so there are no so-called "black diseases." She went back and talked to the doctor, and he did have it. 

Q. It is still true that blacks suffer from significant health disparities. How do we combat that?

A. No one in America, regardless of socially constructed race, should be getting sick. Studies show that 53 percent of toxic waste sites in America are located in communities that have greater than 75 percent minority composition. Toxic materials are known to have disease causing effects, and mutations can be passed on from generation to generation. So the bottom line is that if we clean up the environment, African-Americans and other minorities will benefit. But so will everyone else. If we also give people access to education and improve the economy, we will begin to see the end of racial disparities in health. These are things we should be doing anyway. It's a win-win situation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph L. Graves Jr., an evolutionary biologist, holds that biological races do not exist. (Tom Story for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Little-Known Laureate of Performance Artists 

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
In what seemed like a flashback to the culture wars uproar of the 1990's, two National Endowment for the Arts grants recently ran into trouble. They had been approved by a peer review panel and the National Council on the Arts, only to held up at the last minute by the endowment's acting chairman, Robert S. Martin. 
 One grant, for a production of the new Tony Kushner play, "Homeland/Kabul," ultimately went through in December. The other, for a retrospective of work by the conceptual artist William Pope.L, titled "Eracism," organized by the Maine College of Art in Portland, did not. The refusal was surprising, as Mr. Pope.L had received endowment money in the 1990's to create art that will be documented in the show. 
 Mr. Kushner, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his play "Angels in America," is a high-profile cultural figure. Mr. Pope.L is not widely known even within the hermetic world of contemporary art. He has many admirers among critics and curators; Lowery Stokes Sims, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, has called him "the poet laureate of male performance artists." But in New York he is still something of an underground presence.
In part this is because he lives and works in Lewiston, Me., where he has taught performance, film and black theater history at Bates College for more than a decade. More important, his output does not fit into ready categories. Combining performance, installation and sculpture, it is formally exacting but improvisational, politically pointed but comedic. Social inequality and consumerism are among his targets, and although his work deals intensively with the issue of race, it upsets preconceptions of what "black art" should be. 
For a New York exhibition two summers ago, he spent several days eating and regurgitating copies of The Wall Street Journal. In 1997 he tied himself to the door of a bank on East 42nd Street and handed out money, playing the role of a panhandler in reverse. In one of a series of "crawl projects" -- part ritual, part endurance test and part farce -- he crawled up the Bowery on his stomach wearing a business suit. 
In a 1996 street performance he walked down 125th Street in Harlem wearing a 12-foot-long white penis cut from cardboard, sending up stereotypes from both sides of the racial divide and suggesting that race itself is a performance dictated by social separation and skewed economics. His gallery shows often include paintings done in peanut butter, murals made of Pop Tarts and installations of Wild Irish Rose bottles: in short, art made from the cheap food and drink of the American poor.
Mr. Pope.L, 46, was born in Newark to a working-class family that moved more than a dozen times during his childhood to various homes in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. He says that autobiography is an important factor in his art, helping to keep it physically ephemeral and adaptable, conceptually idealistic and accessible to a wide audience. 
"I was taught this by my family," he wrote. "My grandmother, my mother and her three siblings. One cleaning woman. Two carpenters. Two nurses. Four alcoholics. One murderer. Not a Ph.D. among them." (Pope.L is the family name his mother gave him; the L stands for Lancaster.)
His education was sporadic but lively and included formative study with the Fluxus artist Geoffrey Hendricks at Rutgers University. In the 1970's Mr. Pope.L was lead singer and songwriter for an avant-garde funk band called Jon Waine, and he worked with the Mabou Mines troupe. He is also a writer and has a novel titled "Anna Prophylactic," which is almost finished. 
Although full-time teaching restricts Mr. Pope.L's personal visibility in major art centers like New York, his career has gained significant support. The national endowment has given him three grants, the most recent in 1995, the year that individual grants were eliminated. He has had five residencies at Yaddo Artist Colony and one at the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture. 
The retrospective organized by the Maine College of Art is to continue as planned, opening in Portland next summer and traveling, though the money for it is not yet fully in place. The Andy Warhol Foundation in New York announced an award of $50,000 for the show after the endowment's refusal, though this was not the rescue gesture it might have appeared to be. The Warhol grant had already been applied for and approved before the endowment uproar. 
Whether or not the show comes to New York, the city will soon be seeing more of Mr. Pope.L. He is now represented by an influential gallery, the Project in Harlem. And in March he will be included in the Whitney Biennial, a lightening rod of a show always ferociously noticed. 
Among his contributions to that exhibition is to be a performance titled "The Great White Way," in which he will crawl from the foot of the Statue of Liberty, onto a ferry and proceed up Broadway, in increments, to the bridge at 207th Street that leads to the Bronx, where his mother still lives. The piece will be the most ambitious of the many similar pieces he has done since 1978. And even with the help of an ergonomic skateboard strapped to his back for occasional relief, he estimates it will take him five years to complete. 
The results, like all his work, will be an attention-grabbing gesture with moral underpinnings. Social privilege and the lack of it is a primary theme. "In New York, as in most cities," he said in an interview with the artist Martha Wilson, "if you can remain vertical and moving, you deal with the world. This is urban power. But people who are forced to give up their verticality are prey to all kinds of dangers." 
But the performance will also be about New York as an integrated community of citizens from many backgrounds, an idea that has particular resonance since Sept. 11. "New York is usually portrayed as an architectural solid," Mr. Pope.L said recently. "I want to find a way of suturing all of the city's cultures together in one action."
He will do so by moving, laboriously, inch by inch, up the city's spine and through many of its varied neighborhoods in a journey that will no doubt bring unpredictable meetings and confrontations along the way. "Artists don't make art," he once said. "They make conversations." And to prevent the conversation with New York that begins in March from being too serious, he will perform his marathon pilgrim's progress of a crawl dressed in a Superman outfit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Pope.L, the performance artist, munching on The Wall Street Journal. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Sweeter 4th Quarter for a Sour Year 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The last three months of 2000 were wonderful for foreign stocks -- even with the fallout from terrorist attacks and a global recession. Still, the first positive quarter in the last seven made the year only a little less painful.
 Foreign equities, including stocks in emerging markets, were up 8.1 percent in dollar terms in the last three months of 2001. That was their first positive quarterly performance since a measly 0.43 percent gain in the first quarter of 2000, according to the Morgan Stanley Capital International's All Country Index, excluding the United States. This index plunged 15.1 percent in the third quarter. 
 The driving forces of the fourth-quarter rally in foreign stocks included sharp cuts in benchmark interest rates by central banks around the world and the big drop in oil prices. The interest rate cuts helped bolster consumer confidence in a coming economic recovery and the lower oil prices acted like a tax cut and reduced inflationary pressures. 
Japan was the major country to buck the trend, with its stock market declining in the fourth quarter. The 6 percent sell-off, in dollar terms, came as the economy fell into a recession, and it was not clear when the government would be able to reverse the downward trend.
The overall performance for foreign stock markets in the fourth quarter was not that far behind the United States, where stocks, as measured by Morgan Stanley Capital International, rose 10.9 percent. But some regions did have a better fourth quarter in their own currencies and in dollar terms, including the stock markets in the 12 countries now joined under the euro. Their markets rose 11.5 percent in dollars and 15.2 percent in euros, according to Morgan Stanley Capital International. (All calculations are through the close of the markets on Friday.)
For the year, the performance is still grim. The leading foreign stock indexes around the world had double-digit declines in their local currencies and a stronger-than-expected dollar has added to those losses in many cases, as the resilient dollar did in the fourth quarter. The biggest currency hit for American investors came in Turkey, which devalued its currency early last year. Stocks in the local currency, the lira, were up 43.8 percent, while they plunged 33.3 percent in dollar terms. For American investors, Japan had the biggest decline among major countries, with a drop of 19.5 percent in yen, which turned into a 30 percent decline in dollars.
The Morgan Stanley Capital International All Country Index, excluding the United States, is down 21.4 percent in dollar terms, its second double-digit consecutive annual decline. In local currencies, the index was off a slightly less depressing 15.5 percent. Before 2000, this index, in dollar terms, was up seven years in a row.
Lower interest rates bolstered markets, particularly those in Europe. The European Central Bank has made two half-point rate cuts since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, while the Bank of England has made two quarter-point cuts and one half-point reduction. The price of oil, meanwhile, ended the year at $19.84 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down 32 percent from $29.17 on Sept. 17.
The surprising resilience of the United States after the terrorist attacks has also helped because its economic performance is so crucial for the rest of the world. 
In addition, it appears that many foreign investors behaved like Americans in believing that they must jump back into stocks right now -- even if it turns out to be too early -- to be assured of big gains. This is one reason that technology stocks did so well in the fourth quarter, analysts said.
Opinion is divided on whether that good performance is continuing. A lot depends on whether the world economy can rebound quickly from the first global recession since the 1970's. Analysts like Joe Rooney, global strategist for Lehman Brothers in London, predict that stocks in Continental Europe will easily outperform American stocks this year. He is also favoring Asian stocks, excluding Japan's. 
But David Bowers, global chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, says it is not yet time to favor foreign stocks. He does not expect Europe to rebound strongly, and he expects the dollar to be stable, rather than weakening against the euro, which would make European stocks more attractive.
Among the big winners in the fourth quarter were some of the recent big losers, including both countries and sectors. South Korean stocks rose 56.6 percent in the local currency, the won, in the fourth quarter and 51.6 percent for the year, according to the All Country Index. Even though a rising dollar against the South Korean won cut that annual gain to 44.9 percent, this market was one of the best stock stories of the year.
But before last year's rally, this index, in won, had plunged 51 percent from the beginning of 2000 to its low on Sept. 27 of this year. The rebound is attributed to several factors, including an economy that avoided a recession, strong demand at home and improved government policies, according to Lehman Brothers. But even with the fourth-quarter rally, the South Korean index is still 27.9 percent from its 2000 high.
Russia was also a big performer, with its index, which trades only in dollars, rising 39.3 percent in the fourth quarter and 53 percent for the year. The recent decline in oil prices is a threat to the Russian market, which rallied early in the year on the rise in prices. The market was also helped by the closer relations between the United States and Russia after the terrorist attacks and by the apparent willingness of many investors to take riskier bets again.
But like South Korea, this Russian rally comes after big losses. The fall from its most recent high, in March 2000 , was 51.6 percent to the low last January.
Mexico is another winner. The new administration of President Vicente Fox and the results of Mexico's membership in the North American Free Trade Agreement helped both Mexico's stock market and its currency, the peso, to rally. Those factors made for a 20.9 percent rally for stocks in the fourth quarter, in dollar terms. The stronger peso was a big plus for American investors, with an annual return in pesos of 12.6 percent, a gain of 18.1 percent in dollars.
The stock market sectors that did well in the fourth quarter include information technology, up 35.9 percent, and discretionary consumer products, up 17.5 percent, in dollar terms. Information technology was helped by a rush of money into hard-hit technology stocks, including those of software companies. Consumer discretionary products were helped by expectations of an economic rebound. For the year, however, both sectors were down, with information technology off 27.6 percent and consumer discretionary products down 10.4 percent. The best-performing sectors for the year were materials, down 6.2 percent, and energy, down 8.9 percent.
The list of losers is much longer and is more than enough to erase the gains made by the winners.
Argentina has had the worst ending of the year, with riots forcing the resignation of President Fernando de la Rua, followed by the resignations of two interim presidents. The stock market was closed from Dec. 20 through Dec. 27 in the wake of the riots that forced President de la Rua to resign. The government has officially defaulted on the nation's $132 billion of debt and has set policies in motion that many analysts say will lead to a devaluation of the country's currency, which is now tied to the dollar.
On Friday, when the market reopened, stocks plunged 8.6 percent.
But the stock market had rallied on the possibility of Mr. de la Rua's resignation, jumping 27.9 percent on Dec. 19 and Dec. 20. That meant the market was up 31.8 percent in the fourth quarter in dollar terms and down only 22.2 percent for the year. Without that two-day rally, the market would have been down 33.4 percent for the year.
Finland was the biggest loser among developed countries. Despite a 47.6 percent rally in the fourth quarter, the Finnish market is down 39.7 percent for the year, in dollars. The main reason for that is the dominance of Nokia, the cellular phone company, in the Finnish stock market. Nokia is down 39 percent for the year, and it counts for more than half of the stock market's capitalization.
China had a fourth-quarter rally of 12.9 percent. For the year it was down 26 percent, in dollar terms. Although China has joined the World Trade Organization, its economy has been slowing, and some analysts expect the slowdown to worsen in the first half of this year.
Since Sept. 21, which was the bottom for most markets after the terrorist attacks, Germany has had a much stronger rally than the United States, rising 31.5 percent, compared with 19.6 percent for Wall Street. Its fourth quarter was also stronger -- 15.9 percent, compared with 10.9 percent -- although the German economy ground to a halt. In a year in which the economy was supposed to bounce back, German stocks are down 24.2 percent, in dollar terms, about twice as much as United States stocks.
Greece has not had an auspicious first year as the 12th country under the euro. Its stocks plunged 32 percent for the year, despite a 11.3 percent rally in the fourth quarter. Being outside the euro did not help Britain. Its market was up a weak 6.2 percent in the fourth quarter and off 16.1 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: M.B.A. Schools Shift Focus to Jobs 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER

 BODY:
When planning began for the reorientation program for students returning to the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T. last September, the initial goal was to help them choose courses wisely and start them thinking about what their dream job might be. That goal changed over the summer.
 The job market for graduates of M.B.A. programs has rapidly worsened, so reorientation evolved to include far more emphasis on identifying potential employers, polishing resumes and networking. 
 "It's been a long time since people had to pound the pavement," said Sloan's dean, Richard L. Schmalensee. " 'Reorientation' is the right word," he said, because the school had to shift its own attention to help its students do the same thing. 
With the deteriorating economy and the threat of further terrorism -- and as dreams of e-business riches are being replaced by nightmares of unemployment -- business schools are doing a lot of reorienting. Deans are trying to figure out what they need to do in this volatile new world to find employers for their graduates, even as they welcome an avalanche of applications from laid-off workers or people seeking to hone their skills to avert being caught up in layoffs.
This year, far fewer companies -- 30 percent fewer at some schools -- are visiting business school campuses to recruit, and those that are have made clear that their hiring needs have plummeted, according to both students and officials at M.B.A. programs. Patrick T. Harker, dean of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, called this "the worst job market in a very long time," adding that the current economic climate is a shock to students. "This group of students has never seen a down market," he said.
To cope, students are exploring industries that would once have held no interest for them as they find that the consulting jobs they coveted a year ago are now unavailable, insecure or simply unappealing. That is also leading faculty members to reassess the classes they offer, as the popularity of courses about the Internet and start-ups wanes.
At the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, more than 475 students will attend a winter workshop this month on interviewing skills; that number is up from 150 last year.
"We are in a period of introspection," Mr. Harker said. The issues are not new, he said, but the downturn in the economy, coupled with the terrorist attacks, has cast them in sharp relief. The top priority this year is finding jobs for graduates, most of whom have never seen a market this tough.
"We've reached out beyond the traditional recruiters," like consulting firms and investment banks, Mr. Harker said. This year, there is more activity by smaller companies that once might not have thought they could attract Wharton students, he said.
Even students at Columbia Business School, which has had very strong relationships with banks and consulting firms because it is in New York, are looking at relatively staid and perhaps more stable employers, like Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Unilever and General Motors, said Meyer Feldberg, the school's dean. The environment is similar to that of 1991-92, Mr. Feldberg said. "It was very much like this during Desert Storm," he said, referring to the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf.
This year is likely to be much harder for M.B.A. students at schools that were once considered off the beaten track for many prestigious employers but began attracting their attention during the tight labor market of the late 1990's, said Sidney E. Harris, dean of the J. Mack Robinson College of Business at Georgia State University. Many recruiters, under orders to hire very few people, will limit themselves to the most selective and best-known schools, he said. He estimated that the number of employers recruiting at Robinson had fallen by at least 30 percent this semester.
In response, many schools are reaching out to their alumni, asking them to try to hire new graduates. "That network becomes really important," said Robert S. Sullivan, dean of the Kenan-Flagler Business School at the University of North Carolina. He also said that students were searching much more actively: a group of 29 Kenan-Flagler students organized a trip to Texas to visit energy companies, including Exxon Mobil and the El Paso Corporation. (Of course, that was before the collapse of the Enron Corporation, an energy trader, last month.)
"They've now set up a club that focuses on the energy industry," Mr. Sullivan said. "That has been an industry that we haven't looked to."
Shifts in opportunities have led to changes in what students study. Interest in e-commerce courses, for example, has declined sharply, while interest has increased in biotechnology, as well as in more traditional subjects like finance and marketing.
"We have a basic e-business course that has 90 people in it this year," down from 120 people last year, said Mr. Schmalensee, of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The surge in interest in earlier years was an "e-phenomenon," he said. The same pattern was evident at Robinson and other schools.
Courses on biotechnology-related businesses are becoming more popular, perhaps in place of classes on start-ups, said Mr. Sullivan, of Kenan-Flagler. "This year was the first time that we specifically focused a course on biotech," he said.
Vaguely titled courses on leadership and crisis management are also showing increased enrollments at several business schools.
But even as it becomes less clear what to study and as the job climate worsens, more people are applying to business schools, both to increase their chances of finding jobs and to hunker down during the downturn.
"It's just a booming operation," said Mr. Feldberg at Columbia, where applications to the business school have increased 60 percent so far this academic year. The surge in interest is enormous, he said.
But schools are nervously watching to see whether the downturn in the economy reduces executives' interest in participating in "executive M.B.A." programs, which offer degrees to working professionals. In the late 1990's, many companies paid for executive education programs to retain desired employees, but today the environment is quite different.
So far, many executives are paying for their own educations, both to make themselves more valuable to current employers and to appear more attractive to prospective employers, officials at several business schools said. But there is no way to know how long that trend will continue.
The officials also fear that tighter immigration restrictions on foreign students could cut into business schools' incomes. Such students make up more than a third of the population at many schools. Those students do not usually receive scholarship aid from the schools, so if they do not come to the United States, that revenue source may dry up. Officials at several schools say that it is too early to tell whether the number of applications from foreign students has fallen.
"When I started, you looked out at the world and you thought, 'Boy, how can things get any better,' " said Mr. Harker, who became dean of Wharton in February 2000. "They didn't."

HEADLINE: Crying With Argentina 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; Nicholas D Kristof's column will appear tomorrow.

 BODY:
Although images of the riots in Argentina have flickered across our television screens, hardly anyone in the U.S. cares. It's just another disaster in a small, faraway country of which we know nothing -- a country as remote and unlikely to affect our lives as, say, Afghanistan.
 I don't make that comparison lightly. Most people here may think that this is just another run-of-the-mill Latin American crisis -- hey, those people have them all the time, don't they? -- but in the eyes of much of the world, Argentina's economic policies had "made in Washington" stamped all over them. The catastrophic failure of those policies is first and foremost a disaster for Argentines, but it is also a disaster for U.S. foreign policy. 
 Here's how the story looks to Latin Americans: Argentina, more than any other developing country, bought into the promises of U.S.-promoted "neoliberalism" (that's liberal as in free markets, not as in Ted Kennedy). Tariffs were slashed, state enterprises were privatized, multinational corporations were welcomed, and the peso was pegged to the dollar. Wall Street cheered, and money poured in; for a while, free-market economics seemed vindicated, and its advocates weren't shy about claiming credit. 
Then things began to fall apart. It wasn't surprising that the 1997 Asian financial crisis had repercussions in Latin America, and at first Argentina seemed less affected than its neighbors. But while Brazil bounced back, Argentina's recession just went on and on.
I could explain at length the causes of Argentina's slump: it had more to do with monetary policy than with free markets. But Argentines, understandably, can't be bothered with such fine distinctions -- especially because Wall Street and Washington told them that free markets and hard money were inseparable. 
Moreover, when the economy went sour, the International Monetary Fund -- which much of the world, with considerable justification, views as a branch of the U.S. Treasury Department -- was utterly unhelpful. I.M.F. staffers have known for months, perhaps years, that the one-peso-one-dollar policy could not be sustained. And the I.M.F. could have offered Argentina guidance on how to escape from its monetary trap, as well as political cover for Argentina's leaders as they did what had to be done. Instead, however, I.M.F. officials -- like medieval doctors who insisted on bleeding their patients, and repeated the procedure when the bleeding made them sicker -- prescribed austerity and still more austerity, right to the end.
Now Argentina is in utter chaos -- some observers are even likening it to the Weimar Republic. And Latin Americans do not regard the United States as an innocent bystander.
I'm not sure how many Americans, even among the policy elite, understand this. The people who encouraged Argentina in its disastrous policy course are now busily rewriting history, blaming the victims. Anyway, we are notoriously bad at seeing ourselves as others see us. A recent Pew survey of "opinion leaders" found that 52 percent of the Americans think that our country is liked because it "does a lot of good"; only 21 percent of foreigners, and 12 percent of Latin Americans, agreed.
What happens next? The best hope for an Argentine turnaround was an orderly devaluation, in which the government reduced the dollar value of the peso and at the same time converted many dollar debts into pesos. But that now seems a remote prospect.
Instead, Argentina's new government -- once it has one -- will probably turn back the clock. It will impose exchange controls and import quotas, turning its back on world markets; don't be surprised if it also returns to old-fashioned anti-American rhetoric. 
And let me make a prediction: these retrograde policies will work, in the sense that they will produce a temporary improvement in the economic situation -- just as similar policies did back in the 1930's. Turning your back on the world market is bad for long-run growth; Argentina's own history is the best proof. But as John Maynard Keynes said, in the long run we are all dead.
Back in April, George W. Bush touted the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas as a major foreign policy goal, one that would "build an age of prosperity in a hemisphere of liberty." If that goal really was important, we have just suffered a major setback. Don't cry for Argentina; cry with it.

HEADLINE: Saving Social Security 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "No Help on Social Security" (editorial, Dec. 27): How fortunate that the recommendations of President Bush's Social Security commission seem destined to gather dust. Its mandate to develop private accounts would have undermined the program, which was never intended to be an investment vehicle. 
 It is a social insurance program to supplement private pensions and, as thousands of New Yorkers are painfully aware, to bring a measure of financial security to families when a wage earner dies or is disabled. 
 Given the inevitable boom-and-bust cycles of the economy, it's best to shelve the idea of privatization altogether and dust off the true meaning of Social Security: all Americans sharing the financial risks of growing old or being widowed, orphaned or disabled.

MAX RICHTMAN
Washington, Dec. 30, 2001

The writer is executive vice president, National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare.

HEADLINE: British Columbia's Liberals Deliver a Tax Cut, Then Pay Dearly 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 31 

 BODY:
Residents of British Columbia will receive a big cut in their income taxes on New Year's Day, their second in six months. But far from winning applause, the province's governing Liberal Party is experiencing a drop in public support.
 Tax cuts were a major promise in the campaign that brought the Liberals to office in the province in a landslide election win last May. The Liberals, led by Gordon Campbell, a former secondary school teacher, real-estate executive and three-term mayor of Vancouver, won all but two of the 79 seats in the western province's legislative assembly. They defeated the left-leaning New Democrats, whose 10 years in office were marked by a growing public role in the economy and numerous tales of economic mismanagement. 
 With the Jan. 1 reductions, personal income tax rates for provincial taxes -- which constitute a much larger share of overall taxes for Canadians than state taxes do for Americans -- will have been chopped by an average of 25 percent, turning British Columbia from one of Canada's most heavily taxed provinces to one with some of the lowest tax rates.
The problem for the new government is that the cuts have coincided with an economic downturn. Rather than reverse the tax cuts, the Liberals have cut government spending.
The Liberals "promised more than they could deliver," said Philip Resnick, a political science professor at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver.
The forestry industry, which contributes about one-fifth of the province's gross domestic product and employs about 14 percent of the workers, has been hit by weakening demand and by hefty American anti-dumping tariffs on Canadian softwood lumber. Falling commodity prices have hit mines and oil and gas producers.
In addition, fewer American tourists are visiting British Columbia since the Sept. 11 attacks.
Falling tax revenues and heavier demand for social services have turned a budget surplus of 1.3 billion Canadian dollars, about $815 million, in the fiscal year that ended on March 31 into a large deficit.
A government-appointed panel concluded in July that "unless government makes some fundamental changes, there will be a persistent excess of spending over available revenues, which represents a serious threat to the financial health of the province."
The government plans to reduce the provincial civil service by 28 percent, or 9,800 jobs, including 4,800 layoffs.
A three-year spending freeze has been imposed on health care and education, the two biggest items in the province's budget. Benefits under the government-financed drug plan are being tightened.
Gary Collins, British Columbia's finance minister, contends that the tax cuts will actually help the situation. "By fueling consumer spending and business investment, they will help to restore our province's economic leadership position," he said.
But many British Columbians disagree. A poll conducted by Ipsos-Reid Canada in mid-December indicated that the Liberals' approval rating has dropped to 49 percent, from 71 percent just three months earlier.
What concerns many British Columbians equally is a sense that the province is returning to a long tradition of political polarization. 
The Liberals "are governing as if there's no need to continue to dialogue," said Norman J. Ruff, political science professor at the University of Victoria, in the provincial capital.

HEADLINE: Oil Deals That Warmed Customers' Hearts Leave Them Steaming 

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN with JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
For the last few years, Thelma Di Diego has locked in the cost of heating oil for her home in Montclair, N.J., because she wants both certainty and savings.
 Last winter, when oil was about $1.80 a gallon, Mrs. Di Diego paid just $1.15, cutting her costs by more than $1,000 on the 1,600 gallons of fuel she uses each year. 
 But the contract that Mrs. Di Diego signed in June to pay $1.25 a gallon this winter has proved to be a bad bet. With the economy weak and cold weather arriving late in the Northeast, heating oil prices today are 40 percent lower than a year ago. 
"We pay $1.25 a gallon when it's going for 80 cents," Mrs. Di Diego said, and that is a painful gap. "Every penny counts," she added, "especially with the economy and when you're retired."
Many homeowners throughout the Northeast, where more than a third of all homes are heated with oil, are echoing her sentiments as oil prices dip well below the rates they locked in over the spring and summer. Never mind that last year, when oil prices were high, they reaped big savings.
"We've been getting many calls from angry customers," said James W. Pierson, president of the J. W. Pierson Company in East Orange, N.J., which sells Mrs. De Diego her home heating oil. "We try to explain the difficulties of the market, that we buy the product in advance from major oil companies, but some people don't understand it."
Heating oil is a mom-and-pop industry, unregulated by government, and there is no data on the number of customers who lock in contracts ahead of the heating season rather than take their chances on market prices. Dealers say that customers are more prone to sign contracts after a winter when oil prices are high, like a year ago -- and that the customers who try to be canny shoppers are the ones most easily disappointed when prices make unexpected moves.
"People who normally shop around for pricing are the ones who get more upset than the ones who stay with you and understand these situations," Mr. Pierson said. "All of a sudden the price drops, and they want out of the contract. It doesn't work like that, but people don't care. Today's consumer is price-driven."
Because the business is extremely competitive, homeowners can sometimes negotiate with a supplier for a lower rate if market prices drop below the contracted price. The industry, of course, discourages such bargaining.
"A deal is a deal," said Eric DeGesero, executive vice president of the Fuel Merchants Association of New Jersey. "If the price goes the other way, as it did two years ago, when the price shot up dramatically, you don't see people asking to pay more."
The situation is more complex for natural gas customers. To meet the needs of large numbers of gas users, nearly all utilities buy fuel on long-term contracts. When prices spike upward, the deals generally moderate the pain, but when supplies are ample, consumer prices do not fall as sharply as prices at the wellhead.
Moreover, because most utilities need state regulators' approval for rate changes, consumer gas costs tend to lag movements in the market price for natural gas.
That analysis is borne out by government statistics. Consumers nationally paid an average of more than $10 per thousand cubic feet for natural gas last winter, a hefty 60 percent increase over the price in the winter of 2000. But the spot price for natural gas almost quadrupled in the same period, a statistic that means the commodity costs may not have been fully passed along.
The higher prices kept filtering through the system to consumers through the spring and summer, however, even as spot prices fell back to earth. The Energy Information Administration, part of the federal Department of Energy, does not have up-to-date consumer price information. But its early estimates are that natural gas prices for consumers in October and November were significantly below the prices a year ago. That would mean that lower spot prices had finally begun trickling down to consumers.
The fixed-price contracts for oil primarily affect homeowners in the Northeast and the Middle Atlantic states, where more than three-quarters of all houses depend on oil for heat. Oil is used to heat 11 percent of the houses in the Midwest, 6 percent in the South, 4 percent on the West Coast and 1 percent in the Rocky Mountain states.
Given that big utility companies and energy traders armed with weather forecasts and market intelligence can bet wrong on oil prices, the average consumer can do little more than act on gut instincts when offered a chance to lock in a price for heating oil months ahead of time. 
"It's like buying insurance," said Larry Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "Here you're buying peace of mind. When you buy a fixed-price deal, you're saying you want the certainty that you're not paying more this winter. For people who like budgeting, fixed prices are a good thing."
Customers who are a little more adventuresome might choose a price-cap option, which guarantees that they will not pay more than a specified price no matter what happens to market prices for oil. That arrangement is another kind of insurance policy, and customers usually pay a premium for it. 
Most companies offer lock-in rates only during the spring or summer months, when the coming winter's heating oil prices are just a guess. Occasionally, though, there is less guesswork involved. The Halstead-Quinn Propane Company, a dealer in Mount Kisco, N.Y., that serves Westchester and Putnam Counties and the north Bronx, is offering to lock in a rate of 99.5 cents per gallon through Jan. 1, 2003.
"The only reason we can do this is because we are just signing up to sell heating oil," said Robert Almeida, a manager for Halstead-Quinn.
Such offers, of course, are no help to homeowners who are already committed to higher rates, like Michael Diamond, a homeowner in Woodbridge, Conn.
Over the summer, Mr. Diamond, who owns Premiere Maintenance, a company that provides janitorial and landscaping services, locked in a price of about $1.15 a gallon to heat his split-level home, which has 3,000 square feet. Though he will lose money on the deal, he is not very upset.
"I'm not unhappy because two years ago I was locked in at $1.12 and it was going for about $1.70," he said. "I've been with the same oil company for three years. I use 700 to 800 gallons a year. This year I may be overpaying by a nickel or a dime, but it's offset by what I did in the winter of '99."
Mrs. Di Diego is philosophical, too. "It's a chance I took, and I lost out," she said. Still, she is fairly certain that she will let her costs float with the oil market in the future.
"I don't think I'll ever do this again," she said. "In the future, I think I'll risk it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES; 
The Euro Takes a Visible Shape: Pocket Change

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Tuesday, Jan. 1 

 BODY:
Europe's dream of a common currency became tangible this morning, when euro notes and coins became the legal tender in 12 nations with a combined population of 300 million.
 Cash machines from Madrid to Helsinki began dispensing euro notes as soon as the clock struck midnight, culminating a process under way for a decade. 
 Until today, the euro has been invisible and almost untouchable. It was traded in money markets and used in securities transactions, but it was of little use in buying a newspaper, baguette or cup of coffee. 
Now that coins and notes are available, some hope the currency will open the way to a closer political union among European nations. Page A8. 
The euro has already had a profound economic impact -- one that most economists consider healthy. Thanks largely to the euro, Europe today is far more efficient, flexible and stable than it was when leaders committed themselves to a single currency 10 years ago.
Inflation and interest rates are now as low in Italy and Greece as they are in Germany. Sharply fluctuating exchange rates within Europe, which caused havoc for companies as recently as 1993, have been virtually eliminated.
The euro's most profound impact, however, has been in reshaping the economic ground rules in Europe. Because of the tough entrance requirements to join the euro club, governments have been forced to reduce their budget deficits. They have surrendered their authority to tackle problems by printing more money, instead handing power over monetary policy to the politically independent European Central Bank.
Just as a common currency makes it easier to compare prices among countries, it also makes it easier to compare economic performance, said Frits Bolkestein, head of the European Commission's efforts to push ahead a single European market. And because the currency fluctuations have disappeared, those differences are easier to exploit.
It is no accident that Spain, Portugal, Ireland and the Netherlands have all grown much faster than bigger countries like Germany and France. The smaller countries have put themselves through wrenching reforms and then surged ahead by offering lower labor costs, greater flexibility or a combination of both.
Romano Prodi, now president of the European Commission, was prime minister when Italy was struggling to win acceptance into the euro club. He remembers how Italian interest rates were two and three times the German rates. He remembers how top German officials initially treated Italy's ambitions as almost laughable.
But Italy did make it into the club. It cut its deficit, stabilized its exchange rate and brought down its inflation to German levels. As investors became more confident in Italy, interest rates on Italian bonds dropped to some of the lowest levels in history. That reduced Italy's huge interest rate payments and helped bring down the deficit even more.
"For me, as an Italian, the euro is pure joy," Mr. Prodi said in an interview.
It is easy to forget, and even many Europeans do, that the euro has existed since Jan. 1, 1999. That was when Germany, France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Spain, Italy, Portugal, Ireland, Austria, Finland and the Netherlands officially locked their national currencies together and created the euro as a new combined currency. Greece joined the group two years later. Britain, Denmark and Sweden have stayed out.
To be sure, the euro has been a disappointment to those who expected it to challenge the dominance of the dollar. In the three years leading up to the introduction of euro notes and coins, the euro has not eroded the dollar's position as an international reserve currency. It has not brought Europe's economic growth up to that of the United States. 
And even now, when the American economy is in recession, the euro has not become a safe haven for international investors. The dollar still accounts for 68 percent of the reserve currencies held by governments around the world, while the euro accounts for only 13 percent.
The shaky confidence of investors about Europe is etched clearly on the value of the euro: still down about one-fifth against the dollar since 1999, the euro is worth about 90 cents.
Another example of the euro's impact is in changing the ground rules for doing business, including the way companies raise money.
Before the euro, European companies raised money primarily by borrowing from banks. The single currency, which brought with it a single range of interest rates, opened the way for a European corporate bond market. Because investors no longer had to fret over the comparative strength of the Portuguese escudo versus the Dutch guilder, they could pool bonds from different countries, creating a big, efficient market.
Large companies began raising millions and billions of euros by selling bonds. The volume of corporate bond issuance in Europe has quadrupled in the last four years, according to economists at Deutsche Bank.
To some extent, Americans have the luxury of watching the euro as bystanders. In and of itself, the single currency has only a limited and indirect bearing on American trade and investment ties with Europe.
In theory, a single currency makes Europe a more efficient, and therefore, better place to invest. But investors have poured far more money into the United States in the last few years, convinced that its economic growth will remain stronger than Europe's for the foreseeable future.
That judgment is shared by European central bankers, who think that Europe's long-term growth is about 2.5 percent a year while that of the United States is closer to 3.5 percent.
Most economists think that difference is the main reason the euro's value against the dollar has failed to recover much even after the United States sank into recession this year.
Many economists, including those at the European Central Bank, say this gap reflects Europe's inability to push through economic reforms that would make its labor markets more flexible and its way of doing business simpler and more efficient. The euro provides pressure for reform, and the European Central Bank is a cheerleader for reform. But neither can by themselves make it happen.
"The common European currency is a solid building," remarked Rolf Breuer, chairman of Deutsche Bank. "But there are still some things that need to be done in terms of interior design."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Main Stock Gauges Fall For Second Year in a Row
The three major stock market averages have now fallen for two consecutive years for the first time since the brutal recession years of 1973 and 1974. But a rally in the final three months helped to create optimism that the worst is over for both stocks and the economy.
 With moderate declines on the final day of the year, the Dow Jones industrial average finished 2001 off 7.1 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 13 percent and the Nasdaq composite sank 21 percent. Page A1. 

The last three months of 2000 were wonderful for foreign stocks, but the first positive quarter in the last seven made the year only a little less painful. World Business, Section W.

Business Schools Review Approach
The job market for graduates of M.B.A. programs has rapidly worsened, so the reorientation program for students returning to the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T. evolved to include far more emphasis on identifying potential employers, polishing resumes and networking. "It's been a long time since people had to pound the pavement," said Sloan's dean, Richard L. Schmalensee. " 'Reorientation' is the right word." With the deteriorating economy and as dreams of e-business riches are being replaced by nightmares of unemployment, deans are trying to figure out what they need to do in this volatile new world to find employers for their graduates. C2.

Influence Without Paper or Coins
Europe's dream of a common currency became tangible this morning, when euro notes and coins became the legal tender in 12 nations with a combined population of 300 million. But the euro has already had a profound effect on the economy in Europe. A1.

Difficult Year for Merger Advisers
The business of advising companies on mergers and acquisitions fell by slightly more than half last year, to $1.71 trillion from $3.46 trillion in 2000, according to preliminary figures. However, the business of underwriting stocks and bonds climbed about 24.7 percent. C4.

No Deal Reached With Big Board
The Giuliani administration was unable to close a long-sought deal with the New York Stock Exchange to build a heavily subsidized new trading complex on Wall Street. B5.

Qwest to Share Customers' Data
Some customers of Qwest Communications re angry that the company intends to share with its subsidiaries data like phone services used, billing information and places called. C2.

F.C.C. Told to Re-Examine SBC Plan
A federal appeals court ordered the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider whether SBC Communications should be allowed to offer long-distance phone service in Kansas and Oklahoma. A three-judge panel ruled that the commission did not pay enough attention to competitors' complaints that SBC charged too much for access to its network. Shares of SBC fell 32 cents, to $39.17. C2.

EchoStar Ordered to Keep Channel
A federal judge granted a temporary restraining order against the satellite operator EchoStar Communications, which had threatened to drop the ABC Family channel because of poor ratings, Walt Disney. C3.

9 States Oppose Microsoft Delay
Nine states seeking stricter antitrust penalties against Microsoft asked a federal judge to reject the company's proposal to delay hearings in the case until the summer. C2.

Hyundai Securities Extends Talks
Hyundai Securities of South Korea extended a deadline for selling shares in it and two affiliates to a consortium led by American International Group. World Business, Section W.

U.S. Financial Markets Are Closed
All United States financial markets, government offices and banks are closed today in observance of New Year's Day. Most overseas financial markets are also closed. The markets will reopen tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Today the Europeans Are Jingling Euros, Musing on the Unity They'll Buy Europe 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: SAARBRUCKEN, Germany, Dec. 27 

 BODY:
Here in the Saarland, where French and German blood once spilled with gory regularity, the frontier barriers are gone, and, starting on Tuesday, a single European currency will jingle in people's pockets on both sides of the border.
 Some euro coins carry the German eagle, some the French tree of liberty, some the monarch of little, nearby Luxembourg, but all have the same value. 
 Soon, as people travel more, coins with the symbols of other nations will mix more and more. That will create a kind of coherence from the cacophonous history of wars that will make Europeans feel more European, opening the way to a political union. 
That's the idea, anyway, and Doris Leroux-Keilhauer is willing to give it a shot. "It's certainly more than a change of coins," she said. "It will have a political impact, but exactly what that will be we don't know." 
Jo Leinen, the Saarland's representative in the European Parliament, is confident. "People for the first time in their lives are carrying Europe with them in their pockets," he said. "And I'm sure a European identification will flow from that."
With Europe now economically united, national leaders squabble over the future politics of Europe. There is a great disconnect between people's pride in being European -- not Russian or American -- and their considerable distaste for the institutions that this greater Europe has engendered, which seem to be of the governments, by the politicians and for the bureaucrats.
Polls consistently show that most people favor the idea of a united Europe, Mr. Leinen said, and they are proud of their decades of peace since the horrors of World War II. "But they don't like European institutions or the practice of European politics," he said. "We have a Europe built from the top down, not the bottom up. 
"This is a Europe of the governments, not of the citizens. They built Europe without the Europeans, behind closed doors. There is a democratic deficit, and we have to fix it." 
Mrs. Leroux-Keilhauer, now 56, was born in 1945, as the war ended, and neighboring coal-rich Alsace-Lorraine, which the Nazis had joined with the Saarland and called Westmark, was taken back by the victors. She works at Saarbrucken's fine historical museum in the castle square, where the Gestapo headquarters were and where Alsace's strange history, caught between France and Germany, is laid out nicely.
The nationality of the people of this region has changed five times since the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71. The people of Saarland have voted twice this century, in international plebiscites after German defeats in both World Wars, to return to German sovereignty. The last time, in 1955, the vote was dominated by the desire to join the German postwar "economic miracle" and have the strong, stable German mark.
After a transition period, the mark came to the Saarland on July 6, 1959 -- known as "Day X." Werner Mockel, 62, remembers the vote and the excitement of getting the mark, much the way the East Germans felt in 1990 with reunification, when they, too, could put the real mark in their pockets.
But the introduction of the euro, a kind of "Day E," brings no particular joy, he said, only worries about the economic influence of supposedly less-disciplined nations, like Italy and Greece. "At least with the euro you can compare, you can go to Spain or across to France and see more easily if it's a rip-off or a decent price," he said.
The historical experience of the people here has made them more wary of nationalism than most, said Mr. Leinen, who remembers the shock he felt as a young boy, born in a village straddling the French-German border, trying to visit relatives on the French side after the Saarland became German again in 1957.
"For the first time there was a border, with guards asking for passports, and we kids didn't have them," he said. "I was 9, and I remember saying to my parents, 'These borders are stupid.' "
Ms. Leroux-Keilhauer still carries her French maiden name and the German name of her late husband. "I'm a good example of German-French cooperation," she jokes. Her brother's wife is from Normandy and she has relatives in Montreal, so she's now studying French, and finds this new world a lot safer and more palatable than the old.
"I feel German, but also European," she said. "Europe is something real, but it's hard to define."
Is the euro a step to a real European state? "Well, it could be," she said, wary, then bolder: "I hope so. I'd like to see it. But not like today." 
By that she meant the bureaucracy that Brussels, the informal capital of the new Europe, represents to people, and the lack of democracy. 
"Many people are afraid to lose the mark," she said. "People are afraid prices will go up. But they didn't ask us. The decision was made for us."
The German wariness is real. But it was Helmut Kohl, the former chancellor, who sold away the mark in exchange for German reunification. Facing opposition from the Francois Mitterrand, the president of France at the time, Mr. Kohl did a deal: German support for the euro in exchange for French support of reunification.
At the Maastricht summit meeting of the European Union in February 1992, the deal was done, and a common currency, which the former British prime minister, John Major, once called a project "with all the quaintness of a rain dance and about the same potency," will now unite a market of some 306 million people -- but excluding Britain, Sweden and Denmark.
But there is something hollow here. If the euro coins are a metaphor for coherence from diversity, the euro bills are a metaphor for an artificial unity, constructed by artists and ad men and approved by politicians. The bills have no faces, no heroes, no models for life or culture. They are amalgams of bridges and buildings and doors that are pan-European, but designed to be identified with no particular country. In a sense, they are a euphemism for a culture that does not exist, because no one can agree upon it. Even Homer is regarded as too Greek, Leonardo da Vinci as too Italian.
In France, Philippe de Villiers, a conservative politician, said people should mourn the passing of national heros like Marie Curie and Pascal from their banknotes in favor of "anonymous computer-generated images of bridges and arches leading to nowhere."
With her complaint that no one asked the Germans about the euro, Ms. Leroux-Keilhauer also puts her finger on another big problem with the European project that Mr. Leinen, the European member of Parliament, understands. 
"We must create a legitimacy of its own for European politics, with European parties, European elections and full competence for a European Parliament to control a European executive," said Mr. Leinen. "We need to move from a Europe of treaties to a Europe of a constitution."
Mr. Leinen is at one end of a debate about the political future of Europe that the fuss and euphoria over the euro hides. How to balance the power of the governments with the democratic idea of one-person, one-vote? Will Europe be a real nation-state, and if so, what kind? Will it be a federation, more similar to the United States, or a confederation, with most real power kept by the nation-states?
The debate is taking on an urgency with the prospect of enlargement. In the next few years, a Europe already unwieldy with 15 nations will expand to as many as 25, and the rules will simply have to change, with different weight given to countries of different sizes.
Even the current practice of a six-month presidency of the European Union by each nation in turn will become almost ludicrous with 25 countries, probably including Poland, Hungary and others. Germany or France would get the presidency only once every 12.5 years. 
Previous efforts to deal with such questions have ended in national acrimony and absurdly complicated formulas that no ordinary European understands, as at the 2000 European summit meeting in Nice, France. So this year, at Laeken, Belgium, governments threw the problem to a constitutional convention, to start next March, headed by Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a former French president. Mr. Giscard compares the event to the American constitutional convention of 1787, and the job is expected to take two years.
A reunited Germany, with the largest population and hence the largest democratic weight, wants parliament to rule Europe, with the role of the governments lessened. France, always wary of larger Germany, wants to preserve a significant measure of sovereign control. Smaller countries, and those with significant Euroskepticism, like Britain and Denmark, want even more sovereignty. 
Still, says Christoph Bertram, director of the SWP foundation, a research institution that advises the German government and Parliament, most Europeans agree that something must be done, and soon. "The ways that governments have messed up the constitutional structure has led to great wariness on the part of most people," Mr. Bertram said.
But with France holding national elections in May, and Germany in September, a serious debate is likely to start only afterward. "For Germany and France, this constitutional change is a big challenge," Mr. Bertram said. "But I'm not sure they know how to meet it yet."
But for now there is amusement and even anticipation. "I have three wallets, one for France, one for Germany and one for Belgium," Mr. Leinen said. "Now I can throw two of them away."
Petra Weiss, 30, an architect shopping in Karstadt's department store, thinks the transition to the euro will go smoothly. "It's this year's millennium bug," she said. It will make her shopping in the nearby French town of Sarreguemines, where the cheese and fish are better and the taxes on food lower, that much easier. And with the euro, it will be simpler for residents here to pay their French parking and speeding fines.
But the euro by itself is just a symbol of unity. "The euro will get us closer together," Ms. 
Weiss said, "but it's only a little step. The European idea is still fiction, I think. Europeans must unite in order to have a real voice and weight in the world, and the euro won't solve this problem."
Despite all the intra-European squabbles over immigration, politics, security, enlargement and the like, says Michael Naumann, editor of Die Zeit, the huge influence of the world's single superpower, the United States, will push Europeans together.
"Change comes in times of need, for political and military reasons, and finally out of the looming fears that America's role as superpower will manifest itself as it has done after Sept. 11," Mr. Naumann said. "Colin Powell brings together a great alliance on paper, and in reality, the Pentagon decides what to do. In the long run it produces bad blood among leaders and may be counterproductive to European interests. 
"So to have a more level playing field, there is a foreign-policy necessity for Europe to come to terms with its priorities -- not anti-American, but pro-European. It has to happen."
There is a growing confidence that something called Europe is being built, said Antonio Puri-Purini, an adviser to the Italian president, Carlo Ciampi. "I don't buy for a second this nonsense that the euro was done for technical reasons to help the common market," he said. "Big events don't come out of small lines of bureaucratic thinking. And this is a big event. For countries that managed to kill each other in the millions in the last century, this is not such a bad result."

HEADLINE: Meeting at Harvard On Diversity Policy 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 31 

 BODY:
Jesse Jackson said today that he would meet with the president of Harvard University to discuss its diversity policy after reports that two prominent black professors may leave because of a dispute with the administration.
 "The clarification will be good for Harvard, its faculty and the nation," Mr. 
Jackson said. "Harvard is our flagship university, and there is concern expressed by the professors about the need for an unequivocal commitment to affirmative action, or inclusion." 
 The university's president, Lawrence H. Summers, is looking forward to a meeting "to talk about a range of issues," a Harvard spokesman, Joe Wrinn, said.
The professors, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Cornel West, are considering leaving for Princeton.
Aides to Mr. Summers said Professor West felt insulted in a meeting between the two men in October at which Mr. Summers encouraged Professor West, who has recorded a rap CD, to embark on serious scholarship and to become a leader in fighting grade inflation.
Mr. Jackson said music should not be an issue. Whether Professor West "was on a rap record or conducting a symphony, he's written 16 books, held in critical acclaim," he said.
Mr. Summers, inaugurated in October, said he supported diversity and meant no offense in the meeting.

HEADLINE: Merger Business Plunges for Investment Banks, but Underwriting Is Up 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

 BODY:
So who suffered the least?
 For 2001, that is the measure by which Wall Street banks may have to measure their performance. 
 Indeed, with the economy and the stock market in a deep slump last year, Wall Street bankers had a tough time trying to do anywhere near the amount of business they did in 2000. In total, business dropped off by about 15 percent, according to Thomson Financial.
The most lucrative business, advising companies on mergers and acquisitions, fell by slightly more than half, to $1.71 trillion from $3.46 trillion in 2000, according to preliminary figures from Thomson. However, the business of underwriting stocks and bonds climbed about 24.7 percent in 2001, buoyed in part by a raft of interest rate cuts. 
"It was definitely a sober year," said Richard Peterson, chief market strategist at Thomson Financial.
Goldman Sachs, which just six months ago appeared to be losing market share in offering merger advice, ended the year with a commanding 34.8 percent of the business, considerably more than its next biggest competitor, Merrill Lynch, which held 27.7 percent of the market and edged out Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for second place.
Despite Goldman's lead in market share, its business fell 52 percent compared with 2000. Merger business for Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse First Boston dropped even more, 58.6 percent and 56 percent.
When simply measuring which banks suffered the least compared with their performance the year earlier, J. P. Morgan Chase and Merrill Lynch easily came out on top. J. P. Morgan moved up the rankings to fifth from sixth and lost only 33.4 percent of its business, showing its strength despite the tough market. Likewise, Merrill Lynch leaped to the No. 2 spot for the first time in nearly five years, though its business was down 35.7 percent compared with the previous year.
"We genuinely picked up market share and narrowed the gap this year," said Douglas Braunstein, global head of mergers and acquisitions at J. P. Morgan Chase. The bank has been especially aggressive since its own merger to package merger advice with other capabilities like offering loans to clients.
But Mr. Braunstein says the importance of the bank's loan facilities might be overstated. "While we bring the balance sheet to the table, about 70 percent of the projects we work on are on the sell side, takeover defenses or delivering fairness opinions -- projects that do not directly involve the use of our balance sheet."
Merrill Lynch managed to gain ground because much of the merger activity was in more traditional sectors and not in technology, where the bank has struggled. "For us, we were helped by the fact that the activity this year was across a wide variety of industries and geographies," said Steven Baronoff, head of global mergers at Merrill Lynch. "That breadth plays to Merrill's strengths."
Merrill jumped in the ranks thanks, in part, to a rash of deals that came together in the last month. In fact, Mr. Baronoff said he was surprised by the amount of activity after Sept. 11. "I would have anticipated a more dramatic decline," he said. According to Thomson, 1,795 deals valued at a total of $204.2 billion were announced after Sept. 11, about one-quarter for the year in the United States.
Most experts expect next year will show signs of a recovery. "The M.& A. market has been in decline for 18 months," said Stephen Munger, Morgan Stanley's global co-head of mergers. "We're beginning to see a lot more discussions. The question is when companies will be prepared to act."
For all the declines in the mergers and acquisition business, a boon in stock and bond underwriting helped offset those losses.
The Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup unseated Merrill Lynch as Wall Street's lead underwriter of stocks and bonds in 2001. The top-spot trophy is a coup for Citigroup, which, like J. P. Morgan Chase, has been using its commercial banking muscle to help score clients in other parts of its business. According to Thomson Financial, Salomon Smith Barney ranked No. 1, with $486.9 billion in total proceeds raised, and Merrill was No. 2, at $432.7 billion. Last year, Merrill led with $377 billion in issues, compared with $355.7 billion for Citigroup.
Credit Suisse First Boston remained in third place, with $346.9 billion, while J. P. Morgan Chase edged up one spot, to fourth, with $315 billion, and Goldman rose one position, to fifth, with $302.5 billion.
Morgan Stanley, which was fourth in 2000, slipped to sixth last year, with $277.6 billion.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
POLYMER DEFAULTS ON LOANS AND EXPLORES ITS OPTIONS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 The Polymer Group, which laid off 600 workers last month, said yesterday that it defaulted on loans and that its lenders planned to block the company from paying $17.8 million to bondholders due tomorrow. 
Polymer, which makes fabrics used in diapers and surgical products, said it was "continuing to explore various financial restructuring alternatives with third parties." It has hired an investment banking firm, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, for assistance. The company, based in North Charleston, S.C., said its bank lenders had given it more time to repay the full amount of the loans. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: LAYOFFS (90%); BANKING & FINANCE (88%); BONDS (88%); INVESTMENT BANKING (83%) LABOR AND UNEMPLOYMENT; COMPANY REPORTS AND FORECASTS

An Extraordinary Shift In City Government
The mayoral transition from Rudolph W. Giuliani to Michael R. Bloomberg began when Mr. Bloomberg took an oath at the city clerk's office. This represents an extraordinary shift in city government, with the change of mayoralty; a new comptroller, William C. Thompson; new public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum; and a mostly new City Council. A1

Violent Crime Falls Again
Violent crime in New York City registered its biggest drop in five years in 2001, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced, a decline all the more startling because it came as many other cities saw their violent crime rates start to increase. For Stocks, 2001 Was a Loss

The Euro Era Begins
Europe's dream of a common currency became tangible this morning, when euro notes and coins became the legal tender in 12 nations with a combined population of 300 million. Thanks largely to the euro, Europe is now far more efficient, flexible and stable than it was when leaders committed themselves to a single currency 10 years ago. A1
