HEADLINE: Top Secret Memo 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
 To: Abdiqassim Salad Hassan, transitional president of Somalia
From: Transitional Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Somalia
 Somalia's most urgent priority at the moment is to get bombed by the Americans. Then maybe somebody will finally start paying attention (and money) to our country.
Fortunately, it seems likely that the Americans may oblige -- although there is always the risk that they will get mixed up and hit Somaliland or Sierra Leone instead. Washington is thinking about the next stage in its war on terrorism, and in the search for a target that all players can agree on, these supposed terrorist training camps in Somalia keep coming up.
American knowledge of Somalia is based almost entirely on "Black Hawk Down," now playing at cinemas. It leaves viewers strongly supportive of dropping conventional or nuclear weapons on Somalia.
(Indeed, it's hard to think of a Westerner who has really understood our country since Sir Richard Burton sneaked inside, in 1854. And, considering what he wrote about the sexual practices of our women -- even if he wrote in an admiring tone -- he studied us with rather too much enthusiasm.)
Of course, our government has hitherto publicly opposed being bombed. We have used various arguments against bombing, noting that if our feeble government were toppled and total chaos reigned, then Somalia could become an even greater breeding ground for terrorism.
We have invited Americans to inspect for themselves. Indeed, it would be nice if American officials dared to come, joining us for a traditional Somali breakfast of camel liver and then chewing khat and getting high together, for a mellow discussion of international terrorism. But it seems unlikely.
So let us adopt a new tactic. If some suspected training camps in the desert are to be bombed, let us embrace that fate. Frankly, there is nothing here left to be destroyed. 
The reality is that our transitional government, only a year old, is already falling apart. We are broke and have not paid police or soldiers for three months. Our biggest company, Al Barakaat, has been shut down because Washington claims it was financing terrorists. 
Somalia's greatest problem is that it has been forgotten by the West. Here we are, arguably the poorest and most devastated country in the world, three-quarters of our population malnourished, only 14 percent of our children going to elementary school, our own "national" government ruling only half of this one city of Mogadishu, and we can't get any assistance.
We can call our strategy the Manila Method. The Philippines had a long-running, annoying insurgency in the south, and for years the Americans paid no heed. But then Manila claimed that its insurgency was intimately related to Al Qaeda. 
Bingo -- the Americans condemned this new threat to international security and are helping to eradicate it.
Now in Somalia, everyone is trying to play the Qaeda card. Our enemies, the warlords in the city of Baidoa, are fulminating about the supposed Qaeda networks here, in hopes that the Americans will drop bombs on us. The separatists in Somaliland are offering to help the Americans against us. In the old days, factions in Somalia pretended to be Communist or capitalist to win favors from the superpowers; now they talk about Al Qaeda.
So here is our proposal, Mr. President. We issue a formal invitation to Osama bin Laden to come to Somalia, on behalf of a fictitious warlord in some nearby town -- say, Gialalassi. Then we will announce a few sightings.
The Americans will obligingly drop bombs. At a penny a pound, the scrap metal itself will be a boon to Somalia's economy. And if Osama does come, we can turn him in and claim that $25 million reward.
Then we will announce that Gialalassi has surrendered, and the Americans will arrive to search for Osama. Journalists and aid workers will come, each carrying money belts full of hundred-dollar bills. Foreign exchange reserves will soar. Somalia will be saved.
It may seem strange, Mr. President, that the only way for one of the poorest, most fragile countries in the world to get international help is for it to be linked to terrorism and then bombed. But that is how the world works today.

HEADLINE: THE MAYORAL TRANSITION: TAKING OFFICE; 
New Leaders Say Fiscal Belts Are on the Last Notch

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL

 BODY:
While New York City's top three elected officials took their oaths of office yesterday, promising to repair the city's economy, fix the school system and create housing for working families, dozens of new members of the City Council looked on and braced themselves for the hard choices ahead.
 "As we tackle the financial challenges before us, we should not abandon our values or our priorities," William C. Thompson Jr., the new comptroller, said in his inaugural address. "We must be mindful of not sacrificing our long-term health to meet short-term needs." 
 Precisely how the City Council and the Bloomberg administration will do this remains to be seen. For the fiscal year beginning in July, the city faces a $4 billion budget gap -- nearly 10 percent of the entire budget. 
The comptroller's office and the office of the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, were already facing budgetary troubles before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in his inaugural address, challenged them to reduce their staffs by 20 percent. Mr. Thompson and Ms. Gotbaum both suggested that it would be nearly impossible to perform their basic functions if they accepted the mayor's challenge. 
Mr. Thompson said his office had already undergone a cut of about that magnitude over the last year and his office might have trouble performing its legally mandated functions to monitor city spending and contracts. 
And several City Council members said they were not sure that it would be wise to make the cuts. "It is nice to be able to say things, but we've got to make sure that we can do them so that the city can run," said Helen Foster, who took over her father's seat in the Bronx. "We need to get in. We need to actually start the business running, going, and find out if in fact it is doable. And right now, at this point, I can't say that it is. Most City Council members have been working with shoestring staff, and so when you talk about cutting, we all kind of, you know, held our breath, like, 'You've got to be joking.' "
Bill de Blasio, a council member from Brooklyn, said that if the 20 percent reduction freed money for education and served people, the cuts could be good. But he cautioned that while the central staff of the Council could withstand the trim, individual members' offices could not. "The bottom line is you can't cut the member offices without really undercutting local service to communities," Mr. de Blasio said.
Several members of the new government said yesterday that the shortage of funds created problems within their own offices and affected the city's ability to deliver services. Officials and others emphasized the need to focus on education, housing and economic development in poor neighborhoods, issues that were campaign priorities before the terrorist attack of Sept. 11.
"The thing that's going to be the most challenging is to navigate the very rough economic times but at the same time make sure that the most vulnerable in New York are able to get services that they need," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, president of the Children's Health Fund and the Children's Hospital at Montefiore, who has worked with the new administration on health issues. Somehow, he said, officials "have to make the city economically promising while also ensuring that the basic safety net gets repaired and actually enhanced at a time when resources are going to be limited."
One way to do that, officials suggested, would be to more fully involve nongovernment groups in performing government services. In his inaugural speech, Mr. Thompson said he would "seek out new and more creative ways of leveraging public and private partnerships for the common good," adding that he would find "new ways to invest in our neighborhoods" to create low-cost housing, boost economic development and increase jobs.
Like Mr. Thompson, Ms. Gotbaum said her job was now even more important, because in a time of economic difficulty, "you need the public advocate here to watch and see who's falling through the cracks."
For example, Ms. Gotbaum said, agency heads in the new administration may be unaware of funds available to them. "That's a role for the public advocate to go and say, 'We'd like to work with you to get that,' " she said.
A group of council members is already at work on a similar agenda. Brought together by the Working Families Party, a political party founded largely by unions, the group includes incumbents like Christine Quinn, Philip Reed and Bill Perkins, all of Manhattan, as well as newcomers like Mr. de Blasio, Gale Brewer of Manhattan and G. Oliver Koppell of the Bronx. Hoping to form a progressive caucus within the Council, the group has developed a list of what it calls common-sense proposals for the new administration. Its agenda focuses on aggressively pursuing state and federal funds already earmarked for certain programs, like grants under Temporary Assistance to Needy Families and the Workforce Investment Act, and to make sure that more eligible families take advantage of school lunch programs, food stamps and the earned-income tax credit.
For her part, Ms. Gotbaum outlined ways to do more with scarce resources. She said she would try to expand her office's ombudsman function by working with the complaint divisions in place at various city agencies. She also suggested that she would accept help from New Yorkers who want to volunteer.
"One valuable legacy of the tragedy is the tremendous reservoir of good will among New Yorkers," Ms. Gotbaum said. "We all want to lend a hand in rebuilding our home. I intend to use my office to tap into this good will, to offer New Yorkers a way according to their talents and abilities to pitch and speed our recovery."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; 
Prognosis for Stocks Brightens After 2 Years of Big Declines

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
FOR investors, 2002 should be better than 2001.
 Of course, that prediction is not exactly going out on a limb. Despite a rally in the fall, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended 2001 down 13 percent, the second straight year the index fell more than 10 percent. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many computer and biotechnology stocks, performed even more poorly, giving up 21.1 percent after a 39.3 percent loss in 2000. 
 So investors, like all Americans, can be forgiven for wanting to put 2001 behind them. And with the possibility of an economic recovery early this year, the outlook for stocks appears solid, at least for the next couple of months. 
But analysts warn investors not to get too giddy. Although the economy and corporate profits will probably be growing again soon, the rate of growth may be lower than investors expect. As a result, stocks will rise only moderately this year, they say.
"It is a foregone conclusion, unless something comes totally off the radar screen, that there will be both an economic and a profit recovery before the end of the first half" of the year, said Charles Pradilla, the chief market strategist for SG Cowen. "But there may be some disappointment with the vigor of the recovery. We are not going to get the terrific profit rebound that we were expecting." Like many strategists, Mr. Pradilla forecasts that the S.& P. 500 will end 2002 at around 1,250, a gain of 8.9 percent from its current level of 1,148.08.
The year just past offers reasons for both optimism and fear. The decline in the S.& P. 500 and the enormous losses suffered by many technology investors are proof that stocks can be dangerous, especially for investors who take on too much risk or use margin loans to increase their leverage.
But as they examine their year-end mutual fund and brokerage statements, shareholders might be wise to remember that 2001 could have been much worse. Over the last three months, the stock market has rewarded the optimists, including many small investors, who kept faith in the resiliency of the economy after Sept. 11.
Since their lows of late September, the Dow Jones industrial average and S.& P. 500 have both gained about 20 percent, while the Nasdaq composite index, which contains most big technology stocks, has risen 37 percent. Almost no one expected stocks to recover as quickly as they have, especially given the failure of Congress to pass a stimulus package to aid the economy. But it now appears as though the economy will pull itself out of recession no matter what Washington does.
Housing construction remains very strong, for example, and consumer spending across the board seems solid, though not great. After plunging in September and October and dipping in November, consumer confidence recovered strongly in December. Initial claims for unemployment benefits are dropping, although they remain high.
Even the technology sector seems to be bottoming out after a yearlong slump. Over the last month, several leading technology companies -- including Cisco Systems, the leading maker of Internet equipment, and Nokia, the Finnish cellular phone company -- have reported that business is better than analysts expected.
"The transition from recession to recovery will start in the spring," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Financial Services Group, which manages more than $300 billion in bonds and stocks.
The recovery is being driven by the Federal Reserve, which cut short-term interest rates 11 times last year, and by plunging prices for oil and natural gas, said Tobias M. Levkovich, equity strategist of Salomon Smith Barney. The combination of lower rates and lower energy prices gives consumers and business more money to spend on other goods and services, helping to stimulate the economy.
In addition, companies spent much of 2001 working off excess inventories, so even a moderate increase in demand this year will lead to higher production and profits. And with inflation low, the Federal Reserve will face little pressure to increase short-term interest rates when the economy does rally.
"I do think the market has seen the worst and that the tendency for the market will be to grind its way higher," said Gail P. Seneca, chief investment officer of Seneca Capital Management, which manages $15 billion.
Ms. Seneca says that the S.& P. 500 will gain 8 to 10 percent in 2002. She expects stocks of midsize companies -- those valued at $1.5 billion to $5 billion -- to do better, rising as much as 15 percent, and she likes specialty pharmaceutical companies and niche manufacturing companies. Two of her favorites are the SPX Corporation, which makes specialty tools and equipment, and the Biovail Corporation, which creates time-release versions of both branded and generic drugs.
Before investors grow too excited, analysts warn that they should recognize that this year's recovery may not be as strong as other post-recession bounces. Consumers are carrying heavy debt loads and do not have much room to increase their spending, while businesses are still trying to figure out whether the investments they made in computers and Internet equipment at the end of the 1990's were smart. Even with the Fed's rate cuts, corporate spending on computers and communications equipment is 30 percent lower now than at the end of 2000.
Long-term interest rates, which are crucial for both the economy and the stock market, have, meanwhile, crept higher over the last month. After falling as low as 4.18 percent in November, the interest rate on the 10-year Treasury note, a benchmark for mortgages and corporate bonds, had climbed to 5.02 percent on Monday. And short-term interest rates are already so low that the Federal Reserve does not have much room to cut them further. The Fed, the nation's central bank, last month cut its benchmark federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans among banks, to 1.75 percent, the lowest level in four decades.
In addition, investors are generally too optimistic about the speed at which corporate profits will recover after a recession, said Steven Wieting, a senior economist at Salomon Smith Barney. At the end of 1990, the average market strategist estimated that profits for companies in the S.& P. 500 index would rise 14.3 percent in 1991. In fact, profits fell 15.3 percent in 1991.
The consensus for 2002 is for net operating profit of $52.71 per share for the stocks in the S.& P. 500 index, an increase of 16.1 percent, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.
Mr. Wieting notes that the S.& P. 500 rallied strongly in 1991 even though profits were far short of expectations. But he warns that a profit shortfall might have more severe consequences in 2002 because stocks are more expensive relative to their earnings than they were a decade ago. The S.& P. 500's price-to-earnings ratio stands today at 25, excluding one-time charges, compared with 15 in January 1991 and a historical average in the mid-teens.
With the S.& P. already expensive, price-to-earnings ratios will probably not expand further, so stocks will rise only as quickly as profits, Mr. Wieting said. "All we've got ahead of us are just expectations of recovery in earnings," he said.
The problem is even more acute in the technology sector, which has had the biggest gains this fall. The stocks of some smaller technology companies have tripled or quadrupled in value since bottoming out in late September. Even giants like Intel have posted gains of 60 percent or more. The average large technology stock now trades at more than 50 times its annual profits, according to Salomon Smith Barney. That is the second-highest level ever, after ratios seen in the fall of 1999.
"There are a number of companies that still have very, very high multiples," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer of New Amsterdam Partners, which manages $1.4 billion.
Ms. Clayman said investors seemed to be hoping that technology companies would rapidly return to the sales and profits they posted during the Internet bubble in 1999 and early 2000. "It's very tempting to say tech led the market up in the bull market, so that's where you need to be," Ms. Clayman said. But investors need to recognize that the technology spending bubble is "unlikely to be repeated," she said.
Instead, Ms. Clayman likes capital goods and basic materials companies, as well as some energy companies. Among her top picks is Pogo Producing, a $1.4 billion energy company with wells in the Gulf of Mexico, Texas and Louisiana. Pogo has "nice properties on their own, yet at the same time there's been a lot of consolidation in the oil patch, and this is an acquisition target," she said.
A potential pothole is the declining quality of financial reporting. Investors have largely shrugged off the collapse of Enron, the Houston energy trader that filed for bankruptcy after admitting that it had for years overstated its profits and understated its debts. But if other big companies are forced to restate their earnings or are suddenly denied access to credit, investors' confidence in corporate financial statements could be severely shaken.
In addition, there is a real, but unquantifiable, risk of another major terrorist attack, which could hurt consumer confidence and the economy. Most analysts say they are simply assuming that a second attack will not occur, because they have no way of figuring out what the effects of an attack might be or how likely it is to happen.
Finally, the United States will probably not get much help from either Europe, where growth has been anemic for years, or Japan, where the economy has been mired in a decade-long slump. Nor have overseas stock markets had much appeal for American investors. All the major European markets, as well as those in Japan and Hong Kong, have performed worse than the S.& P. 500 last year.
Despite the possible roadblocks, the combination of low inflation, low energy prices and decent economic growth should produce solid gains for the market this year, Mr. Levkovich of Salomon Smith Barney said. He predicts that the S.& P. 500 could close this year between 1,300 and 1,350, a gain of 13.2 to 17.6 percent, although he is not as sanguine about 2003 and beyond.
"We got ourselves into a mode in the last five years or so that 20 to 25 percent gains were normal," Mr. Levkovich said. "And that's not normal."

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Christian Northeast)

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets and Investing; 
Individual Investors, While Chastened, Are Not Giving Up

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH not exactly disillusioned by what happened to his stock portfolio in the sliding markets of 2000 and 2001, David J. Sunseri, perched behind a counter at the Pennsylvania Macaroni Company, his lavishly provisioned food emporium in a commercial area called the Strip, grumbled that it had forced him to rethink the future.
 "Of course, everyone lost money," he said, consoling himself that his adviser, Eric M. Koter of Salomon Smith Barney, moved him substantially out of technology before many of the sector's stocks collapsed, helping to hold the erosion of his various privately managed accounts and mutual funds to about 11 percent from their peaks to post-Sept. 11 lows. Compared with what he paid, he's still comfortably ahead. 
 Still, he cringed at the huge hit -- "my biggest disappointment" -- suffered by the mutual funds earmarked for the education of his children, David Jr., 17, and Elizabeth, 14, and wistfully pointed to his seemingly lost chance of retiring to the golf courses and ski slopes while still in his 40's.
"If things had continued," said Mr. Sunseri, who is 45, "another two years, and I'd be gone" from the family-owned business. 
But Mr. Sunseri, though sobered by the first back-to-back annual declines in major averages since 1973-1974, has not fled from stocks; he remains committed for the long haul.
His portfolio these days contains a bit more cash and a greater proportion of blue-chip companies than it did in the halcyon days of technology start-ups, but neither real estate nor bonds hold much allure for him.
In this, Mr. Sunseri seems to have plenty of company, judging from interviews with numerous investors and brokers in the Pittsburgh area. Scarred but largely unbowed, they say the stock market is still the place to be, even as they acknowledge that the five-year string averaging more than 20 percent annual returns that they enjoyed from 1995 through 1999 was probably a once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon.
The 1990's as a whole, in fact, was the best decade in stock market history. Interest rates fell as inflation remained subdued. Corporate profits and productivity climbed. And investors became convinced that stocks had become such safe investments that they no longer required the higher returns relative to bonds -- what economists call a risk premium -- that stock buyers had traditionally demanded. They bid prices up with abandon.
"People were operating with the view that stock markets always go up, and they didn't go down," said Mike Mortensen, chief executive of the PNC Brokerage Corporation, a bank unit with about 125,000 individual accounts, one-third of them in the Pittsburgh area.
The enthusiasm was such that policy makers in Washington began to contemplate some mechanism for allowing Americans to channel Social Security taxes into stocks, an idea now sidetracked by the market decline and, more recently, by the priority of the campaign against terrorism.
John E. Tiano, a 47-year-old dentist with two offices in the Pittsburgh metropolitan area, shared much of this ebullience, succumbing in late 1998 to what he found to be a surprisingly persistent mania for speculative dot-com and other technology stocks.
"I caught a pretty good wave," he recalled, nearly doubling his substantial net worth within three years before heavy tax bills and the market skid brought him back to reality. Even now, he said, he still enjoys a handsome profit.
Nowadays, with a period of sleepless nights and "a lot of internal turmoil" behind him, Dr. Tiano has cut his stock-market expectations to single-digit percentage growth and added to his relatively modest holdings of municipal bonds. But he remains about 75 percent committed to stocks, down from 90 percent, and harbors particular optimism about biotechnology.
"Over all, investor psychology has, I'm sure, been damaged" by the bear market, he said. "But I'm still heavily invested."
Mr. Mortensen concurred that while investors have gravitated in a conservative direction -- his staff is selling many more fixed annuities these days -- risk aversion has prompted no general exodus from stocks.
"We have not had redemptions in any meaningful way, which is sort of surprising to me," he said, referring to bank-sponsored and other mutual funds. And, he added, in every month for the last two years more people have opened new accounts with PNC's brokerage business than have closed their accounts.
Another local investor who caught Nasdaq fever was Mark Brown, a 43-year-old partner in a company that automates the processing of health care data. He dived heavily into high technology in the middle of 2000 "in part because of all the press it was getting," he said ruefully one rainy night as he waited outside the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts for a performance, appropriately enough, of "Les Miserables." The individual stocks in his portfolio lost 55 percent to 60 percent of their value in the last year, leaving him with paper losses.
"A bit of a frenzy" was how he described the market that lured him into fledgling companies working on such novel products as a blood substitute and an ice-repellent windshield.
But while Mr. Brown holds a bit more cash these days, he has shifted no money to bonds or real estate and has hung on to both his mutual funds -- down about 20 percent last year -- and his shriveled portfolio of individual stocks.
"I'm in it for the long run," he said gamely.
Even Kay Barry, a marketer for a health care company, whose once six-figure portfolio has been savaged by the implosion of CMGI, Enron and other former market darlings, is keeping 60 percent of the remaining "mess" in stocks, down from a former 90 percent.
Despite considerable disillusionment -- Ms. Barry, whose misfortune includes skids of 40 percent to 50 percent in mutual funds, wishes her broker had been able to rein in her wild enthusiasm for highflying technology stocks -- she has no taste for fixed-income investments.
"Bonds, I don't think they're going anywhere," said Ms. Barry, joking that she was drowning her financial sorrow in a drink as she waited for a friend one evening in the lobby of the Omni William Penn Hotel.
"I'm getting into real estate," Ms. Barry said, discussing her main financial adjustment. She now owns one home each in Florida, Virginia and here in Pittsburgh.
Nor do investors show much inclination to retreat to the security of certificates of deposits on which yields are minimal following 11 rate cuts by the Federal Reserve last year. A sign in the window of Fidelity Bank recently advertised a 13-month "C.D. special" offer paying 2.9 percent interest, a return just a percentage point above the current annual inflation rate, and taxable to boot.
Stock-market mutual funds, though enjoying continued inflows of money, have fallen from favor with some investors who wound up with large tax bills last April on distributed profits at a time when their investments had shrunk in value, in many cases severely. "That turned a lot of people off to funds," said Mark C. Sekera, a senior investment adviser in the local office of Charles Schwab. "You see a lot of people now who prefer individual stocks for the control" over the tax consequences when they are ready to cash out.
Discussing the idea of investing Social Security money in stocks, Mr. Brown said, "I was never a fan of this, even when the market was breaking all the records." Losses like those of the last couple years, he added, would probably mean calls for "people to be hung from the highest tree."
Judging by investors in Pittsburgh, where respect for the city's smokestack industrial heritage can still inspire a historic marker for a grease factory, the stock market gyrations have taught or reaffirmed some basic lessons: one is the truism ignored in the late 1990's -- that stocks carry risk; another is that diversification pays; and, less obviously, that allocating a portfolio into various types of investments is far more important than the choice of specific securities.
"Disciplined investors are not disillusioned" about stocks, said David S. Williams, manager of the Salomon Smith Barney office here. People are financially better educated these days, he said, and "they understand you're going to have bad times and good times in the market."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK; 
Global Oil Glut Contains Subtle Dangers

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE

 BODY:
WHATEVER happened to the energy crisis? Remember those predictions last spring by the Bush administration that unless the United States expanded oil and gas drilling to federally protected lands and encouraged companies to build a power plant a day, American economic might would atrophy?
 The market, it turned out, took care of matters. When demand was high and energy prices rising during the first half of the year, companies responded: 2001 was the first year in a decade that domestic oil production increased, however slightly, the Energy Department said. 
 But the economic slowdown that deepened after the Sept. 11 attacks, particularly the slumps in travel and trade, have created a global oil glut that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is struggling to control to prevent prices from tumbling any lower. 
Most people see low energy prices as a boon, but they contain subtle dangers. If the price of oil falls too low, the economies of American allies from Mexico to Saudi Arabia could be threatened and the health of the domestic industry and states like Alaska and Texas eroded.
"The United States isn't just the largest consumer of oil but one of its largest producers, up there with Russia and Saudi Arabia," said Adam E. Sieminski, oil strategist for Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "If prices fall very low, it will be hard for a lot of American states."
The question that OPEC and the oil companies have been unable to answer is how to smooth the wild swings in the price of oil and the industry's boom and bust cycles. After the economies of Asia collapsed in 1997 and the fallout spread, the price of oil fell to about $10 a barrel by late 1998. On Sept. 20, 2000, it rocketed to $37.20, the highest level since the Persian Gulf war of 1991, only to tumble late last year.
Gasoline prices, which some at midyear predicted would reach $3 a gallon, had dropped below $1 in parts of the United States by December.
OPEC's response has been to try to manage world oil markets, by raising output when demand is high and cutting production when it is low, to keep the price of of crude oil in the OPEC basket within a range of $25 to $28 a barrel.
But OPEC's strategy of keeping oil prices at those relatively high levels eventually backfired. High prices gave non-OPEC exporters, most notably Russia, the cash to repair old wells, drill new ones, and raise overall output. OPEC cut production 3.5 million barrels a day, or 13 percent, throughout 2001 to try to prop up prices, but Russia and others did not. They, in turn, took over the market share that OPEC had relinquished, and prices continued to fall. Last week, with promises of cuts from nonmembers, including Russia, OPEC ministers agreed to reduce the group's production by 1.5 million barrels a day as the new year began.
Any output reductions OPEC makes this year to shore up prices will be passed on to the major oil companies, all of which pump oil in OPEC territory. Typically, OPEC members direct foreign operators of joint ventures in their countries to reduce production first, before cutting their own production.
David J. O'Reilly, the chairman of ChevronTexaco, has said that the company expected to cut production by 40,000 barrels a day, largely at projects in Nigeria and Venezuela, both OPEC members. The amount is small compared with the 2.7 million barrels a day that ChevronTexaco pumps around the world.
Most analysts say that a price of $20 to $23 a barrel would provide ample revenues for producing countries without endangering a global economic recovery.
"From the United States's point of view, $22 or $23 a barrel of oil would be ideal from both perspectives, because the government is thinking about the future of producer countries," said Gerald J. Kepes, a specialist in exploration and production at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting group.
Yet oil companies are being cautious about increasing their exploration and production budgets because of falling oil prices and uncertainty surrounding the recovery of the global economy. Light sweet crude ended 2001 at $19.84 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after tumbling to $17.45 on Nov. 15 from a peak above $32 a barrel early in the year and a post-attack peak of $28.81 on Sept. 17.
According to a survey by Salomon Smith Barney, oil companies increased spending on exploration and production 24.8 percent in 2001, the steepest jump in 20 years. The companies are expected to increase their spending on foreign projects 9.7 percent this year, but spending on domestic exploration and production, especially for natural gas, is expected to fall 14.7 percent. 
But when the economy rebounds, which economists expect to begin this spring, will the domestic oil industry be ready to ramp up oil and gas production? A protracted lag could lead to higher prices again, as demand rises but supplies remain constrained. "We're certainly looking at the boom-and-bust pendulum again." Mr. Sieminski, the Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown oil strategist, said.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; 
Strong Dollar Erodes Global Investments

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
OH, another year of wondering if the beleaguered euro will finally rally against the dollar. And yes, another year of wondering where the Japanese economy is going and, therefore, wither the Japanese yen.
 Even if sometimes boring, these are important questions for American investors. The strength of the dollar in recent years has eaten into returns, or increased losses, for Americans who are buying stocks and bonds abroad. 
 The bite, which comes when assets in weaker currencies are translated back into stronger dollars, was not that big last year in Europe. The 5.5 percent decline in the euro against the dollar turned a 19.8 percent fall in Germany's benchmark DAX stock index into a drop of 24.1 percent and changed a 26.2 percent plunge in Italy's MIB30 index into a 30.2 percent fall. But in Brazil the pain was more significant. A 16 percent decline in the Brazilian currency, the real, magnified a loss in the country's main stock index, the Bovespa, from 11 percent to 24.9 percent.
While not as bad, the difference to investors in Japanese stocks was nonetheless negative. The 8.7 percent rally of the dollar against the yen since the terrorist attacks has made the loss for American investors in the Nikkei 225 stock index a 33.6 percent decline, rather than a 23.5 percent drop for the Japanese.
The currency news was not all bad, however. In Mexico, a rally of the peso against the dollar increased a 12.7 percent gain in the Bolsa stock index to a 18.5 percent return for American investors.
What is in store for this year? It is difficult to tell because the dollar has had a habit, recently, of defying conventions. As the American economy slowed last year it was thought that the dollar would decline in value. While it weakened some, it still remained relatively strong. After the terrorist attacks, a further decline was expected. But that did not occur -- the dollar is actually slightly stronger against the euro than it was on Sept. 10, and is much stronger against the yen.
On a broader basis, using an inflation-adjusted, trade-weighted dollar against the currencies of the trading partners of the United States, the dollar ended last year at a 12-month average that was the strongest it has been since the 12 months ended in September 1986. That was the end of a period in which the dollar had been its strongest since it began to be freely traded in the early 1970's.
For the year ahead, many analysts expect the dollar to continue to rise in value against the yen. At 131.62 yen per dollar at end of the year, the Japanese currency is already at a three-year low against the dollar.
One reason for the forecast is that the Japanese economy is in recession again and there is no recovery in sight. The second reason is that the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, and the government are already driving down the value of the yen. A weaker yen could help a recovery by making Japanese exports cheaper and, therefore, more attractive abroad.
Larry Kantor, global head of foreign exchange strategy at J. P. Morgan, said the dollar could rise to at least 135 yen by the end of 2002. If the Japanese government gets more aggressive in its effort to reduce the value of its currency, the dollar could move even higher, he said.
One check on a tumbling yen could be China, which has already indicated that it is not happy about a cheaper yen. This is because a weaker yen could allow Japanese companies to compete more effectively with Chinese exporters in the world market.
Analysts are uncomfortable forecasting the euro's course this year in part because the past predictions of a strong euro all proved to be wrong. Since its debut, the euro has fallen 23.6 percent in value, including a 5.5 percent fall last year. The good news was that this was the smallest of the three annual declines, and that the lowest low for the euro -- so far -- was hit in 2000.
This is the year the euro, which was born on Jan. 1, 1999, as an accounting unit, actually becomes a tangible currency in 12 countries as banknotes and coins denominated in marks, francs, lire, pesetas, guilders, escudos, punts, markkas, shillings and drachmas finally disappear. But it is not clear that this will make any difference.
Some analysts see the euro declining for a fourth consecutive year. Others said they thought the euro would finally rally, ending the year modestly stronger against the dollar. At the end of 2001, each euro was worth 89.13 United States cents, down from 94.27 cents a year earlier.
Mr. Kantor of J. P. Morgan is in the positive camp, but not because he thinks the euro has suddenly changed and is going to be strong. J. P. Morgan economists have a very weak forecast for the United States economy in the beginning of 2002, and the firm's equity strategist thinks the stock market will do poorly. Because of this, Mr. Kantor believes investors will shy away from American markets, which will mean that European investors will not need to buy as many dollars and so the United States currency will fall in value. He is forecasting the euro at $1 by the spring, an increase of 12.2 percent from the end of 2001. (But that would still leave the euro 16.7 percent below its debut value of $1.16675.)
But when the American economy does turn around later in the year, the dollar will rebound, Mr. Kantor said. So by the end of 2002, he expects the euro to be around 90 cents to 95 cents. At 95 cents, that would be a 6.6 percent jump, a positive year for this beleaguered currency. Mr. Kantor also warns that if the American economy turns out to be stronger than expected, the euro probably will not rally.
As far as other currencies go, there is it likely that Argentina will unhitch its peso from its tie to the dollar and let it float. That would cause the Argentine currency to plunge and the dollar to soar.
But many analysts said that other Latin American countries have detached themselves enough from Argentina's financial and economic problems to avoid having their own currencies hurt by trouble in Buenos Aires. While the Brazilian real fell sharply last year, a strong end-of-the-year rally turned a 31.2 percent decline to 16 percent fall and showed that fallout from Argentina was less dangerous than many investors and economists had feared.
As for the Mexican peso, it had a good year because of the bounce from the new administration of President Vicente Fox. Mexico is also now usually seen as a member of North American Free Trade Agreement rather than a Latin American country. But the rally of 2001 is likely to lose its momentum this year, some analysts said.
So investors cannot expect much help for their foreign investments from the dollar in 2002.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; 
Oversupply and Slackened Demand Vex Commodity Markets

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
NOWHERE do the laws of supply and demand govern economic activity more nakedly or completely than in the buying and selling of commodities.
 For the most part, commodity prices moved lower for the better part of 2001 because supplies were high, demand contracted and the dollar, the currency in which most commodities are priced, was strong. The outlook for this year is not much different, even if the global economy begins to recover. 
 "In order to have a recovery in prices, we are going to need more than a modest recovery in economic activity," said Steve Strongin, director of commodities research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
"To draw down inventories, we are going to need a substantial rebound. Growth of 4 percent to 5 percent for a few quarters or 3 percent for a couple of years would do it."
An unweighted index of commodities futures prices published by the Commodity Research Bureau rose 11.1 percent in 2000, largely because of sharp gains in energy prices. In the year just concluded, that same index fell 16.3 percent. After reaching its high of 231.88 on Jan. 22, it closed the year at 190.61
"The C.R.B. index will probably recover somewhat next year," said David Rinehimer, head of futures research at Salomon Smith Barney.
"But without a weather event or some exogenous factor you can't predict, I don't see any markets that should have dynamic moves to the upside, or to get excited about."
For most of last year, oil prices were the exception to the relentless slide in futures prices, but they tumbled late in the year on a supply glut, as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries struggled to persuade other oil-producing nations to agree to cut output. Crude oil, which began the year at $26.80 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, climbed above $32 and stayed in the upper $20's until it declined from a post-attack high of $28.81 on Sept. 17, to $19.84 at the end of the year.
Natural gas plunged 73.7 percent in futures markets, to $2.57 per million British thermal units.
Abundant harvests dragged down prices of corn and soybeans and consumables like coffee. Live cattle also slipped, but hogs managed a small gain on the year. "Natural disasters, drought, low commodity prices and global surpluses have hurt producers," Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said last month.
Corn, a $4 billion-a-year export for the United States and the nation's most important feed grain for raising beef, pork and poultry for Americans' tables, fell 11.1 percent, to $1.9975 at the end of the year.
One reason for the price slides was that export markets were shrinking since December 2000, when Japanese inspectors said that tests of shipments of American corn had detected StarLink, a genetically modified corn that is not approved for human consumption in the United States and is banned in Japan and some other nations. The Agriculture Department said corn exports were running 4 percent lower so far this crop year compared with the period in 2000. Japan, Taiwan, Egypt and Mexico, the biggest buyers of American corn, have all cut purchases. 
Other grains were mixed. Wheat futures rose 3.4 percent from 2000 to end the year at $2.89 a bushel.
Industrial commodity prices were undercut by a sharp decline in manufacturing. Gold, once a weather vane of inflation expectations, also had a lackluster year. Gold closed at $279 a troy ounce, down from a high of $293.25 on Sept. 26 but up from $273.60 at the end of 2000. Platinum fell 19.1 percent.
In large measure, the market became saturated with goods because at the start of 2000 producers had little reason to expect the world economy would stumble.
"Demand was a lot weaker than anticipated at the beginning of the year," Mr. Rinehimer said. "Not many folks were looking at a global recession."
William E. Byers, director of futures research at Bear, Stearns, said that "historically, people have looked at the supply side as the most important part of the equation because demand for most commodities is usually pretty static."
There are signs that the imbalance of supply and demand is beginning to right itself, Mr. Strongin said. But it will take many months before the change shows up in prices.
And it will take some time to bring commodity prices back up to where they stood at the end of 2000.
Reflecting the slump in the industrial economy, copper prices fell 22.9 percent last year. Cotton tumbled 42.9 percent. Coffee prices, reflecting abundant harvests, slid to 30-year lows and ended the year down 29.5 percent.
The slump has aggravated already weak conditions in developing countries like Chile and Brazil, which are major commodity exporters. Brazil is forecasting a 2002 coffee crop that could match the record set in 1961 of 39.6 million 132-pound bags. The United States Agriculture Department puts Brazil's 2001 harvest at an estimated 33.7 million bags. 
In contrast, in some commodities like aluminum, capacity has been shrinking in important producing areas like Brazil and the Pacific Northwest. "Investment is very low, with a net reduction in capacity," Mr. Strongin said. Still, it will take time for inventories to be worked off.
As tracked by the London Metal Exchange, industrial metal inventories bottomed in the first quarter of 2001, said Mr. Byers of Bear, Stearns, and have been rising ever since.
"This is a decent indicator of what is going on in the market," he said. "By the time that indicator turns, prices will have already moved."
Consequently, analysts say, by next January the picture will look much brighter.
"There was excess capacity for much of the 1990's," Mr. Strongin said. "We would expect prices to stabilize over the next six to nine months and then move higher. It is highly likely you will be hearing very optimistic statements 12 months from now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harvesting coffee beans in Costa Rica. Overproduction pushed coffee prices sharply lower last year, when they plummeted to a 30-year low. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; 
Junk Bonds Still Have Fans Despite a Dismal Showing in 2001

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
AFTER a year filled with failures in the high-yield debt market, junk bonds are expected to live up to their name again in 2002.
 With the economy weak and many companies carrying a lot of debt, default rates on junk bonds will probably rise to new highs this year, analysts say. But that prospect has not deterred junk bond investors, who returned to the market with some vigor in the fall of 2001. Like stock investors, high-yield bondholders are expecting the nation's economy to recover this year and figure that prices on junk bonds have already fallen far enough to compensate them for the higher risk of defaults, analysts say. 
 "The market has already adjusted to reduced expectations," said Sean Egan, the managing director of the Egan-Jones Ratings Company, an independent bond rating agency in Wynnewood, Pa. "The bonds are already way down."
The last 12 months have been by any standard a grim stretch for high-yield debt, the worst year since 1991, when the United States last fell into recession. About 8.9 percent of high-yield bonds defaulted last year, up from 6.3 percent of junk bonds in 2000. Over all, including investment-grade debt, as of Dec. 26, there had been defaults by 196 bond issuers around the world on $107 billion in debt in 2001, according to Standard & Poor's, up sharply from 2000, when 117 companies defaulted on $42 billion in debt.
Leading the march down were the telecommunications companies that raised hundreds of billions of dollars from investors during the last five years to build high-speed fiber optic networks around the world. The list of high-profile telecommunications bankruptcies includes Winstar Communications, 360networks and the At Home Corporation, and more big defaults in the sector are expected. Global Crossing, which has $11 billion in debt, announced on Dec. 21 that it had suspended paying dividends on some of its preferred stock to conserve cash.
Over all, high-yield bond defaults will probably peak in the summer, said Diane Vazza, the managing director for global fixed-income research at S.& P. "We are looking at a bottom of a recession in the first quarter of 2002," Ms. Vazza said. "Typically, defaults peak six months after that."
Standard & Poor's forecasts defaults on 11 percent of high-yield debt in 2002, as struggling companies burn through their cash. But the market has already anticipated many of those defaults, she said.
As a result, some investors are still opening their pockets to buy junk debt. Despite the rising default rate, companies were able to issue $85 billion in high-yield bonds last year, compared with $54 billion in 2000, Ms. Vazza said.
The credit quality of junk bonds varies widely. At the upper end of the junk spectrum are those rated Ba1 by Moody's Investors Service or BB+ by S.& P. Bonds that the rating agencies consider riskier because the issuing companies and municipalities have less likelihood of repaying them may be rated triple-C or D or even be unrated. Junk prices are also much more volatile than those of other bonds, often moving in tandem with the equity markets. After Sept. 11, junk bonds tumbled, along with stocks, but by the end of last year prices were up and yields easing in the sector.
One sign that the $650 billion junk market has stabilized is the shrinking spread in yields between junk bonds and bonds issued by the federal government, which are considered the safest form of debt. Ten-year junk bonds ended the year paying an interest rate of 10.70 percent, or 5.68 percentage points higher than the 10-year Treasury note, according to Bloomberg Financial Markets. That spread was down considerably from Oct. 11, when the high-yield rate peaked at 12.09 percent, or 7.43 percentage points above the 10-year Treasury. The shrinking spread means that investors are not demanding as much extra interest to buy junk bonds.
Also, the ratio of credit rating downgrades to upgrades is expected to drop quickly, another sign that companies are becoming healthier and bonds less risky, Ms. Vazza said.
There will "still be companies that are defaulting," she said, "but in terms of credit quality, we are going to see an improvement."
Still, junk bonds remain too risky for many investors, said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh. "They may yield more than Treasuries, but the risk of being wrong is much greater on the downside."
For investors who do want to speculate in high-yield bonds, one alternative may be a junk bond mutual fund, which can offer investors the relative safety of diversification.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Volatile World of Junk Bonds"As investors jumped back into the high-yield bond market in late 2001,the yield premium over Treasury notes of comparable maturity narrowed sharply. Still, analysts see more defaults in 2002. Graph tracks weekly yield spread between 10-year junk bonds and 10-year Treasury notes from 1997 to 2001.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: DANCE NOTES; 
Dueling Tributes To Graham Legacy

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Performances of work by Martha Graham have been hard to come by, especially in New York, Graham's home base, since the start of a bitter 19-month struggle over the rights to Graham's name and choreographic repertory. Each side in the dispute -- the Martha Graham Trust and the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance -- is planning a performance for April 18 to commemorate the 76th anniversary of Graham's first formal concert, and each program is expected to include her dances as well as work by other choreographers. 
 A federal district judge in Manhattan, Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, effectively gave the center the green light in mid-December to perform Graham dances denied them by the trust, which licenses the works, pending the settlement of an appeal by the trust. "We're up and running and dancing again," said Dale Cendali of O'Melveny & Myers, the lawyer for the center. Neither side has settled on a space or the dancers for its concert. 
 "They do this at their own risk," said Judd Burstein, the lawyer representing the trust and its director, Ronald Protas, to whom Graham left her work on her death in 1991. Mr. Burstein is appealing a ruling made in August by Judge Cedarbaum that allowed the center and its school to continue using Graham's name and teaching her technique, which Mr. Protas had sought to prevent. 
"We will not try to stop them," Mr. Burstein said, adding that as a new lawyer on the case he needed time to prepare briefs for the appeal hearing. Mr. Burstein said, however, that the center might have to pay substantial damages if Mr. Protas won the appeal. 
The first phase of the trial focused on Mr. Protas's trademarking of Graham's name. The second phase, which begins on April 22, will address copyright or the ownership of Graham's work. 

Holiday Cheer
Rebecca Kelly, the choreographer, was unprepared for one telephone call she got on Christmas morning. "Merry Christmas!" an unfamiliar voice wished her. The caller was Donna Whitmer, who was raising money for the Hopkinsville Dance Team of Kentucky. Ms. Whitmer was not asking for a donation. Instead, she had a check for $1,000 that the team -- 19 girls in grades 9 through 12 at the Hopkinsville High School -- wanted to donate to Ms. Kelly's company -- Rebecca Kelly Ballet -- and school after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
"We pay for our own uniforms, and we were raising money for that," Ms. Whitmer said of the team, which dances during halftimes of their high school's football and basketball games and competes nationally. "But it didn't seem appropriate. We wanted to do something for New York. The girls are too small to donate blood, but they wanted to be able to do something." 
They also wanted the money they raised taking up collections and selling ribbons and raffle tickets to go to "a real person." Being a dance team, they reasoned, they ought to give the money to a dance group. Heather Sensing, another team fund-raiser, had relatives in Manhattan who knew of Ms. Kelly's work. One of Ms. Kelly's programs -- dance classes for parents and young children -- was in Battery Park City and was closed after Sept. 11. 
Ms. Kelly has not decided what to do with the money, a choice the team left up to her. She has thought of giving scholarships to families who lost a parent in the attack or had to leave their homes downtown. "They can't think about the pleasures they used to have," she said. "There are so many other things they've had to focus on." 
Ms. Kelly has found it hard to go back to creating dances after the attack. "It was so encouraging to get this phone call from Kentucky," she said. "We're feeling so disoriented now. We need to get back to the rituals of dance and provide a circle of warmth." 

Studio Splendor
The terrorist attacks forced the Mark Morris Dance Group to postpone the opening of its spacious, airy new home in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a block from the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The formal opening occurred on Dec. 19, attended by dancers, writers, donors and politicians, some of whom spoke. Leave it to Mr. Morris, however, to cut to the heart of the matter. 
Dance seems to be in an edifice-building mood, despite the weak economy, but the Morris building will probably be one of the best-appointed. Will this unaccustomed splendor deter dancers from embracing their famously poverty-bound and single-minded profession with the necessary passion? Will dancers be spoiled? "This is something people deserve," Mr. Morris said firmly. He urged his guests to enjoy "the wonderful dignity" of the rest of the building. This -- and the choice of dance as a profession -- was proof, he said, that dancers are serious adults.

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks U.S. Waiver On Air Quality 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 31 

 BODY:
Citing the Sept. 11 attack, the Pataki administration has asked Congress to waive federal air quality controls on New York's transportation projects for four years.
 The governor is seeking an amendment to the Clean Air Act, in part, state officials say, because the small state agency that did the work of meshing the transportation and air quality plans, the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, was on the 82nd floor of 1 World Trade Center. Three of its staff members are missing and presumed dead, and its records and computers were lost when the trade center was destroyed. 
 State officials also contend that the disaster has wrought such large-scale changes in the movement of people around the region that the old transportation plan is not valid anymore. The destruction has created new, pressing needs, like rebuilding West Street and the PATH train and subway tunnels, and, possibly, adding ferry service to replace the lost PATH line, or creating new park-and-ride locations. In the meantime, officials say, changed commuting patterns, especially for former PATH riders, can mean more driving and more air pollution. 
"We need the waiver in order to give us time to rebuild the transportation plan and also allow us to make immediate improvements in response to the World Trade Center attack," said Jennifer Post, spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "Without the waiver, we're frozen into transportation projects that don't make sense any more."
But the request has alarmed environmentalists, and its prospects in Congress are uncertain. Critics contend that the state's reasoning is greatly overstated, and that a waiver would set a dangerous precedent by undermining the Clean Air Act. The waiver the state is seeking, they say, is so broad and would remain in place so long, until late 2005, that it would apply to projects that have nothing to do with the recovery from the attack.
"It would mean they could go ahead and do a project without having to first gauge what the air quality impact would be, and that's not good," said Andrew H. Darrell, New York regional director of Environmental Defense, a nonprofit group.
Some Democrats suggest that the Pataki administration may also hope that obtaining the waiver will speed up the flow of federal money to the state for road and construction projects, to help the sagging economy. 
Under current rules, for every area that does not meet federal clean-air standards, including New York City and its suburbs, the federal government imposes targets for reducing pollution over several years. The state must show that its projects, like building highways or widening old ones, will not prevent it from meeting those targets, or it will lose the federal aid that transportation projects rely on.
State officials say New York cannot embark on any projects that are not in its current plan unless it first conducts a detailed study showing that it will still comply with air quality requirements. They contend that the state needs the flexibility to bypass that time-consuming requirement, and even to exceed its pollution targets.
The Pataki administration began seeking these changes in mid-December, when the State Department of Transportation sent a letter to members of Congress asking for the waiver, and when Carl Johnson, a deputy commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, traveled to Washington to lobby for it. Officials say that Gov. George E. Pataki himself, a Republican, has not called members of Congress to press for the change.
There is little chance that Congress would go along without the support of New York's delegation, and the waiver's prospects are murky, at best, in the Democrat-controlled Senate. New York's senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, are both Democrats. Mrs. Clinton, in particular, plays a pivotal role because she sits on the Environment and Public Works Committee, which would consider such a bill. She declined to be interviewed on the matter.
Environmental Defense, the Natural Resources Defense Council and another group, the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, have sent a letter to Mrs. Clinton contending that if any bill is passed, it should be "a more targeted waiver," with offsetting requirements like strict pollution controls on construction equipment and ferries, and replacement of diesel buses and trucks with vehicles that burn cleaner fuels. These groups, usually among the governor's closest environmental allies, have taken the lead on the issue, while groups more critical of Mr. Pataki have stayed in the background.
"They have to show that they need a waiver, and if so, it has to be very narrowly drawn," said Ashok Gupta, a senior economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "Some kind of waiver might make sense, but giving a blanket waiver, much less for four years, is not a good idea."
The prospects for a waiver are stronger in the Republican-controlled House of Representatives. Several versions of a bill based on the Pataki administration's request have been printed by the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and Representative Vito Fossella, a Republican from Staten Island who sits on that committee, has taken the lead in stating the administration's case.
Members of New York's delegation, Congressional aides and environmental lobbyists say that the Pataki administration is unlikely to get what it is asking for, but that a much more limited waiver might pass.
"Everyone agrees the state has some problems due to 9/11 that need to be addressed," said a Democratic aide in the New York delegation, "but a lot of people have serious concerns about the implications of this for clean air. And one concern is that it would set a precedent."
Mr. Darrell of Environmental Defense said, "If a bill goes forward, I think it will be a very different bill from what's out there now."
For years, members of Congress from New York have opposed efforts by their counterparts from other regions to weaken the Clean Air Act or make exceptions to it.
"For New York to now ask for it to be reopened is to invite the Republican leadership in Congress to eviscerate the act," said State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat and chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee; he has been lobbying members of Congress to rebuff the governor. "There is no reason on God's earth to use Sept. 11 as an excuse to gut clean air protections."
Environmentalists say the state may not be required to conduct extensive pollution studies before beginning certain projects, like merely rebuilding what was destroyed.
They concede that with the damage done to the Metropolitan Transportation Council, the planning agency, the state will need extra time to show that overall, it is still meeting its pollution targets. The federal government can grant that time administratively, without amending the law, environmentalists say.
More important, environmentalists say, the state's pollution targets are probably still attainable. In this respect, the recession and the aftermath of the attack could work in the state's favor because the loss of tens of thousands of jobs in Manhattan means fewer people commuting to work. Also, they contend that ferries and park-and-ride spots can be designed so that they replace street traffic and can be shown to reduce air pollution, or at least not to increase it.
