HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Round Table; 
Wall Street's Prescriptions in a Convalescing Economy

 BODY:
AFTER an unprecedented run of five consecutive years in which many investors earned profits of 20 percent or more in the stock market, the major averages have now lost money for two straight years, and the economy is mired in recession.
 To get perspectives on what will happen this year, Gretchen Morgenson and Floyd Norris of The New York Times turned to two of Wall Street's most respected strategists, and to one man who was in that group before he started a hedge fund just a few days before the stock market peaked in 2000. They are Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Sachs and Byron R. Wien of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, and Charles I. Clough Jr., who started Clough Capital Partners in Boston after stepping down as Merrill Lynch's top market guru. 
 The good news is that all think that the stock market will rise this year and the recession will end, though they do not agree on whether the recovery will be a relatively short, sharp "V shaped" event or a more drawn-out, harder "U shaped" rebound. They are also split about whether the good old days will return. Following are excerpts from that discussion:

Q. Thank you all for coming. Last year was an extraordinary one, both for the economy and the stock market. Where do we go now? What's going to happen to the economy?

COHEN -- I think that the economy will be looking better in 2002 because even though the National Bureau of Economic Research didn't tell us until December that we're in a recession, the recession is probably much closer to its end than its beginning.
The peak in economic activity was the fourth quarter of 1999: real G.D.P. growth of 8.3 percent. The peak in terms of profit growth was also the fourth quarter of 1999: S.& P. operating profit growth of 22 percent. And we have now gone through almost two years of economic deceleration, enormous inventory cutback, reductions in capital spending. And now we're into what is the most painful part of an adjustment process in the economy, and that's in the labor markets. Our judgment is that come spring things will start to look better. We expect economic data to start to stabilize, and what we're hoping is that we begin to see inventories rebuilt, consumer spending stabilize and ultimately, as the year goes on, the labor markets tighten up.

WIEN -- I think we're going to have a recovery in 2002. I think that too many people think it'll be a V recovery, starting with a bell-ringing on July 1 and heading up strongly from there. I'm skeptical. I think sometime toward the middle of the year business conditions will get better. But it will be a feeble recovery, more of a U-shape with a weak right arm to the U. So I look for a recovery but not a dramatic one.

CLOUGH -- Well, I think you have to put it in the context of where we're coming from. The economy, as Abby pointed out, fell into recession in 2001. The events of Sept. 11 obviously exacerbated that, especially in the manufacturing sector and large portions of the services sector.
There's going to be a bounce-back from that. In early October there were trucks lined up at the Ontario border that couldn't get in. So there was an artificial compression of economic activity. It think the bounce-back from that artificial low is going to look and feel like recovery. We may already be beginning to see parts of it.
But I think the real issue is what happens after that natural bounce-back. And there's one major cycle going on here that suggests that the recovery will be sluggish and may be sluggish for a long time, and that's the investment cycle: the overinvestment that became the Achilles' heel of the economy. It takes time to heal that. So I would say 2002 in the first half might actually look pretty good as we hit that snapback effect. I might differ from the consensus and say we might have more difficulty in the latter part of 2002 and 2003 sustaining it because it's going to be a while before the investment side of the economy comes back.

WIEN -- This was a capital spending-led boom that occurred in the 1995-to-1999 period. And it's a capital-spending-led bust. There is an overinventory of capital equipment out there. We're going to have to work off that inventory, which is going to take a while. In addition to that, I think the profit recovery is going to be sluggish, and you need strong profits to become ambitious in terms of capital spending. So for those reasons, I think the recovery will be shallow at best.

Q. So what does the stock market see? It seems to see something far rosier.

WIEN -- The stock market sees a V recovery. The stock market is very optimistic that at the beginning of the second half of the year the economy is going to recover strongly and profits are going to go up. The stock market has a much more ambitious target for S.& P. 500 earnings than we do.

Q. And yours is, while we're on the subject?

WIEN -- We think the S.& P. 500, in 2002, will earn $50. And I think most estimates are above that. There are some estimates that are below. But the consensus is definitely above $50. And even that may be in jeopardy.

Q. Abby, are you more optimistic on profits?

COHEN -- No. Our number for S.& P. operating earnings that we put in our valuation model: $37 for 2001, and $42 for 2002. That is our totally scrubbed U.S. GAAP-consistent generally accepted accounting principles operating earnings estimates. We then have the second series, which is what the data vendors want us to report, which is not U.S. GAAP consistent. Instead, it's more of an "earnings before whatever approach," very simplistic. For 2002, we have about $50 to $52.

CLOUGH -- I think earnings are in trouble. And I think the accounting profession is about to undergo massive restructuring of principles and organization. The Enron event is really just the icing on the cake. Accounting principles have been violated five ways to Sunday for years -- as evidenced by huge write-offs that never stop. They just go on and on and on.
One of the things that corporations have given you over the last several years, even during the boom times, was that in the midst of very rapid reported earnings gains there was huge nonfinancial corporate borrowing. In fact if you subtracted capital expenditures from borrowing, you still got a lot of borrowing, which means that cash flow earnings -- real cash flow -- never came close to what companies were reporting.

WIEN -- When I first entered this business the numbers that were reported by a company were taken as gospel. You really believed in them. Because there was an adversarial relationship between the accountants and the corporation.
Now there's kind of a collegial cooperative relationship. And part of that is encouraged by the fact that most of the major accounting firms have large consulting organizations, and they both do consulting and auditing.
In the case of Enron, for example, Enron paid Arthur Andersen $52 million in 2000; $27 million of it was for consulting services. And it would seem to me that that would put the auditors in a difficult position.

Q. Let's turn to the stock market.

CLOUGH -- What investors have to get used to is that total returns in all the capital markets are going to compound out at substantially lower rates than what they had or were expected to do in the past.
We are in a deflationary period. And it's more than in manufacturing, it's also in the services side. You can see what's happening in the pharmaceutical industry for the first time ever. But the offset is that in the middle of the last recession short rates were 11 percent -- now they're 2 or 1 percent. That's a dramatic change in terms of the price of credit. So the price-earnings ratio is likely to be higher.
My guess -- and it's only a guess -- is that it works out probably to 6 or 7 percent annualized returns in capital markets. But they are achievable. The capital markets looking ahead will provide modest but decent returns.

Q. How about in 2002? Where's the Dow? What are the averages going to be?

CLOUGH -- Where do the averages go? Well, the honest answer is, I haven't the slightest idea. But I'll take a shot. I'll say 11,300 for the Dow, 1,250 for the S.& P., about 2,300 for the Nasdaq.

Q. Byron, how about you?

WIEN -- Those numbers are similar to mine. For the S.& P. 500, I'd say 1,200. For the Dow: 11,000. For the Nasdaq: 2,200.

Q. Abby?

COHEN -- Since the markets reopened on Sept. 17, we've been using the following ranges: S.& P. 500 is 1,300 to 1,425, and the Dow is 11,300 to 12,400. With regard to the Nasdaq, we stopped forecasting the Nasdaq at the end of 1998. Our valuation models are driven by things like earnings and cash flow, and the Nasdaq didn't have earnings and cash flow so we suspended our forecast.

Q. O.K. She's much more optimistic than you guys are about the stock market in 2002. Why is that?

WIEN -- From 1995 to 1999, the market went up 20 percent every year. It averaged, I think, pretty close to 25 percent during the five-year period. It had never done that before. It left the market at a level of overvaluation that may not have been corrected yet. So there's nothing to say that we might not have a three-year period where the market is down every year. The price-earnings ratio of the market using Abby's and my numbers is about 23. While you can say that there are flaws in the price-earnings ratio concept, and I would agree with that, it isn't totally irrelevant. And the long-term average is 14 to 21. So it's above the long-term range.
Now interest rates are low; inflation is dead. And so maybe you can argue for a higher multiple, but there's just no way to say that the market is cheap out there.

CLOUGH -- Not only was it a question of overvaluation, but the corporate sector has left itself very highly leveraged, the consumer sector has left itself very highly leveraged. When we do start an economic recovery there's not going to be a lot of pent-up demand, certainly not in the durable sector. Housing and autos really haven't even broken yet. So there are a lot of drags on an economic recovery.
I think the thing about profits that you have to understand is that profits are a leveraged enterprise. You get a lot more profits if the economy grows at a 4 percent rate than if it grows at a 2 percent rate. Profits are going to labor under that kind of an environment. And that's the kind of environment I see.

WIEN -- You've got to look at what you're entitled to as an investor. In my view all you're entitled to is the profit growth plus the dividend. In the 20-year period from 1981 to 2001, that was about 10 percent. The market during that period gave you about 15 percent. So you got five extra percentage points of reward in relation to how much earnings were increasing. That left the market at a point where, particularly if profits are struggling, there could be some adjustment. And that's why the returns from the market may be below the long-term average of 10 percent.

Q. Abby?

COHEN -- At the end of 1998, we told our clients that it was time to think about the same sort of long-term trends that Chuck and Byron are talking about. And that we thought that earnings growth would be 7 to 8 percent rather than the 15 percent that had been experienced previously. And that returns from the market would be on the order of price appreciation of 8 to 10 percent.
I'd also agree that the recovery from this economic recession will be more muted than the average. If housing and autos are already strong, they're not going to add that much more vigor in 2002.
In addition, I would raise one other point we've not really touched on, and that's the rest of the world. The rest of the world is lethargic. The Fed has lowered interest rates 11 times. The European Central Bank is acting as if there's not much of a problem. And yet, there's not one country in Europe whose industrial production didn't go down in November. There's not one country in Europe that doesn't have a higher unemployment rate than we do and an unemployment rate that's rising. I'm very concerned, too, about the global situation, which is not particularly bright. I haven't even mentioned Japan.

WIEN -- We've gone pretty far in this discussion without mentioning Sept. 11. And the stock market has sort of sloughed it off. The stock market, while it hasn't had a great year, is now trading higher than it was on Sept. 10. And while we may have subdued the Taliban and identified a number of Al Qaeda cells, I don't think that the threat of terrorism has totally been diminished. Even if it has, the costs associated with the terrorist attacks are real. There are going to be higher costs for insurance, for transportation, for security and for inventories as a result of those attacks. And that's going to put additional pressure on profit margins.
The stock market is saying that the risk premium should be about the same as it was before -- the risk premium has declined in the market back to where it was prior to the attacks -- and that the stock market is fairly optimistic about the ability of the economy to recover strongly. And I'm suspicious of both of those concepts.

Q. Chuck, how do you see the world?

CLOUGH -- It does look like a sluggish place. China is a huge area of impact on corporate activity. It's developing very rapidly. It's certainly making it more difficult for Japan to fight its way out of its deflation. And it's going to make it difficult for a number of Asian countries to come back as fast as they might have otherwise. But it's also going to have an impact on the price of manufactured goods here and in Europe. All of that makes it difficult to see an awful lot of profits growth looking ahead.

Q. Before the recent boom, people talked about basic industries like autos and steel as having worldwide overcapacity, and there were dire forecasts that the countries with the highest production costs would be the big losers. That was forgotten during the good days. And now suddenly it's back. Do we have a long-term problem with overcapacity in a lot of industries?

COHEN -- Yes. A number of the industries that you mention do have short-term issues. We're not recommending auto stocks in the United States for the obvious reasons. But on a longer-term basis, what we see happening is that a lot of the U.S. participants may in fact have gained some advantage over the last few years because they have become more efficient. The productivity of the workers has increased. Let's keep in mind that the productivity of the U.S. worker is probably 30 percent above that of other industrial nations. And that's going to be very very helpful to us as we come out of recession. When we're in recession, everybody's going to feel the pain. As we come out of recession, we think there could be some market share improvements.

CLOUGH -- This is the first time that we'll come out of a recession with not only excess capacity in manufacturing but in a lot of services as well. So we're going to test a lot of the theories about how we do come out of recession. The price of capital was zero for many industries -- telecom, for example -- for a pretty extended period of time there. So the bubble was not only in the financial markets but it was in the investment side of the economy as well. You saw it confined in energy in the 70's, and it took 15 years for the energy sector to recover. This one's much more pervasive. It's not only in telecom. You've got this pattern of overexpansion in the services sector as well. Overcapacity seems to be pretty systemic throughout the global economy.

Q. What about the consumer? The consumer is a huge piece of this economic puzzle in the recovery.

WIEN -- I think the consumer will continue to spend because most people still have jobs. Even though the unemployment rate has gone up, we still have 94 percent of Americans who want to work with jobs. But they're not feeling as secure about those jobs as they were before, and they're not being compensated as well. So consequently I think the consumer will be a positive in the economy, but only a mild one.

COHEN -- With regard to unemployment, the reality of the situation is that the impact has come hardest on our youngest and lowest-paid workers. If you look at who have lost their jobs since the beginning of the year, about two-thirds fall into that category. So it helps explain why personal spending continues and personal income growth has actually been positive with the exception of the last three months, even though the unemployment rate is rising. It's because the people who have lost their jobs were earning at the bottom end of the income spectrum.

CLOUGH -- This might be the first recession we go through where consumer credit doesn't decline. Without some deleveraging in the consumer sector, it's hard to make a case for a really powerful recovery looking ahead.

WIEN -- We've made the point that the consumer isn't going to do it. And earlier we made the point that we can't count on capital spending. So it's pretty convincing that the recovery is going to be a meager one.

COHEN -- We're not really talking about the consumer collapsing. Consumer spending is a positive number and will probably get a little more robust.
A recovery comes about for a variety of reasons. No. 1, the consumer continues to spend. No. 2, inventories at some point start to rebuild. And maybe we're getting close. The other thing that could be helpful to us is selective capital spending. There's going to be a rolling recovery. And there are some areas where we see demand beginning to improve in capital goods over the very short term.

Q. The Fed had a really tricky time of it in 2001. The interest rate cuts have not really done what everybody thought they would do in the time that everybody thought they would do it. Going forward, what do we see from the bond market and interest rates in response to this?

WIEN -- More investors got hoodwinked on Fed easing than on any other single concept. The prevailing view last January was that the Fed is your friend and if the Fed is cutting rates the market's going up. In an environment where earnings are deteriorating as fast they did last year, it doesn't matter that the Fed is easing.

CLOUGH -- What ails the economy? An overbuilt capital stock. And again it extends beyond fiber optics. It extends into large numbers of the areas. The price of the overnight Fed funds rate doesn't change demand for this kind of stuff.
I think we could be in a period where we should get ready for astonishingly low interest rates for a fairly extended period of time.

WIEN -- That would be good for growth stocks.

CLOUGH -- You've got to find growth, though.

COHEN -- And equities in general. I think the Fed is not getting the respect that it deserves. Chuck makes a very good point that much of the weakness in the economy is in sectors where interest rate policy is not particularly effective. And let's keep in mind that the areas of the economy which are strong now are areas where interest rate policy is very effective. Housing and autos are extraordinarily strong.
In addition, I think the Fed deserves a great deal of credit for the other function, which is supervision and regulation. The Fed went into the nation's commercial banks in '97 and again in 1998 during the Asian crisis and the currency crises saying, "You guys better make sure of your lending standards." And the banks did a fabulous job. We are now two years into a very broad-based economic deceleration, and I'm not aware of any banking failure.

Q. Is there going to be disappointment in terms of returns for Individual Retirement Accounts and 401(k)'s? Are people being set up for returns that are not going to match their expectations and their plans?

WIEN -- We know that during the late 1990's people expected their mutual fund returns to be in excess of 20 percent. And then they scaled it down to 15 percent. I don't think that there's anybody who expects less than 10. And I think less than 10 on an equity fund is a reasonable possibility. Certainly they haven't gotten 10 over the last two years. And some of them have taken big hits.

CLOUGH -- I remember reading, in the midst of the dot-com boom, an anecdote that one couple looked at their 401(k) and they found it was over a million dollars. And they both quit their jobs and booked a cruise to Australia. True story. I don't think they realized what that would be after tax. But it was a signal of how easy it was to inflate what your retirement assets really were going to be.
So the totally risk-adverse investor, I think, looking forward is going to have to change his or her investment structure. That's why I don't think there's going to be a large exodus of household capital from equities or bonds. I do think there will be more and more pressure to balance portfolios, but I don't see a massive exodus here because the money rate simply won't be much of an enticement.

WIEN -- One of the drivers for the market in the 1995-1999 period was the enormous amount of money that flowed into equity mutual funds. That isn't happening anymore. It's true that the withdrawals have been sluggish. But the net new money coming into funds is almost nonexistent.

Q. We've seen over the last several years quite a flood into the dollar. International investors wanted dollar-based assets and bought a lot of dollars to fund those assets. And that kept the dollar stronger than one might have expected, given balance of payments numbers. Is that going to continue?

COHEN -- Over the longer term it might move lower because of the current account issues and so on. But for the moment, the United States, although we have cyclical problems, is nevertheless looking relatively good. It looks good vis-a-vis Japan. And the Europeans, while there was great enthusiasm about the euro when it was introduced, are feeling that perhaps it's not such a bad thing to own dollars.
By the way, the opposite is also true. If you take a look at what U.S. investors have done, most are not particularly interested in owning non-U.S. equities at this point. The last time we were was the same time the Europeans were interested in owning U.S. stocks, which was the end of 1999, early 2000. They were buying U.S. technology stocks. We returned the favor -- we bought tech and telecom stocks in their markets.

Q. Does that prove that foreign investors are always wrong?

COHEN -- Almost always, yes. Yes. It's not 100 percent, but it's a pretty good rule of thumb.

WIEN -- The U.S. is still the cradle of entrepreneurship. And entrepreneurship is what creates opportunity for investors. In the 1980-2000 period, the United States created 75 million new jobs. And at the same time it eliminated 44 million jobs. It eliminated the 44 million in the old economy sectors -- the steel, auto, basic industry sectors -- and created the new jobs in technology and biotechnology, other fields, the Home Depots and Intels, etc. Europe during that same period created 5 million jobs. And they were all in the public sector.

COHEN -- What Byron didn't tell you was that the population of the two groups is the same. So it becomes even more striking.

WIEN -- My point is that that isn't going to change. So I think capital flows are still going to be positive; whether they will be sufficient to offset the trade flows, I don't know. But I don't think the dollar is headed for a period of significant weakness.

Q. So where should people invest now?

WIEN -- In the growth area, the only sector that we like right now is health care. And we like a variety of facets of it. Most of the things that we like are stocks that were beaten down in the post-Sept. 11 decline and have come back some but not a lot. And that would include industrials, capital goods companies, materials companies, retailers. And another sector in the growth area that we would like is cable.

Q. Give me some names.

WIEN -- BJ's Wholesale. There are two retailers, BJ's Wholesale, one that's probably not familiar to all of your readers, and Abercrombie & Fitch; one conglomerate, ITT; two health care stocks, Medtronic and Abbott; and one dirty old cyclical, Dow Chemical.

CLOUGH -- We've looked for areas where profitability has been very low, the cost of capital, as a result, has been very high, and as a result there's some restriction on supply. And we've got a couple. The hospital industry has been almost in a depression in many of the public sector hospitals ever since a lot of the third-party payments were cut back. And we think that's about to change, that many hospitals are looking at double-digit revenue growth now. Two stocks I scratched down here were Select Medical and HCA.
The second is international reinsurance. This is a story that I think has some very powerful fundamentals behind it. Insurance rates and insurance capacity were already contracting before Sept. 11. I think Sept. 11 kind of exacerbated that. So we like the Ace Ltd. and the Principal Financial Group among others in the property casualty sector.
And some financials are pretty cheap: Golden West Financial and Washington Mutual, among others.
And the cable industry does look like it's going from a period of massive investment needs, as digital cable comes on to generate more positive cash flow, and the stocks are down. We like Adelphia Communications and Cablevision Systems.

COHEN -- We think that there is significant opportunity still in technology: computer-related technology, software and service.
We think that this is an environment that will be good for well-managed financials. Many of the banks look good. Some of the diversified financial services companies look good. And we want to own energy equities when everybody's talking about how warm it is and how low the spot market is.
Finally, within the S.& P. at least, industrials. This is the first time in three years that we're suggesting some of the down-and-dirty industrials because it's the first time we think that consensus earnings estimates are probably in the right place and the stocks are priced relative to that.
And finally, outside the usual S.& P. portfolio, there are two things. One is higher-quality corporate bonds -- and I don't mean necessarily the highest-rated corporate bonds, but even some with lower ratings that are just kind of being ignored because of the problems in the telecom area. And finally, small- and mid-cap stocks.

WIEN -- I do have a disagreement with Abby. In my view, technology has come a long way since Sept. 21. And its earnings prospects have improved, but its multiples have improved faster. So technology, in many cases, seems almost as expensive today as it did on Sept. 10, and it wasn't cheap then. So technology would be a sector we would avoid.

Q. You've told us what we should own. What should we avoid now?

WIEN -- Tech and financials.

CLOUGH -- Well, I think Byron's right. There are shorts in both of those sectors. And I think there are still a lot of problems ahead for the subprime lenders. Not only does consumer credit go bad as unemployment grows and employment and income slow, but a lot of them are heavily dependent on the ability to securitize their assets. They make a lot of loans very aggressively, and they have to securitize those assets.
Some of the stocks that have rallied way too far and are going to have difficulty, really, creating much in the way of earnings in the years ahead are some of the telecom chip providers. I'm also skeptical about some consumer durables. We do like the housing stocks, but that's because there's a consolidation to larger players there. But some other consumer durables in the mobile home area and even the auto stocks, I think, are going to have trouble ahead. So I look for problems there as well.

Q. Abby?

COHEN -- Telecom is an area that we're still not comfortable with. I would have some discomfort with Europe. In the United States we've already had a dramatic reduction in consensus expectations for G.D.P. for earnings and so on. That is not yet the case in Europe, where investors and the central banks also have been very lethargic in recognizing the difficult situation that's being faced.

Q. What about the government?

WIEN -- There's been a complete reversal in thinking about government, from thinking it was irrelevant and in the way to thinking, "God, I'm glad we've got one." That's in terms of the national security. In terms of the economy, though, I think there's a lot of criticism of the Fed. And there's certainly criticism of the president's stimulus policy. And there's even some criticism of Ashcroft's policy on national security.

COHEN -- Let's be honest about where the problem in the economy is. It's inadequate demand, it's consumers feeling funky. And a good deal of the pain from the recession has fallen on middle-income and lower-income people, and the stimulus package that was proposed by the president, and one that's supported in the House, doesn't really address that, in my view, as directly as it could. Some of the measures that could be very effective would be the extension of the rebate program, providing an extension of the earned-income tax credit. Also the extension of the unemployment benefits. Basically, getting to the heart of the problem and affecting those who've been most directly impacted by the recession would be helpful.

CLOUGH -- I'm skeptical that fiscal policy is likely to have that much of an impact, not because of uncertainty and delay in getting a package -- the problems the economy is dealing with have to do more with investment cycles, and fiscal policy doesn't really change that very much. So my guess is more than ever the economy simply needs time to heal the excesses that we've lived through.

Q. Since the market peaked in March 2000, investors have been remarkably able to withstand enormous confidence-shattering events, whether it's Enron or the telecom bust. Have investors just become very resilient and long term in their focus and willing to withstand anything?

HEADLINE: The Bloomberg Era Begins 

 BODY:
One of the tests a New York City mayor faces at the very beginning of his administration is how to look comfortable while sitting outside in freezing weather during an hour-long inauguration on Jan. 1. Mayor Michael Bloomberg surmounted that challenge yesterday, in a ceremony that had its own kind of warmth, despite the participants' blue lips and frozen fingers.
 Standing before a huge American flag that covered City Hall, Mr. Bloomberg told New Yorkers what they already knew -- that the coming year will be a tough one in which everyone will have to make sacrifices and set aside traditional differences. He was short on specifics, except for a call to give the mayor control of the school system, and a delicate suggestion that he was not nearly as enthusiastic as Rudolph Giuliani had been about spending money on new professional baseball stadiums. The city, he said, should have the world's best cultural and sports facilities "when we can afford them." 
 Mr. Bloomberg sent out all the right political signals. The new mayor has been remarkably successful at making it clear that his administration will not be a simple extension of his predecessor's, and the inauguration yesterday continued that theme. Even the choice of master of ceremonies, New York Mets pitcher Al Leiter, sent the message that the era of the Yankee-worshiping Mayor Giuliani had come to an end. All new chief executives promise to be good listeners, but Mr. Bloomberg's promise that New Yorkers would always know their voices had been heard seemed particularly telling as he took command from a man whose great talents did not generally extend to inclusion. While Mr. Bloomberg paid a rightful tribute to his predecessor, he also had praise for former Mayors Edward Koch and David Dinkins. 
The peculiar nature of Mr. Bloomberg's political candidacy and the effects of the Sept. 11 trauma have combined to give him some enormous advantages. Like Mr. Koch, he inherits a city that has already conceded that times will be tough and sacrifices will need to be made. But no one feels New York has brought these problems on itself, and Mr. Bloomberg will not have to apologize to the nation while asking for help. Like Mr. Dinkins, he needs to bring together a city in which minority residents in particular feel estranged from City Hall. But unlike Mr. Dinkins, he is leading a city that has already found an unfamiliar cohesion in the troubles of last year.
Like Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Bloomberg will have to be a fighter. But the enemy he has been given is, for once, not an internal one. Mr. Koch had to take on wasteful New York fiscal practices. Mr. Dinkins was supposed to fight New York bigotry, and Mr. Giuliani promised to defeat New York criminals. The new mayor has to lead New York in a struggle to take back the city from an assault by terrorists. We are all on the same side, and the country is on our side. That gives him an enormous advantage, at least in the beginning.
The theme of most New York City inaugurations is the unwilling transfer of power, as the new mayor generally attempts to define how he will do the job differently than the people who came before. Mr. Bloomberg's job was a little more delicate -- to assure people he will carry on the great achievements of the Giuliani administration without succumbing to its weaknesses. All in all, he handled his assignment well.

HEADLINE: THE MAYORAL TRANSITION; 
Comptroller Praises City's Fearless Optimism

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the inaugural address given yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., as recorded by The New York Times:
 Mayor Bloomberg, Public Advocate Gotbaum, Mayor Giuliani, Mayor Dinkins, Mayor Koch, colleagues in government, family, friends and all New Yorkers: I am honored and humbled to stand before you today as New York's 42nd comptroller, especially at this pivotal moment in our city's history. 
 I, like many of you, have watched with pride as New York has shown the world that no act of terrorism can compromise our democratic way of life or crush our stubborn spirit of optimism. Time and time again we have been touched by the many quiet acts of compassion, heroism and humanity that bear witness to the tenacity and courage of the people of this city. New Yorkers never give up. Our strength flows from our diversity; our differences provide a wealth of wisdom, gathered from traditions and cultures from around the world. And we are better for it. 
On this Inauguration Day I am reminded of the words of Henry Clay, who noted in 1829 that government is a trust and the officers of the government are trustees. And both the trust and the trustees are created for the benefit of the people. 
At this time of tradition and change it is a particularly daunting task to make decisions that will affect the lives of New Yorkers. And so it is with a sober understanding that I accept such an awesome responsibility of leadership in this majestic city, a city of fearless people. 
I know we will meet the challenges before us. Indeed, we will overcome them all. It is our tradition as Americans. We have survived hardship before. New York has suffered depression, fiscal instability, recession and now terrorism. But by your presence here today I know that you are as committed as I am to holding on to our hope and our faith in an abiding future.
Yes, there are challenging times ahead for our city. But as we tackle the financial challenges before us, we should not abandon our values or our priorities. We must be mindful of not sacrificing our long-term health to meet short-term needs. The noted economist John Maynard Keynes once said the difficulty lies not in the new ideas, but in escaping from the old ones. 
Today we must fearlessly embrace new solutions to problems, some of which were not even anticipated six months ago. We must seek out new and more creative ways of leveraging public and private partnerships for the common good. 
As comptroller, I will be a fiscal activist. I will not only work to safeguard our finances, but I will stand firmly committed to overcoming the challenges Keynes described by creating new ways to invest in our neighborhoods. Working families and middle-class families need affordable housing. Communities need the tools for real economic development and real job creation. 
I'm a native New Yorker, a son of this city, a graduate of its public schools. As president of the Board of Education I had one goal: to help our children receive the same chance for a solid educational foundation that I received. We must join together to make that happen today, not tomorrow. 
I'm proud to be the first African-American ever elected to the position of comptroller in this city's history. It's a testament to New Yorkers. When all is said and done, we put character first. So, today let us link arms in partnership, for the time has come for us to rebuild, to raise up new structures that will not only house our bodies but nourish our souls and reflect our dreams. 
There will rise an even greater city that will fully understand the value of its diversity. And from this strength we will rebuild and forge a new social contract that will unite this city and reinforce our place as a beacon of hope to the entire world. Today, let us begin the new New York renaissance.
Thank you and God bless you all. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: William C. Thompson Jr., right, was congratulated by his father after being sworn in as city comptroller yesterday. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: KABUL; 
Afghan Leader Warily Backs U.S. Bombing

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 1 

 BODY:
The chairman of Afghanistan's interim government, Hamid Karzai, said today that he wanted the American bombing of Afghanistan to continue until all terrorist activity was rooted out, but he also expressed concern about mounting civilian casualties. 
 With reports that up to 100 villagers in Paktia Province had been killed in airstrikes overnight Saturday, Mr. Karzai said he planned to raise the issue of civilian deaths with American officials today or on Wednesday. Tribal leaders from Paktia had already asked Mr. Karzai to halt the bombing of their province after an airstrike 12 days ago on a convoy of tribal leaders on their way to Kabul. 
 "We want to finish terrorists in Afghanistan -- we want to finish them completely," Mr. Karzai said. "But we must also make sure our civilians do not suffer." 
Asked when the civilian cost would become too high to justify the bombing campaign's continuation, Mr. Karzai said, "We must make sure there is no civilian cost at all."
The Pentagon has accused the Taliban of exaggerating civilian casualties, and it has accused Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters of hiding among women and children. "This was a valid military target," said Cmdr. Dan Keesee, a spokesman for the United States Central Command in Tampa, Fla. 
Mr. Karzai made his comments in an interview today at the Gulkhanna Palace, at an extraordinary moment in his country's history. Just over a week ago, he took office in Afghanistan, inheriting a country broken by more than two decades of war.
A foreign peacekeeping force, led by the British, is gearing up to begin patrolling Kabul, the capital, even as another foreign force continues intensive bombing in the country's southern provinces.
Mr. Karzai said he welcomed both forms of intervention. For now, peacekeepers will operate only in Kabul, but Mr. Karzai said unequivocally that he wanted to see them in other cities. He said Afghans from the country's most remote corners had come to him asking for peacekeepers.
He said he did not know what was behind the weekend bombing near the village of Niazi Qala. American officials said that they had struck a Taliban and Al Qaeda compound, but villagers told foreign news agencies that many civilians had been killed.
Mr. Karzai said he had sent a helicopter to bring elders from the area to Kabul today so that he could investigate the incident. Another group of tribal leaders drove to Kabul this afternoon.
An aide to Mr. Karzai said he believed that, as with the airstrikes on the convoy in Paktia, deliberately faulty intelligence might have been fed to American officials. A fierce power struggle is raging in the region, largely over who will serve as governor of Paktia and its neighboring province, Paktika.
One group, supportive of Pacha Khan Zadran, a commander who was a delegate to the Bonn conference, has tended to play up the presence of Al Qaeda and Taliban members in the province and play down casualties, leading to suspicions that Mr. Zadran's backers may be encouraging the airstrikes to consolidate his power.
Another faction, which may include some former midlevel Taliban officials, has insisted, perhaps a little too fervently, that the airstrikes are completely mistaken.
"People are using this to settle old scores," Mr. Karzai's aide said of rivalries in the province. "This is politically motivated."
Still, Mr. Karzai gave no sign that his support for the war against terrorism was abating. He called it "our war," saying, "I'm glad the United States has joined in." He said he had authorized the arrest of Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, who is believed to be hiding in Helmand Province, and welcomed American involvement in a mission to capture him.
But he said many lower-level Taliban -- "common people" who had been forcibly recruited, for example -- would be released from the country's prisons and allowed to go home. "The bad guys will stay," he said, as will foreigners who had been fighting on the Taliban's behalf.
According to the records of the International Committee of the Red Cross, about 4,300 prisoners of war are being detained in prisons throughout Afghanistan. Estimates by the American coalition have placed the figure closer to 7,000.
Security remains paramount on Mr. Karzai's agenda. He acknowledged a problem of lawlessness on the country's highways, which has made it difficult to deliver aid and to import goods. He said he was appointing provincial governors who would be responsible for controlling security in their areas.
He also said he had raised concerns with Yunus Qanooni, the interior minister, about the behavior of Northern Alliance soldiers toward Pashtun elders coming to Kabul, including thefts of cars. But he also blamed saboteurs and terrorists still hoping to destabilize the country for some of the city's security problems.
Mr. Karzai refused to explain why his government had essentially modified the Bonn agreement, which had specifically called for all Afghan armed units to be sent out of Kabul. Western military sources said on Monday that Afghan officials had insisted that in the Dari language, the Bonn agreement only called for troops to be removed from the "streets of Kabul," and thus the soldiers would be kept in barracks, in the city.
Asked about the inconsistency of that policy with the Bonn agreement, Mr. Karzai said, "There is a new agreement."
On the question of disarming hundreds of groups and possibly hundreds of thousands of individuals, Mr. Karzai seemed to suggest that the disarmament would not be comprehensive. He ticked off the list of armed entities -- civilians with arms, armed groups, mujahedeen, former mujahedeen -- and said: "There are good and bad people. The bad guys should be disarmed by whatever means."
Mr. Karzai called restoring order to the country's chaotic and bankrupt economic system "as important as security." He said his administration was working quickly to set up a customs system and other mechanisms to generate revenue, select a head of the central bank and work out a new currency policy. "That is a priority area," he said.
For now, Afghan's currency is printed in Russia, and its value tends to fluctuate wildly. Before the bombing began on Oct. 7, for example, Afghans were trading their afghani at 83,000 to the dollar. In the days before Mr. Karzai's swearing in, the exchange rate improved dramatically -- to 11,000 to the dollar. Now it is at 25,000.
Saying there was no money left in the country's banks, Mr. Karzai produced a note from a former Taliban member with information about how the Taliban and "foreign elements" had looted the central bank. He said he planned to meet with the man in the hope that some of the lost revenues could be recovered.
Later this month Mr. Karzai will travel to Japan for a donors' conference on Afghanistan. Aides say he wants to make sure that the pledges Western countries made when the war against terrorism was at its height will be kept. He will also probably visit the United States after Congress reconvenes later this month.
For now, much of Mr. Karzai's time is taken up with greeting delegations. On Sunday, he said, he met with former President Burhanuddin Rabbani, with whom he will have lunch on Wednesday, and Abdul Rab Rassoul Sayyaf, a commander whom some see as a potential troublemaker.
He said they had come to offer their support, and, he suggested, to seek a bit of patronage for their supporters. "Everybody wants appointments," he said.
Mr. Karzai and his aides are also trying, hastily, to put in place the infrastructure for a functioning government. This morning, for example, he met with his minister for women's affairs, who still has no office.
Daoud Yaqub, a spokesman for Mr. Karzai, said people had no idea of the logistical difficulties facing the new administration. Without a telephone system in place, for example, something as simple as coordinating a meeting with the United Nations special representative to Afghanistan requires sending emissaries with notes. Some ministers have been given satellite phones, but there is concern that they will run up bills that will have to be paid out of their ministry budgets. 
Mr. Karzai, who today wore the green Uzbek cape that has become his trademark, seemed unfazed by the trials facing his administration. He said the week since he took office had been easier than when he was in the countryside, where he had no one to organize his time.
By comparison, things now seemed quite organized and civilized, he said. Indeed, part way through the interview, an aide entered carrying two scones. They had been sent by Mr. Karzai's sister-in-law in Baltimore.

 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

Pakistan Leader Orders End to Support for Militants
President Pervez Musharraf told his military intelligence agency to cut off backing for Islamic militant groups fighting in the disputed territory of Kashmir, senior officials said. They said future support would go only to groups with local roots that are not part of the Islamic holy war movement that has its most notorious expression in Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda. Groups like Hizbul Mujahedeen, the officials said, would get "moral and political" support from the Pakistani government but not military training and weapons. A1

Zambians Protest Election
More than 1,000 angry opposition party supporters took to the streets and clashed with riot police officers as dozens of protesters stormed the Supreme Court to accuse the Zambian government of rigging the presidential election last week. Judge Peter Chitengi ordered the government not to release the final election results and said he would decide today whether he had the legal authority to delay the inauguration, as opposition parties have demanded, to allow an investigation into complaints of stuffed or stolen ballot boxes and other vote tampering. A8

New President in Argentina
Eduardo Duhalde, a veteran Peronist politician with a strong populist streak, was chosen by an emergency legislative assembly as Argentina's fifth president in less than two weeks. He announced that he would form a "government of national unity" in a last-ditch attempt to return from "the verge of disintegration and chaos." Like Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, an interim president who resigned on Sunday, Mr. Duhalde encountered stubborn resistance from within his own party. A6

Problems After Lima Explosion
Officials said that so many victims of the fireworks explosion in Lima that killed nearly 300 people were burned so badly that perhaps only 20 percent of the bodies would be identified. President Alejandro Toldeo has announced that the government will pay for DNA analysis, part of a series of measures taken in the days after the fire. He has also named a commission to cover burial costs and to help relocate people who lost their homes. Prosecutors and the police continue to confiscate fireworks caches. A6

The Bush administration said it would send Anthony C. Zinni back to the Middle East to try to end 15 months of Israeli-Palestinian violence. HEADLINE: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; 
Bonds May Have Tougher Time Outperforming Stocks in 2002

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
TWO things will be remembered about the bond market in 2001 -- and both say something about the new year.
 One was the wrenching turns in interest rates as 2001 ended. It took about 15 weeks for the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note to fall a full percentage point to its 2001 low of 4.18 percent on Nov. 7. Then it took just two weeks to shoot back to 5 percent; two weeks to fall to 4.66 percent and just another week and a half to soar to 5.19 percent. That volatility reflected the uncertainty about the outlook for the economy and the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy. That uncertainty -- and volatility -- should continue for a while in 2002. 
 Those wrenching twists also wiped out a big portion of the gains bonds had been making last year. At the low for Treasury interest rates, the return on Treasury notes and bonds was 13.1 percent; by the end of the year, it was 6.7 percent. In contrast, high-yield junk bonds rallied at the end of the year, from an annual return of 2.8 percent on Nov. 7 to 4.5 percent.
The second memorable thing for bonds last year was that the credit markets outperformed the stock market. Investment-grade bonds over all, including Treasuries, corporates, mortgages and agencies, had a return of 8.3 percent last year, according to Merrill Lynch bond indexes. While that was down from an annual return of 12.9 percent on Nov. 7, it stood in sharp contrast to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which fell 13 percent.
This was the second straight year that domestic bonds have been a better bet than stocks and the first two-year outperformance by bonds since 1992-1993. Emerging market bonds, excluding Argentina, had a total return of 19.8 percent in 2001. But Argentina's bonds, on which the government has defaulted, declined 66.9 percent in value. So there was a dip of 0.8 percent over all for emerging market bonds, according to J. P. Morgan bond indexes.
The question is: Can this outperformance continue? While that answer is up in the air, "there is little doubt that making money in bonds will probably be more difficult in 2002 than it was in 2001." said Amy C. Falls, global fixed-income strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
The key variables for volatility and performance are the shape of the economic recovery that is in the consensus forecast for the spring and how long Fed policy makers wait before they decide to push up their short-term interest rate benchmark, the federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks.
The surge in interest rates at the end of the year meant that many investors believed that the economic recovery had begun -- or would begin soon -- and that a strong rebound would force the Fed, which lowered rates 11 times in 2001, to turn around and raise them as a bulwark against inflation by June, if not earlier.
Other analysts, however, say the recovery will be moderate, in part because the recent rise in longer-term interest rates is putting a drag on housing, through higher mortgage rates, and on corporate investment. A slower recovery would make it unlikely that the Fed would move before the end of this year or possibly not before early 2003. Another restraint on the Fed, these analysts argue, is that inflation pressures will remain contained. The core Consumer Price Index, which excludes food and energy, rose 2.8 percent in the 12 months through November.
If the recovery is quick, many investors will take bigger risks to get the higher yields needed to offset the decline in bond prices that comes with rising interest rates. With the economy improving, high-yield bonds would become more attractive because company outlooks would improve. The expectation of a quick recovery set off a rush into high yield at the end of 2001. But if there is a slow recovery and a patient Fed, then picking companies with higher credit ratings would be a better bet.
In an environment of rising or steady interest rates, mortgage-backed securities look good. It is falling interest rates that are troublesome to mortgage performance, as homeowners rush to refinance their mortgages at lower rates.
Analysts generally agree that interest rates hit bottom in November and will move higher this year. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note is forecast to reach between 5.5 percent and 5.75 percent, from the 5.02 percent where it ended last year. The yield on the two-year note, which finished 2001 at 3.04 percent, could rise to 3.75 percent this year.
That rise in rates means that the Treasury market is not the place to be, as rising rates will push Treasury prices lower. (Merrill Lynch argues that there is one more Treasury rally in store as investors find out the recovery will not be immediate or strong. Then interest rates will rise.) This means that the bet for this year in bonds -- whether they outperform stocks or not -- is on what is known as spread product. This covers the other fixed-income securities, including investment-grade corporate bonds, agency and mortgage-backed securities and below-investment-grade junk bonds. They all trade at a higher yield than the comparable maturity in the Treasury market, and the difference is called the spread.
Analysts are recommending investing in spread product for several reasons. First, these sectors offer higher yields than those in the Treasury market. In addition, analysts say that while yields will also rise in these sectors of the fixed-income market, they will go up less than Treasury yields. This means that the spread among corporates, agencies, mortgages and junk bonds will narrow versus Treasuries, and this is a profit opportunity.
This is very much the same advice that analysts gave going into 2001, and it worked out, except maybe in the junk bond market, where an annual rate of return of 98.5 percent in January turned to a minus 8.9 percent in December. The return for corporate bonds was 10.7 percent, compared with 9.1 percent in 2000. Mortgages returned 8.1 percent, compared with 11.3 percent in 2000, and agencies had a total return of 8.3 percent, compared with 11.9 percent.

Graph tracks mortgage, U.S. Treasury, corporate, and high-yield returns for 2001.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Don't Shoot! We're Only Shopping 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: MAIZURU, Japan, Dec. 28 

 BODY:
Framed by freshly unloaded stacks of Siberian lumber, thousands of used Japanese bicycles were loaded onto a ship here today, their tires flat, their chains rusted and their once-prim plastic shopping baskets cracked and faded. They are headed to North Korea, gifts from Kim Jong Il, the "Dear Leader," to his nation of 23 million people, in honor of his birthday.
 "Kim Jong Il's birthday is in six weeks, and he has promised a ration of one bicycle for every household," a Japanese dealer of second-hand goods who is of Korean descent said with a wave to the old bicycles that already covered every possible surface of the Su Song Chon, a low and rusting North Korean coastal ship that was pressed into service for foreign trade. 
 When Mr. Kim shopped for the masses to perk up his 60th birthday festivities, on Feb. 16, it was only natural that he would turn to this mist-shrouded port, 500 miles across the Sea of Japan from North Korea. Here, in Maizuru, a lovely natural harbor where glassy waters are cupped by forest-covered mountains, the number of North Korean trading ships has increased fivefold in five years, reaching 295 last year. 
Recently, a bitter war of words has erupted between Japan and North Korea over a mystery boat that sank after an intense gun battle with Japan Coast Guard ships in the Sea of China on Dec. 22. All 15 crew members of the boat apparently died. North Korea, while denying ownership of what the Japanese news media call "the spy ship," accused Japan of "brutal piracy."
But here on Japan's quiet coast, the northwest shore that faces the Korean Peninsula, it was business as usual today, with seven North Korean boats tied up at wharves here. Because Japan and North Korea do not have diplomatic relations, the North Koreans do all their trading without setting foot on land. Standing on a wooden gangplank, a yard from Japanese soil, the leader of one boat's crew was not happy to see visitors. 
"No pictures, give me the film, you have no right to take pictures inside the port," the North Korean man, who sported a gold watch and designer sunglasses, said as his crew froze in their loading tasks, glaring with suspicion at the unexpected visitors. He ceremoniously dropped the film into the salt water.
Much of North Korea's notorious prickliness may come from an acute awareness that it has badly lost the development race. 
With a state farming system that does not produce enough food and a military that eats up as much as one-quarter of its gross national product, North Korea relied in 2001 on food donated by Japan, South Korea and the United States to help feed a third of its people. Although the donations averted a recurrence of the famines of the late 1990's, North Korea directed its harshest political vitriol last year at those three donor nations.
Half a century ago, North Korea's living standards were not much lower than postwar Japan's. Today, North Korea's per capita income is $760 and Japan's is $32,000. The gap is comparable to that between the United States and Honduras.
A rare intersection appears in this out-of-the-way port, known to Japanese tourists as the starting point for pleasant summer drives along a coastline of craggy cliffs, white beaches and bobbing fishing boats.
"Wonsan, Chongjin, Nampo," said Fumio Kitai, the local Japanese customs director, reading down a shipping list of home ports for 24 North Korean ships that have come here in December. From his office, a crane could be seen lowering a used Japanese car into the hold of an ancient freighter, the Nampo Two. Its port side was streaked with long fingers of rust.
"Used bicycles, refrigerators, televisions, radio-cassette players, second-hand beds, sofas, tables," he said running down the list of Japanese castoffs that flow through here to North Korea. In 2000, with Japanese recycling laws raising disposal costs, the surge in used goods helped triple Japan's exports to North Korea from Maizuru, Japan's busiest port for trade with North Korea.
In turn, Japan imports fish, snow crabs and matsutake mushrooms from North Korea. 
Some of Japan's hand-me-downs are too expensive for North Korea's pinched consumers. Most of the Japanese cars are smuggled into China, evading China's high taxes on imported cars.
"Guided by flashlight signals, Chinese smugglers carrying bags of cash enter the North to test the quality of cars," Chosun Ilbo, a South Korean newspaper, wrote recently of the cross-border trade. "North Korean drivers take them across the Tumen River, driving through shallow streams."
The newspaper estimated that a five-year-old Toyota Crown or Nissan Cedric bought in Japan for $3,000 would fetch twice the price at the Chinese border. The newspaper reported, though, that the number of North Korean groups pursuing this lucrative trade had increased to more than 100 from 6 in the early 1990's.
Japanese companies have also discovered that producing their goods in North Korea allows them to pay some of northeast Asia's lowest wages without fear of labor unrest.
Earlier this month, Daiei, a struggling Japanese supermarket chain, was selling men's suits for $80, a promotional price made possible by North Korean labor. In 2000, imports of clothing from North Korea through Maizuru totaled $2.4 million, a nearly 1,000-fold increase over 1999 levels.
"Japanese companies export textiles to North Korea, they process the cloth, and then it comes back through here," Mr. Kitai said. Leafing through his 2,795-page customs manual, Mr. Kitai found, on Page 1,667, that Japan's only major export restrictions to North Korea concerned military equipment and fishing boats.
In October, a Tokyo court gave suspended jail sentences to four men convicted of selling used fishing boats to North Korea without government permits. As the Dec. 22 clash showed, Japan remains deeply concerned about North Korean "spy ships." According to the Japanese news media, the ship that sank was one of three North Korean "spy ships" tracked by United States military satellites after leaving Nampo, North Korea, in early December.
In the past, Japan says, North Korean boats have landed spies on Japanese beaches, and the crews have smuggled drugs into Japan and kidnapped about a dozen Japanese young people, presumably to use as Japanese language instructors.
During the last two years, almost one-third of all illegal amphetamines seized in Japan have come from North Korea, according to Japan's National Police Agency. North Korea, which has refused to join the International Narcotics Control Board, raised international suspicions in 1998 when its diplomats in Thailand exported from Bangkok to Pyongyang 2.5 tons of ephedrine, a major ingredient for the manufacture of amphetamines.
Reports by North Korean defectors of industrial-scale state amphetamine factories now seem increasingly credible. Over the last two years, Japanese seizures of amphetamines from other Asian countries have averaged 80 pounds. Japanese seizures of amphetamines from North Korea have averaged 670 pounds.
"They need drug smuggling to get hard currency," said Hajime Izumi, an international affairs professor specializing in Korea at Shizuoka Prefectural University. He said that with a reduction in remittances from Koreans in Japan, North Korea had sought to earn hard currency through drug sales and counterfeiting.
"We haven't had any problems with them here," Hisao Nishiyama, the local deputy director of the Japan Coast Guard, said after peering through powerful binoculars from his harbor front office at two North Korean ships. North Korean flagged ships do not have insurance and tend to be in worse shape than Liberian or Panamanian flagged vessels, he said. 
But, he conceded, the high-seas battle last week, about 800 miles southwest of here, so rattled local fishermen that Coast Guard officials have given security talks to the Maizuru fishermen's association.
With geography dictating who will use this port, Akira Ono, the manager of Maizuru's port promotion association, said: "We hope this incident is not going to damage our trade. Trade brings benefits to both sides."
Still, the latest confrontation put another dent in North Korea's already battered image in Japan. Tallying up 577 e-mail messages received in the four days after the confrontation, the Coast Guard reported that 98 percent of the messages supported their conduct. Although autopsies on two of the bodies indicated that the two men had drowned, few people have criticized the Coast Guard for not rescuing the boat's crew members from the water; Japanese officials said Coast Guard officers were concerned at the time that the men were armed.
The conflict came only days after the United Nations World Food Program made a worldwide appeal for $400 million worth of food to feed North Koreans next year. With Japan gearing up to host a major Afghanistan aid conference in Tokyo in January, aid officials worry that Japan may lose interest in feeding North Korea.
"Now the Japanese public mood is quite negative to helping North Korea," Mr. Izumi said. Moreover, Japan is trimming its overall foreign aid budget as part of a recession-driven austerity. "Even though it is humanitarian aid," he added, "it is now quite difficult in Japan to get public support for North Korea."

HEADLINE: THE MAYORAL TRANSITION; 
Mayor's Speech: 'Rebuild, Renew and Remain the Capital of the Free World'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's inaugural address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 Thank you, Reverend, clergy, elected officials, honest guests, my fellow citizens. I am honored and humbled to serve as the 108th mayor of the City of New York. 
 Let me begin by saluting the leadership that Rudy Giuliani has provided over the last eight years. In our darkest hour he was a ray of hope, a voice of reassurance to millions. He made us all proud, and he reminded the world that New Yorkers don't quit. Everyone please stand again and join me in honoring Rudy Giuliani. 
I just want you to know that last night in Times Square when Rudy swore me in, he said to me, "Don't fail our people." Rudy, I will not. 
I also want to recognize former Mayors Ed Koch and David Dinkins, who have devoted their lives to serving the city of New York. Everything we do is built on your service in the past, gentlemen. Thank you both.
Today we celebrate the orderly transfer of power through a democratic process. Here in New York we understand all too well the price of our liberty. Just half a mile from these steps we lost 3,000 of our friends, families, neighbors, co-workers, including more than 400 heroes who gave their lives to save others.
On the worst day in our city's history we were at our best. We saw the spirit of New York in our unity of purpose. Our police, firefighters, emergency service workers exemplified the highest ideal of our national character. That sacrifice continues today. Americans are fighting terrorism around the world. And here at home our uniformed services continue the task of ensuring our safety. 
I pledge that my administration will strive, in everything we do, to honor the memory of those we have lost and honor those now fighting for our freedoms. We will rebuild, renew and remain the capital of the free world. 
To meet the challenges facing our city we must work together to draw upon the energy, entrepreneurship and talents of all New Yorkers. We are the toughest, most resilient and most determined people on the planet. Throughout our history New Yorkers have always made the sacrifices necessary to achieve a better tomorrow. And there will be a better tomorrow. 
In the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, Gov. Hugh Carey brought together the city, the state, labor and business. He went to Washington to deliver our message, and he prevailed. This time Washington came to New York. Within days of the tragedy, President George W. Bush stood at ground zero and pledged that America stands with our city. Thank you, Mr. President, for all you have done and all that you will do to fulfill that explicit pledge. 
We are also indebted to a leadership of United States Senators Chuck Schumer and Hillary Clinton and to the dean of our Congressional delegation, Charlie Rangel. They and their colleagues are the ones who represent us so ably in Washington. And together we pledge to the president and to the Congress, we will justify America's support. 
In Albany we are fortunate to have a governor, George Pataki, who understands and appreciates the importance of our city. I look forward to working closely with the governor and with our state legislative leaders, Senate majority leader Joe Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who have been so supportive. 
As mayor I will form a new partnership with Washington, with Albany, with our City Council, with our borough presidents, with our community boards, with our municipal unions, with business and with all New Yorkers. The people have asked us to set aside partisan differences to overcome traditional barriers and to cooperate in this new partnership. This is an historic moment. We cannot afford to fight with each other. We must work together. 
I am especially pleased that my good friend for 30 years, John Whitehead, has assumed the chairmanship of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation. John and his committee have been charged by Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani with coordinating all the proposals for rebuilding the World Trade Center site. And we know he and his committee will arrive at a consensus we all can support.
And as we must rebuild Lower Manhattan, so we must also invest time and effort throughout our entire city. As Toni Morrison has said, New York is the last true city. And it is the vitality of our neighborhoods that define us. Those streets where we work, raise our children, form friendships and learn the values that we carry through life. New York has been and will continue to be a magnet for people from all over the world. This is where the arts, business, research and technology converge to create the world's foremost urban economy. 
Based on my experience building a business here in New York, I can guarantee that New York is the best place in the world to do business. No city can match New York for its intellectual capital, financial know-how and cultural vibrancy. 
To our corporate leaders, I urge you to strengthen your commitment to New York. This is no time to leave the Big Apple. Your future is New York. And New York's is better than ever. 
I have said it before and I want to say it again: New York is safe, strong, open for business and ready to lead the world in the 21st century. We will continue to improve our quality of life and attract visitors, tourists and businesses in record numbers. We will focus on public safety. We will work tirelessly to provide safe streets and homes for all New Yorkers. We will go forward. We will never go back. 
We will focus on adding and retaining jobs for all our people. The ability for everyone to have the skills and opportunity to feed one's family is the basis for a free, healthy, democratic society, and we must ensure all have it. 
We will improve our public schools. Parents know that their children are safe and receiving an education that prepares them for the future is what they demand. We will test our educators. We will test our students. But the real test is that of political resolve, the test of ourselves. The need is real. The time is now. Without authority there is no accountability. 
The public through the mayor must control the school system. To do this, I will build a partnership with the governor, our State Legislature, the City Council, the borough presidents, the teachers' union and parents. Together we will create a school system that works for all our children. 
Rebuilding our city, restoring our infrastructure, continuing the fight against crime and reforming our schools will not be easy in the current economic climate. It will require tough decisions and hard choices by all of us, in government, the nonprofit sector, business and labor. I will be asking all parts of my city government to do more with less. I will ask for their help, and I will seek their advice. 
But the facts are clear. We will not be able to afford all that we want. We will not even be able to afford everything we currently have. And since leadership means setting an example, and in my book the search for efficiency always begins at the top, I pledge to reduce staffing in the office of the mayor by 20 percent. And I hereby challenge the comptroller, public advocate, borough presidents and the City Council to do the same. 
We cannot ask of others what we are not willing to do ourselves. I will do my part to balance the budget, as I am sure every city employee will do in turn. Let me say once more though, we cannot repeat the mistakes of the past. We cannot drive people and business out of New York. We cannot raise taxes. We will find another way. 
And even though we must sacrifice now, let us not forget we are still a city of big dreams, of big ideas, big projects and a big heart. We must plan and develop for the long term. We can never abandon our future. We will bring new life to our waterfront and stimulate new investment in housing, schools and, when we can afford them, the world's best cultural and athletic facilities. These, along with our parks and transportation infrastructure in all five boroughs, cannot be ignored. We will plan now and build as funds become available. We will emerge from short-term pain to long-term gain. 
This is a city where 140 languages are spoken. Since the days of the Dutch, wave after wave of immigrants have transformed this city. They have flourished because of the culture of tolerance and acceptance that characterizes New York. Our challenge is to strengthen that culture and fight bigotry in any form, wherever it may happen. I will not allow any form of bias to drain our energy or divide our communities. 
Those of us in government must remember that we are here to work with and serve all eight million New Yorkers. When I launched my campaign in Queens, I said my only regret was that my father did not live to see my dreams come true. I want New Yorkers to have the same opportunity my father wanted for my sister and me, the opportunity to pursue one's dreams. 
In the next four years I will devote myself to building a better New York. I promise that I will govern free from partisanship and prejudice. I promise that I will listen, and whether you ultimately agree with my decisions, you will know that your voice has been heard. 
On election night I vowed to build the best government that this city has ever seen, an inclusive, diverse, energetic and innovative government; the right team to lead our city through difficult times. I am very proud of the administration we are assembling. 
But government alone can't find the solutions to all of our problems. It is not in City Hall but in the Rockaways, Bay Ridge, Washington Heights, New Dorp and Belmont, there and in the hundreds of neighborhoods throughout this great city are many of our answers. Together we will make the hard choices. We will forge a new partnership that binds all New Yorkers to meet our challenges head-on, and we will prevail. 
Thank you and God bless New York.
