HEADLINE: It's All Aboard, if They'll Fit, As Sept. 11 Jolts Mass Transit 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A New Jersey Transit train swept into the station, looking more like the subway than a commuter train. The seats were full. The vestibules were full. Even the aisles were full, so crowded that conductors could not move down them to collect tickets.
 It was nothing out of the ordinary. Just another weekday morning in Newark, 8:26 a.m. And once again Simone McGowan, 34, a registered nurse, was throwing herself into the maw. 
 "I've been commuting into the city since I was 16," she said, joining the wide crowd squeezing through the narrow door. "But I don't know how much longer I can take this." 
She is not the only one wondering. On many morning trains heading into Manhattan, the number of passengers has increased 44 percent over the last three months -- the kind of growth that officials thought would take a decade.
And if New Jersey Transit looks like the subway, the PATH system on many mornings can look and feel even worse. With its busiest station, at the World Trade Center, out for at least two years, and ridership still surprisingly high, four of the other five Manhattan stations -- at Christopher, Ninth, 14th and 33rd Streets -- are experiencing passenger loads roughly double what they were before Sept. 11.
"All of those stations are bursting at the seams right now," said Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "There's nowhere for people to go."
The statement is one that could be superimposed on dozens of transportation hubs around the city, and it describes a harsh, new reality: even as many things seem to have recovered remarkably since Sept. 11, the precariously balanced network of highways and rails, long overstrained before the attacks, is still suffering terribly and will continue to do so for much longer than most commuters had feared, transportation officials say.
Though the subway recovered fairly quickly after the attack, it is still snarled weekly by security-related shutdowns and delays that officials say will probably not go away soon. The same uncertainty reigns on the roads, where tunnels and bridges can be closed on a moment's notice.
"There's a new normal, and we can't go back," said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a pedestrian advocacy group that is part of a coalition of officials, advocates and business leaders trying to map out the future of transportation around the city.
At least for the foreseeable future, many of the problems will be the result of an unexpected conundrum -- commuters trying to switch from cars to mass transit, as officials have always urged. But riders are often finding the system too overburdened to handle them, especially as they make their way to Midtown, where thousands of jobs have moved from Lower Manhattan. 
Traffic restrictions after the attack -- both security checkpoints and the morning ban on single-occupant vehicles at several crossings into the city -- have forced tens of thousands of drivers out of their cars and onto commuter trains and buses, several transit agencies say.
"We're pretty sure that many inveterate motorists have decided to give up their wheels for ours," said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the Metro-North Railroad.
Both Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road say their ridership into the city has remained level, or just below where it was before Sept. 11. But given that officials had expected a precipitous drop with the loss of so many jobs in Lower Manhattan, the numbers suggest that the railroads have actually picked up new riders.
Roads and bridges have been overcrowded for years, so the switch to transit is a phenomenon that urban planners had long hoped for and one that has already made morning car commuting into the city noticeably easier. But the switch was much larger than transit officials expected, and it happened much too quickly.
By no means is the entire mass transit system overburdened, but now many choke points -- both those that existed before the attack and others created by it -- are dangerously strained, creating conditions so intolerable that officials and business leaders fear they will drive businesses and people away from the New York area.
Undoubtedly the hardest hit is New Jersey Transit. Its trains make their way to New York's Pennsylvania Station through a single tunnel beneath the Hudson, one that the agency shares with Amtrak. With two train lines, the tunnel has long operated at capacity. After the terrorist attack, for a sum that New Jersey officials would not disclose, Amtrak ceded a small amount of rush-hour time to New Jersey Transit -- meaning four more inbound trains during the morning rush and four more outbound during the evening.
But even with those extra trains, the number of people standing every morning, pressed up against the windows or their neighbors, has grown to more than 23,000.
Those conditions mean that a longstanding plan to relieve serious crowding is now in serious jeopardy. The agency had planned to open the Secaucus Transfer Station next fall, allowing riders from Bergen County to transfer to trains going directly to Manhattan.
But the switch would mean an extra 16,000 passengers boarding Manhattan-bound trains, a scene no one now even wants to imagine, especially as New Jersey Transit considers a fare increase of about 10 percent to help close multimillion-dollar budget deficits.
The agency would love to encourage more of its riders to switch to buses. But New Jersey Transit commuter buses already carry about two-thirds of all the agency's passengers and, as with the trains, the system is full. No more gates are available at the Port Authority for the agency's buses, and Jeffrey A. Warsh, the executive director of New Jersey Transit, said no more buses could go through the Lincoln Tunnel at the height of the morning rush.
Before Sept. 11, 14,000 people were already standing on buses; now there are more than 16,000.
"It's amazing what people have to endure," Mr. Warsh said. "New riders are going to come out and say, 'Oh, my God. I can't deal with that. I can't get a seat. I can't even get on the train.' "
Part of the problem is that thousands of jobs have moved to Midtown. The transit lines pouring people into the area have become like a funnel trying to direct too much water. New Jersey Transit officials have estimated that of the financial jobs that survived the attack and moved from Lower Manhattan, 60 percent relocated to Midtown.
The agency's projections show that even with the opening of a temporary PATH station at the World Trade Center site in about two years, the station would initially siphon away only about 2,000 of the 15,000 or so extra morning riders that New Jersey Transit has picked up.
If that projection is accurate, and more passengers will now be bound for Midtown or other parts of Manhattan, it also means trouble for the Port Authority, which runs the PATH. Although the line's ridership has dropped since the attack -- to 205,000 passengers a day, compared with 257,000 before -- it has not dropped as much as officials thought it would, with two of the system's 13 stations closed.
The tiny Christopher Street station once handled an average of 3,700 passengers a day; now it handles 8,000. The crowds at Ninth Street and 14th Street have slightly more than doubled, and -- suggesting the job shift to Midtown -- the number using the 33rd Street station has increased to 45,000 from 28,700.
That kind of extra crowding on the PATH has largely not occurred on the New York City subway system after the attacks, because ridership was already slowing and the subway was able to restore service to all but four stations in Lower Manhattan. But with train routes mostly back to normal again, the subway must now deal with a new problem in a much less secure city: safety.
In September, the number of subway delays caused by police investigations of suspicious packages or white powders jumped to 458, more than double the total from the month before the terrorist attack. By October, police delays more than quadrupled, to 2,648, making them by far the leading cause of late subway trains, as reports of suspicious packages and white powders flooded in.
Those disruptions have started to ease, transit officials say. There has not been another incident approaching the one on the morning of Oct. 22, when an investigation of a white powder at 34th Street and the Avenue of the Americas delayed 234 trains on five lines.
"Things seem to be heading back in the right direction," said Al O'Leary, the chief spokesman for New York City Transit.
But, in November, the leading cause of subway delays was still listed as "suspicious substances." Subway officials caution that riders must change their expectations about the balance between security and trains running on time.
Iris Weinshall, the city's transportation commissioner, said that on the roads around the city, drivers have changed their expectations, and their behavior, more quickly than planners thought. One change, revolutionary in itself, is simply that drivers now do not expect to be able to drive whenever they want.
Two reasons are the continuing security checkpoints and unexpected road closures that can still make driving a harrowing experience. But the ban on single-occupant vehicles crossing into Lower Manhattan or Midtown from 6 to 10 a.m. has had a profound effect, resulting in a 15 percent drop in traffic on those crossings in the morning.
That result, which has greatly reduced gridlock around the region, could mean that the ban will stay in place well into this year.
"The drumbeat is going to be there to lift the S.O.V. ban, but what's going to happen if we lift it?" asked Ms. Weinshall, who added that her agency had commissioned an ambitious study of the effects of the restrictions on the city's economy and roads. 
Many transportation experts say that if the ban remains, what will undoubtedly happen is a continued funneling of people onto mass transit -- and mounting worries about how the system can handle it.
For now, one of the only pressure valves can be found on the open water, where ferry ridership has surged to 124,000 passengers a day from 97,000 before Sept. 11, with nine new routes added in the last three months and new landings on the way.
Transit officials -- confronted with the huge capital investments and lead time necessary to improve rail service -- are also seriously looking at proposals to create what is known as "bus rapid transit." A kind of subway on the highways, this would be accomplished by rigidly separated bus lanes within and even into the city, where buses could travel much faster and load more the way subways do, at above-ground stations with turnstiles.
"There's a lot more ferment than there has ever been on many of these issues," said Mr. Kaehny, of Transportation Alternatives. "People are being forced to think outside of the box."
Many transportation experts call that kind of thinking imperative.
"People are willing to put up with those conditions for a week or a month or if they knew how long it was going to be," said Jeff Zupan, a senior transportation fellow with the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that advises governments on development.
"But if they don't know how long it's going to go, they're going to start saying, 'Why do I have to take this? Why do I have to live here?' "

 BODY:
Rollout of Notes and Coins Helps Lift Value of Euro
With most signs pointing toward a remarkably smooth rollout of euro notes and coins across 12 European nations, investors bid up the value of the currency while people on the streets clamored to unload their old money.
 Analysts described the rise as a "relief rally" driven by the fact that the complicated process of putting the euro into circulation had unfolded without serious problems. Page A1. 

Congress Steps Up Enron Inquiry
Senate Democrats said that they planned to subpoena documents from Enron executives and to examine the company's high-level connections to the Bush administration as Congress steps up its inquiry into the company's collapse. Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the chairman of the Senate Government Affairs Committee, said his main concern was the interests of shareholders who might have been deceived by the company's statements about its financial health. C3.

The Dow Jones industrial average gained 51.9 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,073.40, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.59 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,154.67. C6.

Shares of Tyco International fell 2.8 percent after a research firm questioned whether Tyco is the subject of a government investigation. SEC Insight had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission in November to disclose its recent correspondence with Tyco. In a newsletter, SEC Insight said the commission had turned down the request on the grounds that disclosing the information might interfere with law enforcement activities. Tyco said it was not being investigated by the S.E.C. A spokeswoman said she was "not aware" of any civil or criminal investigations aside from one grand jury investigation in Connecticut that the company has already disclosed. C2.

HEADLINE: Man in the News; 
Peronist for the Present; Eduardo Alberto Duhalde

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Long before the economy here imploded, Eduardo Duhalde was preaching against what he called "exhausted" free-market economic ideas. 
 Mr. Duhalde's ascension as Argentina's fifth president in two weeks signifies that the country "leaves behind the free-market policies of the past decade and begins moving toward a model that is more protectionist and more inward-looking," said Martin Redrado, a leading economic consultant here. "That means a government more involved in the economy and more present in terms of regulations." 
 Mr. Duhalde is proposing a return to the populist policies championed decades ago by his political idol, Gen. Juan Domingo Peron. His embrace of the past comes at a moment when his weary country is receptive to political solutions that are at least familiar.
But at a time when Argentina needs help from international lenders to fight its way out of a $134-billion debt crisis, there are severe limits to how far Mr. Duhalde can go to reject global market economics and avoid unpopular measures to stave off collapse.
After Congress chose him as president late Tuesday night, Mr. Duhalde talked of an end to the policy that has made the Argentine peso and the American dollar virtually interchangeable since 1991 by linking them at a 1-to-1 rate. Today there were additional hints that a bruising devaluation was coming, as the central bank revoked regulations that required banks to accept payment in pesos for debts incurred in dollars. World Business, Page W1. 
Over a 30-year career, Mr. Duhalde, 60, has demonstrated that he is no stranger to patronage, operates well in smoky backrooms and is schooled in the top-down politics that has made the Peronist Party Argentina's most formidable electoral machine.
Eduardo Alberto Duhalde was born on Oct. 5, 1941, in Lomas de Zamora, a Buenos Aires suburb where he still lives. After studying law, he began his public life in 1971 as a town councilman there and then served as mayor before being elected to the lower house of Congress in 1987.
More recently, as governor of the province of Buenos Aires, which surrounds the capital and is home to more than a quarter of the country's 36 million people, Mr. Duhalde had a mixed record. During eight years in office, he proved adept at keeping normally antagonistic social groups under the Peronist tent and also won praise for confronting police brutality and corruption.
To win political support, though, Mr. Duhalde also spent big and ran up large debts, which led to accusations of corruption against his government. As a result, the province was left virtually bankrupt when he left office in 1999, forcing his successor, Carlos Ruckauf, to begin paying provincial employees and suppliers last year with bonds that are not yet redeemable.
At least some of Mr. Duhalde's trusted associates from his days in the provinces appear to be ready to rejoin him in the central government. A prominent Peronist leader said today that Mr. Duhalde would appoint Jorge Remes Lenicov, who was his provincial chief of finances, as the new economy minister, and there are reports that Mr. Ruckauf will become the foreign minister.
But after the instability the country has lived through in the last month, Mr. Duhalde, a chess player and father of five, is welcomed as a known quantity, with a long track record and strengths and weaknesses that are no secret. Though Argentines are clearly demanding change, they also want to avoid any more unpleasant surprises, analysts say.
"If we are dancing a tango, this is the part where we take a couple of steps back," said Felipe Noguera, a leading pollster and consultant here. Mr. Duhalde, he explained, "is not necessarily the man to lay the foundation for long-term prosperity, but he can pacify Argentina and give it a sense of stability, which does seem to make him a man for this moment."
Mr. Duhalde has already won praise and moved to differentiate himself from Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, the interim president who fell after a week in office, by promising to lead a broad-based "government of national salvation" that will include opposition parties in his cabinet. And instead of offending rivals by crowing about the Peronist return to power, as Mr. Rodriguez Saa did, today he offered humility, sobriety and even a mea culpa.
"We Peronists are part of the problem, just like all the others who have governed this country, civilian and military," Mr. Duhalde told a group of well-wishers this afternoon, shortly after officially donning the sash of office in a brief ceremony at the presidential palace here. But now, he added, "the situation is such that we cannot afford to make mistakes."
Mr. Duhalde was initially an ally of President Carlos Saul Menem, who plucked him from the lower house of Congress and made him his running mate in 1989. He served as vice president for two years, and even wrote a book called "The Productive Revolution" with Mr. Menem. But their relations began to fray after Mr. Duhalde was elected governor of the province of Buenos Aires in 1991.
Many in the Peronist Party saw Mr. Duhalde as their logical candidate in the next presidential election, because Mr. Menem was unable by law to succeed himself. But Mr. Menem was able to overturn that prohibition. Mr. Duhalde, however, finally won the Peronist nomination in the 1999 election. Mr. Menem offered him only token support, which led to a chilly relationship that persists to this day.
Defeated with only 38 percent of the vote, the worst showing by a Peronist presidential candidate in party history, Mr. Duhalde's political career appeared to be finished, or so said the pundits. But he mounted a stunning comeback in October's legislative elections, managing with the help of Mr. Ruckauf, his ally and successor as governor, to be elected senator from the Buenos Aires province by more than 700,000 votes.
Now he has been vindicated again, and on an even larger stage. 
Until recently, Mr. Duhalde was "a leader not held in high regard by the Buenos Aires press or the local establishment, which regarded him as a man of the provinces, surrounded by low-quality people," noted Joaquin Morales Sola, a political columnist for the daily newspaper La Nacion. But "the fragmentation of Argentine society and Peronism" is now so severe, he added, "that Duhalde is now seen as the only leader with the qualities to discipline society and undertake realistic policies."

HEADLINE: N.J. Transit Is Criticized For Planning Fare Increase 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
New Jersey Transit's proposal to raise fares on its buses, trains and the Newark subway system over six years was sharply criticized at public hearings tonight here and in five other cities around the state.
 Commuters, environmental groups and advocates for mass transit denounced nearly every aspect of the proposal and said higher fares would drive riders onto the roads, increasing highway congestion. 
 "A fare increase is a tax increase," said William Wright, secretary of the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers, a commuter group based in Freehold. "History tells us that higher fares will lead to the spiral of fewer riders, higher fares and the ultimate destruction of New Jersey Transit." 
Under the proposal, fares would be increased an average of 10 percent on April 1. In addition, five annual increases tied to the rate of inflation could be imposed.
The proposed increase is intended to raise $44 million for the fiscal year that starts July 1 and help offset a deficit estimated at $169 million.
The agency's board is scheduled to vote on the proposed increase on Monday, one day before Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco leaves office. If the board approves new fares then, which is considered likely, Mr. DiFrancesco will have time to approve them and spare his successor a politically unpalatable chore. 
Many of the 125 people at the Newark hearing criticized a provision allowing New Jersey Transit to order the inflationary increases without public hearings. One commuter, Gary Johnson of Edison, said the five annual inflationary increases could amount to 3 percentage points a year, for a total of 25 percent. 
In Freehold, commuters complained about poor service and crowded trains and said higher fares would force them to consider alternatives to mass transit. "If that happens, you'll have one more car on the parkway," said Ken Allan, a bank employee from Brick Township. 
As an alternative to the fare increase, Mr. Wright's organization, as well as the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club and the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, which promotes mass transit, called for a 10-cent increase in the state's 10.5-cent gasoline tax and asked that the revenue be dedicated to New Jersey Transit. 
At a news conference before the hearings, Jeffrey A. Warsh, New Jersey Transit's executive director, noted that the agency had no power to increase gas taxes. He said he hoped that Governor-elect James E. McGreevey and the State Legislature would increase the agency's annual state subsidy, now $260 million, by $125 million to plug the deficit. 
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. McGreevey declined to take a position on the fare proposal or on any other new transportation financing. 
Besides the projected $169 million deficit for the fiscal year starting July 1, the agency expects a $3.1 billion deficit in both the operating and the capital budgets for the five fiscal years after that.
Some of that shortfall involves projected costs for a major new rail hub in Secaucus; although work has begun, its opening was thrown into doubt after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Other expenses include a new concourse for New Jersey rail passengers in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, a new train station at Newark International Airport and 30 transit police officers hired in the wake of the attacks, Mr. Warsh said.
Besides increasing fares, the proposal would:
*Eliminate the 25 percent discount on weekday round-trip excursion fares on trains.
*Create a uniform fare -- $3.30 one way -- between Newark's two train stations and Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. The current fares are $2.50 between Newark's Penn Station and Manhattan and $3 between Newark's Broad Street Station and Manhattan. 
*Reduce the ticket discount for passengers 62 and older to 50 percent from the current 55 percent. 
*Raise the surcharge for buying tickets on trains to $5 from $3. 
*Eliminate refunds for unused one-way tickets.
*Combine one-zone and two-zone bus routes into a new single zone with a one-way fare of $1.20 and a monthly pass costing $49.

HEADLINE: A SMOOTH DEBUT LIFTS EURO'S VALUE IN MONEY MARKETS 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
After years of preparation and some predictions of chaos, Europeans in 12 nations have begun using a common currency with no significant problems, a surprising amount of enthusiasm and even a slight rise in its value today.
 In a collective expression of relief by world money markets, the euro jumped 1.4 percent against the dollar in New York trading and about 2 percent against the Japanese yen. 
 Analysts described the jump as a "relief rally" driven by the currency's remarkably smooth introduction into circulation on Tuesday and the first full day of business today. Across the continent euros were generally available despite some spot shortages, some balky cash registers and a few long lines at some banks and supermarkets. 
The euro's bounce was in some respects surprising, since bankers, businesses and currency traders have been working in euros for three years. The arrival of euro notes and coins in cash registers and A.T.M.'s has little or no impact on its value.
Ever since Jan. 1, 1999, 11 European countries locked the value of their francs, marks and pesetas to that of the euro, and surrendered their powers to set interest rates and administer monetary policy to a new European Central Bank.
At the time, French leaders expressed the hope that the euro would strengthen Europe politically by enhancing trade without the complexities of currency conversions, and by becoming a counterweight to the dollar.
But the euro, which bought $1.17 at its inception, quickly lost ground, reaching a low of nearly 82 cents in the fall of 2000. It settled in New York today at 90.36 cents today, up from 89.13 cents.
Analysts said the apparently smooth arrival of the euro, refuting months of speculation about the potential for chaos during the changeover, might have been responsible for the lift today.
Larry Kantor, the global head of foreign exchange strategy at J. P. Morgan, said, "One of the things was some kind of psychological boost from the introduction of the euro bills and coins."
Many analysts cautioned that today's rally could prove very short. Many predict that the new single currency could once again slide against the dollar because European growth is likely to be stagnant for the next several months. Some economist have predicted that over the next several months, the euro's value could drift down to 85 cents.
In the first day that most stores were open in the new year, business proceeded smoothly in supermarkets and shops. Lines were a bit slower at stores as cashiers were forced to wrestle with euros as well as the old denominations.
About 80 percent of the 200,000 A.T.M.'s in the region were dispensing euros today, with nearly all cash machines converted in Germany, Austria and the Netherlands.
Many Europeans found themselves fascinated as they held their new money.
"I felt quite moved to keep the new euro money in my hands after expecting this moment for three years," said Sebastian G. Riedmayr, a physician in his early 30's who lives in Munich. "I am sure this is an important psychological point in pushing toward a European political union.
Eugenio Domingo Solans, the European Central Bank official directly responsible for the changeover, said that demand for the new money had been very strong and that cash withdrawals in some countries were four times above normal levels.
Despite that, Mr. Solans said today, the changeover has so far gone "smoothly and even better than we had expected."
Indeed, the very popularity of the new money led to problems. Many cash machines ran short in Germany, and banks were scrambling to replenish them after having raced madly to load them on New Year's Eve.
Here in Frankfurt, people mobbed several downtown bank branches seeking to convert large stocks of German marks to euros.
At a downtown branch of Deutsche Bank 24, the crowds were so large that flustered bank employees blocked off the doors and let customers enter in groups of five.
Elsewhere around Europe, the rollout of euro coins and bills proceeded without major problems.
Even in France, where bank workers had vowed to go on strike today, the changeover continued as smoothly as anywhere else. Nine out of 10 French A.T.M.'s were already dispensing euros by Tuesday night, and most of the bank tellers were on duty today.
"For the moment, knock on wood, everything is going extremely well," said Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister. BNP Paribas, France's biggest bank, reached a tentative agreement with its unions last week.
Societe Generale, also one of the biggest French banks, said that only one-quarter of its workers had taken part in the strike and that most of its bank counters were open.
For many people, the mere arrival of a tangible common currency had seemed like an impossibility for years. European leaders first started dreaming about a single currency more than 40 years ago, and a core group of countries agreed in principle on the idea back in 1971. 
But the idea was derailed by an assortment of global economic crises, beginning with the oil price shocks of 1973 and 1974. The project languished until the fall of the Berlin Wall, when French leaders pushed Germany's chancellor at the time, Helmut Kohl, to commit to a timetable for adopting the single currency in exchange for French support on reuniting east and west Germany.
Nations within the European Union agreed on the basic plan at a historic summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in 1991. The Maastricht Treaty laid out a 10-year plan that began with a European exchange-rate control mechanism, proceeded to the adoption of a "virtual currency" in 1999 -- essentially an electronic currency for banks, businesses and brokers, and finally to a currency for cash boxes and coin purses in 2002.
But the path from Maastricht to today was filled with obstacles.
French and German leaders feuded repeatedly over what each country had to achieve to qualify for the currency, over any possible sanctions when one nation's debt or deficits went off course, and over the ability of political leaders to influence decisions of an independent European Central Bank.
Even after 11 countries adopted the euro in 1999 -- a 12th nation, Greece, came into the fold later -- millions of Europeans thought that nothing had changed because the currency did not physically exist. Prices for the most part in stores were still posted in pesetas, francs, marks, lira, schillings, escudos, drachmas and punts.
If the euro's cash debut does in fact proceed without major problems, it could have a important impact on public attitudes in the three E.U. countries that have refused to adopt the common currency -- Britain, Sweden and Denmark.
Recent opinion polls in both Sweden and Denmark suggest that a slight majority of both populations now supports adopting the euro. In Sweden, Prime Minister Goran Persson suggested last week that the country might hold a referendum on the question as early as this fall. Denmark held a referendum last year, but a majority of voters came out against it and a follow-up referendum is unlikely any time soon.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SYKES TO CLOSE 3 SERVICE CENTERS AND DISMISS 230 PEOPLE

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Sykes Enterprises, an operator of customer service centers, said yesterday that it would close two centers in the United States and one in Europe and lay off 230 employees. Sykes, which operates service centers for computer companies like Microsoft and Apple Computer, blamed the slow economy for the cuts. 
Sykes employs about 15,000 people in 41 centers worldwide. It will close its Greeley, Colo., center and one center in Bismarck, N.D. A second Bismarck center will remain open. One of the company's five European centers will also be closed, but company officials declined to disclose its location. The cuts are expected to cost the company $15 million to $16.5 million. Employees have been notified and most have received two weeks' pay in a severance package, the chief financial officer, Michael Kipphut, said.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: November Chip Sales Show Gain 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 Sales of computer chips in November improved slightly for the second consecutive month, as the industry's sharp decline continued to show signs of having hit bottom. The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group in San Jose, Calif., said global chip sales were $10.6 billion, a 42 percent decline from a year earlier but up 1.6 percent from October, when sales were $10.44 billion. 
Month-to-month growth of 5.3 percent in Europe offset flat sales in the Americas and a 1 percent decline in Japan. George Scalise, president of the association, said the industry was on track to grow 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter, as predicted. But analysts said chip makers might struggle through more dreary times in the beginning of 2002, as a weak economy continues to hamper demand. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index gained 4.5 percent, to 545.44. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE SKI REPORT; 
Season May Still Have Bumpy Patches Ahead

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
September is usually a fairly busy month in the reservations department of North American ski areas. Not surprisingly, from Mammoth Mountain in California to Sunday River in Maine, the telephones stopped ringing on the afternoon of Sept. 11. They did not resume ringing for several weeks.
 As scary as that was, ski area operators knew they were not going to be helped by two subsequent developments: a weakening economy and record warm temperatures just after Thanksgiving in the Northeast. 
 The consensus was that people would be unwilling to fly in the wake of the terrorist attacks and the consequence would be that many Western areas, normally helped by thousands of Eastern visitors, would suffer the most.
But then November turned to December and the East was largely snowless.
Amid all this uneasiness, and with early reservations generally down 10 to 20 percent, snow began to fall in the West and did not stop for days. When it did stop snowing, some people who were on the fence about a trip West seemed to be getting over their squeamishness with reports like this one from Lake Tahoe's Heavenly Ski Resort: seven-foot snow base, all 29 lifts open.
In the East, meanwhile, colder temperatures arrived later than usual but perhaps not too late given today's technologically advanced snow-making systems.
Resorts throughout the nation have just completed their busy holiday periods and there does not appear to have been a significant downturn in business at most areas. The number of reservations -- easier to audit than lift-ticket purchases -- was consistent with a year ago. But that may not tell the story for the rest of the ski season. What happens in the next three months without the lure of a traditional holiday trip?
"If all you're looking at is Christmas then you're getting a misleading picture of the larger story," said Adam Aron, the chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Vail Resorts, owners of Vail, Breckenridge, Keystone and Beaver Creek in Colorado. "When I look at our bookings in January, February and March, I am reminded that Sept. 11 really did occur."
Aron said yesterday that his company's bookings across the whole ski season for guests flying from other parts of the country were off 21 percent.
"It's going on throughout the travel industry," Aron said. "We have fabulous snow and maybe we'll get lucky from the word-of-mouth comments of those who were here for Christmas. Bookings have gotten stronger week to week but it's not back to normal."
There have been no bold predictions from anyone in the industry about the next three months, especially since this season is being compared with the record 57.3 million skier and snowboarder visits of last season.
"At the end of the day, what has the real impact is the same thing that always matters most in our industry -- the weather," said Michael Berry, president of the National Ski Areas Association. "With good snow totals, we saw the West went through a little comeback."
It has been a slower start in the East, but an aggressive recovery by the snow-making crews let the areas of upstate New York and northern New England open late last month. And the turnout last week was reasonably strong.
"We have been sold out for the holiday week," David Dillon, president of the Vermont Ski Areas Association, said. "It may not be a record-breaking season but we have developed a reputation for dependable snow-making."
Some smaller areas have other worries. With less snow-making and more limited water supplies, they are playing a guessing game with the weather. It takes a large volume of water to make ample amounts of snow and there has been a drought throughout the East this year. That may explain why some in the industry think that Nordic activities have become more popular this season.
Still, most snow-condition reports were fast improving last week. Sugarbush opened 80 trails, Stowe nearly 50 and Killington more than 100 trails. Base depths were in the three-foot range. And they certainly have plenty of snow out West.
So while the immediate future is unsettled, and many mountains have put off capital projects, at least something as symbolically significant as the post-Christmas week was not a washout for skiers.
"It's an important activity in terms of the fabric of their lives," Berry said. "It's what they enjoy, and it has a place in their psyche, and that's a powerful dynamic."
Finally, there is another unintended effect of Sept. 11 that is worth mentioning. In recent years, slope etiquette had become something of a misnomer. It is a casual observation, but some people in recent weeks have noticed a gentler, more tolerant visitor on the slopes.
"Guest-services folks have told me that they've noticed people being nicer and more patient," Kim Jackson, Killington's news bureau director, said last week. "I think people are glad to be doing something they love to do again. They're just happy to be here."

HEADLINE: Hoping It's No California, Texas Deregulates Energy 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Less than a year after the nation's most-populous state, California, endured blackouts and political and economic turmoil when it deregulated the power industry, the second-most-populous state, Texas, this week began its own deregulation plan with officials promising that there would be no reprise of California's chaos.
 But consumer advocates, while generally agreeing that the Texas plan included better safeguards than California's, expressed skepticism that residential customers would benefit from long-term reductions as energy providers competed for business. These advocates also warned that Texas, like California, failed to provide adequate protection to ensure that the state did not suffer from electricity shortages as demand increased. 
 For Texas, deregulation comes not long after the Enron Corporation, the Houston energy giant that championed deregulated energy markets, collapsed into bankruptcy. Meanwhile, the chairman of the state agency that will oversee the deregulated electricity market, has come under fire for his ties to Enron. 
The official start of deregulation in Texas was New Year's Day, but today was the first business day of operation and, as yet, few of the 4.7 million eligible households had chosen to switch providers away from the longstanding utilities. State officials predicted that the transition would be gradual, particularly for residential customers, many of whom are still unaware that change is afoot. Nor have electricity retailers rushed into the residential market; as yet, 41 new retailers have registered, but most are seeking commercial and industrial clients.
Terry Hadley, spokesman for the Texas Public Utility Commission, the agency overseeing the electricity marketplace, said electricity retailers were "sharpening their pencils to see what kind of offers they can make." Several companies are already marketing to residential customers. and Mr. Hadley predicted that such appeals would intensify in coming months.
Still uncertain is whether Texas customers will embrace deregulation, particularly after the problems in California. The rules here establish an immediate retail price reduction of 11 percent to 17 percent, a drop partly attributable to the low price of natural gas, which is often used to fuel electric generation plants. This savings is built into the "price to beat," the state-mandated price per kilowatt hour that the old utilities will be allowed to charge under deregulation to keep their customers. New retailers will be allowed to offer lower prices as a way to entice customers to switch.
Texas officials have taken pains to reassure consumers -- and journalists -- that California's problems were unique.
In California, the state deregulated the wholesale power market while keeping retail prices capped. This caused the state's two biggest public utilities to lose billions of dollars when wholesale prices spiked and the retail price caps prevented them from passing the costs along to consumers. One reason the prices jumped was the price of natural gas, then at a record high.
California officials, including Gov. Gray Davis, also accused several energy companies, including Enron, of manipulating prices and making the state's problems worse, a charge the companies denied.
California's problems were also partly attributable to a lack of supply; the state had not built a major power plant in roughly a decade.
The state endured rolling blackouts and other problems before federal regulators ordered restraints on electricity prices last summer. In September, the California Public Utilities Commission voted to shift away from deregulation.
While about two dozen states, including most of those in the Northeast, have begun deregulation, others, like Nevada, New Mexico and Oklahoma have postponed plans in the wake of California's problems. Texas officials, on the other hand, express confidence in their plan.
Unlike California, Texas deregulated the wholesale electrical market in 1995, providing a time buffer to work out any kinks before introducing retail deregulation this year. And also unlike California, Texas has seen about 30 power plants built in the state in the last six years. Officials say the state's electrical supply exceeds demand by 23 percent.
Nor does the state's plan mandate the sort of retail price caps that crippled the California utilities.
"We have more than enough capacity and supply of electricity," Mr. Hadley said. "And the mechanics are in place to make adjustments for any dramatic spike in fuel costs."
Consumer advocates are skeptical. Carol Biedrzycki, executive director of Texas Ratepayers Organization to Save Energy, said the state should have required electricity providers to maintain a "reserve margin" of electrical capacity of roughly 15 percent above demand. Ms. Biedrzycki said she believed that state officials had inflated power-generating capacity and could face problems of increasing demand in a few years. 
"In order to keep the prices stable, we have to have a reserve margin," she said.
The Texas Public Utility Commission has been in the spotlight recently because of questions of whether its chairman, Max Yzaguirre, a former Enron executive appointed by Gov. Rick Perry, misrepresented his connections to the company on state disclosure forms. Last month, as Enron was in the midst of bankruptcy and laying off more than 4,000 employees, Mr. Yzaguirre revised his disclosure forms to expand the list of Enron-related companies to which he had been connected. 
Initially, he had listed his position with Enron's affiliate in Mexico. But his revised listing showed his membership on the board of the Enron North America Corporation and other related companies. Mr. Yzaguirre has attributed the omission to a simple oversight, but a spokesman for a leading Democratic candidate for governor, Tony Sanchez, questioned whether Mr. Yzaguirre had a conflict of interest. One of the new retailers seeking to enter the market, the New Power Company, is partly owned by Enron.
Meanwhile, Mr. Hadley, the spokesman for the commission, said Enron's bankruptcy should not have an impact on deregulation in Texas. Some commercial customers had signed up with two Enron-related electricity retailers, he said, but state regulators are making certain that those customers can be switched to other providers.

HEADLINE: Redmond Journal; 
Microsoft's Hometown Sees Cause for Optimism

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Tina Terada-Santos and Jerry Santos have plenty of reasons to be glad to work at the Microsoft Corporation, chief among them that it was on their very first day of orientation -- Sept. 5, 2000 -- that they met, and fell in love. They were married 11 months later. 
 While the software behemoth's campus here was the setting for their own love story, it is also proving to be a good place for them to hold employment in this turbulent economy. Microsoft's stock was the best performer in 2001 among the 30 companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, rising 53 percent to $66.25, after a dismal year in 2000 in which it lost more than 60 percent of its value. The company has huge amounts of cash on hand, new products like the Xbox game system and the Windows XP operating system are selling well, and the company appears to be on the verge of settling a major part of its antitrust battle with the federal government and several states. 
 "Microsoft just feels like the best place to be, more so than ever before," said Ms. Terada-Santos, 35, a program manager in the company's customer and partner loyalty group. 
There are certainly elements of optimism here in Microsoft's hometown, and several company employees who say they might once have been tempted to leave for a high-tech start-up said they were grateful to hold what appeared to be very steady employment with the industry giant, even if it no longer seemed to be minting multimillionaires by the month. The rebound in stock prices helped Microsoft employees, many of whom receive stock as an major part of their compensation.
But there is hardly any widespread sense of jubilation, not with the regional economy still mired in difficulties, or with Boeing undergoing major layoffs and many Internet companies struggling, or with Washington State facing one of the highest unemployment rates in the nation. And even the Santoses are taking "a very cautious approach" to their personal finances, said Mr. Santos, 32, a technical writer in the company's "dot-net" division, which is part of its strategy to shift much of its software from packaged products to services available over the Internet. 
The couple are putting off a renovation to the house they moved into after their wedding, and delaying buying a new car. "We're not fearful of losing our jobs, but we just don't want to take any big chances with our finances," Ms. Terada-Santos said. Microsoft has not experienced widespread layoffs. 
For others in the high-tech industry, the broader question was whether any rising tide at Microsoft might lift other boats. Some felt it would. 
"As Microsoft gets better, the market will get better," said Jeff Grant, 27, a Web site administrator here who has been a contract employee at several local companies over the last five years, who is to be laid off from his job next month. Despite the prospect of becoming a human figure in the unemployment statistics here, Mr. Grant was optimistic that he could find another job. 
"Once Microsoft stock went bad, a lot of other companies seemed to go down too," Mr. Grant said. "But I think it would follow that if Microsoft is headed up, eventually the whole tech sector will rise up." 
Sam Iredale, 29, a software test engineer, said he also saw reasons for optimism, after a time in which investors grew skittish over investing in the high-tech economy. "I think things went to different extremes," he said. "For a while, it seems they'd put money into just about anything that was a dot-com. They didn't discriminate. A lot of things were clearly overvalued. But now a lot of companies are clearly undervalued, and I think that investors are figuring out that not every tech company is out here on a wing and a prayer, so things are looking up." 
But others who are not facing immediate layoffs said they were having a hard time detecting any major positive shifts in the economy. 
"It's simply very tough," said Mike Nuccio, 41, a sales manager based in Redmond for Isomedia, which provides a range of Internet services. 
Mr. Nuccio sells some compact-disk products, and he said his company faced constant pressure from customers to cut prices. His lament was similar to that of Fran Traxler, the assistant manager at Diva Decor, a store here that sells home-decoration products. 
"If you don't have a sign out front saying you're having a big sale, then forget it," Ms. Traxler said. "People are really looking for bargains, and they're not doing a lot of huge home-renovation projects anyway."
Ms. Traxler said that she was already seeing the effects of the Boeing layoffs -- which are expected to claim 20,000 jobs or more in the Seattle area -- and that if there was any upturn at Microsoft, it was not offsetting the other bad economic news in any obvious way. "I do have a fair number of people who come in the store and look around," she said, "but then they come up to the counter and say, ah, I just lost my job. Are you taking applications?"

HEADLINE: Airlines Shy Away From Loan Guarantees by U.S. 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
The nation's airlines, which pleaded for a federal bailout package to help them survive the impact of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, are shying away for now from applying for government loan guarantees after seeing the stringent requirements placed on the first recipient, America West Airlines,
 Yesterday, Northwest Airlines said it would not submit an application soon to the federal Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which on Friday gave tentative approval to America West's application after exacting an option to buy up to one-third of the carrier's equity. 
 Executives said that Northwest had been gathering the data it would have needed to apply for a loan guarantee, but given the America West package, the airline has slowed its efforts. "We are still in the studying mode," said Bill Mellon, a Northwest spokesman. 
US Airways, which has frequently been mentioned as a likely candidate for a bailout because of its financial woes, said on Monday that it had no plans to file an application for loan guarantees. 
Other carriers declined to comment on their plans, but some industry analysts said executives were reacting uncomfortably to the America West package.
"Most airlines are looking at this as a rough guide, and they don't like what they saw," said Raymond Neidl, aviation analyst with ABN Amro in New York.
America West, the nation's eighth-largest carrier, faced a likely Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing if it failed to secure new financing. The airline, which is based in Phoenix, amended its proposal three times before winning provisional approval. Besides offering the government a big ownership stake, America West said it would cancel raises and bonuses for employees and agreed to hold down labor costs until the deal ends in 2007. 
Investors, like America West executives, welcomed the deal. America West shares have climbed 59 percent since it was announced, closing yesterday at $3.93 each.
Mr. Neidl said many carriers were concluding that they might be better off seeking conventional financing -- even at higher rates than they could obtain with a government-backed loan -- rather than submit to the government board's terms. 
Some may prefer to see whether economic conditions deteriorate during the first quarter, traditionally the weakest for the industry, which might strengthen their case, he added. Or else airlines may wait to see whether a widely predicted recovery arrives in the second quarter, meaning they could skirt the need for government-guaranteed loans.
"People are not going to go down that road until absolutely necessary," said Kevin C. Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporations and business travelers. Even if impatient shareholders ultimately demand that a company apply for help, as may happen with US Airways, Mr. Mitchell said many carriers were fearful about the prospect of a government rejection. 
"You don't want to do this unless you are on the rocks," he said.
Airlines have until June 28 to apply for the loan guarantees, part of a $15 billion emergency assistance package approved by Congress in September. The package included $5 billion in cash payments to make airlines whole for their losses when the air travel system was shut down after the terror attacks, and up to $10 billion in guaranteed loans.
Betsy Holahan, a spokeswoman for the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, said the package for America West was still being completed and that an "active dialogue" continued between the government and the airline. Each application received, she added, will be considered on an individual basis.
So far, only one other carrier, Vanguard Airlines, a low-fare airline based in Kansas City, Mo., has sought assistance, applying for a loan guarantee package of $60 million. 
Analysts said the Vanguard case could provide a further window into the government's thinking on the guarantees. The board could view Vanguard, which serves 15 cities, as too small to warrant help, deciding instead to reserve the remainder of the package to help major carriers.
Among the companies monitoring the board's response to Vanguard's application is the Mesa Air Group, which is based in Phoenix. Jonathan C. Orenstein, the airline's chief executive, said it might seek a loan guarantee, even though it was financially sound.
"We don't need the money, but in this day and age, more cash is better than less cash," said Mr. Orenstein, whose company operates commuter flights under the America West and US Airways brands and flies as Mesa Airlines in New Mexico and Colorado.
Mr. Orenstein said that he was not bothered by the possibility that the government could end up owning a chunk of his company. "The government's playing an activist role in a sick but essential industry is not necessarily a bad thing," he said.

HEADLINE: Gains in Chip Industry Fuel Hope in Korea 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

 BODY:
As many industrialized nations wonder how low the global economic slump will take them, there are signs emerging that South Korea may have found the bottom and turned up again.
 The chip business, a fountain of gloom last year, is a source of hope now. Hynix Semiconductor, the world's No. 3 maker of commodity dynamic random access memory chips, known as DRAM's, said yesterday that it had raised prices about 30 percent, its third increase in a month. 
 There were also indications that Hynix, deep in debt and struggling to revamp, is making progress in talks to sell some operations to an American rival, Micron Technologies, the No. 2 DRAM maker, to raise cash.
The leader in the field, Samsung Electronics, also reported that prices were heading higher, and analysts said Micron and a major German manufacturer, Infineon Technologies, could expect better terms in new sales contracts with customers.
Analysts said the fact that Hynix no longer had to cut its prices to win orders was a sign that consumer demand was firming for the computers and electronic goods that use the chips.
Chip makers had a terrible year in 2001, with DRAM prices falling more than half. Most DRAM chips are sold on contracts, but some trade in a spot market, where prices rose about 8 percent on Monday.
The positive signs touched off a sharp rally in the stock market on the first trading day of the new year. The Korean stock price index jumped 4.5 percent, to close at 724.95, with Hynix hitting the daily limit of a 15 percent gain and Samsung gaining 10 percent. 
Weak prices for semiconductors and other electronic products, South Korea's largest exports, left the country about 5 percent short of its goal of a $10 billion trade surplus for 2001, the commerce ministry announced on Tuesday.
The first decline in motor vehicle exports since the war in the Persian Gulf was also a factor -- South Korea shipped 1,783,486 vehicles last year, down 9.5 percent from 2000. But in that industry, too, the mood has recently turned optimistic, as General Motors completes negotiations to take over the bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company.

HEADLINE: Who Are You, Mr. Mayor? 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
We're dealing with a little culture shock here. The new mayor of New York has $4 billion, a Boston accent and a bizarre sense of whom to root for -- he's a Red Sox fan. I have no choice but to worry about him. He can't possibly know what he's in for.
 When it comes to terrorism, we'll all be united. That's not the problem. It's the madness within this great and wild city that will most likely get to Michael Bloomberg. This ain't Boston. New York is as hard as granite, and as unforgiving. 
 On a typical day the new mayor will have to do battle with belligerent municipal labor leaders whose members got the back of the hand instead of well-deserved raises from Rudy Giuliani. (Mr. Giuliani has just exited the stage to standing ovations, and is currently being fitted for a halo.) Then he can submit to the impertinent questioning of the City Hall reporters and know-it-all columnists who follow all mayors with the same sense of good will that is generally displayed by sharks trailing a wounded whale. The rest of the day can be taken up with, say, the ravings of Al Sharpton and a mass demonstration or two.
Welcome to New York. If he's tough and sane, Mike Bloomberg might manage to succeed. But it's absolutely fair to wonder about the sanity of a man with $4 billion who voluntarily subjects himself to the routine torments inflicted on the mayor of New York.
The groaning got under way almost immediately. Mr. Bloomberg delivered his inaugural address Tuesday in freezing temperatures on the steps of City Hall. The backdrop was an enormous American flag (think "Patton"). The crowd was numb from the cold, and Mr. Bloomberg's oration was not warming anybody up. If the new mayor was hoping his listeners would rally to his theme of shared sacrifice, he was disappointed. When he promised to reduce staffing in the mayor's office by 20 percent, and challenged other elected officials to do the same, the reaction of a large segment of the audience could best be described as a collective rolling of the eyes.
A number of elected officials would later complain, quietly, that the mayor's call for 20 percent cuts was unrealistic.
The sense I get after just two days of the Bloomberg era is that there are an awful lot of people in this town who are anxious to take the measure of the new mayor, and they've been emboldened by the fact that his public personality is not dynamic and his inaugural speech was not a particularly good one.
I suggest they proceed with caution. For one thing, New York has not recovered from the physical and psychological trauma of Sept. 11. The economy has not yet rebounded, and there are staggering budget deficits to overcome. The mayor is absolutely right about the need for cooperation and shared sacrifice.
Second, an awful lot of people (this reporter among them) underestimated Michael Bloomberg during his run for mayor. It might not be a bad idea to put the latest round of quick judgments on hold until a fuller picture of the man as mayor emerges. 
Third, he's done some good things during the transition and in the first several hours of his mayoralty. Mr. Bloomberg has been relentlessly optimistic about the city's prospects (Mr. Giuliani was, too) and that is crucial in times of fear and uncertainty. And he's shown a willingness to listen. He's been open, welcoming even, to the enormous variety of voices that make up the city. That is a blessed contrast to the hostile, chronically confrontational style of his predecessor. 
Perhaps most important, Mr. Bloomberg seems committed to Mr. Giuliani's signature issue, the fight against crime -- an indication that the new mayor recognizes that public safety is the essential cornerstone of a flourishing city.
Beyond this we don't know much. Mr. Bloomberg says he's against raising taxes and he favors mayoral control of the school system. But we don't know how he plans to balance the budget, or how he would improve the schools. The details are still to come. 
So we'll wait and see.
Thomas Kessner opened his biography of Fiorello La Guardia with a quote from Turgenev's "Fathers and Sons":
"What aim do you wish to achieve, where are you going, what is in your soul? In a word, who are you? What are you?"
New Yorkers are asking the same of their new mayor.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
What a City. A Capital Of Contrasts.

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
YOU'VE got to love New York. You do, you really do, and if you are tempted otherwise, revisit the inauguration of Michael R. Bloomberg, watch it through the prism of what it was, the most instructive exercise in the improbable since a sitting first lady from Chicago by way of Little Rock became the junior senator from the Empire State.
 It began when Al Leiter, the Mets pitcher, explained that he was officiating at the ceremony in front of longtime Yankees-mad City Hall because Mr. Bloomberg had made it clear "he's willing to reach out to constituencies that may feel they've been ignored." 
 Bette Midler sang a romantic version of the national anthem, valiantly staying on key despite a sour piano that would not. Four members of the clergy delivered invocations, including -- this in a city still recovering from an attack by Muslim terrorists -- Imam Izak-El Mu'eed Pasha. He followed the rabbi. Cardinal Edward M. Egan gave the benediction, partly in Spanish.
All blessed the city, Mr. Bloomberg, Rudolph W. Giuliani and, implicitly, the new social arrangements on ample display right there in front of City Hall.
To the right of the lectern sat Mr. Bloomberg; his daughters, Emma and Georgina; his mother, Charlotte; his former wife, Susan Brown; and, a few seats away, his friend, Diana Taylor, chief financial officer of the Long Island Power Authority.
Stage left featured current and former officials, and a beaming Judith Nathan sitting next to Mr. Giuliani, who devoted considerable effort in the last eight years trying to be an arbiter of taste and morality. Funny thing is, he may have succeeded, not in punishing wayward museums or closing sex shops, but in making people more tolerant or forcing them to recognize that they already were. It was just a few decades ago, remember, that Nelson A. Rockefeller's divorce thwarted his national political ambitions.
Just a few decades ago, too, it might have seemed unusual for the new mayor to take the oath of office from a woman, the first to head the state's highest court, Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye. Or for a normally gregarious Victor Gotbaum to hold the Bible silently and smile as his wife, Betsy Gotbaum, became public advocate. Or for retired appellate court judge William C. Thompson, father of the first black city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., to note that "for Mrs. Charlotte Bloomberg and myself, this is extreme nachas" -- Yiddish for proud pleasure or special joy, especially from a child's accomplishments. 
Talk of the improbable, consider the very election of Mr. Bloomberg, victorious in overwhelmingly Democratic New York City, with its reputation for liberalism and populism and love of public showmen like Fiorello H. La Guardia, John V. Lindsay, Edward I. Koch and Rudy Giuliani. The 108th mayor is a new Republican convert, a billionaire from Boston who spent $69 million of his own money to win office, and is to showmanship what Madonna is to subtlety.
Yet there he was on Tuesday, making his first speech as mayor that, in 14 economical minutes did more to define him than his fortune's worth of campaign television commercials.
THE Republican mayor sent a pointed message to the Republican president, telling him he expected him to keep his "explicit pledge" to funnel $20 billion to New York City. He promised budget cuts and no tax increases, strongly reiterated his intention to reform the school system, and respectfully but insistently separated himself from his acclaimed predecessor.
Mr. Bloomberg put Mr. Giuliani's ambitious plans for new baseball stadiums on hold, saying the city should have the world's best cultural and sports facilities "when we can afford them." He said: "We cannot afford to fight with each other. We must work together." And in place of Mr. Giuliani's proudly brash pledge in his inaugural speech in 1994 -- "It should be so and it will be so" -- Mr. Bloomberg spoke of forging a "new partnership" with everyone from the president to community board members.
Then he went to the exquisitely renovated Tweed Courthouse just north of City Hall, a 19th-century tribute to greed and corruption transformed into a 21st-century palace of elegance. The new mayor patiently stood on a receiving line for hours, greeting well-wishers.
None had more enthusiastic praise for this Republican communications magnate than black Democrats, the loyal heart of their party. "Such a conciliatory speech," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem. "Just what New York needed."
As we said, you really do have to love the place.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Concern and a Departure Cloud the Lincoln Center Project 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Facing a crucial juncture prompted by its $1.2 billion redevelopment plan, Lincoln Center suffered two blows yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested that the project would have to be delayed and the center's interim executive director told other center officials she was leaving to head a new performing arts center in Philadelphia.
 In response to a reporter's query, Mr. Bloomberg -- until recently a vice chairman of Lincoln Center -- raised strong questions about the city's ability to provide the center with the $240 million it had committed to the project under a 10-year timetable agreed to by the Giuliani administration. He also predicted that the plan would have difficulty raising private funds in an economic climate that has every cultural organization steeling itself for tough times. 
 "Some of these things are just going to get postponed," Mr. Bloomberg said of the expansions planned by many of the city's cultural institutions. "We should not cancel them. We should continue with the planning. But you're not going to be able to do things as fast as we can. That's true probably for the Lincoln Center redevelopment." 
Mr. Bloomberg's statement came as Lincoln Center confronted another episode in the most extensive turnover of top-level management in its 40-year history. In the last 13 months, the center has seen the departure of two presidents -- one after only eight months on the job -- as well as the chairman of the contentious redevelopment project. Now, several officials at the arts complex said, Janice Price, the interim executive director, will leave on Feb. 1 to become president of the Kimmel Center, the new home of the Philadephia Orchestra.
And an even more important departure looms; Beverly Sills, the 72-year-old former diva who has served as chairman of the center for almost eight years, has said she will retire when a new president is in place, though how soon after is unclear. 
Ms. Sills said she was unperturbed by Mr. Bloomberg's statement and the imminent departure of Ms. Price, one of her most loyal aides. "It's a 10-year plan and it's not going to come in one business cycle," she said of the city financing. "I think we will ask to make a presentation to him and brief him and I expect him to make a reasonable decision."
Ms. Sills also said she was confident that the city would honor Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent commitment to provide the first $24 million installment pledged to the project. "I don't feel beleaguered," Ms. Sills added. "I feel very well surrounded with extremely gifted people."
A new president is expected to be named shortly. Among those being considered for the job, which has had a salary of more than a half-million dollars a year, are Anthony P. Coles, a deputy mayor under Mr. Giuliani who serves on the board of Lincoln Center's redevelopment corporation. Prior to Gordon J. Davis's short tenure, Nathan Leventhal held the job for 17 years before stepping down in December 2000.
The latest turbulence at Lincoln Center arrives when many of the world's arts centers are grappling with similar upheavals because of the economy. The specifics of the redevelopment project are far from resolved, and some people at the center view this moment as an opportunity for the institution to rethink its artistic mission to become a temple of the classics that is also in touch with contemporary culture. 
Although it has achieved unparalleled success as a purveyor of the classical performing arts through formidable constituents like the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the New York City Ballet, these critics urge more programming that can nurture experimental artists and achieve an even wider appeal.
"Lincoln Center is great -- it attracts the world's greatest performers -- but it could be infinitely greater," said Rita E. Hauser, who serves on the boards of the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center Inc., the umbrella organization that manages the complex.
Ms. Hauser suggested for example that rather than renovating Avery Fisher Hall, the Philharmonic's home, as part of the redevelopment plan, it might be better to simply "tear it down and start over." Then, she said, the hall could be replaced with not only a large auditorium but also smaller halls to present new music and build younger audiences.
Other Lincoln Center executives say the institution is good at what it does and should not try to be something it isn't. "It's what happens on the stage that matters," said Martin E. Segal, one of two chairmen emeriti at the center. "Does the place have a lot of problems? No."
If you want to see modern dance, for example, Mr. Segal suggested, go to other theaters, like the Brooklyn Academy of Music to see Mark Morris, or the Joyce Theater to see Eliot Feld. Should the Philharmonic perform more modern works even though people walk out when it does?, Mr. Segal asked rhetorically. "Who's going to pick up the tab for the deficit?" he said.
Like all fortresses of high culture, Lincoln Center must contend with the continuing challenge of how to take artistic risks and still fill seats, luring new audiences without losing traditional ones that are hard to hold on to as it is. Although the Philharmonic, for example, has often boasted of its high attendance, the orchestra fails to sell hundreds of seats at 6 of every 10 of its performances, according to figures in the project's master plan. 
Lincoln Center is a behemoth. Its 12 constituent groups employ about 8,000 workers in eight buildings with 19 performance halls that hold more than 3,000 performances a year. They have a combined operating budget of $450 million a year and attract 4.7 million visitors annually. More than 400,000 students and teachers participate in the center's educational programs.
Inevitably, arts executives acknowledge, size breeds conservatism. This becomes even more of a concern for Lincoln Center as the institution contemplates becoming larger and handsomer under its redevelopment plan, which calls for everything from new lobbies for Lincoln Center Theater to a tree-lined lawn in Damrosch Park. 
Other than the Lincoln Center Festival in the summertime, some critics say, the center generally plays it safe, paying too little attention to work that would draw minorities, less affluent groups and young people. 
The Philharmonic, for example, chose as its new conductor last year Lorin Maazel, 71, an accomplished traditionalist. The New York City Ballet, once the imaginative springboard for the legendary partnership of George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, is still championed by some reviewers, but also chastised by others for being less than adventurous under Peter Martins.
"There's not the kind of excitement and creative energy that I felt with a Balanchine," said Harvey Lichtenstein, the chairman emeritus of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which tends to present more experimental work. "It's a fairly conservative place."
Even the relatively new Jazz at Lincoln Center -- the center's boldest commitment to new programming -- has been faulted by some enthusiasts for hewing too close to tradition. As an indication of how averse Lincoln Center has been to change, a 1986 report by the center's committee on the future advised against establishing jazz as a new constituent.
"Straying too far from the classical performing arts represented by its constituents would probably be a disservice to audiences," the report said. "It is not clear that Lincoln Center has a 'comparative advantage' in offering a broader array of performing arts or more experimental art forms, and the evidence suggests that innovations in this direction have generally not won the acclaim of the core audience."
Things have changed since; most obviously, Jazz at Lincoln Center has been a constituent since 1996 and will be getting a new home in the AOL Time Warner building in Columbus Circle. The New York City Opera has made a point of presenting new works or new interpretations of older productions. 
The Film Society of Lincoln Center offers series on Spanish cinema and has presented programs of Iranian films. Richard Pena, the society's program director, recalled receiving a call from a teacher asking whether her students needed to wear ties to attend a film. "In a way, people have that image of Lincoln Center, that you have to dress up," Mr. Pena said. "That's partly why we decided to serve popcorn."
Until Bruce Gordon, president of retail markets for Verizon Communications, was appointed to its 50-member board last month, the center had only one black director, Richard D. Parsons, recently named chief executive of AOL Time Warner.
Since Sept. 11 ticket sales have been down overall about 10 percent. Complicating matters are the turf battles that almost killed the redevelopment plan and drove out its chairman, Marshall Rose. Much of the project is an effort to gain back space that was sacrificed more than 40 years ago after budget cuts ordered by the center's chairman, John D. Rockefeller III.
When ground was broken in 1959 by President Dwight D. Eisenhower on a West Side urban-renewal site envisioned by Robert Moses, it seemed inspired: clustering several stellar arts institutions in one location, creating the most powerful cultural destination in the country. And to a large extent, it worked. 
Audiences still love going to Lincoln Center to attend such offerings as the new production of Richard Strauss's "Frau Ohne Schatten" at the Met; the Haydn and Schoenberg series presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and Great Performers at Alice Tully Hall; and "Contact," the Tony Award-winning musical at Lincoln Center Theater. Aspiring dancers dream of attending the School of American Ballet, and young actors and musicians clamor to get into the Juilliard School.
In a 1984 report, Mr. Segal, then Lincoln Center's chairman, wrote, "The challenge is to make the whole even greater than the sum of its parts." Some argue, the opposite has proved true. Lincoln Center's strength, many arts professionals say, is the success achieved by its constituents operating apart from one another -- each with its own programs, administration and boards, which include more than 400 directors. "We're our own little duchies, our own independent nations," said Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater.
"That sense of independence, it seems to me, has been key to our existence," he added. "No one has ever said, 'You're doing it wrong.' "
The constituents also compete with one another for donors, audiences and, to some extent, artists. And when they meet to decide joint issues the fur can fly, most vividly over issues like the redevelopment plan, which requires unanimity among the 11 participating constituents. (Jazz at Lincoln Center and the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts are not part of the plan because they have their own new homes.)
At one point the powerful Metropolitan Opera temporarily withdrew from the project, and the New York City Opera is likely to leave Lincoln Center altogether.
Documents obtained by The New York Times detailing the vote tallies on various proposals show the extent of the dissension. The New York City Ballet voted yes for a new entrance to Avery Fisher Hall on Columbus Avenue, but only if it were redesigned. The New York Philharmonic said yes to a smaller pool to surround the Henry Moore statue but only as a possibility. Out of 33 proposals, the Metropolitan Opera said no to 13. (The constituent group that registered the next highest amount of outright objections was the New York City Ballet with three.) 
All of which, some say, points to a leadership vacuum. The center, this argument goes, needs a force like a Moses or a Rockefeller to yank the constituents in line. "There is no central overall final control, that's the problem," Ms. Hauser said. "It's a governance issue."
But many constituents think otherwise. "Lincoln Center depends on the constituents more than the constituents depend on Lincoln Center," said Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. 
The bulk of the fund-raising, among other duties, has fallen to Ms. Sills, in part because she is so good at it. As a result, while she might like to be phasing out her role at the center right now -- and several news reports have speculated about her imminent departure -- Ms. Sills said she cannot imagine stepping down anytime soon. "I don't see myself being able to leave before June," she said. "At the moment I am doing both jobs which is a killer. I've never stayed too long at a job and eventually I will retire." 
Mr. Segal suggested that raising money privately would not be so difficult, given that foundations have more money now than they did five years ago. "It's daunting till you imagine the realities of it," he said. "Then it's not daunting at all."
High-profile flare-ups notwithstanding, constituents say day-to-day life at the center is not the soap opera it may seem. "I don't get the sense that we're all walking around at sword's point -- quite the contrary," said Joanne Koch, executive vice president of the Film Society.
To some degree, constituents say, there is safety and strength in their numbers. "Certain benefits have accrued just by being shoulder to shoulder," said Mr. Gersten of Lincoln Center Theater, "even though we don't interact a lot."
And, he added, one cannot discount the unmistakable magic of curtain time. "At 7:30, each night, with people streaming into the plaza," Mr. Gersten said, "there is the sense that the assemblage of those forces in pursuit of the different disciplines is part of the New York experience."
