HEADLINE: Mining Company Is Given Protection 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
A mining company in South Dakota has tapped a rich vein of influence on Capitol Hill, turning to the Senate Democratic leader to obtain valuable help for a project in his state.
 With little debate, lawmakers agreed to relieve the company, Homestake Mining, of any legal liability that it might have for damage done to the environment in digging gold from the Black Hills over the last 125 years. 
 The company, which has excellent political connections and high-powered lobbyists, had been planning to close the mine this month. Scientists said it would be a good site for an underground physics laboratory. But Homestake, now owned by Barrick Gold of Toronto, insisted that it first had to be protected against lawsuits. 
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, was the chief sponsor of the bill under which the federal government will assume liability for any environmental damage. Representative John Thune, Republican of South Dakota, also claims credit for the legislation. President Bush has recruited Mr. Thune to run against South Dakota's other senator, Tim Johnson, a Democrat, as part of the Republicans' effort to regain control of the Senate.
The Homestake legislation was one of the "miscellaneous provisions" tacked onto the 2002 appropriations bill for the Defense Department. The House and the Senate approved the bill on Dec. 20, hours before adjourning for the year, and Mr. Bush is widely expected to sign it in a few days.
Mr. Daschle said the lab would be an economic boon to the small town of Lead (pronounced leed) and would create opportunities for scientific research on subatomic particles known as neutrinos that could yield insights into the nature of matter and the evolution of the universe.
Critics call the bill a sweetheart deal for the company and the state. Environmental groups and some members of Congress have expressed concern about the precedent that would be set if the government took over the liability. 
Supporters of the science project said they needed three types of assistance from the government, federal assumption of liability, $281 million to convert the mine to a lab and several hundred million dollars to operate the lab.
Scientists and federal officials said the total cost to the government over 10 years could reach $500 million to $1 billion. That includes the cost of buying a neutrino detector and other equipment and conducting experiments. A spokesman for Mr. Daschle, Jay Carson, said the cost of the bill covering liability protection had been estimated at $50 million.
Officials at the National Science Foundation said they were apprehensive that, under the legislation, they might also have to contribute to the cost of cleaning up the site.
Mr. Carson said the senator rejected the criticism. "The legislation assures that the public interest will be protected," Mr. Carson said. "The project is contingent on grants from the National Science Foundation. An independent entity would inspect the site, and the Environmental Protection Agency can veto the project if it would endanger public health or the environment."
Homestake says the mine has been in operation since 1876, 13 years before South Dakota became a state. The company describes it as the world's oldest continuously operated gold mine. 
The chairman of Homestake, Jack E. Thompson, said 1,250 tons of gold had been extracted since the company was formed by George Hearst, father of William Randolph Hearst, and his partners.
Scientists said the Homestake mine, 8,000 feet underground, would be valuable for research because it was shielded from cosmic rays and other radiation that interfere with experiments. About 200 people would work at the lab.
In recommending construction of a lab, John Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., said it could become "a gold mine for science discoveries about physics, astronomy, biology and geology."
But Representative Sherwood Boehlert, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House Science Committee, said the legislation was "a sweetheart deal for the Canadian company that owns Homestake and for the state of South Dakota." 
"This bill," Mr. Boehlert said, "could saddle taxpayers with costly and unprecedented environmental responsibilities. The federal government will be financially responsible for activities it did not undertake at a piece of property it does not control."
Jay Tutchton, a lawyer in the Denver office of Earthjustice, a law firm that specializes in the environment, said: "The legislation is a huge gift to Homestake. It makes some sense as a local economic stimulus. But there are probably cheaper ways to stimulate the local economy."
Mr. Tutchton estimated that "Homestake is getting off the hook for $30 million to $40 million of potential liability, based on the experience of adjacent mines that were closed and became Superfund sites." 
The mine tunnels, he said, can leak highly acidic water harmful to human health and to fish and other aquatic life. The mine includes two deep shafts, more than 500 miles of underground tunnels and machinery above ground that operates elevators that carry workers into the mine and remove the ore.
Under the Superfund law, owners and operators of mines and toxic dumps can be held liable for the costs of cleaning up the properties long after they have been sold or shut.
Daschle aides insisted that federal officials would have control over the project and could block it if environmental damage was found to be too extensive.
Patton Boggs, a law firm here, lobbied for the legislation on behalf of Homestake. Peter D. Robertson, a partner at the firm who was chief of staff at the Environmental Protection Agency under President Bill Clinton, said, "Our firm drafted the first several versions of the legislation."
Under the bill passed by Congress, the government will "assume any and all liability relating to the mine and laboratory, including liability for damages, reclamation, the costs of response to any hazardous substance" and closing the mine.
The bill says Homestake will not be liable to any person or to the government for "damages to natural resources or the environment" arising from use of the mine or the lab, regardless of when the damages occurred or were found. 
Under the bill, the government promises to defend and indemnify, or reimburse, Homestake for any liability. But the government waives its sovereign immunity so that it could be sued by Homestake or the State of South Dakota.
Mr. Thompson said the company was not fully satisfied and might ask Congress for even greater protection against suits.
Democrats have generally opposed legislation to limit the damages that consumers can recover in civil suits. Dick Armey, the House Republican leader, said he found it paradoxical that Mr. Daschle had opposed limits on suits by future victims of terrorism but now supported such limits when they would help Homestake.
"You have Senator Daschle feigning moral outrage over limitations on liability in antiterrorism insurance," Mr. Armey said. "Yet he comes right back on behalf of a special interest in his own state and says, 'I want liability limitations.' "
A spokesman for the foundation, Curt Suplee, said many other projects, reviewed and approved by the agency, had been waiting for years to receive their funds. Scientists working on those projects would be puzzled if the Homestake project "jumped ahead" of them, Mr. Suplee said.

HEADLINE: Doubts Raised On Abolishing School Board 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
Just a day after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proclaimed mayoral control of the New York City school system an important goal of his fledgling administration, a high-ranking Democratic legislator said yesterday that the State Assembly would almost certainly not allow the abolition of the Board of Education.
 The warning by Steven Sanders, the Manhattan Democrat who heads the Assembly Education Committee, was a sign that political reality may quickly set in for Mr. Bloomberg, a novice politician who cited in his inaugural address the need to "set aside partisan differences" and not "fight with each other." 
 Rudolph W. Giuliani lobbied for mayoral control of the school system throughout his eight-year tenure in City Hall. But the Democratic-controlled Assembly, with whom he had a rocky relationship, ignored his pleas. Last week, Mr. Giuliani said his failure to bring about the change was his only regret as mayor. 
In an interview, Mr. Sanders said that abolishing the seven-member board and giving City Hall complete control over education policy would stifle public input. Although he did not say as much, getting rid of the board would also weaken the influence of state and local lawmakers, who lobby the seven board members to support projects or expenses that benefit their constituents.
Mr. Sanders is serving on a panel appointed by Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly speaker, to study the issue of mayoral control, and he is a close ally of Mr. Silver. While the panel has met only once, Mr. Sanders said yesterday that abolishing the Board of Education would probably not be among its recommendations. The Legislature, with the governor, has to approve any changes in the structure of school systems.
"It would be highly unlikely that at the end of the day," Mr. Sanders said, "there would be a recommendation embraced either by the task force or by the members of the Assembly that would entail abolition of the school board."
During his campaign, Mr. Bloomberg called for abolishing the board and letting the mayor appoint the schools chancellor, who would report directly to City Hall. He was less specific in his inaugural address, saying only, "The public through the mayor must control the school system."
Yesterday, however, Mr. Bloomberg's press secretary, Edward Skyler, said he still believed that abolishing the board was the best way to make that happen. But Mr. Skyler added: "He is looking forward to working with New York's elected officials, such as Assemblyman Sanders and Speaker Silver, to improve the quality of education for the children of New York City."
The mayor could, in fact, have increased power over education policy even if the Board of Education continued to exist. One possibility, proposed by the city teachers' union, would expand the board but allow the mayor to appoint most of the members. Currently, the mayor appoints two members and the borough presidents choose the other five.
But Mr. Silver, whose support will be crucial for any school management changes, said yesterday that an expanded board, most of whose members were appointed by the mayor, would only allow the mayor to continue shrugging off responsibility for the school system's failings. At the same time, Mr. Silver stressed that he would keep an open mind while the panel examined various proposals. "I'm not prepared to make a statement until we have had a full examination," Mr. Silver said.
Another idea under discussion, Mr. Silver said, is to give the Board of Education independent taxing authority, so that it will not be financially dependent on City Hall and Albany. But other panel members said they doubted that proposal would fly, because of the precarious economy.
The issue of mayoral control is gaining attention at a crucial time for the school system: the contract of Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy expires in July, as do the terms of all seven board members. If the Legislature acted in the next few months, it could significantly affect the immediate future of the school system.
Mr. Sanders said yesterday that the panel would meet at least three more times and perhaps submit recommendations to the Legislature by the end of February. Spokesmen for Gov. George E. Pataki and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said yesterday that they fully supported mayoral control and were merely waiting for the Assembly to come around. Both men are Republicans, like Mr. Bloomberg.
"The only problem in Albany has been with the Assembly and the speaker," said John McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Bruno.
In addition to Mr. Sanders and Mr. Silver, the panel studying school management includes Roger L. Green, Audrey I. Pheffer, Peter M. Rivera and John W. Lavelle, all Democratic Assembly members from New York City. It also includes Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union; Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who was a deputy mayor in the Dinkins administration; and Dennis Walcott, who stepped down as president of the New York Urban League to become Mr. Bloomberg's deputy mayor for policy.
The panel also includes several business leaders, including Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the New York City Partnership, which has long advocated abolishing the Board of Education. Ms. Wylde said yesterday that the panel's task was far more complex than deciding whether or not to give the mayor control of the schools. The members are discussing a number of questions, she said, including who should control collective bargaining and budgetary decisions and how parents can have more input into education policy. She pointed out that while Mr. Sanders said abolishing the board was unlikely, he had not ruled it out entirely.
"I think people's positions are not hardened at this point," Ms. Wylde said. "We are in a honeymoon era for Mayor Bloomberg, and I think the fact that he raised this issue in his inaugural message is going to make everybody rethink their position to try to give him the benefit of the doubt."
At the same time, Mr. Sanders said he believed that Mr. Bloomberg, unlike his predecessor, might be willing to compromise and allow a management change that was not as extreme as abolishing the board.
"My sense is that he would rather take a half a loaf or three-quarters of a loaf," Mr. Sanders said, "than to have no change at all and simply maintain a position on an issue that can probably never be changed."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 4676 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "AMERICAN RADIANCE: THE RALPH ESMERIAN GIFT" AND "DARGER: THE HENRY DARGER COLLECTION," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through June 2 and June 23, respectively). This 40-year-old museum finally has a home of its own and is celebrating its new quarters by showcasing two important recent gifts. The 400 objects of traditional folk art from Ralph Esmerian include extraordinary caches of portraits and needlework as well as walking sticks, painted furniture, frakturs, ceramics and weather vanes. Rife with acknowledged masterpieces, they raise the museum's collection to a new level while giving folk art itself a new visibility on the city's artscape. The Henry Darger gift, which includes 27 large two-sided watercolors and seven bound volumes by this Chicago recluse, counters the comforts of traditional folk art with a strong dose of the outsider variety, art made for an insatiable community of one. Reflecting the expanding folk art field, the shows symbolize where the museum comes from and where it is going. Together they indicate that it intends to leave nothing behind. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5, students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "BRAZIL: BODY AND SOUL," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 27). The rotunda is black and half filled by an immense altar. The French architect Jean Nouvel's installation is aptly over the top, considering that the show is about a culture gloriously, self-consciously excessive. A sampler of Brazilian culture, the show divides attention between the Baroque and the modern. Physicality, spectacle, eroticism and pleasure: the cliches of Brazilian culture are all leitmotifs in stunning objects mixing indigenous, African and European roots. These include the works of genius eccentrics like Aleijadinho, Brazil's Bernini, and Arthur Bispo do Rosario, a seaman, boxer, doorman, bodyguard, jailbird and mental patient who died in 1989 at 78. He sewed banners out of bedsheets and embroidered them with long incantatory lists of places and people, including a presentation mantle he made for himself to wear before God on Judgment Day. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $12, students over 12 and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"TELLING TALES II: RELIGIOUS IMAGES IN 19TH-CENTURY ACADEMIC ART," Dahesh Museum of Art, 601 Fifth Avenue, near 48th Street, (212) 759-0606 (through Jan. 26). The iconoclastic French Revolution posed a challenge to religious art, one that was robustly met by French academic artists, this show is out to demonstrate. But the work, which spans the times of social change and upheaval from the restoration of the French monarchy in 1814 until the end of the century, is a far cry from the old masters whose glories it attempted to emulate. Still, as a bible of French academic styles, the show is worth a walk-through. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Grace Glueck).

* "ETERNAL EGYPT: MASTERWORKS OF ANCIENT ART FROM THE BRITISH MUSEUM," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 24). An extensive renovation at the British Museum makes possible an American tour for works from its legendary Egyptian collection, many allowed out of the building for the first time. Included are treasures that are almost always on display in London, like one of the museum's proud red granite lions from the 18th dynasty. Other high points include the great Buddha-like stone carving of Amenhotep III and seven papyruses from the Book of the Dead. Presented in fairly strict chronology, the works trace Egyptian art along its entire 3,000-year trajectory from the Old Kingdom to the Roman conquest in 30 B.C. The goal is to show that the art was not tied to Old Kingdom precedents but subject to stylistic development, formal innovation and changes in emotional tenor. With the superb quality of the British works and the august proportions of Brooklyn's galleries, the demonstration proceeds with exceptional beauty and clarity. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "NEW WORLDS: GERMAN AND AUSTRIAN ART, 1890-1940," Neue Galerie New York, Museum for German and Austrian Art, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Feb. 18). This superb addition to the Museum Mile, ensconced in an impeccably renovated mansion, brings some welcome balance to a city in which European modernism usually has a French accent. The opening show's survey of art and design from the Viennese Secession to the Bauhaus includes six paintings by Gustav Klimt, a wall of watercolors and gouaches by Egon Schiele and a room ablaze with the undiluted colors of German Expressionist paintings. Unusually fine, often rare examples of furniture, silver, jewelry and tableware by Otto Wagner, Josef Hoffmann, Wilhelm Wagenfeld and Mies van der Rohe are installed with particular sensitivity. The building's interior has been altered and sometimes merely tweaked to complement its new mission, most spectacularly the echt Viennese coffeehouse. It is all just about perfect. Hours: Fridays, Saturdays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 65+; under 12 not admitted (Smith).

* "OVER THE LINE: THE ART AND LIFE OF JACOB LAWRENCE," Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 3). Lawrence was a modernist artist, an American artist and an African-American artist, and all three aspects of his career are discernible in this retrospective. The complete "Migration of the Negro" is here, and its 60 paintings -- small enough together to fit in a suitcase -- are the centerpiece. Later art touches on political traumas and personal crises, but at the end come samples of the optimistic "Builder" series that he worked on for 30 years. With their images of skyscrapers going up and of men and women, black and white, working away side by side, they are just the thing for New York City right now. (A recently unveiled mosaic by Lawrence is on view in the Times Square subway station. A complete set of silk-screen prints of his "John Brown Series" is at the Queens Museum of Art through Jan. 27.) Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

"RUSSEL WRIGHT: CREATING AMERICAN LIFESTYLE," Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through March 10). Remembered today largely for his tableware, Russel Wright (1906-74) was the most popular designer in the nation in the mid-20th century. China, furniture, fabrics, glass and giftware were his province, cleverly marketed by him and his wife, Mary. They advanced the cause of a modern, simplified American design that deeply influenced middle-class taste. The centerpiece of the show, a combination of brilliant utility and high-gloss kitsch, is a 40-foot-long table with many of Wright's ceramic lines orchestrated along its length. In smaller rooms are installations of his other creations: aluminum and wood pieces, furniture, fabrics and glassware along with a multimedia presentation of his architectural masterpiece, the stone, wood and glass house he designed for his 80-acre estate at Garrison, N.Y. This show should be on the to-see list of anyone interested in the creation and marketing of American manufactured design. Wright himself might not have found inappropriate its accompaniment of twittering tapes of cocktail party noises. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $3, students and 62+ (Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

HELEN FRANKENTHALER, "Lighthouse Series," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Jan. 12). Ms. Frankenthaler seems to be channeling the spirit of Turner in her washy, medium-size acrylic-on-paper works. In colors from incandescent red to foggy gray, this legendary Color Field painter created pictures that hover between luminous seascape and pure abstraction. Some works give way to free painterly gesturalism; most hew to a horizontal order. All are more decorous than adventurous (Ken Johnson).

* "INHERITING CUBISM," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000 (through Jan. 12). Cubism inspired interesting efforts by American painters, as this fine selection of about 40 American paintings from 1909 to 1936 demonstrates. The show is studded with gems, including a tiny, hyperactive watercolor of New York Harbor by John Marin, a townscape glowing red and green like a stained-glass window by Oscar Bleumner, a riff on sailboats by Charles Demuth that is like shattered glass and a small, angular, vigorously painted and richly colored still life by Arshile Gorky (Johnson).

* ROY LICHTENSTEIN, "Brush Strokes, Four Decades," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400 (through Jan. 12). Lichtenstein's touch in his early Pop days has come to look not anonymous and machine-manufactured but particular, quirky, even strangely vulnerable, which is to say human, with its imperfect, slightly vulgar handmade imitations of mechanically reproduced objects, advertisements and other cheap commercial images. Here his "brush stroke" paintings, most from the 1980's and 90's, are freeze-dried versions of the Abstract Expressionist cliche, the hot-blooded brush stroke. They have a snap, crackle and pop that goes far beyond the one-line joke. Some of these multilayered pictures come as close as Lichtenstein ever did to letting it all hang out (Kimmelman).

BARBARA TAKENAGA, Graham, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Jan. 12). Ms. Takenaga's compact, densely patterned paintings are optically riveting and transcendentally suggestive. Working on wood panels with small brushes, she creates fields of extremely fine spirals and dots that tend to concentrate and become more luminous toward the center. There is a swarming, spacey feeling, as if one were traveling at the speed of light through some distant galaxy or into the depths of some inner psychic center of mystical illumination (Johnson).

HIRO YOKOSE, Winston Wachter Mayer, 39 East 78th Street, (212) 327-2526 (through Jan. 12). Mr. Yokose's misty, luminous seascapes spoof a certain style of hyperromantic quasi-19th-century romance, yet his dreamy visions of pellucid waves rolling gently onto peaceful beaches under big, Turneresque skies -- sensuously painted in waxy glazes -- are not without a genuine yearning for some Edenic never-never land (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

"HOLIDAY REALITIES," Katharina Rich Perlow, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through Jan. 29) This 25-artist grab bag of a show needs editing but has some good things in it, like one of the Chicago Imagist Roger Brown's mysterious comic-book style landscapes; an odd sort of "Peaceable Kingdom" painting by Gail Boyajian; a slightly soft-focus view of the Brooklyn Bridge by Steven Katz; an almost surrealistic still life in jewel-like colors by Jennifer Cross; and by Ellen Kozak a small painting of green water that verges on pure, sensuous abstraction (Johnson).

* NEIL WELLIVER, "Early Figurative Paintings," Alexandre, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 755-2828 (through Jan. 26). The women in Mr. Welliver's large nude-in-the-landscape paintings from the late 1960's and early 70's are powerfully sexy. Partly immersed in the waters of forest pools, they have voluptuous bodies, lovely faces and wide-eyed come-hither expressions. At the same time, the paintings focus on the optical perception of light, watery reflections and bright green foliage and on the generous, gesturally activated application of paint itself. The tension between fantasy and formalism is an exquisite tease (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

STELLA DE BOO, LiebmanMagnan, 552 West 24th Street, (212) 255-3225 (through Jan. 12). The delicately made, cartoonish paintings of this Dutch New Yorker have a quality of girlish innocence. But the imagery -- handbags, sexy shoes, bare legs, body hair and female genitalia -- evokes a grown-up layering of Freudian fears and desires (Johnson).

STEVE GIANAKOS, "Whatever Tickles Your Fancy," Fredericks Freiser, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 633-6555 (through Jan. 19). Mr. Gianakos combines wacky Pop-style comedy and erotically transgressive surrealism. In these works from the last three decades, collages that look as if they were exhumed from some moldy basement depict women with animal heads, faces floating in soup bowls and breasts, buttocks and legs from different sources, disjunctively joined. A singular nonsexual canvas from 1982 depicts three boys laughing at a big jug-eared fellow: it's called "Village Idiot" (Johnson).

ALEX HANK, "Crime," Generous Miracles, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-2858 (through Jan. 19). In his first New York solo venture, this young Mexican artist offers a Neo-Pop critique of contemporary mass media. Large canvases bear slightly blurred, photographic copies of covers of popular magazines like Vanity Fair and Vogue. On the floor a large marquee-style sign spells out "Crime" in bright lights. The message is obvious but delivered with a satisfying punch (Johnson).

SCOTT HEWICKER, "Days Without End," Rare, 435 West 14th Street, (212) 645-5591 (through Jan. 12). Mr. Hewicker, a San Franciscan, paints faux-primitive, visionary landscapes. Poured, dripped, smeared and brushed areas of paint are altered to become mountains, oceans, clouds and trees populated by tiny cats, butterflies, flowers, mushrooms and old ships. The best, like "Legend Days Are Over," have an engaging abstract complexity while exuding zany cosmic consciousness (Johnson).

"HUMANOID," Frederieke Taylor, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992 (through Jan. 19). This entertaining selection of weird and funny transformations of the human figure includes Andy Yoder's bulbous phallic knob with a braided rug surface, Ray Rapp's biomorphic video sculpture, Jerry Mischak's mysterious vertical object mummified in duct tape, a painting by Amanda Church that looks like abstracted ice cream, a funky pagan goddess painted by Nancy Rielle, Nancy Davidson's photograph of sexualized weather balloons and lovely lumpy ceramics by Charles Long (Johnson).

LARS NORGARD, DCA, 525 West 22nd Street, 212) 255-5511 (through Jan. 19). This Danish artist paints Surrealistic cartoons in loose black lines over white washes with brushy abstract underpainting. They are not much as paintings, but images like that of a big egg in trousers shot full of arrows in the seat and with a chicken's head poking out of the fly are appealingly goofy (Johnson).

KARIM NOURELDIN, "Unknown Zone," Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Jan. 19). A wrap-around abstract mural painted by a young Swiss artist has the bright, ultra-modern flare of 60's-style Color Field and hard-edged geometric painting. Playfully interacting with the architecture of the gallery, zones of pure yellow expand and contract while pink, orange and brown racing stripes break into a polygonal shape that turns corners, dives through a doorway and fills a short wall with a coolly jazzy energy (Johnson).

TIM THYZEL, "Tiled," Cynthia Broan, 423 West 14th Street, (212) 633-6525 (through Jan. 19). For a second you might think you've entered a kitchen and bath showroom. Then you notice that the forms Mr. Thyzel constructs using mostly white tiles are dysfunctionally eccentric. Elemental configurations -- cubes, stacks, altars, cruciform shapes -- have soap dishes, shower heads and chrome handles attached as purely decorative accents. It's like a collision between Brancusi and Duchamp (Johnson).

MARJORIE WELISH AND PETER DOWNSBROUGH, "Within/Without," Baumgartner, 418 West 15th Street, (212) 633-2276 (through Jan. 23). Two Euclidians toy with conventions of Modernism to dryly intellectual effect. Ms. Welish, painting within the boundaries of the traditional canvas, sets up dialogues between grid systems in primary colors and black and white. Mr. Downsbrough, a Minimalist Conceptualist, draws outside pictorial borders. Straight black lines and rectangles on the walls and floors and words like "and," "as" and "or" call attention to gestalts of architectural space (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* TACITA DEAN, "The Russian Ending," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Feb. 9). Russian movie audiences are said to prefer tragic endings, which accounts for the title of this English filmmaker's series of evocative black-and-white photogravures: richly printed, enlarged copies of old postcards depicting strangely sad or violent subjects like a derelict car, a dead whale and several kinds of explosions. The artist has added finely scripted directions as if the images were final movie scenes. Another series of found, flea-market photographs translated into color photogravures gives the touching impression of an epic family saga (Johnson).

MIA WESTERLUND ROOSEN, Lennon Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through Jan. 12). Comical and surreal, Ms. Westerlund's sprawling arrangement of big concrete tubes, serpentine lines, accumulated discs and scattered rough balls looks as if it had been made of clay by a giant child. "Fagin," a funky monument by the artist, a veteran Postminimalist, resembles an electrical fixture lifted from a mysteriously erotic dream (Johnson).

"WINTER ORCHIDARIUM," Nancy Hoffman, 429 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-6676 (through Jan. 16). Highlights of an exhibition devoted to one of the world's sexiest flowers include jewel-like, postage-stamp-size portraits of orchids by Ray Halili; expansive watercolors like Tiffany windows by Joseph Raffael; a tiny, exquisitely refined graphite drawing by Bill Richards; three-dimensional varieties made of richly colored glass by Debora Moore; iconic images painted by Michael Gregory; and postmodernist homages to the orchid paintings of Martin Johnson Heade by David Bierk (Johnson).

LYNNE YAMAMOTO, "Resplendent," P.P.O.W., 476 Broome Street, (212) 941-8642 (through Jan. 19). This young artist, born in Hawaii, presents a delicately theatrical, symbolically complex meditation on war, death and beauty. Each of nine massive, clear-glass bell jars shaped like bombs is engraved with a cherry blossom sign that once decorated a World War II Japanese war plane. On the walls, pink cut-paper cherry blossoms pinned like butterflies seem to drift down to pile up near the floor. At the center of most blossoms is the face of a Japanese soldier who was killed in the war (Johnson).

Other Galleries

CHRISTOF BUCHEL, Maccarone, 45 Canal Street, Chinatown, (212) 431-4977 (through Jan. 13). This two-story crawl-through environment is the New York debut of a young Swiss artist and inaugurates a cutting-edge way-downtown gallery. The show is extreme art in the extreme, an unrelieved sequence of small openings and tight squeezes that is as detailed as one of Kurt Schwitters's tiny collages, but more interactive. It also adds up to a kind of American road trip, including a homeless person's crib, a stunted classroom, a survivalist's lair and a messy motel room hideout where the whole thing may have been plotted. Count on getting your clothes dirty, but also on seeing what may be an art-world legend in formation (Smith).

VERNER PANTON, R 20th Century, 82 Franklin Street, TriBeCa, (212) 343-7979 (through Jan. 15). The name of this influential Danish designer may be unfamiliar, but his Op-Pop fabrics, bright foam and plastic furniture, architectonic lamps and trippy environments are part of the collective unconscious, especially the one with roots in the 1960's and 70's. The famous 1967 S-curve Panton chair, the first mass-produced seating made of single material, has pride of place (Smith).

Last Chance

"A CENTURY OF DESIGN, PART 4: 1975-2000," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). The tangle of design trends in the last quarter-century is seen in the tables, chairs, lamps, architectural projects, fabrics, dining implements, windup lantern, lemon squeezer and wristwatch that furnish this internationally minded show. Some of the work is very playful, notably a wildly confused but lovable table by the Italian designer Ettore Sottsass. From this show you could get the idea that the last quarter of the 20th century was not the weightiest era in design history. And you would not be wrong. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "ALBERTO GIACOMETTI," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Tuesday). Giacometti as the Sartre of sculpture might lead you to imagine him the right subject for troubled times. But that would be the wrong reason to see this exhibition. The right reason is that, like all perceptive and eloquent art, his tells you why it is good to be alive. It investigates the pleasure of thinking and looking long and hard, which is never as simple as it sounds. The work is more varied than you may think: sometimes black humored, playful, sensual, even devoutly tender. It includes a clunky garden sculpture, a splendid oddity, and plasters and painted bronzes that demonstrate the material virtuosity and subtle coloration of an artist too often presumed to be pretty much just dark and heavy. Spread chronologically across two floors, compressed then open, like the art they contain, the show has as its unnecessary excuse the centenary of Giacometti's birth. We don't learn much that isn't already known, but it is a thorough, serious, very elegant exhibition, and there is nothing the matter with being reacquainted from time to time with what great art looks like. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $8.50 (Kimmelman).

* "MONKS AND MERCHANTS: SILK ROAD TREASURES FROM NORTHWEST CHINA, FOURTH THROUGH SEVENTH CENTURY," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Sunday). After an extensive renovation that doubled its gallery space, the Asia Society has reopened with a new name. "Monks and Merchants," perfect in size and beautifully wrought, is the main event and explores the florescence of Chinese Buddhism with objects on loan from China itself. At a time when the eyes of the world are on Asia, this institution is indispensable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"MAN RAY IN AMERICA: "Paintings, Drawings, Sculpture and Photographs of the New York/Ridgefield (1912-21) and Hollywood (1940-50) Years," Francis M. Naumann Fine Art, 22 East 80th Street, (212) 472-6800 (through tomorrow). Regarded primarily as a photographer, Man Ray (1890-1976) craved at least equal recognition as a painter. Though born in the United States, he spent much of his life in Paris and is therefore thought of primarily as European. This ambitious show seeks to undermine assumptions of both his primacy as a photographer and his Europeanism, by playing up the paintings, drawings and watercolors (some photographs, too) that he did in the United States in his early years and during World War II, when he fled Paris for a 10-year stay in Hollywood. Some vivid landscapes that he painted in Brooklyn, where he lived with his family, and at an artists' colony in Ridgefield, N.J., are on view, along with later works made under the influence of Marcel Duchamp and Cubism. Adventurous and innovative, he worked up experimental art forms and techniques, for one thing combining ready-made objects in witty ways, like his "Sculpture by Itself I" and "Sculpture by Itself II," two mechanomorphic figures made of found machine parts, each posing a quirky question of gender. The variety of his Hollywood decade is carefully chronicled here, too, including one of his rare totally abstract paintings. Yet although the show impresses with its rich variety, Man Ray's European work, particularly his photographs, still represent him at his most outrageously original (Glueck).

* "TRADITIONAL JAPANESE DESIGN: FIVE TASTES," Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Sunday). This inspired exhibition parses nearly 150 objects of everyday use according to distinct, if not entirely separate, sensibilities; in the process it reveals the complex role that aesthetics has always played in Japan's social, economic and intellectual life. Spanning periods from the prehistoric Jomon to the late-19th-century Edo, the beautifully installed show includes tools, clothing, weapons, shop signs, sake bottles, tea bowls, a range of lacquer and much else. The simple household objects of artisans and farmers are contrasted with a more contrived simplicity of the masters of the tea ceremony. The ostentatious kimonos of noblewomen are followed by the discreetly luxurious robes of Edo merchants' wives, whose extravagances were restricted by sumptuary laws. Despite considerable diversity in craft, material and visual ideals, the exhibition is united by a profound reverence for the beauty of the natural world and the conviction that it should not be marred by manmade objects. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5 (Smith).

* "VITAL FORMS: AMERICAN ART AND DESIGN IN THE ATOMIC AGE, 1940-1960," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). The use of organic forms in the visual arts exploded after World War II, drawn from the human figure and its components along with plant, teardrop, amoeboid, cellular and molecular shapes. This ambitious display of more than 250 fine-art and design objects tracks the use of these "vital" forms in mediums from highbrow painting to popular consumer products. The organizers argue that the artists were expressing humanism and humane values at a time of worldwide cataclysm, but not enough is made of the role that Surrealism and its dream imagery played. Still, the exhibition does a good job in demonstrating that by the mid-1950's the hard-edged machine aesthetic of the prewar years had given way to a visual language centered more on natural forms, helped along by more flexible materials. There's some enlightening and enjoyable looking here, but in the show's broad coverage some of the work -- particularly the paintings -- gets a little lost. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "CANDACE WHEELER: THE ART AND ENTERPRISE OF AMERICAN DESIGN, 1875-1900," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). All but forgotten as a textile designer of sophisticated taste and a dynamic do-gooder who promoted the idea of art and design as paying careers for women, Wheeler (1827-1923) has now been rehabilitated by the Met with her first major retrospective. It includes more than 100 objects: textiles and wallpaper designed by Wheeler and her colleagues in Associated Artists, the all-woman company she started in 1883; photographs and other examples of luxurious interiors on which she collaborated in an earlier partnership with Louis Comfort Tiffany. Besides its appealing marriage of design with fine art, the show pays tribute to a real American role model of woman as entrepreneur. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A room installation with the work of the Danish designer Verner Panton, part of his show at the R 20th Century gallery in TriBeCa. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times); Carafes designed in 1946 by Russel Wright, at Cooper-Hewitt. (Anita Calero/Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum)(pg. E41)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 5; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 3189 words

HEADLINE: THE MATERIAL WORLD/Ceramics at the Met; 
Over Time And Space, The Power Of the Pot

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
GETTING to know -- really know -- the contents of a big museum like the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a process, and a pleasure, that can last a lifetime. Figuring out how to do this is part of the experience. The easiest way, of course, is to follow the museum's lead and take things as they come, which is largely according to culture, country, period and style, with Western art occupying the prime real estate. But other approaches are possible, ones that work with but also against the museum's organizational logic.
 Recently I started mulling over ways to downplay periods, styles, national borders and art history's big names and to sidestep the well-worn paths of European painting and sculpture. I was after something more basic, a kind of visual cross-referencing system. 
The idea of homing in on the physical stuff of art suggested itself and later sprang into focus during a visit to the Met's Egyptian galleries, before a large painted pottery jar from the reign of the Pharaoh Akhenaten. Originally used for wine or beer, this amazing object is decorated with abstract black-on-blue waves, red-blue checkerboard and schematic blue leaves that alternate with bands of plain red and dotted blue strawberrylike ovals. 
The jar is more than two feet tall, but to my chagrin, I couldn't recall seeing it before. I began to imagine rearranging the Met's vast holdings into big cross-cultural categories based on materials alone -- ceramics, for example, or ivory or jade. Such a radical reordering would show how different materials have moved across time and through different cultures, their possibilities expanding or contracting according to different needs and levels of sophistication.
Pots are the perfect place to start. The Met has the premier collection of ceramics in the United States and one of the best and most comprehensive in the world. It numbers just under 24,000 objects, and you can spend decades poring over its Asian, Islamic, pre-Columbian and Greek ceramics -- and lucky for us, generations of Met curators have done just that. In addition, there are countless pockets of ceramics in the museum's period rooms, the Robert Lehman Collection, the new Byzantine galleries and, of course, in the various decorative arts galleries. It soon became obvious that ceramics was too much to handle at once, and that even ceramic vessels were an unwieldy category. So I opted for pottery -- earthenware and stoneware vessels -- leaving figures, tiles and porcelains for another time.
That left plenty to deal with, from ancient storage jars and Greek kraters, through Islamic lusterware and Renaissance plates, to Art Nouveau vases and beyond. The challenge was to chart a path with a maximum of coverage and chronological accuracy and a minimum of backtracking. Ceramics have been an all-cultures, all-the-time phenomenon for thousands of years. 
The result is a partial timeline in the form of a whirlwind tour that can be taken at different speeds. You may want to try the route described here at a brisk, once-over-lightly pace to grasp its scope, and then move along the same trajectories more slowly, maybe even in segments, looking at the objects mentioned or at whatever catches your interest.
Ultimately, one benefit of a tour like this is the restorative give-and-take between concentrated looking and carefree walking; you may be surprised at how much you can see if you are looking at just one kind of thing. There's also the Venice effect: the museum can feel as crowded as the Piazza San Marco on a summer day, yet if you duck into a side street, as it were -- where ceramics often dwell -- complete quiet sometimes prevails. Finally, an important byproduct of concentrating on a single medium is, paradoxically, a more holistic understanding of the museum's multilimbed sprawl -- its layout, history and glories, as well as some of its gaps and oversights. Always an amazing place to roam, a big museum like the Met is even better when roamed with a mission.

The Fundamentals
No one really knows when it was discovered that certain kinds of earth were cohesive and capable of being molded and then baked to form portable objects suitable for cooking and for holding water. In the 1968 book "World Ceramics," the editor, Robert J. Charleston, describes the medium as "the longest-lived handicraft of which we have continuous knowledge." Bakable clay was a discovery of incalculable importance, whose applications continue to expand. (Witness the ceramic shields on certain space vehicles.) 
The continuity of the medium stems also from the slow but steady development of different clay bodies, of slips and glazes, of the potter's wheel (used by the Egyptians as early as 1500 B.C.), of stamping and molding techniques. It encompasses social habits, myths and religious beliefs, and the economies of both local industry and foreign trade, as well as the impulse to decorate and depict the world. And baked clay was also a huge step for art. Its possibilities for sculpture, drawing, painting, texture and relief may make it the most aesthetically efficient of all art forms. That pots are often round seems more than symbolic: the best are worlds unto themselves. 
In plotting my tour, I followed my eye and relied on the museum's extensive labels and helpful text. It's an empirical, formalist approach, out of favor in many quarters but based on the assumption that what engages the mind must first excite the eye. I was interested in seeing what could be seen, especially recurring decorative motifs, shapes and techniques.
Some repeat by coincidence, like the tight crosshatched grids found in different cultures, and others by influence, like the splashed and three-color glazes, called sancai, of Tang-dynasty China, which are echoed in Islamic, English and American ceramics. At the Met sancai reaches an apotheosis of outrageousness in a nearly five-foot-tall swan-footed vase, one of a pair made in 1883 by Wedgwood.

Beginning the Tour
It is best to start with a swing through the Met's Egyptian galleries. This isn't exactly a foregone conclusion: there are examples of relatively ancient pottery -- 4,000 to 6,000 years old -- at several other points in the museum, as we shall see. But it makes geographical and narrative sense. The Egyptian collections are just to the right of the museum's main entrance, in an enormous, nearly self-contained wing, and they open with a kind of ceramic overture: a long wall densely arrayed with pre-dynastic pots (4800-3200 B.C.), alive with the sense of clay's possibilities.
The display begins with the jars and bowls, made of red clay burned black around the rims, from the Badarian culture. Especially noteworthy are the crosshatched designs, including crocodiles, of the Amratians and the buff-colored slipware of the Gerzean culture, some of it decorated with spiral patterns, other pieces with goddesses standing in multi-oared barges. Below these are several pots whose mottled clays were intended to imitate stone pots, which predate ceramic ones. 
Nearly all the small study galleries in the Egyptian collection contain pots and shards worth studying. Keep an eye out for the red-and-blue jar described above in the corner of Gallery 17, and for a similar white version in the adjacent gallery (17a) from Tutankhamen's tomb. Gallery 15 holds a cluster of smaller jars with similar decorations, minus the red.

The Greek Challenge
A travel advisory: Keep in mind that the Met's galleries of Greek art amount to a museum-within-a-museum, one of several at the Met, and it can devastate your schedule. The entire history of two-dimensional art seems to have been rehearsed on the surfaces of Attic pottery between 800 and 400 B.C. Geometric form and pattern were put through their paces, and what we consider modern drawing was explored, including caricature and cartooning. Fifth- and fourth-century B.C. vase painters all but plotted one-point perspective.
After leaving the Egyptian Galleries, cross the Great Hall and take the first right just inside the Robert and Renee Belfer Court; start with a little Cycladic box in crudely textured terra cotta. Then make the exhilarating round of the west and east portions of the court, past the Minoan ceramics, where patterns based on nature -- waves, plants, nautiluses -- prevail. An especially striking Minoan three-handled vase, animated by interlocking S-curves that circle its girth like fast-moving seas, was once owned by the German archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann.
But nature soon gives way to culture. By the second corner of this gallery, in the vitrines devoted to Helladic (Mycenaean) and Geometric style ceramics, fluidly drawn images -- mostly silhouettes -- of shield-bearing warriors, chariots and horses are being marshaled into careful rows on increasingly monumental kraters. On the second loop, in the vitrines of Etruscan, Euboean, Boeotian and Corinthian pots, nature often returns, but in the form of stylized lions and oxen. 
Amid such depictions the relaxed, almost painterly blankness of the seventh- and sixth-century B.C. Lydian vases, located in the last vitrine, stands out. On a big jug (oinochoe) terra cotta shows through casually brushed-on black slip; a two-handled drinking cup (skyphos) has an interior of wavy, brushed-on patterns unlike anything else here. 

Pre-Columbian Treasures
The next stop is the western edge of the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas. There you'll find two large spaces ringed with vitrines of Pre-Columbian ceramics, beginning with examples of Olmec pottery from 1200-900 B.C., which are among the plainest and most beautifully shaped in the museum. But as in the Greek galleries, drawing wins out, reaching one zenith in a large cylindrical vase with a white surface and incised red lines that depict an imperious seated lord. Other high points are the ceramics of Andean peoples like the Wari, Moche and Chavin.
In adjacent galleries are a few African ceramics, most prominently three large 20th-century Senufo storage jars. The small display of American Indian objects includes no ceramics, although it is interesting how often the geometric designs of Mimbres and Navajo potters come to mind while looking at early Greek, Cypriot and Iranian ceramics.
Things become more complicated on the Met's second floor, where several ceramic timelines and ancient cultures are represented. A definite must-see are several bowls and a large storage jar that occupy two free-standing vitrines in the Ancient Near Eastern galleries, near the Assyrian reliefs. Made in Iran during the fifth or fourth millennium B.C., they are labeled as pottery masterworks, and they do not disappoint.
Hand-built in either red or buff clay, they have a consummate thinness and are sparely decorated with geometric designs and schematic animals: a sprightly goat with big arching horns on the storage jar, a string of tiny flamingoes on a sturdy footed bowl. Moving up a short flight of stairs toward the Islamic galleries, there are many different ceramic treasures to consider, but it is even more worthwhile to duck through the Assyrian galleries to visit the stupendous new Cypriot galleries, which run parallel to those of Ancient Near Eastern art.
The ceramic vessels in the Norbert Schimmel Gallery of prehistoric Cypriot art predate by at least 500 years, and sometimes much more, nearly everything in the Belfer Court downstairs, and they hold a few surprises. Among them are what are the 14th-century B.C. ancestors of the fluid hieroglyphic drawing style on eighth-century B.C. Attic charioteer kraters, especially the ingenious drawings of the chariots' teams of horses. Their shared legs and eyes line up in ways that evoke Picasso's renderings of Olga and Dora Maar.
Also here is a cache of white kraters from 1450 to 1200 B.C. Hand-built and decorated with bands of crosshatching, grids and diamonds, they are veritable bouquets of subtle asymmetries and wavering lines.

Islamic Grandeur
It's no surprise that Claude Levi-Strauss called ceramics "a jealous art." In the Islamic galleries, you start to suspect, even before the wall texts confirm the thought, that ninth-century potters in Nishapur and Samarkand were looking at Chinese ceramics. Yes, contemporary Tang dynasty vessels were making their way west along Asian trade routes and stirring up all kinds of creative competition.
Unable to mimic the white clay body of Chinese ceramics, Islamic potters developed the next best thing: an opaque white glaze. After that, they developed opaque colored glazes that made a whole new kind of decoration possible.

The Asian Effect
Additional waves of Chinese influence came with the import of Song whitewares and then Ming blue-and-white wares (a particularly important influence on 16th-century Iznik ceramics of Ottoman Turkey, although keep in mind that the cobalt that made blue-and-white possible came to China from Persia). These brought about further achievement, with the potters of different Islamic cultures always adding their own inventions. Most famous is that of lusterware, which brought a metallic sheen to a rainbow of colors, starting with gold, orange and yellow.
Note the imposingly large 13th-century Kashan bowl just to the left of the entrance that features four bands of contrasting calligraphy and two musicians at its center. Farther along are two especially beautiful lusterware examples: a plate whose fat little circles of dotted lines suggest a kind of bush, and a shallow bowl decorated with a grid of herringbone patterns and circles-in-squares that could almost, but not quite, have been made in 1950's America.
These galleries contain endless riches: Syrian lusterware from around 1200 patterned in blue, brown and white, and 17th-century Safavid lusterware covered with nearly monochromatic patterns of red and blue flowers. Don't miss the cul-de-sac gallery of ceramics from the Met's excavation at Nishapur, with numerous examples of the splash technique; the colored glazes often cascade, like fountains, across incised sgrafitto that suggest arches and colonnades.
On most art-historical timelines, the Chinese ceramics should be visited before the Islamic, but in this context, that requires energy to burn. Anyway, there's something to be said for walking past the Qing and Ming porcelains on the Great Hall balcony with all the achievements of Islam dancing in your head. The Islamic pieces don't pale a bit.
Head for the concentration of nonporcelains in the extensive Chinese ceramic displays. They're outnumbered by the porcelains, but to my taste, offer a greater percentage of wonders.
For convenience, jump into the history already in progress with the vitrines along the north side of the balcony: they begin with Sixth Dynasty celadons and include a Western Han covered jar whose swirling painted colors glow like well-preserved fresco. 
This stretch concludes with several Tang pieces, including a beautiful covered jar in a three-color glaze (sancai), whose elegant proportions feel both round and tall, and a blue-and-brown splashware vase that has the bravura of an Abstract Expressionist painting.
At the top of the stairs to the main Chinese galleries, there is a display of big, round Neolithic storage jars whose bold geometric designs relate enough to the Minoan pots downstairs to confirm Jung's theory about the collective unconscious. Nearby, you can peruse the Korean ceramics. Toward the end of this long gallery are additional Han and Tang pieces that deserve attention.
Around the next corner await the Japanese galleries and a pair of Jomon-period jars whose fanciful rims break out in sculptural curves and portholes. The Japanese achievement in ceramics is scanted by the current installation of these galleries, but they are one of the few places in the museum where what I would call modern ceramics are on fairly permanent display, including, at the moment, the work of the influential Shoji Hamada.

New World Surprise
At the very back of the Japanese galleries you can have an Alice-in-Wonderland moment. Go through the plain double doors and, voila, you're in the American Wing, not too far from its main display of ceramics. But maybe it's not such a big jump, given the presence of a pitcher and washbowl from the 1880's with a splashed, three-color glaze and a Tang-like Pennsylvania German redware jug in black and brown over green.
It is disconcerting to see that George Ohr, also known as the "mad potter of Biloxi" and one of America's great 19th-century artists, is represented by only a single, if spectacular, example of his thin-walled, eccentrically formed pots in the vitrine of Art Pottery. The nearby Henry R. Luce Center for the Study of American Art has four more Ohrs on its crowded shelves, as well as additional redware. On the way, visit "Women China Decorators," a show of 19th- and early-20th-century art pottery, whose strongest talent is Adelaide Alsop Robineau. 

A Continental Drift
Passing from the American Wing into the European sculpture and decorative arts galleries on the ground floor puts you back on a reasonable chronological track, among medieval ceramics whose Islamic demeanor reflects the Moorish presence in Spain. The first gallery has a generous display of 15th-century Spanish lusterware, apothecary jars and plates. (Such works are also on view in the Islamic galleries.)
Just across the gallery, a two-handled 15th-century Tuscan apothecary jar, strikingly decorated with black-on-white animal and oak leaf motifs, represents another Islamic technique: tin-glazed earthenware that became variously known in Europe as majolica (Italy), faience (France) or delftware (England).
There is much to be seen in subsequent galleries, including a large tin-glaze two-handled jar from 15th-century Florence decorated with a marvelously drawn stag highlighted with pale turquoise. But the main event of the final leg of the tour is the almost unseemly profusion with which luster, tin glazing and painting mix in the displays of Italian Renaissance majolica in the galleries at and just inside the entrance to the Lehman Collection. Patterns descended from mosques and Greek vases join forces, and Renaissance painting in all its aspects -- religious, secular, Classical -- is given a run for its money. The artists or workshops that produced these wonders are named when possible; the towns where the pieces were made are credited precisely, as in "lustered in Gubbio."
Finally, try to take in the turn-of-the-20th-century ceramics just beyond the Petrie European Sculpture Court. These include two irregularly rotund, flambe-glaze stoneware vases by the French Art Nouveau ceramicist Pierre-Adrien Dalpayrat; two exceptionally lustrous examples of modern lusterware by Zsolnay, the Hungarian manufacturer; and that commanding, if somewhat dreadful, Wedgwood swan vase.

The Material World

HEADLINE: Advice to Bloomberg 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "What New Yorkers Want From Their Next Mayor" (Op-Ed, Dec. 30): 
 Wendy Wasserstein and Alfonse M. D'Amato hint at valuable advice: Rebuild and sustain the city's spirit found in neighborhoods. 
Organizations like settlement houses, community centers and libraries build the social bonds and connections that nourish a sense of neighborhood. Programs in these organizations helped city residents cope after Sept. 11, and will help people find jobs and deal with the budget and service cuts. 
Child care, mental health care, literacy, senior centers, Meals on Wheels, home care, after-school programs, and employment and training for the unemployed help people succeed despite life's downturns. Maintaining the city's investment will save money spent on expensive alternatives.

EMILY MENLO MARKS
Executive Director
United Neighborhood Houses
New York, Jan. 2, 2002

HEADLINE: Blame in Argentina 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 By blaming the United States and the International Monetary Fund for Argentina's problems, Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 1) is telling every political hack, protectionist-minded business person and anti-capitalist intellectual here just what they want to hear: they are "victims," as he puts it, of an international conspiracy. 
 Yes, the I.M.F. made some major blunders. 
Its biggest, however, wasn't failing to provide the "political cover" for the government to undertake an unpopular devaluation, but buying into promises, never fulfilled, of the reforms that would have made it possible to sustain the dollar peg, or perhaps even dollarize.
For the last 70 years, with the exception of a hiccup in the early 1990's, Argentina's economic policy has been a mess. But the problem is, and always has been, political and social, not the exchange rate. A devaluation probably would not have resolved this crisis any more than past devaluations -- and there have been many -- resolved past crises.

DAN KRISHOCK
Buenos Aires, Jan. 2, 2002

The writer is managing editor of The Buenos Aires Herald.

HEADLINE: Staying Off Welfare for Good 

BYLINE:  By Bruce Reed; Bruce Reed, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, was director of the Domestic Policy Council in the Clinton administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Now that we've officially entered our first recession in a decade, both supporters and opponents of the 1996 welfare reform law are asking the same question: Will tough love still work in tough times?
 The good news still far outweighs the bad. Thanks to a relentless national effort to reward and require work in the 1990's, single mothers are more likely to be working and less likely to be poor than ever before. A nine-year decline in teen births has reduced the number of young mothers, a group at high risk for going on welfare. Despite the recession, most people who left welfare for work are still working, and most who have lost jobs still have welfare to fall back on. 
 Still, some aspects of the current downturn give cause for concern. The travel and tourism industry hired thousands of people who had been on welfare, and this was the economic sector hit hardest by the Sept. 11 attack. New York, where the economic impact of the terror attacks was greatest, also has the most new immigrants -- and new immigrants do not qualify for federal assistance.
Those of us who fought for welfare reform have a special responsibility to help the reformed system weather the recession. The Bush administration and Congress should revisit this issue and take steps now to make sure hard times don't slow the steady march from welfare to independence.
Welfare reform should not have cut legal immigrants off from benefits. Although some benefits have been restored in recent years -- including Supplemental Security Income, food stamps and Medicaid for elderly and disabled immigrants who have lived here longer than five years -- millions of legal immigrants are without any social safety net. Those who arrived in this country after August 1996 cannot get federal benefits based on low income at all, no matter how hard the times.
The difficulties of the immigrants' situation have also given the Bush administration leverage in its antiterror investigations. The Justice Department recently announced a program to make citizenship and its benefits easier to attain for immigrant informers who help track down potential terrorists. But a recent immigrant who just lost her job as a hotel maid shouldn't have to know a terrorist in order to get food stamps. The law should be changed to restore benefits for all legal immigrants.
Congress and the states should also make new and part-time workers eligible for unemployment benefits. You won't hear most welfare recipients complain about time limits: People who leave welfare never want to go back. But for some of the newly jobless, welfare might be the only option. According to the Urban Institute, four out of five people who have moved from welfare to work haven't worked enough hours or months to qualify for unemployment. More than half a million Americans would benefit if the unemployment system were modernized to include new and part-time workers, as the Senate Democratic stimulus package sought to do.
The federal government should also reward states that maintain their own spending for welfare-to-work programs. In 1996, the major objection to turning welfare into block grants to states, rather than continuing to base it on actual caseloads, was that states would be left holding the bag in a recession. But now the federal block grant for welfare is one of the few bright spots in most state budgets. With caseloads down 60 percent, the federal government is paying states more than twice what it would have if the system had not changed. This makes it possible for states to maintain or even increase welfare spending during this recession.
But the sudden drop in state tax revenues is squeezing other state initiatives to help the working poor. Congress should make states a one-time offer: a year of federal subsidies for any state that agrees not to cut its health care, child care and job placement budgets in 2002.
States should also devote money from their block grant surpluses to providing transitional public jobs for those who still need a foothold in the work force. The old adage that the best social program is a job becomes even more apparent in bad times.
With care, we can help people get through the current slump. But only work, not welfare, can keep them out of a slump that lasts a lifetime. As Congress begins debate sometime this year on the future of the welfare law, the current downturn shouldn't cause Americans to lose sight of why we reformed welfare in the first place.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Peter Hoey)

HEADLINE: Central Bank Of Europe Leaves Rates Unchanged 

BYLINE:  By The International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 

 BODY:
Policy makers at the European Central Bank decided today to leave monetary policy unchanged even though the economic outlook for the first half of the year remains bleak. The prospects remain dim despite the mostly smooth and successful introduction of new euro coins and bills to replace national currencies in 12 countries this week.
 Wim Duisenberg, the president of the central bank, in his first public appearance since the rollout of euro cash, predicted that growth in the 12-nation euro zone would be stagnant for the next few months. "We expect the first quarter to be pretty much the same as the last two quarters of last year," Mr. Duisenberg said after the policy-making meeting. 
 Gross domestic product in the euro zone grew just 0.1 percent in the third quarter of 2001 and is estimated to have been flat or to have contracted slightly in the fourth quarter.
Analysts saw in Mr. Duisenberg's remarks a suggestion that while short-term interest rates were left unchanged by the bank today, a cut of half a percentage point might be coming within weeks.
The bank sees better results in the second half of 2002, but "there are risks," Mr. Duisenberg observed. The fragile state of the global economy, and of the United States in particular, could derail a recovery in Europe, he said.
Much of the bank's news conference today was given over to proclaiming the euro a hit. "We can already pronounce this unprecedented move a tremendous success," Mr. Duisenberg said. The transition, he said, was "one of the major, if not the major step forward in the history of European integration."
Rodrigo Rato, the Spanish finance minister, told reporters that the apparent public enthusiasm for the euro notes and coins this week gave him hope that Europeans would have patience and an appetite for the more fundamental economic changes that many analysts think the euro will bring.
The ascent of an independent pan-European reserve bank "is certainly one of the most important structural reforms in the European economy," Mr. Rato said.
The European Central Bank has been more hawkish about inflation in recent years than the Federal Reserve, leading to criticisms that it has been too slow to cut rates in response to slowing global economic conditions. But with economic conditions varying much more among euro zone countries than they do among American states, bank officials say they must take care not to overheat some, like Ireland or Portugal, with rate cuts meant to perk up Germany or France.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Climb Sharply; Building Is Up 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
The number of the nation's workers filing new claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly surged during the last full week of 2001, the Labor Department reported today.
 Jobless claims increased by 36,000 during the week that ended Saturday to 447,000, the highest level in a month, the Labor Department said. Claims the prior week were 411,000, more than the 392,000 reported earlier. 
 The first recession in a decade has crimped demand for labor, and the return of cold weather to much of the nation may have slowed construction. The government is likely to report Friday that the jobless rate rose to 5.8 percent last month, its highest level in six and a half years. 
Warm weather in November gave a boost to construction spending, figures from the Commerce Department suggested. Spending on building rose 0.8 percent during the month, to an annual rate of $865.1 billion, matching the October increase. The November rise, led by government projects like schools, highways and sewers, will contribute to gross domestic product in the final quarter. 
The four-week moving average of claims, a less-volatile indicator, dropped to 409,750 last week, the lowest since the end of August and before the terrorist attacks Sept. 11 further weakened the economy.
Analysts had expected initial jobless claims to total 392,000 last week, based on the median of 17 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, is among those who follow the report, which economists consider to be among the most current gauges of demand for labor.
The numbers come one day before the government's report on December employment. The economy probably lost 150,000 jobs last month, based on the median of 45 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. That would be the smallest cut in payrolls since August.
The jobless rate, which tends to increase long after the economy recovers, probably rose from 5.7 percent, a six-year high.
United States companies in December announced plans to eliminate 161,584 positions, according to a tally maintained by Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a job placement company in Chicago. That is down 11 percent from November and is the lowest since August, another sign the pace of payroll reductions is slowing.
Still, few companies are hiring. The number of workers who continued to collect benefits rose to 3.72 million during the week that ended Dec. 22 from 3.67 million the prior week.

HEADLINE: Profile Of a Killer 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
I think I know who sent out the anthrax last fall.
 He is an American insider, a man working in the military bio-weapons field. He's a skilled microbiologist who did not aim to kill anybody or even to disrupt the postal system. Rather, he wanted to sow terror. Like many in the bio-warfare field, he felt that the government was not sufficiently attuned to the risks of anthrax, so he seized upon the opportunity presented by Sept. 11 to get more attention and funding for bio-terror programs like those that have been his career. 
 How do I know all this? Well, I don't exactly. But talk to the people in the spooky world of bio-terror awhile, sop up the gossip and theories, and as you put the clues together -- as bio-terror experts and F.B.I. officials are now doing -- a hazy picture seems to come into focus. It's not a certainty but an educated guess, circulating among many who know their business.
"I think there are on the order of 100 people who could have done it, who have the access to the spores and the technical expertise to have done it," says one man with long experience in the shadows of the United States bio-defense program. "I've got to admit that I could be a suspect. I've been interviewed by the F.B.I."
The emerging image of the killer that many of the experts see (but not all; anthrax experts agree about as much as economists do) is precisely the opposite of the perpetrator whom we initially imagined. Our first impulse when catastrophes happen is to look for foreigners to round up, as we did after the Oklahoma City bombing and after the crash of Flight 800. The Bush administration tried hard to find evidence to pin the anthrax attacks on Iraq.
In fact, many experts believe that the killer is tied to the American bio-weapons program because the anthrax he sent out is genetically identical to the anthrax kept by the United States Army. A microbiologist named Paul Keim is helping the authorities compare the genetic fingerprint of the mailed anthrax, and every indication is that it derives at least indirectly from the mother lode of the military strain, kept at Fort Detrick, Md.
The mailed anthrax is also astonishingly pure and equivalent (in spore size and concentration) to the best the American Army ever achieved. Making anthrax in a dry powdered form of this quality is difficult, and beginning in 1959 took 900 workers in the "hot" area of Fort Detrick years of effort (and two accidental deaths, including that of an unlucky electrician who changed light bulbs at the wrong time). Thus it seems that the murderer had access not only to the American military germs but also to some knowledge of the American military method of preparing it in its dry form.
Why do specialists agree that the murderer was not trying to kill anybody? Because he taped the envelopes tightly, and as of September nobody expected that the spores could leak through envelopes. Moreover, each of the letters that has been recovered announced that the substance was anthrax and advised the recipient to take antibiotics.
"I don't think that he was trying to kill anybody," said Barbara Hatch Rosenberg, a microbiologist who has studied the attacks for the Federation of American Scientists. "I think the motive was to create public fear, to raise the profile of biological warfare."
The F.B.I. may already have talked to the killer. There are not that many people with the access to germs, the knowledge and an anthrax vaccine booster shot in the last year. But the murderer showed a knowledge of forensics (apparently not licking a stamp or envelope, for example, to avoid leaving DNA), and it may be very difficult to move from suspicions to sufficient proof for an arrest.
Washington has been pressing Russia, Pakistan and other countries, quite rightly, to improve their control of germs, chemicals and nuclear weapons. But one of the lessons of the anthrax investigation is that the first thing we need to do to feel safer is put our own house in order. It is appalling that we cannot even determine which labs have exchanged anthrax with Fort Detrick.
Terrorism and laxity, it seems, afflict not only foreigners with different complexions and religions, but -- in exceptional cases -- perhaps also those with white lab coats and military haircuts.
