HEADLINE: Career Management Company Fights Complaints 

BYLINE:  By KATY McLAUGHLIN

 BODY:
When Michael Gonzales, an aerospace engineer in Arlington, Tex., lost his job in October 1999, he turned to Bernard Haldane Associates, a business that describes itself as the nation's oldest and largest career-management company, with 93 offices in Britain, Canada and the United States.
 Mr. Gonzales said he paid Bernard Haldane, which is based in New York, an upfront fee of $4,815, a decision he says he now regrets. He said Haldane promised to deliver "hidden market" job leads, but instead provided a mostly useless "data dump" of company information, much of which could have been obtained free on the Internet. 
 Mr. Gonazales has since found a job on his own, but he is battling for a full refund from Haldane. He is among hundreds of dissatisfied Haldane customers, some paying as much as $20,000, who have complained about the company's practices to 11 state attorneys general, including those in California, New York and Texas. One state, Kansas, is investigating nearly 100 consumer complaints against the company. 
In response, Haldane said some complaints were to be expected given its history of serving more than 600,000 customers over 53 years. It also said Mr. Gonzales received what he was promised, and that it never guaranteed career advancement. 
"What we do is give our clients tools so they can have a successful job search," said Jerold Weinger, Haldane's chairman and chief executive.
Haldane has faced similar complaints in the past. In 1982, after the attorney general in New York accused the firm of making "false, misleading and deceptive" statements, Haldane agreed, without admitting guilt, to make refunds to clients. In 1983, California obtained an injunction against the company, preventing it from making misleading statements to potential clients.
And in 1992, the district attorney of Contra Costa County, Calif., reached a settlement with the company under which it agreed, again without admitting wrongdoing, to refund $60,000 to 63 clients.
"They give the impression that the big check leads to the big job," said Bill Mitchell, president of the Southern California Better Business Bureau. After receiving many complaints about the company, Mr. Mitchell in 1998 wrote an article in his online newsletter about the complaints.
While headhunters, executive recruiters, employment agencies and outplacement companies earn commissions and fees from employers, retail outplacement concerns like Haldane are paid directly by the client. According to Tom Rodenhauser, an independent consultant for the recruiting industry, the ready availability of job listings and databases on the Internet has eliminated much of the exclusive value that companies like Haldane used to be able to offer clients. Critics argue that Haldane compensates for its outmoded business model by misrepresenting what it can do for clients.
Mr. Weinger said his firm does not promise to make calls or provide contacts, set up interviews, create networks, match clients with recruiters or guarantee job placement for any of its clients. "It would be ridiculous for us to set up interviews," he said. "That would be another person getting in the way between our client and the prospective employer."
He said Haldane offered clients guidance in redesigning a resume and access, via a password, to an Internet service that consolidates job-search engines and databases. It also assigns each client to a career adviser, usually a former executive, he says, though not a "career counselor," a designation that, in most states, requires licensing by the state. 
For access to these services for three years, Haldane clients pay from $4,000 to $20,000. Mr. Weinger, the chief executive, said they are charged roughly 10 percent of their most recent salaries.
Pamela Pagliochini, a career counselor whose company Vocatus, based in Manhattan, offers career development and management services at $110 a session, said she considered $20,000 a staggering sum to charge.
"I think upfront fees are unethical," Ms. Pagliochini said, "because if it's not working for you, you should be able to stop." 
Haldane, which has expanded greatly under Mr. Weinger's leadership since 1989, operates by a system of licensing, meaning that various businesses pay royalty fees to Haldane for the use of its name and program. 
Mr. Gonzales, the aerospace engineer, said he first learned about the firm in a newspaper advertisement reading "Job Hunting." Such advertisements appear weekly in many national newspapers, including The New York Times. He sent his resume to the firm, believing it was a recruiter, which called him for an interview. Before meeting with Robert Lewis, a Haldane vice president for client services, Mr. Gonzales gave information about his job history and his savings and other assets.
In his complaint to the Texas attorney general, Mr. Gonzales stated that in two meetings, Mr. Lewis "described how after years in the business, Haldane amassed a robust and proprietary network of contacts to which I would have access." Convinced Haldane would be the conduit to unpublished jobs, Mr. Gonzales paid by check and signed a contract.
People familiar with the firm say those taking legal action against it face high hurdles because clients sign a contract that does not bind Haldane to specific tasks or results. Clients also regularly sign off on a waiver that states they have not been orally promised anything that contradicts the paper contract.
Mr. Gonzales said the promises made to him were mostly oral, a claim echoed by hundreds of other former Haldane customers across the country and in Canada. Asked why he signed the documents, he said, "I was vulnerable and convinced by the sales pitch. I didn't scrutinize the paperwork." Other clients claim they were told to view the wording in the documents as nothing more than legalese from the company's lawyers.
Ian McClure, Haldane's executive vice president, wrote to the Texas attorney general in response to the complaint, "I am having a difficult time determining where Mr. Gonzales misunderstood our program." He stated that the written contract was very clear that Haldane made no guarantees of providing career advancement.
Bernard Haldane Associates was founded in 1947 by Bernard Haldane, revered by many as the father of outplacement. Dr. Haldane, who holds a Ph.D. in management and human resources, sold his interest in the firm in 1974 and now, at age 91, continues to lecture on career-management issues at the University of Washington. He said that while his contact with the company was limited to a meeting perhaps every two years, he thinks it provides a useful service. 
"In all the reports I have seen intermittently over the years, everybody says they have gained a great deal from being a client," he said.
Disgruntled clients tell a different tale. Teresa King of Indianapolis, for example, said she paid $4,005 to Haldane in March because she was "promised an inside track and a database of clients they match you up with." While she has cut off contact with the firm and posted an account of her experience on a Web site, she says she has not complained directly to the company.
Jay Jungalwala of Hudson, Mass., did. Mr. Jungalwala was looking for a position as an executive vice president and pledged $17,000 in April because, he said, Haldane gave him the impression it had personal relationships with chief executives in his field, which was related to Internet technology. Upon unearthing unfavorable opinions about Haldane, Mr. Jungalwala said, he demanded and received a refund before his contract was fully executed.
Tom Sparber, a former Haldane vice president who worked for a year in a Haldane office in New Jersey owned by B. L. Marketing before leaving last May, said he was encouraged to make vague references to potential clients about a beneficial relationship Haldane had with an outside company called Sterling Hightower. This company, these potential customers were assured, would put their resumes in front of thousands of executive recruiters across the nation. In an interview, Mr. Weinger acknowledged that this supposed third-party firm was in fact owned by the Haldane licensee in Tucson, Ariz., Sarah Hightower-Hill. Ms. Hightower-Hill said the company provides resumes to executive recruiters who request them, but she declined to identify the recruiters or to say how many used her service.
In Kansas, Assistant Attorney General Dave Harder said the highly unusual number of complaints there raised a red flag. His office has tried to mediate by seeking refunds for dissatisfied customers, which he said Haldane had refused to provide.He said he was in the process of taking sworn statements to determine whether Haldane has breached state statutes protecting consumers against deceptive practices.
Asked about the nearly 100 complaints in Kansas, Mr. Weinger, Haldane's chief executive, said he did not believe the number was that high. Positive feedback from clients far outweighs the negative, he said, adding that he was aware of very few unhappy customers.
Haldane provided the phone numbers of three customers, one of whom responded to the request for an interview. 
"I am satisfied," said Larry Jalowiec of Quakertown, Pa., whose former employer financed the service as part of an outplacement package. "Haldane helped me by bucking me up whenever my job search got frustrating."
As for Mr. Gonzales, he found a job on his own by answering a want ad in the newspaper. Haldane has offered him a partial refund in exchange for signing a confidentiality agreement that would prohibit him from telling his story, a settlement he has refused.

HEADLINE: Newark Arena Is on Agenda in the Assembly's Final Days 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
On the second-to-last day of the legislative session, the New Jersey Assembly today chipped away at a schedule of more than 100 bills, while Speaker Jack Collins promised to revive the long-disputed proposal for a new sports arena in Newark. 
 It was not clear whether the arena proposal could be brought to a vote in both chambers on Monday, the legislature's last day. The new version of the proposal is laden with other projects in South Jersey, Mr. Collins's home territory, that are not in the bill approved last summer by the Senate. 
 Democratic leaders continued to insist that they would no longer support the $355 million arena in light of the budget gap that they are inheriting from a Republican governor and legislature.
The last days of the lame-duck legislature have turned into a flurry of pleas for pet projects, countered by pleas by Governor-elect James E. McGreevey to stem state spending.
Today, the Assembly did approve a package of bills establishing terrorism as a new criminal offense and a bill expanding access to public records; New Jersey now has the most restrictive public-records law in the nation. Final passage of both measures would require votes by the Senate on Monday. 
Most of the spending bills were put off until Monday, among them a measure to change the state's corporate tax formula. Even its advocates concede that the proposed new method of calculating the tax, to base it entirely on sales revenue, will cut taxes for large corporations with headquarters in New Jersey and will cost the treasury at least $12 million in the first year. Estimates of the cost over the five-year phase-in period are as high as hundreds of millions of dollars. But over time, advocates say, the measure will make New Jersey as attractive for businesses as a growing number of other states that use similar "single sales" formulas.
The voting session today slowed as Assembly members took time out for tributes to the 17 members who are leaving. 
Mr. Collins's measure on the Newark arena would include $46 million in additional spending on economic development grants to South Jersey. Among the projects are $20,000 for a conference center in Pennsauken, outside Camden, and a $3 million sculling course on the Cooper River; $20 million to build athletic fields at Rowan University, and $3 million for improvements to local zoos. 
Mr. Collins has insisted on some South Jersey projects for months, but the Republican-dominated Assembly Appropriations Committee rejected an earlier version of the arena bill. 
Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco had recently stayed out of the wrangling over the arena project, which in addition to giving the New Jersey Nets and Devils a new home in Newark would transform their current home, the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, into a "sports entertainment" complex.
Tom Wilson, the acting governor's press secretary, said Mr. DiFrancesco "really hasn't spent a lot of time thinking about this since the middle of September, when we made our last push on it" and was not likely to consider it in the next few days. "He's got 50 bills on his desk," Mr. Wilson said. 
If the speaker brings the measure to a vote on Monday, it will still have to be approved as amended by the Senate. 
Also on Monday, Mr. DiFrancesco is to address the legislature. He leaves office at noon Tuesday, and at 3 p.m. the State of the State address will be delivered by John O. Bennett, who as the Senate Republican leader will be acting governor for several days.

HEADLINE: Parents Oppose Return Date For a School At Ground Zero 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Teachers and parents from one of the downtown schools closed by the World Trade Center attack are fighting a plan to reopen the building next month, saying that returning so soon would be traumatic and disruptive.
 The Board of Education said last month that the school, Public School 89 on Warren Street, would reopen on Feb. 4. Two other elementary schools near the disaster site, P.S. 234 and P.S. 150, both on Greenwich Street, are to reopen the same day. 
 Two other schools near the trade center site that were shuttered since the attack, the High School for Economics and Finance and the High School for Leadership and Public Service, are to reopen on Jan. 30.
But while Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has declared the school buildings safe -- and some parents are eagerly awaiting the return -- the teachers and the parent association at P.S. 89 are anxious. The school has already relocated twice since September -- first to a wing of P.S. 3 in Greenwich Village, and then, in October, to a building on the Lower East Side, where they have shared space with a small alternative school. P.S. 89's enrollment has dropped to 218, from 415 on Sept. 11.
At first, parents angrily resisted the move to the Lower East Side school, saying it was inconvenient. At the time, many said they wanted only to return to the P.S. 89 building as soon as possible. But yesterday, Sharon Sprague, co-chairwoman of the PTA, said parents, students and teachers had adjusted well to the Lower East Side building and had many concerns about returning to the Warren Street location.
"There's a lot that needs to be addressed," Ms. Sprague said, adding that parents were especially worried about passing trucks loaded with debris and the unobstructed views of the disaster site from some classroom windows, which could further traumatize the many students.
Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for Chancellor Levy, said the return date was not negotiable.
"There is no good reason to wait, because the schools are ready now," Ms. Marshall said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AID GROUPS; 
Aid Groups Say Warlords Steal As Needy Wait

BYLINE:  By C. J. CHIVERS with ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
An effort to feed Afghan refugees returning from Pakistan descended into violence here today as food ran short and local soldiers beat back a hungry crowd that had swarmed around a Red Crescent Society compound. As the crowd dispersed, relief officials said they had run low on food because shipments had been stolen by local warlords.
 The confrontation, which at one point almost turned into a riot, began this morning when several hundred refugees converged on the compound and demanded the bags of rice stored inside. 
 But the society had fewer than 300 sacks of rice, and its staff decided not to distribute them out of fear that there would be fights between families who had received food and those that had not. The crowd shouted in protest and soldiers, using branches stripped from nearby trees, began driving the refugees away from the compound's concrete walls. 
In Washington, the struggle to provide famine relief to Afghans provoked a battle of words. The Bush administration said today that widespread hunger had been averted in Afghanistan, but officials from relief agencies said the White House was speaking too soon, offering a success story from a war-torn country where solid proof is hard to find.
Andrew S. Natsios, the administrator of the United States' Agency for International Development, said that with American support the United Nations World Food Program appeared to "have averted a widespread famine in Afghanistan." Relief groups countered that the country was too unstable, its rural areas too remote, for an early celebration.
Outside the Red Crescent compound in Jalalabad, soldiers at times struck children, women and old men indiscriminately. Some soldiers hit women who sat on the ground and begged. At least one struck a boy so hard that the branch broke across the boy's back. The crowd responded by throwing stones.
"There are too many people who come here for food," said Abdul Basir Basirat, the Red Crescent Society supervisor in Jalalabad. "All of them need rice and other things. What should I do?"
As Mr. Basirat spoke from inside his office the crowd wailed and pushed on the compound gate. The crowd surged, the gate held, the crowd relaxed, then surged again. Soldiers could be seen swinging sticks from the top of the walls down into the crowd, striking those who pressed too close.
Mr. Basirat said that the same soldiers who were trying to control the crowd were actually linked to the source of the problem.
The troops are members of the Eastern Shura, the group of anti-Taliban warlords in the region who worked with the United States military to hunt down Taliban and Al Qaeda forces in cave complexes nearby. Since the Taliban fled Jalalabad in November, these warlords have controlled the city and the surrounding Nangarhar Province. They are a largely undisciplined force.
Relief officials said that several days ago six trucks loaded with rice arrived from Pakistan, enough food to feed everyone now requesting assistance. But the Eastern Shura seized four of the trucks to feed its armies or the relatives of soldiers who died in the war. The seizures left little rice for the refugees.
"The local commanders took all of the rice," Mr. Basirat said. "We were allowed only two trucks. All of the rest went to their houses, or to the families of the martyrs."
The thefts were confirmed by Atiqullah Mohmand, the Jalalabad program director for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "That is true," he said. "Right now, we don't have a proper system of government in this province. The mujahedeen put force on us and take the food. They are looting."
Mr. Mohmand said that since late November relief organizations have also tried three times to distribute wheat, and each time local soldiers stole most of the food. He declined to name the commanders responsible. 
"Nobody wants to mention a clear name, because it might put them in danger," he said.
The senior commander in the region, Hajji Hazat Ali, brushed aside questions about the thefts, suggesting that some of the rice was missing because the Red Crescent society was corrupt.
"Some people who are working for the non-government organizations are all thieves," he said. "They try to divide some food they receive between themselves and some of the local commanders. We are trying to capture these people."
But he did not seem to be trying very hard to catch the thieves or recover the rice, sacks of which could be found today in the city being used to feed his own soldiers at each of the checkpoints he maintains.
The United Nations said that as many as 300 families a day are arriving in Jalalabad from Pakistan. The new arrivals have been joining as many as 5,000 displaced Afghans who were counted in a Red Crescent survey in early December. 
"There are children who have become very thin because of the cold and not enough food," said Muktar, a society employee. "Some of them are dead already, and others will die soon."
For months, a muscular propaganda campaign directed by the White House has been focused on showing that the American air campaign has helped, not harmed, the Afghan people. This week, the White House information center is highlighting its relief efforts, reflecting how avoiding famine in Afghanistan has been a critical national security goal.
While no one disputed that the relief effort has been successful, several relief officials expressed concern that the United States was exaggerating that success and could possibly imperil future relief operations by drawing too rosy a picture. Mr. Natsios was careful to say that food will be needed for at least another year but he also said only some people in fringe areas may still need emergency relief to avoid famine.
Nigun Ogun of Save The Children, a relief group that has worked in Afghanistan since 1994, was skeptical. "I don't think we averted a famine," he said. "I would say that the problem has been averted for two months -- no more."
Officials at the World Food Program disagreed and said they knew they had turned a corner in December when they were running their trucks on all six routes into Afghanistan, bringing 4,000 tons of wheat into the country every day.
"It's not that simple to say when we averted famine, but we have," said Abby Spring, of the aid program. "Yes, people are still in tough shape but it is a tribute to the international community that this much was accomplished."
As the crowd left the Red Crescent compound today, Mr. Basirat said he hoped to register as many new arrivals as possible and circulate identification cards to them so the society could distribute its remaining sacks of rice within the next few days.
The refugees were not satisfied. One white-haired man wandered near the compound, clutching a petition and begging for food. He spoke English, and said he had been a teacher, but now was destitute.
"There are many different problems about this food distribution," said the man, Zaid Gulab, 50. "Many people do not have any information about how to get food here today. I am hungry. I do not know how to get any. I cannot find out because the soldiers are there with guns and sticks."
Mr. Mohmand, of the United Nations, said conditions today were reminiscent of those in the early 1990's, when guerrilla commanders ran the province, abusing civilians and taking whatever they wanted. Popular anger with their conduct helped bring the Taliban to power.
"The people who are now in the positions of authority in our province, they are exactly the same persons who were here before," Mr. Mohmand said. "They are following the same system as before. It is not good. There is no killing right now, but the thieves are very active."

HEADLINE: Argentina's Quest for Salvation 

 BODY:
Sworn in on Wednesday, Argentina's fifth president in two weeks called his a "government of national salvation." The label might seem to emanate from the same overwrought, tragic streak that bequeathed the tango and the saga of Evita to the world. But President Eduardo Duhalde was not exaggerating. Argentina's crisis is dire, and threatens the viability of its democracy. Mr. Duhalde must govern accordingly, presiding over an administration that works with all the major parties to create a consensus on how to proceed. 
 Most leaders within Mr. Duhalde's Peronist Party engaged in unseemly political infighting after President Fernando de la Rua of the Radical Party resigned on Dec. 21, in the face of mounting riots across the country. The Peronists, who control the Congress, acted as if they had suddenly won a landslide election but still needed to designate their candidate. The previous interim president, Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, was forced to resign from office after only a week, once it became clear that he lacked the support of major Peronist leaders. 
 Mr. Duhalde, a former vice president of Argentina and former governor of the province of Buenos Aires, wisely recognized that what Argentina needs now is a national unity government. He obtained the backing of the main opposition parties in exchange for a pledge that they would be involved in his government and that he would not run in the 2003 election. Exercising its constitutional prerogative, Congress elected him to fill out Mr. de la Rua's four-year term, and abandoned its earlier plan to hold new elections in March. 
A populist who often criticized President Carlos Menem's free-market reforms in the 1990's, Mr. Duhalde supported President Rodriguez Saa's unavoidable announcement last week that Argentina would default on payments of its crushing $132 billion foreign debt, the largest such default ever by a sovereign debtor. He is now expected to end Argentina's decade-old policy of pegging its peso to the United States dollar at a one-to-one rate of exchange. This monetary straitjacket helped tame inflation in the 1990's, but also allowed the country to go on its disastrous borrowing binge. 
Most economists believe that such a devaluation, though politically difficult, is needed to make the country's exports more competitive. The government must also restore confidence in the financial system to a point where it can lift unpopular limits on bank withdrawals. 
The International Monetary Fund and other foreign creditors share the blame for Argentina's woes. They were arguably too indulgent for too long, even after it became apparent that Argentina was too indebted and its currency was overvalued. The I.M.F. then held Argentina to an unsustainable austerity program amid a recession, and abruptly cut off promised loans late last year, contributing to the financial panic. 
It would be a tragic mistake, however, for Mr. Duhalde to fuel Argentines' sense that theirs is a rich nation forced into poverty by outside forces. Blaming the free market or globalization for the country's ills, and adopting an overly protectionist course for South America's second-largest economy, would only make matters worse. Argentina must instead acknowledge and address its past failures to reform its public finances, and become a more competitive exporter. President Duhalde needs to keep his promises and avoid governing narrowly as a Peronist. In return, the international community ought to give his unity government all the assistance possible.

HEADLINE: Black Scholars Mending a Rift With Harvard 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 

 BODY:
After more than a week of racially charged tensions, Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard University, met and mended fences today with Cornel West, a senior black professor, apparently ending a dispute that had threatened to cost the university its team of celebrated African-American scholars.
 The meeting occurred a day after Mr. Summers issued a statement expressing his commitment to diversity at Harvard and to the strength of the Afro-American Studies department. That statement in turn was a response to the anger of several members of the department who had threatened to move to Princeton University after what they said were several snubs by Mr. Summers over the last few months and the absence of a strong statement of his commitment to affirmative action. 
 The professors particularly felt that Mr. Summers had insulted Professor West in a private meeting by raising questions about his pursuit of scholarship, grade inflation in his classes and his making a rap CD. 
William Julius Wilson, a university professor of social policy, said: "The new president is clearly reaching out, and I think that these problems are going to be resolved. He admits there has been a problem of communication, and to his credit he is trying to correct a previous mistake and misjudgment and thereby affirm a strong commitment to issues relating to diversity and affirmative action. That's encouraging."
The conflict had created a storm on the issue of race for Mr. Summers, who has been president of Harvard, the nation's oldest university, for six months. On Jan. 1, the Rev. Jesse Jackson held a news conference here to accuse the university of equivocating on affirmative action. 
The Rev. Al Sharpton also threatened to sue Mr. Summers over accusations, which the president flatly denied, that he had criticized Professor West for supporting Mr. Sharpton's bid for president. 
As soon as the conflict with the black professors seemed to subside, however, Mr. Summers faced another similarly charged tangle, as Latin American studies professors said they had been rebuffed in requests for more attention from the president and the establishment of a full-fledged Latino studies center.
By today, some members of the Afro-American Studies department were cringing at how what was essentially a bidding war with Princeton over star professors had become an internationally reported account of racial tension. 
Marilyn Marks, a spokeswoman for Princeton, said, "We're pleased that fences appear to have been mended at Harvard, and we're still eager to build on our strong program in African-American studies, as we have been doing for several years."
Late today, Mr. Summers resolved the last issue with the Afro-American Studies department, when he met with Dr. West and cleared the air, though he made no explicit apology.
Dr. West, who had led the threat of an exodus, declined to say whether he would stay. People close to the department said they did not expect him or anyone else to leave.
Mr. Summers, too, seemed eager to set the dispute behind him.
"I regret any misunderstandings there, and I hope they will be cleared up," he said in an interview in his office. "I've had good conversations with members of the African-American Studies department expressing my strong desire that they stay at Harvard and our continued commitment to making this an attractive intellectual environment for African-American studies."
The members of the Afro-American Studies department distanced themselves from the issues raised by the Latino studies professors, saying that they knew nothing about the complaints and that there was no coordinated campaign. 
But one discord seemed to feed on the other. Administration members noted that there had been no letters or phone calls expressing concerns about a Latino studies center that would focus on the experience of Hispanic people in the United States until newspapers printed articles about the black professors' threat to go to Princeton.
Administration officials said they were considering the Latino center as they considered all proposals for new programs or centers. But they said approving it would require reversing a longstanding policy to avoid creating narrowly constructed ethnic programs.
Prof. John Coatsworth, a specialist in Latin American studies who has been seeking a Latino center, said today he thought that Mr. Summers was trying to make amends, but that he faced a serious challenge.
"I think no leader of a major American cultural institution can afford to have his commitment to diversity in question," Professor Coatsworth said.
Members of the Afro-American Studies department said Mr. Summers had previously left the impression that the department had been relegated to second-class status. That was particularly striking compared with the relationship they enjoyed with Mr. Summers's predecessor, Neil L. Rudenstine.
Mr. Rudenstine created the department by luring Henry Louis Gates from Duke University. Dr. Gates in turn recruited what he called the "dream team." Mr. Rudenstine gave the department special presidential money and granted Dr. Wilson and Dr. West university professorships, which are the highest stars in the academic realm and allow their holders to circulate among the university's schools.
Some Harvard faculty members had accused the Afro-American Studies department of crying racism to disguise a power play, but Professor Gates, the department's chairman, challenged that, noting that his professors were not pressing demands for more money. 
"As a person who has been recruiting some of the finest scholars in America to Harvard over the past decade," he said, "I can safely say that people of the stature of Cornel West do not move for financial reasons. 
"The compensation at his level will only be comparable elsewhere. Only someone who doesn't understand how the academy functions would make such a ridiculous statement. It vulgarizes what's a matter of principle."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 14, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Jan. 4 about recent tensions between Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard, and several professors of Afro-American studies misstated the period in which their department was created. It was in 1969 -- not during the presidency of Neil L. Rudenstine, who served from 1991 to 2001.

HEADLINE: A Fortunate Son's Death, And a Missing $5 Million 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY and DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Growing up in the gilded suburb of Short Hills, N.J., Michael B. Schwartz was as skilled with a soccer ball as he was at charming the girls. A star on the Millburn High School soccer team, he was wildly popular with his classmates, and if anyone could make good on his dream of becoming a filmmaker, it was Michael.
 But somewhere along the way, Mr. Schwartz's dreams ran off the track. His film career never took off, and at the age of 36, he found himself in the business of filling automated teller machines with cash, a job that earned him a decent living but nowhere near the affluence he had known as a boy. 
 According to friends and family, the temptation of handling so much money might have been irresistible. In early December, Mr. Schwartz mysteriously disappeared from his Jersey City apartment. So did $5 million he had taken from the California bank he did business with, the authorities said. 
On Christmas Day, part of the mystery was solved when Mr. Schwartz was found dead in a rented room in West Palm Beach, Fla. Officials said they believed that he had choked on his own vomit after a two-week drinking binge.
The money, however, remains missing. And as investigators search for packets of $20 bills, Mr. Schwartz's family, friends and neighbors are left wondering why a gentle man who fancied himself a poet and a musician came to such a puzzling end.
"He always struck me as a fine, successful businessman," said Norman Merker, who owns a drugstore across the street from Mr. Schwartz's apartment in Jersey City. "It's a complete shock. I never would have expected it."
F.B.I. agents and officials at the California bank, Humboldt Bancorp, of Eureka, say they are now trying to figure out how the money was pilfered from the A.T.M.'s, and over how long a period of time. Bill Evanina, a spokesman at the F.B.I. office in Newark, described the crime as a rare form of white-collar bank theft.
"We believe this is the first time an authorized servicer has been siphoning money from the machines on such a large scale," Mr. Evanina said yesterday. "We're trying to ascertain if he was solo in this criminal endeavor or if he had a co-conspirator who may currently possess the money."
A warrant for Mr. Schwartz's arrest was issued on Dec. 12, about a week after Humboldt Bancorp informed the F.B.I. of what the bank's chief financial officer, Pat Rusnak, described yesterday as an "irregular pattern of activities" at some of the A.T.M.'s for which the bank had provided money.
Mr. Rusnak said that Mr. Schwartz and Humboldt entered an agreement in December 2000 under which the bank provided money to a company that Mr. Schwartz owned, Schwaz Armored L.L.C., to stock 138 A.T.M.'s that Mr. Schwartz owned in northern New Jersey and in New York City. Most of the machines were in small neighborhood groceries and pharmacies.
Mr. Rusnak called the bank's arrangement with Mr. Schwartz an unusual one because Mr. Schwartz owned the A.T.M.'s and stocked them with money. Customarily, he said, A.T.M.'s are not owned by the same company that fills them with cash.
Mr. Rusnak said bank authorities believe that the $5 million, which Humboldt provided to Mr. Schwartz through wire transfers, was probably stolen over time by one of two ways: either the money the bank provided for the A.T.M.'s was never placed in the machines or it was placed in them and later taken out of the drawer where it had been loaded.
The F.B.I. has found a white 1998 Ford Econoline van owned by Schwaz Armored L.L.C. in a garage at the West Palm Beach apartment Mr. Schwartz moved into about two weeks before his death, Mr. Evanina said. As of yesterday evening, F.B.I. agents were awaiting a warrant to search the vehicle, he said.
Mr. Schwartz found the apartment through a rent-finder who dates a man who lives there and who was looking for a roommate, according to the West Palm Beach police. Detectives said that the man, Chris Lacroix, found Mr. Schwartz's body on Christmas Day and told them that he knew Mr. Schwartz only as Jeff Alexander. According to the police, Mr. Lacroix said Mr. Schwartz had paid him $1,800 in cash for three months' rent.
During his two weeks in the apartment, Mr. Schwartz routinely drank wine and up to a case of beer a day, the police said Mr. Lacroix told them. Detectives said he told them that he found Mr. Schwartz dead on a den sofa, next to a coffee table with beer cans and a wine bottle on it. Yesterday, Mr. Lacroix angrily ordered a reporter away from his front door. 
The police in West Palm Beach say they have ruled out foul play in Mr. Schwartz's death. A finding of the cause awaits completion of toxicological tests, they said.
Those who knew Mr. Schwartz during his days in Short Hills say he was handsome and athletic and seemed destined for greatness. But although he studied at New York University's film program, his artistic ambitions never came to anything. He had Siamese cats, Bonnie and Clyde, which he took to Florida.
When his father died about a decade ago, Mr. Schwartz inherited enough money to start the A.T.M. business, his family said. He apparently earned enough to buy a BMW and a condominium in Jersey City, but he was not a born businessman, friends and family said. 
Mr. Schwartz's mother, Linda Schnoll, a real estate agent, lives with his stepfather, Jack Schnoll, in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Reached at their home yesterday, the Schnolls, who are sitting shiva, declined to speak to a reporter.

HEADLINE: Walgreen Profit Up 17%, Aided by Pharmacies 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
The Walgreen Company reported a 17 percent quarterly earnings gain today, helped by soaring pharmaceutical sales, and it said it would add 475 stores this year. 
 Net profit was $185.9 million, or 18 cents a share, up from $158.4 million, or 15 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. 
 Sales in the period, which ended Nov. 30 and was the first quarter of Walgreen's fiscal year, rose 17 percent, to $6.56 billion from $5.61 billion, from the quarter a year earlier. 
Walgreen's income exceeded by 1 cent the estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call, and the company's stock rose $1.33, or 4 percent, to $34.41 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Prescription sales, which accounted for just 15 percent of sales in 1980, continued their rise as a result of the aging of the population and pharmaceutical advances. Prescriptions accounted for 60 percent of Walgreen's sales in the quarter, up 22 percent from a year earlier.
In an indication that growth has continued into this quarter, the company, based in Deerfield, Ill., announced separately that December sales totaled $2.8 billion, up 14 percent from the previous December.
"The nature of our business -- selling basic goods that everyone needs -- gives us the chance to perform well despite the current recession and tough retail environment," said the chairman, Dan Jorndt. "It also means we will continue as planned with our expansion program."
Walgreen said its 475 new stores in fiscal 2002 would entail 14,000 new jobs, $1.3 billion in capital spending and two new distribution centers.
An analyst, Derek Leckow of Barrington Research Associates, based in Chicago, said the results showed that Walgreen's continuing expansion was paying off in higher sales and increased market share.
"We think that's a good strategy," Mr. Leckow said, "given that some of their competitors -- primarily CVS and Rite Aid -- are facing capital constraints and issues related to the pharmacist shortage. It seems to me that Walgreen is doing a better job recruiting and getting its pharmacies better staffed."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Forecast Hurts Software Maker 

BYLINE:  By Laurie J. Flynn (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss)

 BODY:
 Shares of Peregrine Systems, a 20-year-old enterprise software company, fell $5.24, or 36.1 percent, to $9.27 yesterday on news that it would post a loss for its latest quarter rather than the profit analysts had expected. Peregrine, based in San Diego, said it anticipated a loss of 7 cents to 8 cents a share on revenue of $175 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2002, which ended Dec. 31. 
Analysts had projected a profit of a dime a share. The pro forma loss excludes approximately $75 million in acquisition costs. Executives attributed the loss to poor economic conditions in Europe and delays in purchasing decisions by customers. It said business activity was up in North America. Final results are due Jan. 24. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
PROVIDIAN TO LAY OFF 800 WORKERS; WARNS OF MORE CUTS

BYLINE:  AP

 BODY:
 Providian Financial said yesterday that it would lay off 800 workers in California and Kentucky, and it warned of more layoffs as it struggled to recover from mounting loan losses. 
The layoffs, affecting 6 percent of the work force, follow 550 job cuts made after the company decided in November to close a Nevada office. The latest cuts involve employees in four California cities, San Francisco, Oakland, Pleasanton and Sacramento, as well as Louisville, Ky., a spokesman said. Providian, a San Francisco-based issuer of credit cards, expects to take a charge of $10 million to $15 million to pay for the layoffs.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Consumer Confidence Falls 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Consumers in New York City turned gloomier in December, even as their counterparts upstate and across the nation grew cheerier, according to a monthly survey of consumer confidence, an important economic indicator. The index for the New York City metropolitan area fell by almost six points in December, to 79.6; meanwhile, the upstate index rose by almost three points, to 78.8. But both levels are much lower than the national confidence index, which rose almost five points last month, to 88.8. The study was conducted by the Siena College Research Institute, in conjunction with the University of Michigan. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: 'Battle of Normandy' May Go to Denver Mine 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Newmont Mining, which is based in Denver, appeared set today to win the contest to take over Normandy Mining of Australia with a bid of $2.2 billion. The deal would make Newmont the world's biggest gold producer.
 AngloGold of South Africa, which had been vying for Normandy, bowed out of the bidding today after Newmont sweetened its bid. Anglo Gold said it had "no basis upon which it could justify an increase" in its last offer, made on Dec. 26. At current prices, Newmont's bid is worth about 6 cents a share more than AngloGold's; both are combinations of stock and cash. 
 A small chance remains that shifts in stock prices will close the gap between the two bids and make AngloGold's competitive again. "The game is going to be called by shareholders in the marketplace," Robert M. Godsell, chairman and chief executive of AngloGold, said in a telephone interview from Johannesburg.
But Ronald Coll, an analyst at Thomson Kernaghan in Toronto, summed up the view of many analysts and fund managers when he said, "I believe this is the end of it." Normandy's board reaffirmed its support for Newmont's bid today.
The three-way Newmont proposal also includes an uncontested offer for Franco-Nevada Mining, a Toronto-based company that derives most of its income from mining royalties. Franco-Nevada is Normandy's biggest single shareholder.
The four-month Battle of Normandy, as the takeover struggle came to be known, is seen as a landmark event in the gold mining industry, signaling an acceleration in the pace of mergers and acquisitions. The industry appears headed for domination by a few global players with efficient mines and wide appeal to institutional investors.
Pierre Lassonde, who is president of Franco-Nevada and will have the same title at the enlarged Newmont, said in a telephone interview: "For the first time in 20 years, you're going to have four or five producers who will control 35 to 40 percent of the industry. These producers can work together to shut down uneconomic production."
Mr. Godsell of AngloGold said that in the past equity investors viewed North America, South Africa and Australia as distinct spheres, but that the outcome of the Normandy battle showed that "we're all being put into one pot and being compared." He said the challenge for gold producers now was not so much to keep growing in size, but to demonstrate that they can operate profitably even at low gold prices.
Michael Fowler, an analyst at Harris Partners in Toronto, said the emerging leaders would probably include Newmont, AngloGold, Barrick Gold of Canada and possibly one more company. Potential takeover targets, he said, include Placer Dome of Vancouver, Gold Fields of South Africa and Lihir Gold, which operates a large mine in Papua New Guinea.
Mr. Coll said that having failed to win Normandy, AngloGold, which is 53 percent owned by Anglo American of London, "has an unfulfilled urge to merge with a non-South African company."
According to Mr. Godsell, more consolidation is also likely regionally, especially in Nevada and western Australia, where competing mines are close together and could achieve economies of scale if combined. AngloGold and Barrick are talking about cooperating in Tanzania; analysts say Barrick and Newmont have interests in Nevada and northern Ontario that are ripe for rationalization.
The enlarged Newmont will have 22 mines on five continents, annual production of 8.2 million ounces and a market value of more than $8 billion. AngloGold produces 7.2 million ounces a year; Barrick Gold, including Homestake Mining of Walnut Creek, Calif., which it bought recently, produces about 5.7 million ounces.
With a strong balance sheet and much of its revenue locked in through an active hedging program, Barrick has been the clear favorite of gold investors. Newmont has pledged to offer investors an obvious alternative to Barrick by unwinding Normandy's hedge book, making it fully exposed to changes in gold prices. It said today that it would sell some "noncore, non-Australian" assets, raising $250 million to $300 million; it gave no details.
Newmont's latest offer is 50 Australian dollars ($25.75) -- 10 Australian dollars more than before -- plus 3.85 of its shares for each 100 shares of Normandy; it put the total value at 1.93 Australian dollars a share.

HEADLINE: Slack Results for Hedge Funds 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Hedge funds, which make bets on swings in stocks, bonds, currencies and commodity prices, rose about 4 percent on average last year, about the same as what investors made holding three-month United States Treasury bills. 
 Gains in 2001 fell short of the 10.6 percent average advance in 2000, according to the Allenbridge Group, a London-based research firm. 
They also were about a fifth of what investors tend to expect from the loosely regulated funds, which are marketed to institutions and the wealthy. Performance in the $500 billion hedge fund business lagged as stock markets tumbled. 
 "Hedge funds didn't make a lot of money in 2001," said Jacob Schmidt, head of Allenbridge's hedge fund research unit, which tracks 2,100 funds. "We had extremely difficult markets in terms of volatility for stocks, bonds and currencies." 
The Weavering Capital Fund Ltd. lost more than 90 percent last year, mainly because it expected interest rates to fall less than they did, while the Argent Classic Convertible Arbitrage Fund gained 85 percent by investing in the debt of companies with lower credit ratings. The Quadriga GCT Futures fund rose 45 percent after betting stocks would fall. 
The Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 13 percent while the Nasdaq composite index and Europe's Dow Jones Stoxx 50 index each lost about 20 percent last year. Stock mutual funds in America and Europe had their biggest losses since 1974.
Three-month bills, regarded as the least risky fixed-income security, returned 4.4 percent last year, according to Merrill Lynch & Company indexes. That is also what Fidelity Cash Reserves, the biggest money market fund, earned for investors in 2001, according to iMoneynet, a research firm in Westborough, Mass.

HEADLINE: Airline to Close 5 Offices 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation's United Airlines unit said today that it would close five reservations offices and lay off 899 employees because of a soft economy, fewer flights and lower sales after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
 Four of the offices are in California and the fifth is in Illinois, the airline said. They will be closed effective Feb. 28. Some of the workers may be eligible to relocate to other offices of the airline. 
 United has reduced flight and seat capacity about 23 percent since Sept. 11. The airline said today that it had laid off 19,000 of the 100,000 workers it had before the attacks. UAL plans to anounce a recovery plan later this month.

HEADLINE: Incentives Prop Up Sales but May Haunt Carmakers Later 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Auto sales, propelled by low-cost financing, finished the year slightly below a record set in 2000, according to data released today. But expectations for 2002 are pessimistic because of the economy as well as the dent that the incentives have probably made in demand.
 Carmakers ended 2001 with sales of about 17.1 million vehicles, down slightly from the record 17.3 million in sales a year earlier. Few analysts expected such a strong performance last summer, when industry sales were lagging, and the Sept. 11 attacks all but halted showroom traffic. 
 But buyers came back in droves when the automakers, led by General Motors, introduced interest-free financing on many of their vehicles. Without the loan deals, industry officials estimate, the industry's selling pace for the fourth quarter would have been a tepid 15 million vehicles, on a seasonally adjusted annual basis.
Instead, the deals led to double-digit sales increases during the fall. But they came at a cost, for both the companies' pocketbooks, and, therefore, for their 2001 results and their 2002 sales.
Each loan cost the auto companies about $2,300 in lost interest payments. Moreover, analysts and executives estimate that about 500,000 sales were cannibalized from 2002, as people bought vehicles sooner than they had planned.
Forecasters say that if the economy recovers quickly, sales of about 15.9 million cars and trucks are expected this year. If it remains sluggish, they say, those expectations fall to about 15 million vehicles, a level not seen since 1996. "That's a million units gone -- vaporized," said James Hall, an auto industry analyst with AutoPacific Inc. in Southfield, Mich. 
Some auto executives predict that sales will be higher, even if their own economists do not agree. G.M. is forecasting industry sales of 15 million to 15.5 million, but that sober projection is rejected by William J. Lovejoy, G.M.'s group vice president for North American sales, service and marketing.
"I'm optimistic," he said today. "I think it will be stronger."
Mr. Lovejoy was glowing as G.M. claimed its first increase in overall market share since 1988, even though G.M., Ford and Chrysler all reported sales declines for 2001.
According to Ward's Automotive Reports, G.M. wound up with 28.34 percent of car and light-truck sales, a tiny increase of about 0.03 percent. That was still well below the 30 percent share that has long been the company's target.
G.M.'s market share peaked in 1960 at 60 percent, and the company -- trying to take advantage of financial problems at Ford and Chrysler -- has focused lately on regaining share, even at the expense of profits.
G.M., which led the industry into the fall's round of loan incentives and persisted even as its rivals cried foul over the cost, introduced a new incentive program today to replace its interest-free loan plan, which expired on Wednesday. 
Under the new program, G.M. is offering rebates of $2,002 on most models. Unlike the loan program, which was available only to the best credit risks, the new plan offers discounts to people leasing vehicles or paying cash. The rebates can also be coupled with discounted loans.
The plan is intended to maintain G.M.'s sales momentum, Mr. Lovejoy said. 
There were signs in December that the interest-free loans were losing their initial appeal. G.M., Ford and Chrysler reported only single-digit sales increases last month, compared with jumps of 30 percent and more in October and November, when the loans were still a novelty.
Officials at Ford and Chrysler, which will continue to offer interest-free financing plans into this month, said they would study the new G.M. program. James G. O'Connor, president of the Ford division, termed the plan "rich." Even so, the $2,002 rebates are less than the average cost of G.M.'s interest-free loans and smaller than the $2,500 discounts the company had already been offering on some vehicles.
The new deals are also far smaller than the rebates of up to $5,000 a car that auto companies have routinely promoted over the years during inventory clearance promotions at the end of the season.
Along with its market share increase, G.M. is claiming the crown as the industry's leader in truck sales. G.M. was slow to spot buyers' shift to pickups, sport utilities and minivans in the 1990's, but it has recently begun offering a new S.U.V. series that has helped propel the industry's truck sales past those of cars in 2001, for the first time. 
In December, 68 percent of G.M.'s sales were of light trucks, according to Mr. Lovejoy; for the year, the figure was about 58 percent of sales.
Ford's F-series pickup remained the industry's best-selling vehicle for the 25th consecutive year. Ford said it had sold more than 911,000 F-series trucks, the first time since 1972 that a single vehicle nameplate topped the 900,000 mark. Chevrolet's big sedans -- the Bel Air, Caprice and Impala -- were the last to achieve sales volume that high. Back then, G.M. counted the three as a single nameplate for sales purposes.
But the truck sales boom could not propel Detroit's Big Three companies to overall sales increases for the year. G.M.'s sales fell 1.1 percent, Ford's were off 5.5 percent, and Chrysler's sales dropped 10 percent.
The year was different for a number of foreign-based auto companies. Several of them set United States sales records in 2001 without having to offer widespread discounting. 
Audi, a division of Volkswagen; Volvo, owned by Ford; and BMW all set sales records, as did Toyota, with sales up 7.9 percent. 
Though analysts expect that Toyota could eventually surpass Chrysler to become the third-biggest company in the American market, Toyota ended 2001 about 400,000 vehicles behind Chrysler, with sales of 1.7 million cars and trucks. Toyota's Lexus brand remained the best-selling one in the luxury category for the second consecutive year.
But the Toyota Camry lost the best-selling-car title to the Honda Accord, which last held that crown a decade ago. Honda, which sold just over 411,000 Accords, said its American sales for the year had risen 4.2 percent, to just over 1.2 million.
Nissan, in the midst of a corporate overhaul under the guidance of Carlos Ghosn, the Renault executive dispatched to run the Japanese carmaker, said its sales for the year had dropped 6.5 percent, though sales proved to be stronger in December, thanks in part to the company's refurbished Altima sedan.
South Korean automakers, which focus on lower-priced vehicles, posted their best year ever in the United States. Hyundai, Kia, part of Hyundai, and Daewoo sold a collective 618,000 vehicles, the first time the three had topped the 600,000 mark.

HEADLINE: America The Polarized 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
When Congress returns to Washington, the battles will resume -- and each party will accuse the other of partisanship. Why can't they just get along?
 Because fundamental issues are at stake, and the parties are as far apart on those issues as they have ever been. 
 A recent article in Slate led me to Keith Poole and Howard Rosenthal, political scientists who use data on Congressional voting to create "maps" of politicians' ideological positions. They find that a representative's votes can be predicted quite accurately by his position in two dimensions, one corresponding to race issues, the other a left vs. right economic scale reflecting issues such as marginal tax rates and the generosity of benefits to the poor. 
And they also find -- not too surprisingly -- that the center did not hold. Ralph Nader may sneer at "Republicrats," but Democrats and Republicans have diverged sharply since the 1980's, and are now further apart on economic issues than they have been since the early 20th century.
Whose position changed? Tom Daschle doesn't seem markedly more liberal than, say, the late Tip O'Neill. On the other hand, Tom DeLay, who will soon be House majority leader, is clearly to the right of previous Republican leaders. In short, casual observation suggests that American politics has become polarized because Republicans have shifted to the right, and Democrats haven't followed them. And sure enough, the Poole-Rosenthal numbers that show a divergence between the parties also show that this divergence reflects a Republican move toward more conservative economic policies, while Democrats have more or less stayed put. As people like James Jeffords and Lincoln Chafee have found, it has become very hard to be what we used to call a moderate Republican. 
But why did the Republicans move to the right?
It could be a matter of sheer intellectual conviction. Republicans have realized that low taxes and small government are good for everyone, and Democrats just don't get it. But ideas tend to take root when the soil has been fertilized by social and economic trends. Dr. Poole suggests that the most likely source of political polarization is economic polarization: the sharply widening inequality of income and wealth. 
I know from experience that even mentioning income distribution leads to angry accusations of "class warfare," but anyway here's what the (truly) nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office recently found: Adjusting for inflation, the income of families in the middle of the U.S. income distribution rose from $41,400 in 1979 to $45,100 in 1997, a 9 percent increase. Meanwhile the income of families in the top 1 percent rose from $420,200 to $1.016 million, a 140 percent increase. Or to put it another way, the income of families in the top 1 percent was 10 times that of typical families in 1979, and 23 times and rising in 1997.
It would be surprising indeed if this tectonic shift in the economic landscape weren't reflected in politics. 
You might have expected the concentration of income at the top to provoke populist demands to soak the rich. But as I've said, both casual observation and the Poole-Rosenthal numbers tell us that the Democrats haven't moved left, the Republicans have moved right. Indeed, the Republicans have moved so far to the right that ordinary voters have trouble taking it in; as I pointed out in an earlier column, focus groups literally refused to believe accurate descriptions of the stimulus bill that House Republican leaders passed on a party-line vote back in October.
Why has the response to rising inequality been a drive to reduce taxes on the rich? Good question. It's not a simple matter of rich people voting themselves a better deal: there just aren't enough of them. To understand political trends in the United States we probably need to think about campaign finance, lobbying, and the general power of money to shape political debate.
In any case, the moral of this story is that the political struggles in Washington right now are not petty squabbles. The right is on the offensive; the left -- occupying the position formerly known as the center -- wants to hold the line. Many commentators still delude themselves with the comforting notion that all this partisanship is a temporary aberration. Sorry, guys: this is the way it's going to be, for the foreseeable future. Get used to it. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Long Reach of War in Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By SARITHA RAI

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Zameer Pasha, a 42-year-old Muslim, owns a small store in the heart of a Muslim neighborhood here. The store, Pan Plaza, sells American brands of soft drinks, ice cream and cigarettes, along with some locally made products, like cookies and chewing tobacco.
 It is thousands of miles away from Kabul, and Mr. Pasha has no known relatives in Afghanistan. 
 Still, as American-backed troops advanced there and as Afghans celebrated the toppling of the Taliban last month, Mr. Pasha reveled in every bit of the news -- news that meant a local Muslim boycott of American-made goods would soon end and it would be business as usual for him.
"It is a relief that people are thirsting for Coke and Pepsi again," Mr. Pasha said recently, even as he prayed that another war would not break out closer to home, between the nuclear-armed rivals India and Pakistan.
Mr. Pasha's store and hundreds of other businesses across the country had been caught in an unexpected business upheaval when Muslim leaders in India called for a boycott of American products after the aerial strikes on Afghanistan began in October. Buying and selling such products constitutes support of the United States and, indirectly, its bombing of civilians in Afghanistan, the leaders said.
Sales in Mr. Pasha's shop plummeted. His profit from the bulk of the business, the sale of soft drinks -- mostly Coke and Pepsi -- had been about 200 rupees ($4.25) a day; it fell by half.
Though the boycott was supposed to be voluntary, the pressure was intense. And Mr. Pasha was torn between devotion to his community and having to earn a living. If he had to give up stocking soft drinks, he, his wife and their three children would have faced rough times. He would probably not have been able to pay the 1,000 rupees ($21.27) monthly rent on his store or keep his business profitable solely by selling locally made odds and ends. 
Mr. Pasha spent anxious nights after locals from his community came to his door several times exhorting him to stop selling American products. The list of boycotted goods included everything from soaps to toothpaste, branded jeans to cigarettes, even cars and credit cards. The Muslim leaders were asking that shoppers substitute Indian products for American brands.
At the height of the war, sales of American products fell in hundreds of small stores in cities with sizable Muslim populations, like Bangalore and Mumbai. The slump was pronounced in shops selling Coke and Pepsi, the most visible American brands in India, controlling the bulk of the country's $1.1 billion soft drink market.
Coke's Indian subsidiary employs nearly 6,000 people and sells the drink from thousands of coolers across the country. The boycott had very little impact on Coke's soft drink sales, said Nantoo Banerjee, director of communications for Coca-Cola India. But, he added: "Tens of thousands of people in India live on products such as ours. Boycotts such as these threaten local jobs and affect the local economy."
Though only 12 percent of the population in Hindu-dominated India is Muslim, that equals around 120 million potential customers in the world's second-most-populous country. And the longer the war lasted, the more businesses were likely to be hit.
But the tide of the war and the local sentiment soon turned. As the boycott pinched, some Muslims started asking questions. "Why should we lose business over something going on between America and Afghanistan so far away?" asked Salim Khan, a Muslim who manages a restaurant called Rock Garden on the bustling Infantry Road in downtown Bangalore.
In Mr. Khan's restaurant, which serves Chinese and Indian food, the effects of the boycott were minimal. Not so for Mr. Pasha's store. The boycott had started just before Ramadan, the high season for soft-drink sales. Muslims typically break their ritual fast with a feast of lamb biryani downed with bottles of Coke or Pepsi.
Mr. Pasha's business suffered further because it is just around the corner from a mosque. Every Friday after the prayers, he could hear the moulvis -- priests who lead the prayers -- call on the faithful to shun American brands.
At home, too, Mr. Pasha was under siege. His 14-year-old son, Zamit, who regularly attends Friday Prayers, had not only stopped drinking Coke and Pepsi but had persuaded two younger siblings to do the same. "Every week, empty soft drinks crates used to be returned from my home but not anymore," Mr. Pasha said at the height of the boycott.
In another Bangalore neighborhood, another Muslim businessman, Syed Afzal, had been quick to bow to the order laid out by the ulemas, or Muslim scholars. Mr. Afzal owns Cool Point, a company that distributed 6,000 bottles of mostly American brands of soft drinks a day to small stores in his neighborhood. He said he had canceled his PepsiCo distributorship at the end of October and had stopped taking in Coke as well.
Mr. Afzal, who employs 20 people, all Muslims, said his workers also took a voluntary 50 percent cut in their daily wages. "They said they would take 50 rupees instead of 100 ($2.12), a sacrifice for the sake of the innocent civilians in Afghanistan," Mr. Afzal said.
When his community leaders directed him to buy Indian, Mr. Afzal began a search for a domestic soft drink that could make up for the business lost because of the boycott of the multinational favorites. The daunting task was made even tougher by the fact that the biggest Indian soft drink brand, Thums Up, had been bought by Coca-Cola a few years earlier.
As his search for that elusive Indian soft drink replacement became intense, news trickled in that the Taliban had been defeated by the United States' vigorous air strikes.
A relieved Mr. Afzal revived his Coke and Pepsi distributorships. Other retailers who had sworn never to stock Pepsi and Coke also softened as Afghans celebrated the defeat of the Taliban with singing and dancing on the streets.
Mr. Afzal ruminated on the excesses of the Taliban regime. "They wronged their own people -- our religion is not so rigid," he said.
Since business has returned to normal, Mr. Afzal is abandoning his search for a popular Indian replacement.
Still, "it's been over 50 years since independence and we don't have a soft drink that can outsell the American ones," he rued. Then he smiled. "Maybe when we have an Indian brand as big as Pepsi or Coke, we could revive this ban."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Argentina Is Preparing For Currency Devaluation
With a substantial devaluation of their currency now certain, Argentines braced for the worst as President Eduardo Duhalde and his newly appointed cabinet discussed ways to cushion the blow and avoid a repetition of the riots and protests that toppled his predecessor.
 Economists and political leaders predict that the government will lower the exchange rate of the peso, which has been valued at one to one with the dollar for the last decade, by 30 percent to 40 percent. A formal announcement is expected as early as today. Page A4. 

Newmont Raises Bid for Normandy
Newmont Mining of Denver sweetened its bid for Normandy Mining of Australia to $2.2 billion and appeared set to win the contest for the company after AngloGold of South Africa bowed out. World Business, Section W.

Wasserstein Makes Moves at Lazard
Bruce Wasserstein, the new chief executive at Lazard, the largest privately held investment bank, named four deputy chairmen. He also plans to distribute equity to the firm's 140 partners worldwide in an attempt to halt defections. The firm's existing partners will share about 36 percent of the company's equity, and there will be a separate pool, equal to about 24 percent of the company, that will be reserved for future partners. Mr. Wasserstein said he would also add employees in the United States and Europe, including a dozen partners in New York over the next six months. C3.

Little Savings Seen in Drug Cards
Federal investigators said that drug discount cards of the type proposed by President Bush had not significantly cut costs for elderly consumers buying brand-name medicines in metropolitan areas. A16.

Europeans Warmly Accept the Euro
At supermarkets and stores across Europe, the transition to euro notes and coins has been almost seamless. The European Commission estimates that 60 million people now have at least some euro notes and about 200 million have a supply of the new coins. A8.

Rates Left Unchanged in Europe
Policy makers at the European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged even though the economic outlook for the first half of the year remains bleak. World Business, Section W.

Comcast Copes With Web Trouble
Comcast said that it had "for the most part" solved problems that caused Internet and e-mail failures for about 7,000 customers in New Jersey, though some customers say the company has played down the extent of the problems. The problems occurred as Comcast switched Internet customers onto its own network from a network operated by Excite@Home, which declared bankruptcy. Shares of Comcast fell 30 cents, to $35.61. C2.

Career Company Faces Complaints
Hundreds of customers of Bernard Haldane Associates, which describes itself as the nation's oldest and largest career-management company, have complained about its practices to 11 state attorneys general. C3.

Jobless Claims Rise Unexpectedly
The number of the nation's workers filing new claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly surged during the last full week of 2001, the Labor Department reported. C5.

Disney to Close 50 More Stores
Walt Disney plans to close 50 more stores as it continues to revamp its retail unit, which has held down earnings in recent years. The company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, said Disney was poised for growth when the economy turned around. C3.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Vision For Ground Zero: Memorial and More 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the head of the commission charged with rebuilding Lower Manhattan said yesterday that the World Trade Center site was unlikely to be transformed mainly into a memorial to the victims of the terrorist attack -- an idea former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promoted just last week.
 Instead, Mr. Bloomberg, in his third day as mayor, and John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation, said they both supported using the 16-acre site for office space, a memorial to the victims and other uses, perhaps including retail space. 
 At a news conference at City Hall yesterday, after a meeting between the mayor and 8 of the 11 members of the redevelopment corporation's board, Mr. Whitehead also cautioned that he did not envision the development of any giant office towers at the site. 
"I think there is a developing consensus -- among everybody I've talked to -- that it is not either practical or appropriate to build another 100-story building," Mr. Whitehead said. 
The announcements seemed to be another effort by the new mayor to set distinctions between his ideas for the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan and his predecessor's. 
In his farewell address last week at St. Paul's Chapel, steps from the trade center site, Mayor Giuliani said that "we shouldn't think about this site out there, right beyond us, right here, as a site for economic development."
Rather, he said, a "soaring, monumental, beautiful" memorial should be pursued first. "And then if we do that part right, then the economic development will just happen," he added. Office space could be built "in a lot of different places," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Whitehead has embraced the idea of giving first priority to the design of a memorial. But yesterday, he said that "the size of the plot is not nearly as important as what appears on the plot." 
And when pressed to put emotions aside and consider whether the city needed some development there, given the size of the site and the value of real estate in Manhattan, Mr. Whitehead answered, "Yes, I think we do." 
"It must be the appropriate size," he said. "We'll be trying to determine that after consultation with everyone, including the families of the victims, of course."
In addition, he said, some of the office space will have to be rebuilt, even though Wall Street and the economy in general are currently in a recession. 
"We will need, before long, more office space," to replace some of the the 10 million square feet of space lost in the trade center attacks, Mr. Whitehead said. 
Mr. Bloomberg, too, noted that Mr. Giuliani had floated the idea of using the trade center site primarily for a memorial. But he said the redevelopment corporation "was appointed to look at all of the different possibilities."
"That's certainly one of the possibilities," he said. But he added that the board also represented "a number of interested parties," including people who live in the neighborhoods around the site and who have stores, businesses or jobs there. Their interests, too, must be taken into account in consideration of the site's future, he said.
Mr. Whitehead offered few other details of the 80-minute meeting with the mayor, or of any decisions reached by the redevelopment corporation since its formation more than a month ago. 
The group has yet to select an executive director to guide its daily operations. Mr. Whitehead said the redevelopment board would announce "in the next few days" the appointment of at least a half-dozen advisory panels. 
Separate groups of advisers will represent the interests of the families of victims, downtown residents, commuters to the downtown business district, the big Wall Street firms, developers, retail shopkeepers, and arts and cultural organizations, he said. 
Any priorities set by the board are also likely to reflect the desires of Gov. George E. Pataki, who appointed seven of its members. The other four were selected by Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Bloomberg shrugged off the suggestion yesterday that his interests might not be represented on the board. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani "did run by me all of their appointees," he said, and he did not have any objections.
