HEADLINE: City Faces Challenge to Close Widest Budget Gap Since 70's 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON and MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Suddenly, it's over. New York City's days of simultaneously cutting taxes, spending more and still managing to have billions of dollars left over at the end of each year have come to an abrupt halt, a victim of the recession, the fizzling of the Wall Street boom and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. 
 The city is facing a budget gap of $3 billion to $5 billion in the fiscal year beginning this July -- roughly a tenth of its total budget. It is the largest next-year gap the city has had to close since the late 1970's, when it was still dealing with the fallout of the fiscal crisis. 
 It is a daunting challenge, one that is made all the more difficult by a hard truth of budgeting: the city typically faces pressure to spend the most when it has the least, because as the economy sours, more people turn to the city for help. In fact, after a long decline, the welfare rolls and unemployment had already started to edge up again in the final months of 2001. 
But for all the difficulties, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can take at least a bit of solace: budget monitors and analysts say that the fiscal problems are far from insurmountable this year.
The city is still in fundamentally better shape than it was during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and it is at almost no risk of defaulting on its obligations to debtors, budget monitors say. As long as the recession does not drag into next year, the city should be able to get through this coming budget year without extreme sacrifices, current and former city budget officials said.
City government jobs will be left unfilled. There will most likely be cuts again in spending for libraries, cultural institutions and city parks, among other areas. In labor talks, the city will be under pressure to limit raises it offers to police officers and teachers, who make up 53 percent of the city's work force. New city government programs and major construction projects will probably be delayed and other recently expanded city initiatives rolled back, budget monitors predicted.
But a review of city finances shows that it should be possible to close the gap without severely curtailing basic city services, laying off large numbers of city employees or imposing tax increases as large as those of the early 1990's.
"I'm not trying to say at all that this is going to be a walk in the park," said Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service. "There are tough decisions that are going to have to be made, but I think the city has a long record of making those decisions and of getting to balance."
Much of the flexibility comes as a result of hundreds of millions of dollars -- perhaps more than $1 billion -- worth of budget maneuvers that could create one-time savings for the city to help it get through this difficult year. Several of these so-called one-shots require approval from Congress or Albany, which is far from guaranteed. But many of them, including the use of debt reserve funds and the sale of city property, are expected to surface in several weeks, when Mr. Bloomberg issues his first budget plan for the 2003 fiscal year, which starts this July.
The city, in the final months of the Giuliani administration, also took some important steps to ease the coming austerity by making sure that the current fiscal year ends on June 30 without a deficit and perhaps even a sizable surplus.
And perhaps most promising, while the city's economy today is far worse than it has been since at least the early 1990's, the drop since the Sept. 11 attack has not been as precipitous as some had feared. As a result, while tax revenues will still be down for the fiscal year, they will not have dropped nearly as much as some had predicted.
Whatever relief this all provides, the era in which the city taxpayers delivered so much money that a mayor could cut taxes, increase spending at twice the rate of inflation and still finish the year with record budget surpluses is, at least for now, a piece of history. The ultimate test here, economists and fiscal monitors said, will not merely be balancing the 2003 fiscal year budget. It will be balancing the 2004 fiscal year budget, if the economy does not turn around by then, as all of the budget tricks may have already been pulled out of the bag.

Awesome Reckonings
New York City is a $40-billion-a-year enterprise, a government of such reach and responsibility that each year it spends more money than most states and some small nations. Its 40,000-member Police Department is the largest municipal force in the country, as is its school system, which educates more than a million students. The city government over all employs a quarter of a million people, equaling the population of Louisville, Ky.
All this means that when the reckoning comes -- as it has least at once for each of the mayors who have served the city over the last 35 years -- the budget deficit that has to be avoided is similarly awesome.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, on his last day in office, estimated the 2003 fiscal year budget gap at $2.9 billion. Alan G. Hevesi, the former city comptroller, says it ranges from $3.9 billion to $4.3 billion. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, citing potential risks in the city's long-term plan, says it could be as high as $4.1 billion. Mr. Bloomberg said this week that he anticipated a $4 billion gap. Whatever it turns out to be, that is not good news; even at the lowest guess, the gap is nearly 10 percent of city taxpayer-financed revenues.
In its simplest terms, the projected budget deficit means the city is expecting to spend more money than it anticipates it will take in.
The World Trade Center disaster, of course, is a major factor. The nation has been in a recession since March, but for most of the past year the city's economy was still doing notably better than the rest of the country's.
The attack drove the city into a deeper recession than the nation. The New York Stock Exchange was closed for four days. Flights were suspended, and when they resumed, many passengers stayed earthbound, hurting the airline industry, local businesses connected to it, and tourism. As large downtown businesses remained closed or relocated, the small businesses that served them suffered painfully.
The city lost 94,700 jobs in October and November alone, leading budget monitors to predict that despite large job gains in the beginning of 2001, the city would end the year with roughly 3.7 million jobs, the same total it had when the year started. And during 2002, economists expect employment in the city to be nearly flat or, in the worst case, to drop by 114,000 jobs.
The danger is not merely of Wall Street jobs' moving to New Jersey and Connecticut, but of city businesses' laying off workers and even closing their doors for good. The confluence of the recession and the losses from terrorism, among other matters, means that the city is bracing for a sharp decline in expected tax revenues -- about $1.3 billion less this fiscal year.
Tax revenues are expected to pick up again slightly in the 2003 fiscal year, beginning in July, but are not anticipated to reach the soaring growth rates of the late 1990's.
To many budget monitors, the city's fiscal trouble started long before the attacks. These budget watchdog groups say that the just-departed Mayor Giuliani deserves a fair share of the blame.
When Mr. Giuliani arrived in office in 1994, also a time when the city was in an economic bind, he quickly established a reputation as a fiscal conservative by cutting back many city services, from street cleaning to the maintenance of city parks. As a result, during his first three years, the city's full-time work force dropped by about 20,000 to about 235,000, with particularly large dips among social service agencies.
But as his tenure at City Hall continued, he loosened the budget belt more than just a bit. City spending over the last five full budget years increased by an average of 5.3 percent per year, or more than twice the rate of inflation. During that time, the city payroll surged, returning to early 1990 levels. The city work force now includes far more police officers and teachers and fewer social workers. There also are tens of thousands more part-time workers today and more private contractors doing work once performed by city employees.
Mr. Giuliani succeeded in increasing the work force and expanding city services while simultaneously cutting taxes because of the skyrocketing tax revenues that generated giant surpluses in the mid-to-late 1990's. His administration used the huge surpluses to balance the budget in the following fiscal years.
Budget monitors had warned him for many years that relying on those surpluses to pay basic bills was a flawed strategy. It would not be unlike stockbrokers, or dot-com workers, who leased expensive apartments with their chunky bonuses and then had trouble paying the exorbitant rents as Wall Street slumped. 
"For the city, it was a big fiscal mistake," said Charles Brecher, research director at the Citizens Budget Commission. "The problem, of course, is once it exhausts the surplus, the people it hired are still on the payroll."
Other steps taken during the Giuliani years increased the pressure. After years of unexpectedly large returns from city pension fund investments, thanks to the rise in the stock market, the city took advantage of those gains by cutting its payments -- amounting to $800 million over two years -- to the pension fund system. Mr. Hevesi warned two years ago that this windfall should be saved in case the stock market dropped, which would require higher pension contributions, or that the money might be saved for a general buffer against a cooling economy. His warnings turned out to be true.
Finally, during the last eight years, the city took on much more debt to pay for all the new courthouses, schools and other government buildings and expanded or new cultural institutions that Mr. Giuliani made commitments during his tenure to build. Those promises now mean higher annual payments to pay off this increased debt.
Adam L. Barsky, who was Mr. Giuliani's last budget director, defended their spending plans, saying that the city government never spent more than it could afford, and at the same time cut taxes by billions of dollars.
"We are leaving the next mayor with a surplus in the current year's budget and a road map" for closing future gaps, he said.

Not Shy About Warnings
One result of the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's was the creation of a number of boards to monitor the budget. Altogether, the budget is now monitored by the state's Financial Control Board, the state comptroller's office, the city comptroller's office and groups like the Independent Budget Office and the Citizens Budget Commission. 
None are shy about warning of coming deficits. In fact, Mr. Hevesi in late 1998 predicted a deficit totaling as much as $2.3 billion in the 2000 fiscal year, which instead ended with the largest surplus in city history, $3.2 billion. The Giuliani administration, not surprisingly, took particular umbrage at their predictions, disparaging the warnings as the work of back-seat drivers at best and political enemies or opportunists at worst.
The record surplus occurred in part because the Wall Street boom surpassed everyone's expectations, and in part because the Giuliani administration was intentionally conservative in projecting tax revenues. But by sounding alarms, these watchdog groups may have paved the way for the kind of actions that helped to close that budget gap.
This year, though, the monitors are warning that the situation really is serious. The big gaps are not two years down the line. Last month the city passed a package of spending reductions and newly found revenue sources to close a $1.3 billion gap in the current year's budget.
"This one is serious," said Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, who noted that the city is confronting a structural imbalance -- its spending is outstripping its revenues -- during a national recession at a time when the local economy is reeling from terrorist attacks.
And compared with others of recent years, the gap is large. 
An analysis by the Citizens Budget Commission in early December put the 2003 shortfall at 10 percent to 16 percent of all city-financed spending. That is not as bad as the fiscal crisis of 1975, when Abraham D. Beame was mayor and the city had to borrow the equivalent of 19 percent of its spending.
But the analysis found that it is worse than in other recent fiscal crises. During Mayor Edward I. Koch's first term, he had to close budget shortfalls of roughly 10 percent of city spending. The gaps that Mayor David N. Dinkins had to close were not that large, but came during a recession when tax revenues were plummeting even as social spending obligations were growing. And Mayor Giuliani had to close a gap of more than 8 percent in the first full year following his inauguration. 
The budget commission concludes that "the problem confronting Mayor Bloomberg is greater than any since the mid-1970's fiscal crisis under Mayor Beame."
Other analysts, however, paint a brighter picture. They note that the city is healthier today than in past years, as even the most dire predictions of job losses expected during the current recession are modest compared with losses in earlier slumps. Crime is still way down. New York today is still considered to be a more attractive place to work and live, said Mr. Kurtter, who rates bonds for cities and states nationwide.
Federal disaster recovery aid will certainly help the city, both in the short and long term, with one city estimate suggesting that over the next decade it could generate 136,000 jobs and nearly $900 million in city tax revenues. But that estimate assumes the city will get a total of $20 billion in aid, a figure that is not yet assured. So the ultimate impact and pace of the benefit will depend on how quickly Lower Manhattan is rebuilt and how much and how quickly federal aid arrives.
Low bond interest rates, experts say, will certainly help the city save on major construction projects.

Many Possible Solutions
So, how can a deficit of this magnitude be overcome?
The city has already taken some major steps to increase revenues: it decided to withdraw a $200 million tax cut package that seemed unlikely to win approval in Albany, and then decided not to extend a cut in the personal income tax surcharge adopted in 2000 and costing about $350 million a year. 
Following are other ways to free up millions, some of which are already planned in the 2003 budget. 
*The leftover surplus at the end of June could range from $126 million to as much as $1 billion, city budget officials say, depending on how badly tax revenues slide and other factors. 
*About $100 million or more could be realized through refinancing some of the city's $40 billion outstanding debt. But that would require loosening federal restrictions on municipal debt and easing some of the rules imposed by the city comptroller's office.
*A sale of the city's Off-Track Betting Corporation parlors could fetch $250 million, but would require legislative approval, which is not certain. And city labor unions are fiercely opposed to the sale.
*As much as $200 million could be freed up through an early retirement incentive and a severance package for city employees -- which work only if the positions remain unfilled. Part of this package needs approval by the state and the labor unions. A probable selective hiring freeze could save another $150 million.
*There are other, relatively painless potential savings -- taking about $30 million from the city jails, which have about 25 percent fewer inmates than five years ago, or having the Sanitation Department pick up recyclables every other week instead of once a week, saving roughly $15 million. 
*One of the proposed one-shot deals involves the entity that bailed the city out of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's: the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created to issue debt for the city when the bond markets shut it out. In 2003, the city wants to take $250 million from the corporation's reserve fund.
*Easing federal requirements for how the city pays for welfare programs, and increasing the share of Medicaid costs borne by the state and federal governments, could save the city hundreds of millions of dollars. Both proposals have been submitted to the state and federal governments, but are far from assured. 
*An amnesty program, followed by an aggressive tax collection drive, could yield tens of millions that the city is owed from past years but has remained uncollected.

'All of the Above'
To Mr. Barsky, the options listed above are all on the table and probably necessary. "The answer to this question is 'all of the above,' " he said.
Mayor Bloomberg has consistently ruled out raising taxes, saying during his inaugural address: "We cannot drive people and business out of New York. We cannot raise taxes. We will find another way." But before the year is out, some tax measures are almost sure to be discussed.
For example, if the city property tax rate, which has remained constant for a decade, were increased an average of $100 per household per year, it would generate about $500 million in extra city revenues.
While ratings agencies and budget monitors typically frown on one-shot deals to close budget shortfalls, several said in interviews that they would be more willing to tolerate them this year, given the circumstances, than they would in normal years. Still, they cautioned that in taking such actions, the city should carefully consider the future costs.
"If they have a menu of gimmicks, and with each one an associated cost, they will have to make the choices that maximize the benefit in closing the gap but minimize the cost in the coming years," said Dr. Marcia Van Wagner, the chief economist for the Citizens Budget Commission. 
Mr. Barsky predicted that several moves would drive down the shortfall to roughly $1.5 billion. 
It is that number, give or take a bit, that the difficult spending cuts will have to make up for. Parks, libraries and cultural institutions, as well as social service programs like day care and services for the elderly, are often among the first to go. Efforts to reduce classroom sizes and invest in low-cost housing would also most likely be deferred. 
Maintenance projects to repair the city's roads and bridges could be put off, but that often leads to increased costs later. And capital projects -- to build courthouses, cultural institutions and other public facilities -- could be postponed. For each billion dollars in capital spending that is put off, the city can save $60 million to $100 million in debt service annually, city officials said.
But getting through June 2003 is one thing. Getting through the year after that, if the economy does not improve, is quite another.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York predicts that the regional recession will end in the final quarter of this year, but that the economy will remain extremely weak. If that is the case, and hundreds of millions of dollars in one-time deals are no longer available to close the budget gap, the city will face particular stress. 
"If the recession lasts into 2003," Mr. Kurtter of Moody's said, "that's when the fiscal fabric of the city really starts to tear."

HEADLINE: Agencies Say Relocation of Survivors' Aid Center Comes as a Surprise 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday afternoon that the comprehensive social services center set up on Pier 94 for people left jobless, homeless, bereaved or injured by the attack on the World Trade Center would shut down today, and that a similar center would open in a city-owned downtown building on Monday.
 He said that many of the leaders of organizations that have been offering economic, legal and emotional help at the Pier 94 center were "ecstatic" about the move. 
 But representatives of the various agencies said yesterday that they had not been told about the closing or the move. They said they would have appreciated more notice. 
The new center will be situated at 51 Chambers Street, a 13,000-square-foot space that used to be an Emigrant Savings Bank branch. Like the Pier 94 center, it will be a social services version of one-stop shopping, said Jonathan D. Greenspun, commissioner of the Community Assistance Unit. Most of the 15 or so agencies at Pier 94 -- which included the Red Cross, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Safe Horizons, the Salvation Army and a chaplains' center -- will have stations there, he said.
Mr. Greenspun said that agency representatives were told at a meeting Wednesday evening about the closing. But officials of the Red Cross, Safe Horizons and the Salvation Army said that references to the closing were vague. The Red Cross learned of the moving date only yesterday afternoon, said Nancy Rutherford, an agency spokeswoman.
And Becky Michaels of Safe Horizons said: "There's been an ever-liquid end date. But it hadn't ever been concrete."
Mr. Greenspun said that the relocation of the center was necessary to accommodate a trade show scheduled to open at Pier 94 in 10 days.
Employees who arrived at Pier 94 yesterday expecting a typical day encountered workers packing equipment that the agencies had been using. The Rev. Bill Minson found that the curtains surrounding the chaplains' station had been removed. "We had to ask them to please put them up again and leave them until the end of the day," he said.
Employees said they had long known that Pier 94 was a temporary site and had heard rumors of various moving dates, but that the timing had come as a surprise.
"I'm in shock," said a volunteer at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. "Where are we going to go now? We've been here all these months, through all these emotional times and now -- poof! I think we deserved some ceremony in closing this."
Agency officials and employees also said they were worried that certain advantages of the Pier 94 center might be lost in the move. In particular, they were concerned that there might not be space for some agencies at the new location. The proximity of the various agencies was one of the best features of the Pier 94 center, said Maj. George Polarek, a Salvation Army commander. "We got to know each other," he said. "We could walk clients to another agency and stay with them through the entire process."
Also important to many agency workers was the preservation of the remembrance wall at Pier 94, covered with hundreds of letters, drawings and posters of the missing. Mr. Greenspun said that the photos, posters and letters would be taken off the wall and eventually exhibited at the Museum of the City of New York.
He also said that most agencies would be given space at the Chambers Street building but that some of the specialized services, like hot meals and DNA sampling to help identify victims, might not be available. Signs will be posted at the Pier 94 site about the new downtown center and information will be posted on World Trade Center Web sites, Mr. Greenspun said. 
Mr. Minson, the chaplain, said that in the long run, the move would probably be a good thing. But it would have been better, he said, to give employees, volunteers and family members more time to say goodbye to a center that has been the focus of so much grief.
"We experienced a lot of emotions here," he said. "We've given a lot of comfort and felt a lot of stress."

HEADLINE: Disney Plans More Cutbacks As Chief Forecasts Rebound 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
The chairman of the Walt Disney Company, Michael D. Eisner, acknowledged today that he, like many shareholders, was disappointed with Disney's stock price, but said it was poised for growth when the economy turned around.
 In his annual letter to shareholders, Mr. Eisner vowed to shave costs further. He forecast that when Disney's fiscal year ends in September, its money-losing Internet operations will show a profit. 
 "We are now officially in a recession, and people have less disposable income for travel," Mr. Eisner wrote. "However, when the economy does come back, and as confidence in America's safety continues to grow, there is every reason to believe that the performance at our parks will be stronger than ever."
Mr. Eisner said Disney would close 50 more Disney Stores as it continues to revamp its retail unit. Disney aims to drop the number of stores to 300 to 400 in North America from more than 600 in fiscal 1997.
But analysts said the big questions for Disney in 2002 were whether and when Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland and California Adventure in Southern California would bounce back from the tourism slump after the Sept. 11 attacks and the recession.
Second to theme park attendance is the timing of a rebound at Disney's ABC television network, which has suffered from a severe advertising slump and a steep ratings decline because it currently lacks the kind of hit it had in 2000 with the game show "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." This year, the popularity of "Millionaire" faded.
A Prudential analyst, Kathy Styponias, said Disney "is doing as much as it can on the cost side" of the theme park business, and it should be poised for a rebound "as consumers feel more comfortable with flying and traveling."
She added, "With ABC, the company is facing different issues. The ability to turn that around is a long process."
She said Disney needed to use Hollywood's TV development talent outside ABC's own programming executives, if necessary, to find a winning program.
Disney's major cost-cutting efforts in 2001 included reductions of some 4,000 positions -- many at the theme parks -- primarily through voluntary resignations.
The cutbacks, however, failed to overcome the triple blow of a recession, an ad slump and the Sept. 11 attacks. Disney earnings in fiscal 2001, ended Sept. 30, plummeted to $120 million, before accounting changes, versus $920 million in 2000.
After accounting adjustments, Disney reported a net loss of $158 million in fiscal 2001, and its stock sank, too.
Disney rose 67 cents today, to $22.12.

HEADLINE: At the Election Year Starting Line 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Worried about President Bush's wartime popularity, Democrats are beginning a concerted election year drive to criticize his stewardship of the economy and portray themselves as the party of job growth and fiscal responsibility.
 Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, will start the offensive in a speech here on Friday, trying to frame the debate over the budget and recession three weeks before Mr. Bush's State of the Union address. 
 Mr. Daschle, of South Dakota, is to set out a seven-point Democratic program for growth, including a tax credit for businesses that add workers and a package of unemployment insurance and health benefits for displaced workers. He will sharply criticize the $1.35 trillion tax cut enacted last year as the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's legislative program. 
The House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, is to amplify the themes in his own speech just before the State of the Union address. And the Democratic National Committee is deploying lawmakers and local elected officials across the country this month to talk about the recession and the federal budget.
Mr. Bush, keenly aware that his father lost his re-election bid because he was viewed as detached from domestic concerns, is not planning to cede the debate. He is to travel to California and Oregon on Saturday to sell his proposals for tax cuts and unemployment aid under the banner of "economic security.'
The Democratic drive occurs at the start of an election-year struggle for control of both houses of Congress, and Republicans and Democrats alike say the economy will be a dominant concern. Efforts to pass an economic stimulus package collapsed last month in partisan finger-pointing. Leaders of both parties said they would revisit the issue when Congress reconvenes this month.
On Friday, the government is to release employment figures for December that are likely to show a substantial increase in unemployment for the third month in a row.
In the text of his speech, Mr. Daschle faults Mr. Bush's tax cut for consuming the budget surplus, saying, "At a time when we need to fight both a war and a recession, when our nation has urgent needs on all fronts, the tax cut has taken away our flexibility and left us with only two choices, both of them bad." 
The choices, the speech says, are to "shortchange critical needs such as strengthening homeland security" or "raid the Social Security surplus."
Although Democrats consider bread-and-butter issues as one of their strengths, polls show that many voters fault the Sept. 11 attacks and not Mr. Bush for the disappearance of budget surpluses. The polls also indicate that Democrats have lost the edge that they gained in the Clinton years as the party most trusted to start the economy moving.
"Some of the pre-Clinton perceptions are coming back," said Al From, head of the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist group.
Grappling with Mr. Bush's high approval ratings, Democrats are also seeking other lines of attack. They have revived arguments that the Republicans favor special interests. Several Democratic senators announced an inquiry this week into the collapse of Enron, the giant energy company with close ties to the Bush administration. Democratic strategists are trying to use the troubles that led to Enron's bankruptcy as a metaphor for mismanagement that they can apply to the tax cut.
"Sure you can argue no one foresaw Sept. 11," said Mark Mellman, a pollster for the Democratic Congressional leadership. "But it's also true that Democrats said there are events you can't foresee, that you have to plan for them. That's the very definition of mismanagement at a fundamental level when you don't plan for the future."
Yet the Democrats face deep splits over going beyond criticism of Mr. Bush and pushing to delay or roll back part of the 10-year tax cut. Without such a move, it will prove difficult for Democrats to pay for their priorities like education, benefits for prescription drugs or increased domestic security.
The Democrats' problem is that Republicans could once again paint them as a party of big taxers. Republicans are virtually daring the Democrats to try to undo the tax cut.
"If they think it was so bad, why don't they call for its repeal?" asked Representative Thomas M. Davis III, the Virginia Republican who heads his party's campaign effort in the House. "They don't have the guts to do it."
Mr. Daschle has repeatedly said an effort to roll back the tax cut would be pointless, because Mr. Bush and House Republicans would oppose it. His aides acknowledge that Mr. Daschle would also face difficulties because 12 Senate Democrats voted for the final tax-cut plan, and half of them face elections this year.
In the House, there is more sentiment among Democrats for taking on the tax cut to frame the budget debate as a choice of tax cuts for the wealthiest versus investments in popular programs.
Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, has introduced legislation intended to save $100 billion over 10 years by repealing a new reduction in the top marginal tax rate and restoring it to 39.6 percent. Mr. Frank argues that Democratic senators could justify a change in position.
"The answer is, We voted for it before Sept. 11," he said. "Now we have to spend hundreds of billions over the period of this tax cut on defense to pay for this war and for protecting the water supply and the public health system. Sept. 11 changed things." 
The maneuvering begins an election year that is widely expected to be deeply partisan despite the unity over the war. Republicans need to win one more seat to regain control of the Senate. Democrats are six seats short of controlling the House.
Both parties are polling on perceptions of the economy.
"If the playing field in November is going to be favorable to Democrats, it will only be because we've gotten the economic issue right," Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, said.
Democrats are trying to draw attention to the disappearance of surpluses, once estimated to grow as high as $5.6 trillion over the decade.
"The Republicans," Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Party chairman, said, "have taken a budget that had surpluses as far as the eye can see and now have turned them into deficits as far as the eye can see."
Mr. McAuliffe said Democrats would be striking the theme in news conferences and appearances, but not in television advertisements. Still, he did not preclude turning to the airwaves after Mr. Bush's budget comes out next month.
Republican strategists counter that Americans attribute the disappearing surplus to the post-Sept. 11 need to prosecute the war and spend more on security. And they are advising the party to do everything it can to emphasize that idea.
A Republican pollster, Bill McInturff, said he was telling clients: "You'd better say right now: We had a horrible terrorist attack. It hurt the economy, and we have to spend billions of dollars to keep the public safe.
"We need to say this with equal force and weight day after day after day."

HEADLINE: The Enron Post-Mortem 

 BODY:
The most spectacular corporate demise ever cannot remain a befuddling mystery. In order to restore confidence in American capitalism and in the integrity of its financial markets, the public needs to understand what brought Enron down so suddenly last year. How could the Houston-based energy company, ranked seventh on the Fortune 500 list of America's largest companies, and often touted as one of its most innovative, fail so unexpectedly, wiping out $60 billion in shareholder value? 
 Congress is appropriately holding a number of hearings to seek answers to that question. Enron's financial bankruptcy, triggered in part by revelations of faulty financial reporting, was a shocking national calamity. Its post-mortem, which will take the form of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation and private lawsuits as well as the Congressional hearings, is likely to reveal serious deficiencies in how the public interest is protected on an array of regulatory fronts. It may lead to new federal regulations of pension plans, accounting procedures and energy markets. 
 On Capitol Hill, calls for an inquiry have come from both sides of the aisle, though Democrats clearly have an added incentive to pursue the matter. No company has more generously backed President Bush throughout his political career than Enron. Its chairman, Kenneth Lay, was among the influential advisers to Vice President Dick Cheney's secretive energy task force last spring. Even before Enron's implosion, the General Accounting Office, acting at the behest of some Democratic legislators, sought documents from Mr. Cheney about the task force's meetings and its participants' agenda. The vice president's office was uncooperative. 
At his Crawford ranch on Monday President Bush supported Congress's right to look into Enron's collapse. To address concerns about Enron's ability to take regulatory shortcuts because of its political influence, Mr. Bush should direct everyone in his employ, including the vice president, to be forthcoming with Congress about any dealings they had with the energy company.
Democrats, for their part, should resist the temptation to use the Enron saga for cheap political gain. Talk of a "cancer on the presidency" and of a "Bush Whitewater" is unwarranted at this point, and threatens to trivialize and unduly politicize an inquiry vital to the health of the American economy.
It was before President Bush ever took office that Congress granted Enron exemptions for much of its complex trading activity, in everything from energy futures to broadband capacity, from oversight by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and other regulators. Senator Joseph Lieberman's hearings later this month will rightly explore whether such oversight could have prevented Enron's deceptive transactions with mysterious off-balance-sheet partnerships run by its own officers.
The fate of Enron employees' retirement accounts provides a second broad subject of inquiry. Criminal charges may still be in store for top Enron executives, who sold nearly $1 billion worth of their company stock, possibly knowing it was improperly inflated, before it plummeted. Thousands of employees were not so lucky, and lost their lifetime savings. Close to 60 percent of all employee 401(k) money was tied up in Enron stock. Congress should consider a proposal by Senator Jon Corzine to cap the percentage of employees' retirement accounts that can be held in company stock. 
The third issue that Congress and the S.E.C. need to address is the lack of public confidence in financial reporting. Beyond Enron's questionable behavior, the most alarming failure of all may have been that of its outside auditor, Arthur Andersen, to flag the company's dubious accounting practices. 
Enron is only the latest and most dramatic instance of an accounting firm's failing to protect the public from largely fictional financial reporting by a major company. The accounting industry insists it can regulate itself, but the evidence points to the contrary. Firms have placed themselves in an untenable conflict of interest by providing the same companies they audit on behalf of the public with an array of consulting services. Congress ought to pass legislation to bar such conflicts. 
Unsuspecting Enron employees were the most direct victims of the company's lack of forthrightness, but overall investor confidence in the integrity of the marketplace took a serious hit with Enron's demise. There are plenty of reasons for Congress to try to find out why it happened and how it can be prevented from ever happening again.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-10

India and Pakistan Avoid Meeting on Confrontation
The leaders of India and Pakistan will attend a South Asian summit meeting in Nepal in the next few days, but they have scheduled no face-to-face meetings. In recent days, India's leaders have begun talking openly about the possibility of war if Pakistan does not halt what India considers sponsorship of terrorism against India. Both countries have nuclear weapons and have mobilized forces along their border. A3

Soldiers on the Indian side of the border have turned thousands of acres of farmland into minefields. A3

On his way to Nepal, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan stopped in Beijing for talks on the standoff. A3

Israel Pulls Back in West Bank
Israel eased a military blockade on parts of the West Bank as the American peace envoy, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, returned to try to bring the sides close enough to resume negotiations on a cease-fire. A10

World Briefing A6

NATION CHALLENGED A14-15

Taliban's Slow Surrender Raises U.S. Suspicions
Taliban fighters near Baghran continued to surrender weapons and vehicles to American-backed forces, but the slow pace raised concern that senior leaders might slip away. A1

Taliban Envoy in Custody
Pakistani officials said they had arrested the former Taliban ambassador, and that Pakistani and American officials were questioning him about the whereabouts of Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar. A14

Hunger, Theft and Beatings
An effort to feed Afghan refugees descended into violence as food ran short and Afghan guards beat back a hungry crowd. Relief officials said stocks were low because shipments had been stolen by warlords. A1

Prisoners May Be Held in U.S.
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld suggested that Afghanistan detainees could be housed in jails on military bases in the United States. A15

Renewed Warning on Terror
The F.B.I. extended its terrorist threat warning, notifying police agencies nationwide to remain on high alert through March 11. A14

Airline and Agent in Dispute
American Airlines and lawyers for a Secret Service agent of Arab descent disagreed over the circumstances that led the agent's being barred from a flight on Christmas Day. The lawyers said the agent was the victim of bias; the pilot's report said the agent was loud and abusive. A15

Democrats Take Offensive On the Economy and Bush
Democrats, worried about President Bush's wartime popularity, are beginning a concerted election year drive to criticize his fiscal stewardship, with Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, to deliver the first salvo in a speech today. A18

Drug Discount Plan Doubted
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said drug discount cards of the type proposed by President Bush had not significantly cut costs for elderly consumers buying brand-name medicines in metropolitan areas. A16

Snowstorm Buries South

HEADLINE: The Price of a Commute 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "N.J. Transit Is Criticized for Planning Fare Increase" (news article, Jan. 3): 
 As a daily commuter on New Jersey Transit, I don't particularly want to pay more money for a monthly ticket. But I favor the fare increase. 
 Like any business, New Jersey Transit needs to make money to survive.
Those of us who depend on this (usually) reliable service to get to our jobs are lucky to receive an income in this turbulent economy. So we should not complain about paying a slightly higher fare. There are thousands worse off than we are.

CRAIG WYNNE
Suffern, N.Y., Jan. 3, 2002

HEADLINE: Charity Overwhelmed in Bid To Meet Attack Victims' Bills 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The Salvation Army, which raised more than $60 million to help victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, came up with a simple idea for providing immediate, practical help to families affected by the disaster: It offered to pay their household bills -- any bill, from car insurance to gas meters.
 It had no idea what this generous gesture would entail. 
 Bills flew in from thousands of families. The agency's technology for processing and writing checks was immediately overwhelmed. And now, in fresh proof of how the scale of Sept. 11 can overwhelm even the best-established and most-admired charities, thousands of families have discovered that their bills never got paid. 
One widow's car insurance was canceled; hundreds of families got late notices and had to scramble to preserve essential services or prevent a smudge on their credit history. "We've got all kinds of horror stories," said Carie Lemack, president of Families of Sept. 11, a victim advocacy group. "One man got an eviction notice when his rent wasn't paid."
Alfred J. Peck Jr., the director of social services for the Salvation Army in New York, said: "This is very embarrassing. We feel badly about it, and we're doing everything we can to get our system to work."
The numbers suggest the force of the storm that has hit the agency. Since the attacks, it has received more than 30,000 bills from roughly 8,000 families.
The Salvation Army had originally intended its program primarily to help people who had lost their homes or jobs in the attacks, and it did not publicly announce any limits on the size or type of bills it would accept. Mr. Peck did not provide any details about the range of requests, but the avalanche of paperwork soon swamped his agency. 
Its limited personnel and its quaint check-writing equipment -- a few cables feeding data to some slow dot-matrix printers -- could produce only 100 checks a day. It needed to turn out more than 1,500 checks a day, Mr. Peck said. The bill payments fell more than four weeks behind, and fresh bills arrive every day.
Even now, with faster equipment finally installed and the backlog pared to about three weeks, the Salvation Army's office in New York is still getting 75 to 100 calls a day -- "angry calls," Mr. Peck said -- from families anxiously checking on whether their overdue bills for crucial services have been paid. In fact, the agency has had to spend some of the money it raised for Sept. 11 relief to upgrade its equipment and increase its staff for handling the bills.
"It's understandable," Mr. Peck said of people's distress about the situation. "If somebody's bills aren't being paid, they're going to be upset."
Scrambling to limit the damage, the agency has sent urgent letters to utilities, major credit-card companies and other large vendors, explaining the problem and assuring them that the bills will be paid. "The major mortgage companies and rental agencies are O.K. with this; they're forgiving late fees, because they recognize that it's the Army and they're going to get their money," Mr. Peck said.
Officials with the Salvation Army, who at first estimated that they might spend about $5 million on their bill-paying effort, now concede that they do not know what the total payments will amount to.
People submitting bills are now told that there is a backlog, Mr. Peck said, although families that submitted bills earlier were not given this warning because "we weren't aware of the extent of the problem ourselves." And the agency kept accepting fresh bills to pay, despite its growing backlog, because it believed it could fix the problem quickly and continue to help the affected families, Mr. Peck said.
A second shift of volunteers was put in place to process bills, and up to a dozen people were assigned to field telephone calls from worried families. Faster laser printers were bought. A computer consultant was brought in to bypass the old check-writing system and knit the improved system to the database of family information the agency had already collected. But a few flaws delayed the process further.
"But, to our knowledge, we've prevented any service cutoffs," Mr. Peck said. Major utilities in the New York area confirm that they have begun getting checks from the Salvation Army in payment of outstanding bills, but they say they cannot confirm that someone did not fall through the cracks, as one utility spokeswoman said.
Laurie Quinn, whose brother, Ken Tietjen, was a Port Authority police officer who died in the attacks, accompanied another Port Authority family to the New Jersey service center at Liberty State Park about three weeks ago and left a few small bills with the Salvation Army, she said. "We were told that the family would be called in a few days, but we still haven't heard anything," she said. Nor was the family warned about a possible delay in payment, she added.
The largest vendors -- big mortgage companies, rental agencies, utilities and credit-card companies -- have been very cooperative, Mr. Peck said. But smaller vendors, pinched by a sluggish economy and relying on prompt payment, have been less patient. "We're putting them up at the head of the line," Mr. Peck said. "Or in some cases, we're just paying it on our personal credit cards and seeking reimbursement ourselves."
Not even the affected families seem to doubt the agency's good intentions. Ms. Quinn said that the agency staff members "always treat you with such kindness and respect; they tried to make it all as painless as possible."
In its wider response to the terrorist attacks, the agency has served millions of meals to rescue workers and provided counseling and help to displaced families who lived near ground zero or who have lost jobs in the aftermath of the attacks. Gordon J. Campbell, the chief executive of Safe Horizon, the agency that has operated the Family Assistance Center in New York, defended the Salvation Army's overall efforts.
"We're confident that they will find a way to resolve this situation so that the needs of their clients are met as quickly as possible," he said.
With the agency's other efforts garnering praise around the country, its bill-paying quagmire has been "embarrassing, to say the least," Mr. Peck said.
Although he is not yet sure how much the repair work will cost, Mr. Peck said the Salvation Army had spent some of the donations it had received to upgrade the check-processing system. It is an expense he considers money well spent, even if it is not exactly how donors might have imagined their gifts would be spent. 
"It will cut the turnaround to 72 hours once we catch up, which we hope will take just a few more weeks," he said. "We hope people will be patient."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tim Ditmer, left, an accountant at the Salvation Army on West 14th Street, waits as the system that prints the agency's checks goes down for a few minutes. (Photographs by Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)(pg. B3)

HEADLINE: The New School Spirit 

BYLINE:  By Donald Kennedy; Donald Kennedy is president emeritus of Stanford University and editor in chief of Science magazine.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif. 

 BODY:
The departure of Tyrone Willingham, the much admired football coach at Stanford, for Notre Dame has set off some interesting faculty conversations here. Some of my colleagues, who respect the way in which he has brought moderate success to a notably "clean" program, are philosophical. After all, it has happened before: Dennis Green had some good seasons here, took his last team to a bowl game, and then left us for the Minnesota Vikings.
 The members of this community take some consolation and pride in the fact that Stanford, unlike the vast majority of major colleges and National Football League teams, has had two African-American head football coaches. After all, some of my colleagues say, maybe it's even right that these successful coaches are sought after by bigger and wealthier football programs that have yet to integrate their top coaching staffs. 
 Yet not all my fellow faculty members are so understanding about this loss because Mr. Willingham brought some of the university's academic and service ideals into the locker room. In many quarters here, he was thought of more as a professor of football than as a coach. So a sense of rejection can be heard in comments like "Notre Dame must have paid him a lot more than we could." 
Sour-grapes commentary is predictable and not very constructive. A related reaction, though, invites more careful inspection. It is the response of those who ask: "What ever happened to loyalty?"
The sphere in which Mr. Willingham conducts his career includes precious little incentive for the development of institutional loyalty. Notre Dame unhesitatingly dumped its coach Bob Davie, whose career win/loss record was about as good as Mr. Willingham's at Stanford. Stanford has been able to develop and retain "dynasty" coaches in nonrevenue sports like swimming and tennis, in baseball, and even -- knock on wood -- in basketball. But its history of firing unsuccessful football coaches is about like everybody else's and gives little reason for anyone to feel secure. Big-time college football is a tough marketplace, and anyone who believes it has room for institutional loyalty is living in cloud-cuckoo land.
Nor is that kind of loyalty deeply embedded in the rest of the academic culture. When the heavily courted football coach looks around the rest of the campus to evaluate how loyalty is practiced by its faculty stars -- the Willinghams of economics or molecular biology -- he sees a culture not so very different from that of the football stadium. In 1998, Columbia made a stunning offer to the Harvard economist Robert Barro. The salary, according to a New York Times report, was nearly $300,000 plus various other benefits -- high enough to attract the astonished attention of dozens of envious high-profile academic economists. But Mr. Barro soon reversed field and stayed at Harvard, presumably for a sweetened offer.
The institutions that practice academic raiding -- and Stanford is one of them -- have real needs, and naturally they attempt to meet them. And the faculty members who move are subject to a widening set of loyalties that run well beyond the institution. The biologist who moves from University A to B for better facilities in which to pursue innovative research is being loyal to her craft. A political scientist who moves from B to C because C has a large foundation grant to explore the comparative origins of state failure is being loyal to his discipline. As for Tyrone Willingham, he will bring strong values and an African-American presence to a highly visible and influential program. He's loyal to his craft, too.
In short, there are all kinds of loyalties, and the institutional kind no longer trumps the others. Competition in the academic sector, as elsewhere in contemporary American culture, follows what economists call a "tournament" model -- one in which small advantages lead to winner-take-all successes. Why should athletic programs be exceptions to this model? What happened to loyalty is that it has been broken up into a lot of pieces in a highly complex world. But I confess I rather liked the old world in which loyalty was easier to keep track of.

HEADLINE: Zero-Emission Quota on Cars Is Postponed for Two Years 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration today postponed for two years, until 2004, a requirement that automakers devote a small percentage of New York sales to electric cars that do not produce air pollution. At the same time, the administration adopted a plan to encourage car companies over the next few years to sell large numbers of low-smog vehicles.
 Automakers had lobbied heavily to delay the electric car, or zero-emission vehicle mandate, saying the vehicles were not yet technologically or financially viable. Administration officials contended that, legally, they had no choice but to go along. 
 New York's new regulation and a similar one being adopted by Massachusetts represent a compromise from a draft last summer that was bitterly denounced by environmental groups. That version included a four-year postponement of the electric car mandate and a system of trade-offs that critics said would badly undercut the requirement.
Today, environmentalists said that the shorter period of postponement, combined with interim measures designed to spur sales of low-emission cars like gasoline-electric hybrids, represented a significant victory. They also hailed a new element of the New York plan that would impose pollution limits on trucks and buses that use heavy-duty diesel engines.
"We think our plan gets more clean cars on the road, quicker," said Erin M. Crotty, the state's environmental conservation commissioner.
Elizabeth C. Miller, chief executive officer of the American Lung Association of New York State, said, "This regulation marks the dawn of a healthier era for New Yorkers."
The moves by New York and Massachusetts could leave California as the only state requiring no tailpipe emissions from 2003 model cars, vans and light trucks. The status of a similar regulation in Vermont, the only other state that had been on California's timetable, is uncertain. While most 2003 models will hit the market in August or September of this year, any model introduced in 2002 is considered a 2003 model.
For a decade, California has driven the development of low-emission cars and trucks with a series of ever-stricter standards. Federal law allows California to set rules that are tougher than federal restrictions. The law generally gives other states only two choices, with some limited exceptions. They can do nothing and live with the federal standards, or they can adopt California's; that way, automakers do not have to build one version of a car for Illinois, for instance, and another for Indiana and yet another for Ohio.
In 1999, Gov. George E. Pataki announced that New York would join the latest phase of the California rules, with a zero-emission vehicle requirement starting this year on 2 percent of all sales for each automaker, a number that would increase gradually each year. Massachusetts and Vermont quickly followed. Auto industry experts and environmentalists said having the Northeast states join the program was crucial to creating the economies of scale that would make electric car production viable, because those states, together with California, account for about 20 percent of the national auto market.
Last month, California modified its rules, in part to close a loophole that might have let carmakers comply with the electric car mandate by building vehicles that were little more than large golf carts. California's zero-mission mandate still begins this year.
New York State officials said that the Northeast states had to go along with the changes California made or abandon the program. But legally, they said, they could not change the rules so close to the introduction of electric cars. Environmentalists said the state was probably right.
But Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee, said the state probably could have gone ahead with requiring electric cars this year."They've been wanting to make these changes for a year and they floated a bad proposal last summer, prior to California doing anything," he said."They're just using the California action as cover."
New York's new regulation allows each automaker to choose between the California plan, starting with the 2005 model year, or an "alternative compliance plan" for production of low-emission vehicles like hybrids, starting this year, with a later introduction of electric cars.
Ms. Crotty said that when the earlier version was written, "We were not at the end of the process."
"The next step was to talk to the environmentalists, and the next step happened," she said. "They made the product better."

HEADLINE: Argentine Leader Seeks Broad Powers in Economic Crisis 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
After urging Argentines to stop buying foreign goods and begin "protecting what is ours," the country's new president, Eduardo Duhalde, sent Congress a "public emergency law" today that would give him sweeping powers to deal with the economic crisis that has immobilized the country for the last month.
 The legislation would end a decade-long policy of setting the value of the Argentine peso at one American dollar and using the two currencies almost interchangeably. 
 But the proposal does not specify how much of a devaluation Mr. Duhalde will decree. The resulting uncertainty led to shortages today of food and especially medicine as products vanished from shelves and bank depositors tried, usually in vain, to get their hands on dollars. 
Mr. Duhalde hopes that the two houses of Congress, which his Peronist party dominates, will debate his proposal on Saturday and approve it no later than Sunday. 
That would allow the country to resume business on Monday with a new set of rules for the financial system in place, instead of prolonging the suspicion and paralysis that have sapped the economy this week.
The new president first indicated that he would devalue the peso in his inaugural address on Tuesday night, and he has done so again in every public declaration since then. But the lack of details and the wait for Congress to change the law are making Argentines nervous.
Government officials say Mr. Duhalde intends to replace the one-peso-to-the-dollar system with a dual exchange rate. 
Exporters and importers would operate at a fixed rate of about 1.35 pesos to the dollar, at least at first, while for most other Argentines a more expensive floating rate would be determined by the currency markets.
In an effort to cushion the impact of the devaluation on middle-class consumers and owners of small businesses, two groups that have been hard hit by a four-year recession, the package also includes a provision that would require all bank debts of $100,000 or less to be repaid only in pesos. 
Though most Argentines earn salaries in pesos, about 80 percent of the country's debt, from mortgages to car loans, is denominated in dollars.
The big losers are likely to be banks and foreign-owned telephone, gas and electricity companies. The draft legislation calls for banks to be compensated for their losses by a special tax on exports of oil and gas, but it is not clear how long that process would take or how the compensation would be calculated. Utilities, though, would have to begin accepting payment in pesos.
Aware that today was likely to be the last day that one peso would officially be worth one dollar, thousands of people rushed to pay their bills, including many that were due much later in the month. 
Public anger grew as bank after bank either refused outright to accept pesos and demanded dollars or claimed that they could not carry out any transactions because their computer systems were not functioning.
"It's disgraceful the way they are openly defying the law," Carlos David Oviedo Espinosa, a middle-aged salesman who was trying to pay an installment on a car loan, said as he stood in line outside an Italian-owned bank this morning. "They're up to a lot of dirty tricks, and no one is doing anything to stop them."
In a televised speech to business and labor leaders this afternoon, Mr. Duhalde also showed little sympathy for the banks' situation. To a round of loud applause, he said his government intended to put an end to "an alliance that has damaged the country for decades, the alliance of political power with financial might instead of the productive sector."
But with public anxiety rising, problems have also begun appearing in other parts of the economy. In grocery stores and supermarkets, prices were marked up and shelves were going bare as distributors held back products until the new policies went into effect and consumers tried to stock up on basic goods like cooking oil.
The most serious shortages are of drugs. Patients needing insulin and other expensive or imported medicines have been unable to get their prescriptions filled, and at Argentina's request, the government of neighboring Brazil today began sending emergency supplies of the drugs that have become hardest to find.
"There is no chain of distribution, and medicine hasn't been delivered since Wednesday," Gimena Ibanez, a clerk at a pharmacy here, said this afternoon. A colleague, Ana di Salvo, added: "We're telling people not to despair, that we will continue to be able to get their medicine, and at the same price. I hope it's true."
In his speech, Mr. Duhalde called on store owners and distributors to be patriotic and not raise prices or hoard products. But if that appeal fails, the government "has multiple policy instruments to stabilize the economy in the face of markups" and will not hesitate to use them, warned his chief of staff, Jorge Capitanich.
Jose Ignacio de Mendiguren, head of the newly created Ministry of Production, said the government was considering price controls, because some producers were taking advantage of the devaluation to raise prices even though their costs had not increased. But that step is seen as likely to produce other complications and a loss of public confidence.
"Price controls have not produced good results in the past," the daily La Nacion warned today. "The big question mark is whether Argentina is going to pay an enormous cost to exit one scheme that ceased working only to return to another that in the past led to catastrophic hyperinflation."

Nasdaq Increases 5.6% In First Days of New Year

Dynegy Gains Gas Pipeline After All
A risky investment in Enron has paid off for Dynegy. As part of a planned acquisition of Enron, Dynegy invested $1.5 billion in Enron early in November for preferred shares in the subsidiary that owns the pipeline and the option to take control of it. The merger plan collapsed soon after, and Enron filed for bankruptcy protection last month. But late Thursday Enron agreed to transfer ownership of the Northern Natural Gas pipeline, which can deliver 4.3 billion cubic feet of gas daily -- about 8 percent of total United States output -- and runs about 16,600 miles from Texas to the Canadian border and supplies gas to utilities and companies in several states. HEADLINE: Investigators Say Elevator Union Members Were Paid Millions for No-Show Jobs 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Federal law enforcement officials say they are investigating a network of no-show jobs in which members of the elevator constructors union bilked New York City's building industry out of millions of dollars. 
 As part of the scheme, investigators say, members of the union often received more than $3,000 a week by holding a regular job as well as one or two no-show jobs. 
 Two workers who asked union officials to investigate the no-show jobs, complaining that it stole work from unemployed union members, said they were attacked after a union meeting, with one of them being kicked in the teeth.
In papers filed in federal court in Brooklyn, F.B.I. investigators detailed an elaborate scheme in which Matthew Joseph Downey, a member of the union, received more than $1.5 million over three years from workers holding the no-show jobs. In November, Mr. Downey was indicted on charges of obstructing justice and urging two union members to lie to a grand jury investigating no-show jobs. 
Joseph M. Bowen, an F.B.I. special agent, described in a series of criminal complaints how union members received payments for no-show work at major construction projects, including 10 Rockefeller Plaza and a Marriott Hotel on Third Avenue. 
Before overtime, union members often earn $1,400 a week operating the temporary elevators at a single construction site. They can often earn twice that by also holding a no-show job and working overtime. The court papers suggest that the scheme has inflated construction costs citywide by millions of dollars in recent years.
Mr. Downey's lawyer, Stephen Scaring, denied any wrongdoing by his client, saying that prosecutors were trying to pressure Mr. Downey to provide evidence against others. Mr. Scaring said he expected there would be additional indictments soon, although officials with the F.B.I. and the United States attorney in Brooklyn declined to comment on any future actions.
John G. Green, president of Local 1 of the International Union of Elevator Constructors, insisted that his union and its members were clean.
"There are no no-show jobs," he said. "We're 107 years in existence and we never had any problem whatsoever about this kind of operation that they're making accusations about."
Mr. Green said his union was cooperating with federal investigators and provided all the documents requested on hours worked and other matters.
"If they have proof about all these things, then they should by all means show it to me," Mr. Green said. "There is no such thing as somebody not showing up and getting paid."
In September 1999, the United States attorney in Brooklyn filed a criminal complaint against Mr. Green's son-in-law, Terence Carr, charging him with holding at least seven no-show jobs in 1997 and 1998. 
Prosecutors said that for one day alone -- April 27, 1998 -- Mr. Carr had been paid for 30 hours of work: for 10 hours, including 2 overtime hours, at 10 Hanover Square; for 12 hours, including 4 overtime hours, at Riverside South; and for 8 hours at Battery Park City.
"There was no such thing as they're babbling about the son-in-law," Mr. Green said. "He never received any checks improperly from anybody."
Seeking to build their case, federal prosecutors withdrew that complaint against Mr. Carr and three other union members accused of holding no-show jobs, reserving the right to indict them later.
The local's 2,000 members install new elevators and run temporary ones that carry workers and building materials to upper floors at construction sites. Under union contracts, only members of Local 1 can operate the temporary elevators.
But one worker, who testified before the federal grand jury in Brooklyn and spoke on condition of anonymity, said that because of no-show jobs, workers from other construction trades often have to run the elevators themselves. 
One prominent construction executive who insisted on anonymity said some industry officials have looked the other way on no-show elevator jobs, believing that they were reserved for injured or sick workers who badly needed the income.
Two union members, Martin Hastings and Stephen Brennan, said two years ago that after a union meeting in Long Island City, two large men beat and bloodied Mr. Brennan, with one kicking him in the teeth. Mr. Hastings had angered some union officials by asking the union to investigate the widespread allegations of no-show jobs. 
At the meeting, Mr. Brennan had seconded a nomination for Mr. Hastings to run for business agent. Mr. Brennan has since left the elevator industry and the union, saying he feared for his safety.
In court papers, Agent Bowen said he had been investigating no-show jobs since December 1997, working with the Department of Labor and the Internal Revenue Service. 
"Local 1 members routinely get paid for hours at which they were not present at the job sites," Mr. Bowen said in a criminal complaint and affidavit filed in November. "The Department of Labor's analysis reveals dozens of instances of operators being paid for supposedly being at two different job sites at the exact same time."
In the criminal complaint against Mr. Downey, federal investigators said the no-show scheme involved at least 30 union members. The complaint suggests that Mr. Downey coordinated much of the scheme and had many participants deposit some of their no-show checks in an account he set up under the name "Mattlynn" at a Bank of New York branch on Long Island. 
The complaint stated, "In total, between 1996 and 1998, more than $1.5 million worth of third-party checks -- more than 1,400 -- of this type were deposited into the Mattlynn account." It added that the endorsements on all the checks appeared to have been written by the same person, but in 30 different names. The F.B.I.'s handwriting experts concluded that the handwriting matched examples of Mr. Downey's writing.
Agent Bowen said in court papers that two cooperating witnesses who acknowledged holding no-show jobs had deposited checks into Mr. Downey's Mattlynn account.
The criminal complaint accompanying the Downey indictment said one union member had secretly recorded a conversation with Mr. Downey. Mr. Downey is recorded as telling him: "If a guy says to you, 'Did you give Downey permission to cash your check?' 'Absolutely, he cashed my check.' 'Why?' 'Saved me from going to the bank.' "
Later, the complaint quoted Mr. Downey as saying that what "you should maintain all the time is that I was on every" job. "They can't disprove it."
Mr. Downey's lawyer, Mr. Scaring, said, "Mr. Downey denies all these accusations."

HEADLINE: Nation's Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.8% 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate continued to creep upward last month, though fewer Americans lost their jobs than in any of the previous three months.
 The Labor Department reported yesterday that the economy lost 124,000 jobs in December, the smallest decline since August. The unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.8 percent, a level it last reached in April 1995. 
 Economists said the numbers suggested the job market might be stabilizing after severe cutbacks caused by the terrorist attacks and the recession. They also said they saw other promising signs, like a rise in the number of hours worked per week in manufacturing, and a wave of hiring in education and health care. 
But most experts continued to paint a gloomy picture of the economy. "The overall report was quite weak," Lynn Reaser, chief economist for the Bank of America, said. Job losses are still high, and several forecasters expect the unemployment rate to climb as high as 6.5 percent in the first half of the year.
In Washington, the Bush administration showed little surprise at the job losses. "Unemployment has continued to rise, which is not unexpected," said Elaine L. Chao, the secretary of labor. "We are in for a couple more months of disappointing unemployment numbers."
Her department also released dreary figures on new applications for unemployment benefits on Thursday. Claims climbed 36,000, to 447,000 last week, and the previous week's increase in claims was revised sharply upward, to 26,000 from 7,000.
Some of the worst job losses in December occurred in the travel industry, where the hangover from Sept. 11 continues. Travel lost 32,000 jobs last month, for a five-month total of 273,000. Employment in retail sales also fell, by 77,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis, as a result of retailers' pessimism about holiday shopping.
Unemployment for black and Hispanic workers continued to climb. The jobless rate for blacks rose to 10.2 percent in December, twice the rate for whites. Maya Rockeymoore, a labor expert at the National Urban League, said that more blacks worked in the service industries that suffered after the terrorist attacks, especially hospitality and entertainment. "The unfortunate incidents of Sept. 11 actually had disproportionately negative impact on African-Americans," she said.
From a broad economic perspective, though, the numbers were better than William C. Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, expected. He said the rise in hours worked per week in manufacturing, to 40.7 from 40.3, suggested a turnaround in that sector. "That's a big change from what you've seen in recent months," he said. Hours worked in manufacturing last stood at 40.7 in August.
Half the increase in hours worked came from overtime. That could mean employers are working their existing employees harder as an interim measure before hiring more workers, said Diane Swonk, chief economist of Bank One in Chicago. "The overtime is what you want to see," she said. "It is income, and income is important."
Mr. Dudley said the rising hours worked could mean that a recovery had already begun. "What normally happens is businesses work their existing workers harder during the early stages of an expansion," he said.
Companies were also shifting from long-term to short-term employment changes in December, according to the report. The number of permanent job losers, up to 2,463,000 from 2,403,000, grew far less than the number of workers who said they were on a temporary layoff, up to 1,183,000 from 1,017,000.
Ms. Reaser said that manufacturing companies could indeed be seeing an improvement in production orders. She also said that large employment gains in two service-heavy industries, health care (31,000 jobs) and private education (28,000 jobs), boded well for a recovery.
Further reason for encouragement, Ms. Reaser said, came from a substantial increase in business activity in services, reported by the Institute for Supply Management. "Perhaps we're beginning to come to the tail end of the recession, at least in the nonmanufacturing side."
The strength of an expansion is far from assured, though. "We're expecting a muted rather than a powerful recovery," Mr. Dudley said. He added that consumer demand for goods and services probably could not rise much higher, especially after a car-buying spree in the fall and an anticipated drop in year-end performance-based bonuses.
Ms. Swonk worried that a recovery without a big boost in consumer spending might disappoint investors. "I'm afraid Wall Street might get upset when the consumer wanes in the first quarter, where really that's just a reflection of earlier gains," she said.
Ms. Swonk also said that consumer debt, often a worry on Wall Street, was under control during the holiday season. "They were paying back their credit cards as they were spending," she said. "A lot of people were using more checks, more cash."
Last month, consumer confidence rose to levels unseen since the summer. Bigger paychecks helped to keep spending strong. Hourly wages for nonfarm workers edged up to $14.65 from $14.56.
But Edward E. Leamer, a professor at the University of California in Los Angeles who heads the U.C.L.A.-Anderson Forecast, warned that the burden of debt could present serious long-term problems. "Consumers are going to have to adjust," he said. "We're going to have to adapt to a saving mode. If that happens rapidly, that's a recipe for a deep recession."
In the meantime, Professor Leamer said, the economy could safely lose hundreds of thousands more jobs during the next few months. "I don't think there's any news from the employment report for December, except that we are on track for one of the mildest recessions in this country's history."
