HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
How the Clip 'N Snip's Owner Changed Special Education

BYLINE:  By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
The people of Florence, S.C., know Shannon Carter as the owner of Shannon's Clip 'N Snip, a barber shop where the locals get haircuts and conversation. The Clip 'N Snip has room for seven barber chairs, but Shannon is limiting the business to two for the moment and renting out space until the economy improves enough for the barbering business to expand.
 Shannon's public school teachers are no doubt surprised to see her running a business and working out a financial plan. During the 1980's she finished ninth grade failing virtually every subject, and was nearly illiterate. The schools told Emory and Elaine Carter that their daughter was terminally lazy and would "never see a day of college." In truth, Shannon was suffering from a common but undiagnosed learning disability that made it difficult for her to comprehend the little that she could read. Alienated and depressed, Shannon became suicidal. In desperation her parents placed her in a private school for disabled children, where she jumped several grade levels within a few years and graduated actually reading on grade level. 
 The Carters then sued the school system for private-school tuition and were upheld in the landmark Supreme Court case known as Florence County School District Four v. Shannon Carter. The law before this case limited parents of disabled children to schools approved by the state. But the court ruled in Shannon's case that the school system lost its right to plan a disabled child's education if it failed to provide an "appropriate public education" as required by the federal Individuals With Disabilities Education Act, known as the IDEA. 
Ask about Shannon Carter in New York or Los Angeles, and you see school board lawyers snarling or hanging their heads in dismay. The school boards see Carter cases as "a voucher program for the rich," in which affluent parents reserve spaces in private schools and then badger the school systems into paying burdensome tuition costs. Critics have a point when they note that small districts can be destabilized by the cost of one student's stay at an expensive residential school, and that urban districts with too few textbooks are sometimes forced to underwrite lavish private school tuition. But as Congress prepares to reauthorize the federal special education program, it should bear in mind that the Carters went to court only after the public schools failed at their most basic mission: teaching Shannon to read.
The task of teaching reading is undermined by the common but mistaken belief that children are somehow neurologically "wired" to read. This view led to the "whole language" fad of the 1970's, in which children were allowed to wander through books, improvising individual approaches to reading. The whole language technique works well with some children. But data from four decades of studies by the National Institutes of Health show that it is disastrous for the 4 in 10 children who have trouble learning to read. Nearly half these youngsters fall behind in the early grades, never catch up and eventually drop out.
In the most extreme cases, children seem to have abnormal activity in the parts of the brain that process phonemes -- the basic sounds that correspond to the letters of the alphabet. The simplest rules of language make no sense to them. Asked for a word that rhymes with "cat," for example, they simply draw a blank. The disorder strikes children of all backgrounds. It afflicts those who are read to as infants as well as those who grow up without a book in the house. 
The fortunate children are diagnosed early and assigned to smaller classes where teachers take special care to teach them the fundamentals of written language that others take for granted. The children are walked through the alphabet again and again, learning to connect the letters to the sounds, the sounds to the syllables, the syllables to words and so on. The good news from the N.I.H. findings is that 95 percent of learning-impaired children can become effective readers if taught by scientifically proven methods. The bad news is that less than a quarter of American teachers know how to teach reading to children who do not get it automatically. At the moment, nearly half of all children placed in special education are there for reading difficulties. Federal scientists commonly describe them as "casualties of bad instruction." 
Part of the blame lies with colleges that have resisted federal attempts to improve teacher education programs. Part of the blame lies with Congress, which has clung to the view that curriculum is a state and local matter in which the federal government should not meddle. Congress failed to even notice the reading research until just recently, when the Bush administration made reading a priority. 
Congress has focused almost solely on the fact that special education is expensive -- and that it takes away money from regular education. The debate will go nowhere until lawmakers begin to view special and regular education as part of a single system that is being hampered by an all too pervasive problem -- that schools are teaching reading in a way that fails to effectively reach millions of children. The basic lesson of the Carter case and the tens of thousands that have followed is that the country needs a national reading campaign, based on research. The longer we delay, the more families like Shannon Carter's will bolt the system, taking public dollars with them.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SERVICE MERCHANDISE, A RETAILER, TO CLOSE

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Service Merchandise Company, a 42-year-old retail chain that has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since March 1999, said yesterday that it would go out of business. 
Executives said the weak economy and slow sales after the Sept. 11 attacks hurt the 2001 results and prevented the company from completing its planned business reorganization and emergence from bankruptcy. Service Merchandise, with more than 200 stores in 32 states, reported losses of $180 million in 2000 and as of November had liabilities totaling $1.34 billion and assets of $1 billion. The company is based in Nashville.

HEADLINE: Times Plans Art Auction For Neediest Cases Fund 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
Reacting to a decline in charitable donations after Sept. 11, The New York Times Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would have an art auction this month featuring the works of 14 well-known New York City artists and that the proceeds would go to The Times Neediest Cases Fund.
 The artists who have donated their work are Ross Bleckner, Louise Bourgeois, Larry Clark, Chuck Close, Gregory Crewdson, Jenny Holzer, William Kentridge, Sol LeWitt, Shirin Nashat, Nam June Paik, Doug and Cindy Sherman, Mike Starn and Christopher Wool. The Roy Lichtenstein Foundation has also contributed a painting by the late Pop artist. 
 The works will be displayed from Jan. 15 to Jan. 19 at the Luhring Augustine Gallery, at 531 West 24th Street in Chelsea. A silent auction will begin on Jan. 16 at a reception at the gallery featuring a speech by Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University and president of the New-York Historical Society.
Jack Rosenthal, the president of the Times Company Foundation, said that while the Sept. 11 attack had inspired an outpouring of contributions to charities related to the relief efforts, it had also caused a significant decline in giving to other charities, like the Neediest Cases Fund, which has been giving financial and other assistance to the poor for 90 years. Contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund are off about 8 percent from the campaign of 2000-1.
The auction will be advertised in The New York Times and on its Web site, nytimes.com.
Bids will be taken at the gallery through Jan. 19. The fund's seasonal campaign ends on Feb. 1.
Mr. Rosenthal said he suspected the auction might raise more than $150,000. "The decline of contributions unfortunately coincides with the increase in need," Mr. Rosenthal said, citing the current economic slump. "But what's equally important to the value of the works, whatever they raise, is the attention that it all gives to the cause."
Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund may be sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: Patriotism on the Cheap 

BYLINE:  By Frank Rich; E-mail: frankrich@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Rudy and Judi are in Boca. Bulls have been sighted on Wall Street. Churchgoing is back down, and "Portraits of Grief" has been retired as a daily hymnal. 
 The national New Year's resolution is Closure or Bust. 
 "9/11" is now free to be a brand, ready to do its American duty and move product. Ground zero, at last an official tourist attraction with its own viewing stand, has vendors and lines to rival those at Disneyland. (When Ashleigh Banfield stops by, visitors wave and smile at the TV camera just as they do uptown at the "Today" show.) Barnes & Noble offers competing coffee-table books handsomely packaging the carnage of yesteryear. On Gary Condit's Web site, a snapshot of the congressman's own visit to ground zero sells his re-election campaign. NBC, whose Christmas gift to the nation was its unilateral lifting of a half-century taboo against hard-liquor commercials, deflects criticism by continuing to outfit its corporate peacock logo in stars and stripes. 
Though President Bush has been a bulldog in counseling patience and declaring that the war isn't over, it's not clear how many Americans believe him. The further our distance from the World Trade Center -- in both time and geography -- the easier it is to forget. This is in part how it should be. It's inhuman, as well as impossible, to function on constant alert, to wake up every morning afraid to switch on the news lest we be ambushed by another unthinkable catastrophe. But must a return to normal mean a return to the same complacency and civic fatuity of Sept. 10? If so, that's a pitiful memorial to the 3,000 who were slaughtered on Sept. 11, regardless of whatever is or isn't eventually built on the site of ground zero. 
A week ago The New York Times ran a detailed history of the failures of the Clinton and George W. Bush administrations alike to combat terrorism, including the utter lack of follow-through on the recommendations of the 1997 Gore commission on airline security, which might have prevented some of the Sept. 11 hijackings. Yet the adjacent news article on the same front page revealed that this sorry history, far from teaching us a lesson, was already condemned to repeat itself. The Department of Transportation announced that its "new" standards for hiring airport security screeners would not require a high-school diploma, allowing thousands of the existing screeners to stay in place.
The department's motto seems to be: If it's broke, don't fix it. Never mind that even four months after the attacks, the state of passenger screening remains such that American Airlines let Richard Reid board one of its flights but turned away one of the president's Secret Service agents. Now we're asked to believe that high school dropouts are our best front line of defense against the cunning likes of Mohamed Atta, the recipient of two university degrees.
There has been a lot of talk about patriotism and sacrifice since Sept. 11, but talk is cheap. Real airline security is expensive, and you get what you pay for. Congress, exercising its favorite form of bipartisanship, that which serves its corporate donors, did hand the airlines a $15 billion bailout in September but it allotted nothing like that sum to putting teeth into the airline security bill passed with such fanfare in November. 
How fleeting is infamy, after all. Osama bin Laden didn't make it as Time's Man of the Year, the Taliban have been routed, been there, done that. We can take solace in the fact that there has been no major follow-up terrorist attack since Sept. 11 and so pursue cut-rate security at a leisurely pace -- all the while forgetting another part of pre-Sept. 11 history, namely that the typical interval between Al Qaeda actions is 12 to 24 months. Contrast the $8.3 billion that Congress has appropriated to domestic security with its latest "absolute insanity" (in the words of John McCain) -- a dubious $22 billion slab of corporate pork that it bestowed upon Boeing in the form of an Air Force contract to lease 100 new wide-body jets that might be cheaper to buy outright. You can see how much our national priorities have changed since the day the world changed. 
On the home front, sacrifice often seems no more pressing than in the capital. As Bill Maher has said, supporting the war effort by plastering flags on a gas-guzzling foreign car "is literally the least you can do." Yet the new patriotism that was said to be a product of America's New War often seems to be little more than vicarious patriotism reminiscent of the pre-Sept. 11 fetishism of the Greatest Generation. We all applaud our selfless men and women in uniform, whether at ground zero or in battle, but we are not inclined to make even a fractionally commensurate sacrifice of our own. We have no interest in reducing our dependence on the oil from the country that nurtured most of the hijackers, Saudi Arabia, or revisiting an upper-brackets-skewed $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut to find the serious money needed to fight future hijackers and bioterrorists effectively. 
Among media bloviators, wartime sacrifice is even more of an abstraction. Many of the same hawks who predicted American defeat three weeks into the war in Afghanistan, Democrats and Republicans alike, are now prematurely declaring that war over so that someone else's children can be sent at once into what they predict, with undiminished certitude, will be a slam-dunk battle in Iraq. "The next time you hear some self-styled patriot, on or off TV, telling you how easy it would be 'to take out Saddam,' " wrote the commentator Mark Shields of these armchair generals, "first ask him to give you the names and hometowns of two enlisted members of the armed services , then ask him if he is volunteering his son or daughter for that 'easy' mission." 
Just as patriotism isn't the jingoistic bluster that Mr. Shields punctures, neither is it the new form of political correctness that has broken out since Sept. 11. In the new p.c., anyone who says anything critical about the president or his administration is branded an anti-American akin to the Marin County Taliban. But if Donald Rumsfeld is good at his job, that's his talent, not a magic spell that automatically rubs off on John Ashcroft and Norman Mineta. If George W. Bush has been a strong practitioner of war, that doesn't elevate his pettier domestic policies, whether an Enron-friendly energy plan or an inequitable economic "stimulus," to the holy grail or brand his critics as evildoers akin to Saddam Hussein (as one conservative group did to Tom Daschle in a recent ad). 
The reason all these ersatz forms of patriotism have taken hold since Sept. 11 is easy to see. There's a vacuum of leadership in defining what real patriotism might be for the many Americans who are not in uniform but who came together on Sept. 11, eager to be part of a national mobilization even if they weren't packing off to war themselves. On the domestic front, Mr. Bush's most frequent call for sacrifice, woefully amplified by a Marriott-sponsored TV ad to which he lends his image, has been for Americans to take more vacations. We can only hope that the book he read over the holidays, Edmund Morris's "Theodore Rex," will give him a broader vision of what Teddy Roosevelt Republicanism can be at home. The Democrats are no better; they snipe at the president's domestic priorities and offer small-bore programs for the recession's growing victims without seriously suggesting that the better-off sacrifice any of the tax cut that Democrats helped put over the top in the first place. 
This is where we were, and it is why our new closure feels so empty. Rather than visit the new, tourist-friendly ground zero, a sharper antidote to complacency may be to travel uptown to a Sept. 11 exhibition at the New-York Historical Society, where a 25-minute impromptu video of the attack, aptly labeled "a Zapruder film for our time" by The Times's Sarah Boxer, runs continuously. The video is jagged and its images are not suitable for framing. It plays out as spontaneously as its cameraman, Evan Fairbanks, shot it. There are no logos, no crawls, no flag graphics, no network anchors to mediate between the viewer and the unfolding events -- in fact, no sound at all, either on the tape or from those watching it in stunned silence. 
Even jaded New Yorkers are shocked all over again by seeing hell naked, unexpurgated, stripped of all the branding and slick packaging that has accrued to it in the weeks since. Confronting that morning again, you suddenly remember the senselessness of the slaughter and the hope we had that change, not a return to business as usual, was what might give it meaning.

HEADLINE: India and Pakistan Pave Way for Talks 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan, here for a regional summit meeting, are privately discussing terms under which the two nuclear rivals could sit down for talks about resolving the current crisis that has led to a perilous military buildup along their common border, officials from both countries said tonight. 
 The discussions, taking place under diplomatic pressure from world leaders to defuse a confrontation that threatens to turn into full-scale war, are aimed at finding a compromise that would assure India that Pakistan is genuinely cracking down on anti-India terrorism while allowing Pakistan, the smaller, more insecure country, to save face, the officials said. 
 India also wants a commitment from the United States to see to it that Pakistan follows through on cutting off support to Pakistan-based groups waging a holy war against India in Jammu and Kashmir, India's only majority Muslim state -- a commitment an Indian official said had not yet been given.
"If the Americans don't want this to escalate, they must take certain responsibilities," the official said. 
As Pakistan's military ruler, President Pervez Musharraf, arrived here today for the conference of South Asian heads of state, India continued to take a tough public line, saying there would be no negotiations until Pakistan had taken stronger measures to combat the extreme Islamic groups based in Pakistan that India accuses of carrying out a suicide attack on its Parliament on Dec. 13. 
Tonight, the seven South Asian leaders gathered at the royal palace for a dinner hosted by King Gyanendra, Nepal's constitutional monarch. Officials said India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, and General Musharraf did not sit "within conversation distance" at a long dinner table, though some who were there said they shook hands. 
General Musharraf was late in arriving today for what was to have been the inaugural session of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, officials said, because his flight was delayed by bad weather en route from Beijing, where he paid his second visit to China's leaders in two weeks as tensions have mounted with India. 
Under the association's rules, all seven heads of state must be present to hold a session, so the start of the conference was delayed until Saturday morning. 
Indian officials said they would be carefully analyzing the tone of a speech by General Musharraf. "That's very crucial," one said, expressing concern that the Pakistani leader would say something provocative and contentious. 
It is not yet certain that India and Pakistan will find a way to revive talks that broke off abruptly last summer as the nations tried to thaw relations that were frozen after an incursion into the Indian-controlled side of Kashmir by Pakistan-based militants in 1999. But some officials said they were hopeful that talks could resume. 
Nirupama Rao, an Indian spokeswoman, denied that Jaswant Singh, India's foreign minister, had met with Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar. But other Indian and Pakistani officials, who did not want to be identified because of the delicacy of the current situation, said the two ministers had had private discussions.
India has apparently decided to give Pakistan some time to shut down the Islamic militants operating openly from Pakistan into Kashmir. Pakistan said today that since Thursday night its security agents had detained more than 130 Islamic militants, including leaders of two groups India blames for a suicide attack on its Parliament, though it made public no names. 
Pakistani officials here insisted the crackdown on militants had absolutely nothing to do with India's demands and everything to do with Pakistan's own policies to jail individuals inciting others to commit terrorist acts or sectarian killings in Pakistan itself. 
"That really has no linkage with what the Indian government has been demanding," Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi, spokesman for General Musharraf, said tonight in a news briefing. "That's what the government of Pakistan has been doing on its own."
While India waits for a broader crackdown by Pakistan, it wants quick action 20 accused criminals and terrorists that India has demanded Pakistan hand over. "To show their sincerity, let them begin with those," said an Indian official. 
But Pakistan, which does not want to be seen to be bowing to its more powerful neighbor, is demanding evidence and suggesting that an impartial, third party investigator examine India's allegations, officials said. 
Speaking of General Musharraf, the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said today, "Fundamentally, we think he has made the strategic decision to move against terrorism." On Thursday, he encouraged the Indians "to make available, as much as they can, evidence and information on the perpetrators of these actions."
India -- apparently responding to Pakistan's sensitivity -- released a two-page summary of evidence on Thursday about some of the more notorious cases that India says it has shared with Pakistan over the past eight years since a series of devastating bomb blasts in Bombay, including at the stock exchange, that killed more than 260 people. General Qureshi said tonight that he was not aware that any such proof had been provided to Pakistan. 
India's demand for the 20 people it has accused places Pakistan in an awkward position, not least because Pakistan has long insisted that some on the list do not live in Pakistan. 
These include the men India says hijacked an Indian jetliner from Katmandu to Kandahar two years ago, as well as Dawood Ibrahim, a Bombay gangster wanted for his alleged involvement in the bombings. 
While it is unclear how India and Pakistan will resolve the tricky issues around the list, officials here are very much focused on whether the leaders of India and Pakistan, now staying here in the same hotel, will find a way to talk to each other in the open. 
India, which sees itself as the aggrieved party after the Dec. 13 attack on Parliament, has been the reluctant partner, while Pakistan is pushing for negotiations. "I'm sure the Indian government knows that we're just waiting for a response," General Qureshi said.
Diplomatic pressure on the two sides, meanwhile, continued to mount with a visit to the region by the British prime minister, Tony Blair, who arrived today in the southern Indian city of Bangalore. He is expected to meet Mr. Vajpayee on Sunday before heading to Pakistan and to report on the results of his conversations to President Bush.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, meanwhile, said today that he would make a decision early next week on whether to send an envoy to South Asia to try to pull India and Pakistan away from confrontation. "It's important to our international campaign against terrorism," Secretary Powell said in a BBC radio and television interview.
"We will try to be helpful," he said. "We will encourage them to talk to one another."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Musharraf, far left, and Prime Minister Vajpayee, far right, with other guests at the royal dinner. (Associated Press) Map of India highlighting Katmandu: Leaders of India and Pakistan are at a summit meeting in Katmandu.

HEADLINE: Democrat Assails Bush on Economy 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
Senator Tom Daschle, the capital's most prominent Democrat, accused President Bush and the Republicans today of causing the "most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history" when they pushed through a major tax cut last year.
 Mr. Daschle praised Mr. Bush repeatedly for his leadership in the war effort. But using pointed language in his speech to set out the Democrats' election-year stance on the economy, he said that domestic policy was "being written by a wing of the Republican Party that isn't interested in fiscal discipline." He added, "They have one unchanging, unyielding solution they offer for every problem: tax cuts that go disproportionately to the most affluent." 
 He said the $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax reduction that was the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's domestic program had led to dwindling surpluses, high long-term interest rates and an erosion of investor confidence. 
"So not only did the tax cut fail to prevent a recession, as its supporters said it would," Mr. Daschle said, "it probably made the recession worse." 
The speech by Mr. Daschle, the Senate majority leader from South Dakota, was the opening shot in what is likely to be a fierce election-year struggle over the weak economy. It came just weeks after partisan strife stalled economic stimulus legislation. And with Mr. Daschle considered a potential presidential contender, the address might also be a first salvo in the 2004 campaign.
Mr. Bush plans to travel to California and Oregon this weekend and use his Saturday radio address to promote his own economic stimulus measure -- a mix of large business tax cuts, benefits for the unemployed and an accelerated reduction in income taxes. 
In a sign of the importance placed on the debate, the White House brought out one of Mr. Bush's most influential advisers, Karen P. Hughes, to respond. A chorus of high-ranking Republicans in Congress also shot back, with a barrage of accusations that Mr. Daschle wanted to raise taxes by repealing tax cuts. 
Ms. Hughes said Mr. Daschle "seems to be implying that tax increases might be necessary." She said, "Nothing could be worse for workers who want to keep their jobs than to increase taxes at a time when our economy, we hope, is just beginning to recover."
The office of the minority leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, provided a "glossary" for understanding Mr. Daschle's speech, titled "Senator Daschle's Economic Speech for Dummies." It said that when Mr. Daschle spoke of restoring "fiscal discipline" he really meant he favored raising taxes.
And Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said, "Perhaps the most important thing the Congress did last year to promote economic security was to pass the president's tax relief proposal." He added, "Senator Daschle voted against that proposal and now he seems to indicate that he wants to repeal it."
With Democrats deeply divided over whether to push to repeal or delay part of the tax cut, Mr. Daschle was silent on the issue. He sought to put Democrats on record in favor of "tax cuts that work."
"We want to make sure that any tax cuts we pass don't threaten Social Security or Medicare reserves, crowd out other critical investments, or drive us deeper into debt," he said. 
Mr. Daschle tried to dispel the idea that the Sept. 11 attacks and the war on terrorism were the main causes of returning federal deficits. "Sept. 11 and the war aren't the only reasons the surplus is nearly gone," he said. "They're not even the biggest reasons. The biggest reason is the tax cut." 
At the heart of Mr. Daschle's speech was an effort to contrast Mr. Bush's economic policies with those of former President Bill Clinton and to tie Democrats to the prosperity of the last decade. He was flanked by a former Clinton treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and a onetime Clinton budget director and chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, who is board chairman of the Center for National Policy, the site of the speech. 
"In 1993," Mr. Daschle said, speaking of Mr. Clinton's first year in office, "our economy was saddled with a record $290 billion deficit, and that deficit was projected to grow substantially for years. By 2000 not only was the deficit gone, we had a record $236 billion surplus, and that surplus was expected to increase dramatically for years."
Careful not to attack Mr. Bush by name, he said that when the recession started in March, "Republicans chose exactly the wrong solution" and pushed through the $1.35 trillion 10-year tax cut. Mr. Daschle said supporters of the tax cut had been "certain we could do everything" -- reduce taxes, increase spending, protect the federal retirement programs and pay off debt.
"What we got instead," he said, "was the most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history."
Mr. Daschle proposed two ideas to spur economic stimulus talks -- a one-year business payroll tax credit and a new business depreciation schedule to encourage companies to replace equipment and technology this year. The proposal would allow companies to write off 40 percent of new investments for six months and then 20 percent for the next six months. The administration favors write-offs of 30 percent a year for three years.
More broadly, Mr. Daschle endorsed a "balanced national energy plan" that relies more on conservation than does Mr. Bush's to increase production. And he pledged an early Senate vote this year on giving Mr. Bush expanded trade negotiating power. He said approval of the trade measure should be tied to a package of aid for displaced workers.
Ms. Hughes said that much of the Daschle plan sounded like Mr. Bush's own calls for an energy policy and for trade negotiating authority. She said she hoped Mr. Daschle's speech was an acknowledgment "that his posture at the end of the year in obstructing some of this important legislation was wrong."

HEADLINE: Practical Help for Afghans 

BYLINE:  By Fred P. Hochberg; Fred P. Hochberg was deputy administrator and acting administrator of the Small Business Administration from 1998 to 2001. He is an adviser to the Foundation for International Community Assistance, a microfinance organization.

 BODY:
As allied forces narrow their hunt for Osama bin Laden, the broader mission is creating a stable, secure Afghanistan. That will take time and resources, but President Bush can start now by drawing on one of the most effective, cost-efficient weapons in the fight against poverty: providing very small business loans to the poorest people -- especially women -- through microlending.
 Fortune 500 companies may not be lining up to do business in war-ravaged Afghanistan, but there is still business to be done. Like much of the developing world, Afghanistan has a well-established, yet informal, economy of street vendors, neighborhood shops and cottage industries. Small loans go a long way. Just $50, for example, could buy a used refrigerator to keep a vendor's produce fresh, a used sewing machine to make stitchery go faster or a bicycle to deliver goods. Tiny transactions like these are part of a proven strategy of poverty reduction. Across the globe, 25 million microentrepreneurs are using loans of very small amounts to increase their incomes and lift their communities. 
 Microfinance has worked well in war-torn areas. Within nine months of the start of a microlending effort in Kosovo's hardest-hit areas, 1,500 microentrepreneurs were in business and paying their loans back on time at an incredible rate of 99 percent. In El Salvador, recovering from the effects of civil war and then devastating hurricanes, microfinance institutions are now making more business loans than commercial banks.
Microfinancing serves both men and women, but all around the world, it focuses especially on women's business development, because helping women helps children. One group that can benefit greatly in Afghanistan, for example, is the many women who have become the sole support of their children after years of war. Afghan women and men need the access to microfinance to build something better.
While I served at the Small Business Administration, our own domestic microenterprise initiative grew to a permanent program. With average loans of $10,000, Americans with ideas and initiative but no credit history have been able to start thousands of businesses providing services from day care to gardening to travel arrangements. As small businesses were established, poor communities were strengthened.
Worldwide, the demand for microcredit keeps growing far faster than the funds available for it. Despite increased microlending support in recent years, the World Bank estimates nearly half a billion microentrepreneurs have no ability to get financial services. Many are forced to turn to loan sharks, who may charge interest of as much as 10 percent a day.
Microfinance is clearly good development policy, but it is also good security policy. Microenterprise assistance won't end the threat of terrorism, but it is a down payment on building stronger economies and more stable societies.
As Congress considers legislation to renew international microcredit assistance, the president should raise our investment to $500 million in annual aid from the current $150 million. Unlike other foreign aid, this is a renewable resource; as one family repays a loan, another receives one, multiplying the impact thousands of times over.
The World Bank should also do more. Today less than one penny out of every World Bank dollar is devoted to microlending. The bank should reform its charter to allow it to provide direct financing to microfinance institutions. The United States should also urge other wealthy nations to increase their contributions and include microfinance on the agenda of upcoming meetings of the G-7 group of industrial nations and the World Trade Organization.
We need to update our thinking about helping the world's poor. Everyone knows the adage that says, "If you teach a person to fish . . ." But in Afghanistan and throughout the developing world, people already know how to fish and farm and make and sell all kinds of goods and services. They need capital to invest in what they know. And that investment will pay dividends for us all.

HEADLINE: Bush's Policy on Argentina Signals Shift in Approach 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
Seven years ago this month, President Bill Clinton's economic advisers told him Mexico was hours away from economic default and perhaps chaos on the streets. Mr. Clinton ordered an unpopular multibillion-dollar bailout, over the objections of Congress, but with the support of a prominent Republican governor, George W. Bush of Texas.
 When Argentina barreled toward a similar default in recent weeks, it was Mr. Bush who had to make the bailout call -- and his decision was to let Argentina suffer the consequences of its own economic mismanagement. His aides argue that the circumstances were somewhat different: Mexico appeared ready to make reforms but needed time and cash, while Argentina had not heeded repeated warnings that its policies were leading to financial disaster. 
 Still, Mr. Bush's reaction to the biggest international economic crisis so far in his presidency is a telling example of a new -- and perhaps risky -- approach to the kind of national economic bankruptcies that dominated Washington's dealings with the world's emerging markets in the late 1990's.
The Clinton administration, fearing "economic contagion," was willing to back loans to teetering governments in Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and Russia. But Mr. Bush's aides have adopted a policy some call "tough love," meant to reverse the expectation in capitals around the world that if you are big enough, or strategically important, Washington will always find a way to prevent fiscal and political collapse.
Mr. Bush promised just such a policy during his presidential campaign. But the first time his approach was tested, when Turkey ran into deep trouble last spring, Mr. Bush's national security aides warned that it was no time to abandon a well-located ally whose government seemed willing to take the medicine the International Monetary Fund prescribed. Washington joined in the bailout. 
"It's fair to say," one senior administration official noted during the last week, "that while we have been clear, we haven't always been consistent."
The hard line on Argentina, White House and Treasury officials say, was calculated to send the message that under the Bush administration, the United States would be a reluctant financial firefighter and that the markets should not bet on a bailout. It is a message that Mr. Bush's aides said in interviews this week that they hoped would force officials of developing countries and foreign investors to work out their problems without relying as much on huge aid packages from the International Monetary Fund and from Washington, which became commonplace after Mexico.
"It is a different approach, but we needed a different approach," said John B. Taylor, undersecretary of the Treasury for international affairs. "We want to follow a policy that does not bail out bondholders and improves the market over all."
There are other new aspects to the Bush policy.
Treasury officials in the Clinton era never shied away from dispensing a steady stream of advice to countries on the condition that they would have to meet to get Western aid. In contrast, during the Argentina crisis, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill was nearly invisible, rarely commenting on the country's approaching default, or the violent protests that led to the resignation of President Fernando de la Rua.
Officials say Mr. O'Neill supported the decision by the I.M.F. to cut off Argentina's loans because it had failed to meet the fund's demands for fiscal restraint. And now Washington's message to Argentina's new president, Eduardo Duhalde, is straightforward: Come up with a workable plan, and then we will talk.
"President Bush never talked about specific steps he expected the Argentine government to take," said one White House official familiar with Mr. Bush's periodic calls and letters to Mr. de la Rua and the series of his successors in recent weeks. "You won't find this administration having those kinds of conversations. Argentina has to come up with what works for them, and if we can support it, we will."
Mr. Bush's approach carries considerable risk. There is every possibility that Argentina's new government will abandon the free-market leanings, tight fiscal and banking controls the country embraced with strong International Monetary Fund support over the last decade. Already there is considerable doubt that Argentina will now agree to the kind of hemispheric free-trade agreement that Mr. Bush himself, with Mr. de la Rua at his side, said last year was a major goal of his administration.
Both the I.M.F. and the United States, the fund's largest shareholder, have come under some sharp criticism for denying new loans to Argentina after previously approving aid to the country. The last emergency loan was put together in August, with Mr. O'Neill's close supervision.
The critics of Mr. Bush's decision to pull the plug on aid argue that the I.M.F. and the Bush administration were callous for abandoning an ally at a sensitive moment. And some argue that both the Clinton and Bush administrations should have acted sooner to steer Argentina away from its doomed efforts to defend a 1-to-1 peg of its peso to the dollar.
But administration and I.M.F. officials respond that they aided Argentina for as long as they thought there was a reasonable chance that its political leaders were serious about reform. They pulled the plug, one senior administration official said, "only when it became clear that the collapse was going to happen sooner or later, and there was no use spending billions to get a few more weeks before the inevitable happened."
Some longtime critics of the fund applauded the Bush administration's stance. Both left-wing anti-globalization activists and some conservative economists have argued that the fund became too interventionist during the Clinton years. That allowed investors to make reckless bets on the assumption that lending agencies would rescue them when things went wrong.
"I am hopeful that we're in transition to a world in which countries and lenders learn more about risk," said Allan H. Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon University, who headed a Congressional panel two years ago that advocated sweeping changes at the I.M.F. and the World Bank. "You can't just keep throwing money at these problems and hope they will go away."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Four Decades, Two Democrats and a Nassau Twist of Fate

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: MINEOLA , N.Y. 

 BODY:
NINETEEN SIXTY-TWO was an auspicious year for Democrats in Nassau County, who until very recently had to look that far back to have any basis for hope. Eugene H. Nickerson took office as the first Democratic county executive. And Thomas R. Suozzi, the second one, was born.
 On Tuesday, in an eerie but somehow fittingly symmetrical fluke of fate, Mr. Suozzi was sworn in, and Mr. Nickerson, 83, died, of complications from ulcer surgery. 
 The two men had little in common beside their dark-eyed good looks and ambitions for higher office. Mr. Nickerson was a patrician, white-shoe lawyer with no experience in government. Mr. Suozzi, 39, the son of an Italian immigrant, was the mayor of Glen Cove for four terms.
Mr. Suozzi takes over a county government bleeding red ink, weighed down by debt, and teetering on the brink of financial collapse. Mr. Nickerson's challenges, by contrast, were largely of his own choosing.
The Nassau he inherited in 1962 had just reached adulthood following the postwar boom that made it the biggest and foremost American suburb, its corn and potato fields largely subdivided and paved over, its roadways already choked with traffic, its tap water already fouled with chemicals from unchecked growth, The Republican-led county government was awash in money but had been concerned with little more than maintaining the status quo.
"What problems there were were the beginning problems of suburbia: inadequate transportation, the welfare rolls going up, the city's problems coming out into Nassau," said James C. Shelland, a historian at Empire State College in Old Westbury. "Nickerson saw his mission as confronting those things."
There was little that the optimistic Mr. Nickerson did not confront. He promoted affirmative action, low-cost housing and better ties between the police and minorities. He started recreation programs for patients at the county nursing home. And he pushed to turn the county's tiny hospital into a modern medical center for the middle class and poor alike.
He was helped by a torrent of state and federal aid pouring into Nassau during the 1960's. While county spending soared, taxes rose less steeply, Mr. Shelland said.
Mr. Nickerson also saw his mission as unifying Nassau and elevating its self-image. "He recognized that Nassau was not just a bedroom, but our home," said Sol Wachtler, who was the North Hempstead supervisor before he became a judge, and whom Mr. Nickerson narrowly defeated in 1967 to win his last three-year term. "And as a result, the people living in Nassau became interested in the things being provided for them. Up till that time, people were pretty indifferent. They wanted things to be left alone, they didn't want people and problems coming out here from the city, they didn't want the earmarks of liberalism."
It was Mr. Nickerson who persuaded the Kennedy administration to turn over sprawling Mitchel Field, then an undeveloped jewel at the county's core, for what he hoped would be a sports, cultural and transit center, a Madison Square Garden, Lincoln Center and Penn Station rolled into one. The Nassau Coliseum was all he got. But his ideas for a transit hub are still kicking around.
ANOTHER bit of unfinished business: Mr. Nickerson often complained that the county had no system of reporting on municipal services, making it impossible to know whether streets had been cleaned or workers were showing up. Forty years later, Mr. Suozzi says the same thing.
Unlike Mr. Suozzi, whose fellow Democrats hold a one-vote edge in the County Legislature, Mr. Nickerson faced an obstructionist, Republican-controlled Board of Supervisors throughout his tenure. But he was a canny operator: to push his plan for the medical center through, Mr. Wachtler recalled, "He had the hearing room filled with people on iron lungs. He made me feel like such a miserable person. And of course I was the first vote in favor of it."
Mr. Suozzi will need all of Mr. Nickerson's political smarts, and then some. The county, he said gently in his inaugural, is "showing its age." The medical center and nursing home laid off 353 workers on Thursday to help stave off bankruptcy. 
And many more cuts are coming. The Republicans who succeeded Mr. Nickerson preached fiscal conservatism, but they never eliminated the programs and departments -- and the jobs -- that he created.
So the most symmetrical link between Nassau's two Democrats will be if it is Mr. Suozzi who has to curtail the expansive, programs that Mr. Nickerson created. "We cannot tackle the problems of 2002 if we are guided by visions of 1962," Mr. Suozzi said Tuesday, before Mr. Nickerson's death had become known.

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
Contender for Governor Keeps Outspoken Views
His spin in the spotlight was short, his campaign for governor of New York unconventional, his loss big and his exit from the news almost instant.
 In 1990, after 19 potential candidates turned down the state Republican Party's nomination to run against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the two-term Democratic incumbent, desperate Republican leaders turned to a man who had never run for public office, Pierre A. Rinfret. 
 A Montreal-born, New York City-bred financial and economic consultant, he was a feisty, blunt-spoken cage-rattler who did not hesitate to denounce fellow Republicans as well as Mr. Cuomo, whom he called inept at dealing with what he saw as the state's economic decline. The Republicans who had refused to run against Mr. Cuomo, he said, were "gutless wonders."
Not surprisingly, some Republicans were among the politicians who saw Mr. Rinfret as a loose cannon prone to shooting himself in the foot. The race ended with the worst showing of any Republican candidate for governor in the state's history. Mr. Rinfret's 21 percent of the vote barely beat the 20 percent won by the Conservative Party candidate, Herbert London. Mr. London had attacked Mr. Rinfret as aggressively as he had Mr. Cuomo, who won with 53 percent.
"I knew from Day 1 I couldn't win," Mr. Rinfret said last week from Nantucket, Mass., where, at 77, he lives in retirement. But he ran, he said, "to try and get the people to see" that the state "was deteriorating economically" and that rampant crime had made New York City's residents "frightened to walk" the streets at night.
Mr. Rinfret said his effort had helped show the vulnerability of Mr. Cuomo, who "won by a bare majority against two rank amateurs" who had split the anti-Cuomo vote. Four years later, Mr. Cuomo lost to George E. Pataki.
Mr. Rinfret said that the Republican Party "did nothing" to help his campaign, but he conceded that he "made some dumb mistakes," such as "taking on the press too much." As he did during the campaign, he maintained that The New York Times had been especially "nasty" and unfair to him.
Though no longer in the consulting business, Mr. Rinfret gives his economic views free on the Web at www.rinfret.com and www.parida.com. Ever the iconoclast, he offers such advice as: "Ignore any and all statements about the future of the economy by any and all government officials" because "they all lie."

Bidding for Site Delays Bookstore's Moving Day
The book is still being written on a legendary bookstore's planned move.
In July, the owner of the Gotham Book Mart, a nostalgic trove long popular with buyers, browsers and authors, said he planned to sell its cramped home in Midtown Manhattan and seek larger quarters in the area. 
The owner, Andreas Brown, said the shop had outgrown the five-story building at 41 West 47th Street, its home for 56 of its 82 years. And strong interest in the site in the thriving diamond district made selling financially wise, he said, adding that he hoped to complete the sale and acquire a new home for the shop by Christmas.
But as of last week, neither had been done. "There are a huge number of bidders, and we're going into a second round," Mr. Brown said. He could not pin down a new location "because our budget for purchasing depends on what we get for this building."
"Our asking price is $7.9 million," he said. "Early bids show we have a shot at it."

HEADLINE: Harvard President Brings Elbows to the Table 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE and PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5 

 BODY:
It was undoubtedly the most negative publicity Harvard University's new president, Lawrence H. Summers, had received in his six months on the job. A dust-up with the professor Cornel West and complaints that Mr. Summers had snubbed or disappointed other celebrated black scholars raised the possibility that Harvard would lose the stars of its Afro-American studies department.
 But the dispute, resolved this week when Mr. Summers took steps to mend fences with the professors, was not the only time that Harvard's president has ruffled feathers. 
 In November, at a meeting with law professors, he was perceived as giving a disparaging response to a professor who objected to plans to move the law school's campus. 
In September, he rankled leaders of public service organizations on campus, who complained that he was unfairly advising them to stick to charitable work and not get involved in social or political advocacy.
And several professors of Latin American studies say that over the last few months, Mr. Summers has deflected requests that a Latino studies center be established on campus.
His critics say that since Mr. Summers took office in July, he has developed a reputation for excessive bluntness, lacking the quiet diplomacy they praise in his predecessor, Neil L. Rudenstine. They say Mr. Summers, who was treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton, brought with him the sharp elbows for which he was known in Washington. Even though he taught economics here for nearly a decade, they speak of him as a kind of interloper, one who does not understand how universities are supposed to operate.
In many ways, he is what people used to expect university presidents to be: outspoken, a strong hand and a public figure, not simply a smooth fund-raiser. The education of Larry Summers suggests how much that expectation has changed.
"Given someone who has experience in Washington, his behavior has been quite shocking," said William Julius Wilson, who was recruited under Mr. Rudenstine as a professor and part of the Afro-American studies department.
"He's now saying things he should have said from the beginning," Dr. Wilson added. "That's to his credit. I hope he learns something from this."
At the least, Mr. Summers cast a figure far different from the owlish Mr. Rudenstine -- and faced more withering scrutiny. When Mr. Summers's sweat pants sagged during a halftime game of Red Rover at a November football game, for example, gossip columns here and in Washington obsessed about whether his underwear had been red or white.
In an interview in his office off Harvard Yard, Mr. Summers defended his tenure and suggested that the criticism reflected the need to adjust to a new style, one of questioning, not conciliation. The questions are intended to force people to rise to the high expectations worthy of Harvard, not to shoot them down.
"I think the questioning is a mark of respect for people, an interest in what they have to say," Mr. Summers said. "I've always believed that you can't do anything without having a sense of the pros and cons."
Mr. Summers's defenders, too, challenge the idea that he sought an imperial presidency by saying that he is acting from his roots as a professor. It is not uncommon, they say, for faculty members to challenge one another's ideas; rather, it is the essence of the university. Instead of being unfamiliar with the university ethos, Mr. Summers is perhaps a little too familiar with it.
"If he made any mistake at all, it's that he thought he was coming back as a faculty member," said Sol Gittleman, provost of Tufts University. "The faculty is free to say whatever they want. Once you became an administrator it's something else."
Dr. Gittleman said that Mr. Summers "brings his own kind of unique faculty baggage to the job." He added: "I don't see him as arched. I don't see him as pompous. He didn't realize that he was no longer faculty; he's the president of Harvard."
Others say that the committee that chose Mr. Summers was looking for a strong voice. And that, say Morton and Phyllis Keller, historians and authors of a recent book on the university, is a natural transition for Harvard. Historically, the Kellers say, Harvard has alternated between strong presidents and those they call stewards, whose chief task is to build up the university's endowment. The presidents in between have been freer to focus on some aspect of the university that they think needs improvement. For Charles Eliot, it was making the curriculum more flexible. For James Conant, it was improving the quality of the faculty and students. For Derek Bok, it was making Harvard more relevant to the outside world.
"Larry Summers comes in at a time when money is not the problem, the quality of students is not the problem," Morton Keller said in an interview. "There is a serious problem in the way in which Harvard's worldliness and prestige drives professors away from their core responsibilities: teaching and scholarship. He is responding not only to his own sense of the university having strayed from its core mission, but to the criticism outside the university."
The criticism of Mr. Summers is largely over how he delivers his message, but sometimes it is the message. Trevor Cox, president of Phillips Brooks House, Harvard's umbrella for community service groups, said that at the meeting with student leaders, Mr. Summers seemed to be saying that public service should focus more on charity work than on advocacy of a particular approach to solving social problems. Tutoring children might be appropriate, for example, while fighting vouchers might not, even if it was based in a belief that they make conditions for children in public schools worse.
"The general drift of it was that he didn't consider advocacy public service," Mr. Cox said. "His conception was more of charity. To have the president of the university define a narrow definition of public service was not well met." 
So far, Mr. Cox said, he and other students have found things about Mr. Summers to praise and criticize.
"Summers has done a very good job at the beginning of visiting groups of people, indicating by his presence that he's willing to learn about issues that affect the college," Mr. Cox said. "He has had office hours, and a lot of students have gone in to see him."
On the other hand, his probing questions can be disconcerting.
"If you have a short time with him, it's not too encouraging if the whole time he spends a lot of time challenging your views, even though he may not really believe that," Mr. Cox said. "I think he is for both his sake and ours challenging us and challenging himself on a lot of these issues."
That is how Mr. Summers explains it. In two interviews in his office, he seemed eager to refute any suggestion that he was too confrontational.
All his questions, he said, are aimed at making the best decisions toward a broad agenda: improving undergraduate education, tamping down grade inflation, making it possible for more students to attend Harvard regardless of cost. He acknowledges that there are challenges in trying to satisfy everyone.
"Not everything can be a priority," he said.
At the meeting with the students, he said, he was making the point that the university cannot be seen as endorsing political causes, particularly if they are at one end of the ideological spectrum. As for the misunderstanding at the law school, he called the faculty member to make sure no insult was felt -- an account the faculty member corroborates.
And while Mr. Summers acknowledges that it may be different for Harvard to have its president in the gossip columns, he is a public figure and has been for years.
Even his critics seem to grant that Mr. Summers has learned from the disputes over the past few weeks. "He's trying to make things better," said Charles Ogletree, a professor at the law school who represented the Afro-American studies professors in their dispute. "He's been conciliatory. He's been calling people, meeting people, wanting to set the record straight, trying to fix what he describes as a misunderstanding."
"We've made a lot of progress," Dr. Ogletree said. "I'm just thrilled that he's open."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Help on Rent Eases Strain As a Life Is Ending

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Moshik Khivazov has memorized the appearance of the residential tower outside his bedroom window -- the way the white curtains behind one window rest just so, the droop of the plant leaves in the windows a few floors below.
 The building will likely be one of the last things he sees. 
 Late last month, doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center told him that he had a week to live, maybe a little more, maybe a little less, his family said.
His once-vigorous muscles have atrophied to the point where his arms are thin sticks, his torso emaciated. He spends his days on his bed at home, heavily sedated by morphine and inclined to stare out that window. 
One day two weeks ago, Mr. Khivazov, 53, a musician, woke up and asked his wife to get his saxophone. 
"I have to play now," he told her. "I have to prepare for my concert."
It was just a delusion, said Larisa Khivazov, 44, his wife of 25 years.
Mr. Khivazov's head rests on an oversized pillow and his body is covered by only a thin white blanket. He speaks in a whisper, but rarely says more than a word or two.
His story, and that of his family, is better told by his wife, a former kindergarten teacher who immigrated with him from Uzbekistan two years ago and is now a part-time home health aide.
"For two days I felt dead myself," she said of her reaction to learning her husband's prognosis. "But then my husband told me, 'God says when we are born and when we have to die. God chooses the right time. So for me, it's the right time. Don't cry, be strong.' "
In September 1999, the couple and their daughter, Milana, now 21, left Yangier, Uzbekistan, a small town on the slopes of the Himalayas about 250 miles from Afghanistan. They said they faced discrimination there because they are Jewish.
Mr. Khivazov had hoped to play the saxophone in front of larger audiences when he moved to the United States. But three months after the family arrived in New York, Mrs. Khivazov said, doctors discovered a large cancerous tumor on his kidney that had gone undetected in Uzbekistan. "When we left he was not all right," Mrs. Khivazov said, as Fira Furman, a social worker from the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services who helps her, translated from Russian. "He fainted a few times but they had no idea why."
The tumor was removed after it was detected but the cancer had already spread. Mr. Khivazov has been undergoing experimental drug treatment in the two years since having surgery, but has not improved, his wife said.
After his cancer was diagnosed in December 1999, he realized he was too sick to work. Mrs. Khivazov obtained certification to be a home health aide, but she has curtailed her work recently to spend as much time as possible with her husband.
Now she earns $300 a month at her job, and the family receives $1,106 a month in Supplemental Security Income.
But with many expenses, Mrs. Khivazov was in danger of falling behind on the rent, $881 a month for a one-bedroom high-rise apartment in Rego Park, Queens. With help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, she was able to pay it.
The family has been receiving help from the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services since shortly after arriving in New York. The agency, a beneficiary of UJA-Federation of New York, helps them with their immigration paperwork and public benefits. UJA-Federation is one of the seven local charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund.
"We try to help this family in any way we can," Ms. Furman said. "They are facing very unusual circumstances."
While the money is unlikely to help Mr. Khivazov get well, it will help tide the family over until Mrs. Khivazov is able to obtain full-time employment.
Mr. Khivazov hoped to bring his family to the United States to pursue better economic opportunities and escape religious intolerance, but the most significant thing that happened here was that he had access to better medical treatment.
The Khivazovs' son, Eugene, 26, also came to the United States recently, bringing his wife, Christine, 20, and their daughter, Camilla, 2. 
Moshik Khivazov looked at his granddaughter and smiled as she showed him a stuffed animal. "At least two more years he was given by Sloan-Kettering," Mrs. Khivazov said. "The U.S.A. kept him alive and let him see his granddaughter."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
New Careers for 3 Who'd Been Around the Block

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
ON the morning of Sept. 11, Alan Guinn decided he would change the way he lived his life. Standing in Penn Station amid swarms of anxious commuters trying to get home, Mr. Guinn made a commitment to himself.
 "Right there, I realized we have only so many minutes to live our lives," Mr. Guinn said. "I decided to start my future immediately." 
 The next day he walked into his boss's office at a bill processing company on West 72nd Street and resigned his position as director of global sales. He gave six days' notice. "I couldn't wait two weeks," he said. 
 By the following week he had converted a spare room in his Massapequa home into an office and had begun soliciting business for his new consulting company, helping companies build and operate sales and marketing programs and other business development efforts.
 Every year, thousands of Long Islanders flee the restrictions and relative safety of salaried jobs to begin their own businesses. Such ventures emerge out of New Year's resolutions to pursue long-deferred dreams of independence, or following traumatic events. The state small business development center in Stony Brook, on the campus of the state university, reports a 15 percent increase in calls since Sept. 11.
 Sometimes it's simply that the time is right for change.
 Mr. Guinn, 49, said he had wanted to set out his shingle long before Sept. 11 but never made the commitment. "All the office politics, the do-it-by-committee mentality and the endless meetings," he said. "I really don't miss corporate life."
 Judith Tyne, director of the Center for Entrepreneurship at Hofstra University, said, "People in midlife and later start businesses around what they care about, and what we care about changes as we get older."
 But Mr. Guinn said the work he does is similar to what he did as an executive for companies like Pepsico, Haagen-Dazs and 1-800-flowers.com. Now, however, he's his own boss. That, he said, makes all the difference.
The bill processing company, Cashpoint, welcomed him back as a consultant. "One thing I learned early on," he said. "Don't burn any bridges."
 Several other contracts followed. Mr. Guinn is also teaching a business class through an online university and has completed writing and self-publishing a motivational book called "Psyched For Life."
 "My calendar is pretty full," he said, sounding pleased.
 Not everyone finds the transition so smooth. Sue Byrnes of Huntington, a single mother who raised two children and put them through college on her salary as a nurse, said she felt increasingly dissatisfied with her chosen field. She worked in a Huntington nursing home and found the burden of paperwork ever more difficult to bear.
 "I went into nursing to take care of people," she said, "not to fill out forms."
 Two years ago, at age 54, she quit her job and opened a tea shop in Huntington. She and a friend, Candace Osias of East Meadow, leased a storefront on New York Avenue and called their new business Miss Haversham's Tea Shop, after the Dickens character in "Great Expectations."
 In addition to offering 500 brands of tea, Ms. Byrnes said, the shop features sandwiches, scones and soups. Ms. Byrnes said she cooks the soups every day from scratch. The work isn't easy. "I work more hours these days, sometimes 55 hours a week," she said. "I never worked more than 48 as a nurse."
 Her father provided the motivation to get out of nursing, she said.
 "Late in life my father became regretful," she said. "He was always a workaholic. In old age he talked about everything he never found time to do. I decided not to let that happen to me."
 Ms. Byrnes said she likes dealing with people and likes tea, and thought running a tea shop would be a good fit one day. She researched business opportunities for nearly a year. She turned to the small business development center in Stony Brook for help, receiving free information and advice.
 Two years later, she said, results are mixed. She enjoys serving customers, but in retrospect wishes she had asked more questions of people in the business.
 "I would have talked more to people with actual experience and spent less time reading books about it," she said.
 One thing she'd change is her location.
 "Downtown Huntington is busy, but here we're several blocks south of everything," she said, indicating that business could be better.
 She wonders when people will go out again as they did before Sept. 11. And she worries how she will master all the unfamiliar business skills she now knows she needs.
 "I never had to manage cash flow before, but now I'm learning how to do it," she said. "And I know I won't be regretful like my father over what I never tried."
 For Gene Seraphine, semi-retirement from his public relations agency has afforded him time to study music and become, at age 84, the leader of a working jazz band.
 As a young man blessed with a good ear and an extensive collection of 78's -- plenty of Lester Young and Coleman Hawkins, the reigning innovators of the tenor saxophone -- Mr. Seraphine skipped formal training. Instead he took his saxophone with him to clubs and restaurants, sitting in when a bandleader gave the O.K.
 "I never learned theory and harmony," he said. "But I enjoyed playing, and I knew the tunes everybody liked." 
 After college he worked for the Cunard cruise line, traveling widely. In Paris he once talked his way into a jam session with the guitarist Django Reinhardt. 
 Back in the States, Mr. Seraphine began building a career in public relations. He founded an agency in Manhattan serving hotel, travel and entertainment accounts. There were celebrity clients too, including Salvador Dali and Steve Allen. In off hours he still made the rounds, saxophone in hand.
 Mr. Seraphine gave up his Manhattan office space and his Port Wwashington home and moved to Hampton Bays 16 years ago. He still handles occassional assignments from old clients. But these days, he said, there's time for fishing. And jazz.
 Playing a guest solo one night with a band at Bridges, a restaurant in Sag Harbor, he marveled at the playing of the keyboard player, Mark Gatz. Told that Mr. Gatz also taught music, he asked to become a student. Mr. Gatz agreed.
 "It was my late-life crisis," he said with a grin. The weekly lessons continued for three years, followed by extensive practice on his own, Mr. Seraphine said.
 "There has been a great improvement in the way I hear things," he declared. "I can hear some of the newer tunes now that the band wants to play. I used to stumble over chord changes. Not anymore. Now I know what I'm doing up there."
 Mr. Seraphine printed up new business cards with the image of a saxophone next to his telephone number. He gets calls to bring small groups to play at various East End business functions, political events and weddings. The quartet is booked regularly at local restaurants on jazz nights.
 "I'd like to record a CD with this quartet," Mr. Seraphine said. "These guys swing like crazy. I'm proud of us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gene Seraphine, who played the saxophone for years as an avocation, has become the leader of a jazz band at the age of 84. Ray Williams is the group's bass player. (Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; 
A Friend to the Scaly and Many-Legged

BYLINE:  By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
BOB SMITH'S office in a Hauppauge industrial park is a mecca for snakes, amphibians and bugs. There's Dumpy, a silky smooth, lime green Australian tree frog with a dreamy, smiley look on his face, sitting on the tray of Mr. Smith's business-card holder, breathing ever so gently that the nocturnal amphibian looks more like a gargoyle. Lurking under the moss in the terrarium by Mr. Smith's desk is a Brazilian rainbow boa constrictor that had 26 babies earlier this year, though the offspring have been relocated to separate lodgings in his Northport basement. When not between sheds, the boa's skin looks iridescent.
 Across the room is a tank with three larger boas wrapped around each other. Mr. Smith is more than happy to regale a rather skittish visitor by pulling out one of the eight-foot snakes and pointing out the bulge along its length that is most likely the rat it recently savored.
 Want to see another creepy crawler? From a vivarium in the next room, Mr. Smith proudly shows off an African millipede that freaks out his wife, Diane, every time he takes the coiled up brown critter out of the tank. 
"It doesn't bite," said Mr. Smith, stroking the thousand-legged creature and touting it as an inexpensive pet that doesn't need walking and is content with a lump of lettuce and an occasional misting.
 "It's a vegetable eater," he said. "It has to feel a little bit comfortable and then it will start walking. It's interesting to see how the legs oscillate. The fear of every mom in America is that it gets out of the cage. That's why I have it here and not at my house."
 Mr. Smith's office is actually the headquarters of the Right Financial Group, which services computers and financial equipment in banks. But if his employees had any trepidation about working amid his extensive collection of reptiles, amphibians and insects in cages that make the rooms seem more like a pet shop, they have had to get over it. Since last January, when Mr. Smith launched Fauna magazine, the staff has been pulling double duty.
 Mr. Smith is an amateur herpetologist with big plans for this slick, full-color magazine stuffed with razor-sharp images of snake-necked turtles, legless lizards, giant hornets and the seldom seen ridge-nosed rattlesnake and articles with headlines like "The Joy of Toads" and "Along Came a Spider." So far, he's been publishing 15,000 copies every other month, and toting his menagerie to schools all over the Island in search of an audience. His staff handles the business and advertising end; Mr. Smith does some editing but farms out assignments to scientists who know their invertebrates. The articles are geared to a general interest readers and are reviewed by an independent editorial board.
 "When we do grow up, we'd like to be National Geographic," said Mr. Smith, 43. "That's the benchmark for success in a nature magazine."
 Part of Mr. Smith's goal, he said, is to "dispel the myth that snakes are evil monsters."
"On a survey, when people ask what are you most afraid of, even today, after Sept. 11, 50 percent of the respondents said snakes," he said.
 Tarantulas also rank up there on the scary charts, said Mr. Smith, reaching into another tank, plucking out an African scorpion while mimicking an eerie soundtrack with a shiver-inducing "woooooooooooooo."
"This guy down here has a little danger involved," he said. "There's a bit of a wives' tale in every James Bond movie. You see this thing is crawling on somebody and you think it is going to kill you like a tarantula," he said, knowledgeably noting that it's the claws that can clip a victim like a lobster and the stinger in the back is venomous, though not more than a yellow jacket sting.
 Mr. Smith said his hankering for creatures that others shirk away from propelled him to launch the magazine.
 "I am a firm believer that these things have a right to exist," he said while readily admitting that though he's an environmentalist, the skin of a dead snake might make a fine-looking pair of shoes. "There are enough people worrying about polar bears and jaguars. When you get into the wild and see the relationship between all these animals that live on the forest floor, that's why we started Fauna. It's the forgotten fauna. These are animals no one knows about or cares about anymore. They really are the basis of the food chain and the basis of life. Without them, everything stops. They are not in danger. They are just completely understudied and misunderstood."
 Mr. Smith's fascination with snakes started when he was 6. The family had just moved to West Babylon from Manhattan and he was having a hard time acclimating to the neighborhood.
 "The kids across the hedges were screaming about something and out comes this little snake and I just instinctively went over and picked it up," he recalled. "It just didn't dawn on me to do anything but."
 His soon-to-be best buddies were absolutely shocked. His mother ran out of the kitchen screaming "put that down." The animal turned out to be a nonvenomous garter snake. From then on, he was hooked, venturing out on his bicycle all over the Island chasing down snakes, turtles and frogs, collecting them in a 55-gallon drum in the garage and peddling them to the pet departments of local department stores.
Except for breaks during college, where he studied business economics, and when he got married, Mr. Smith kept up his hobby. When his oldest son, Tyler, now 12, caught a snake in the backyard as a toddler, Mr. Smith got the bug all over again and started breeding. For hibernation season coming up, Mr. Smith and his three children boxed their 50 to 60 reptiles into cozy sweater boxes and put them in the crawl space under the basement to sleep for the winter.
 Humans wiped out the rattlesnakes that were indigenous to Long Island more than 125 years ago, Mr. Smith said. He is looking farther. It was during a eco-tour of Costa Rica last year that he started talking about a business to promote reptiles and amphibians and the possibility of reincarnating Fauna was proposed. The name had been used on reptile magazines that came and went three times in the last 50 years.
"It means the animal kingdom, that's the true definition of the word," said Mr. Smith, hoping to someday make jungle tours of Costa Rica, Madagascar and the Amazon part of the magazine's outreach. "We are just describing these forgotten species. We want people to understand that these animals certainly are not something you hit with a shovel if you see them in your garden, that they have a right to live."

Literary Great Neck
Great Neck has no shortage of literary aspirants. To celebrate the peninsula's writers, Muriel Turk, the director of programming for the Great Neck Library, initially compiled a list of people who grew up in Great Neck and became authors. "We heard from very few of them but their parents called a lot," Ms. Turk said. However, she was inundated with calls from authors who had lived in town for decades and felt they should be remembered too. 
 "We are including writers of every ilk," Ms. Turk said, counting novelists, editors, critics, journalists, biographers, playwrights, essayists, songwriters and poets. The register topped 300.
 Among those who showed up at a dessert reception on a recent Sunday afternoon were Murray T. Bloom, who since he moved to the area 51 years ago, has written eight books, seven of them non-fiction. His novel, "The Thirteenth Man," became a film, "Last Embrace," with Roy Scheider; his 1969 book, "The Trouble With Lawyers" was a best seller. He said writers were attracted to Great Neck because of its proximity to the city and that the locals "seemed to encourage literate pursuits."
 David J. Silverman, an enrolled agent and a Great Neck resident for three decades, was touting his "Taxes for Dummies,", now in its eighth edition. Robert H. Phillips, a psychologist, ticked off some of his more than 20 books on coping including, "Overcoming Your Panic: A Strategy Guidebook," "Coping with Diabetes" and "Coping with Breast Cancer." One-time author, Ricca Metz, was holding a copy of "Maudie: A Positive Nursing Home Experience," a book about her mother published last year.
 Gordon Korman, who has written 40 children's books including "No More Dead Dogs" and "I Want to Go Home," moved to Great Neck three years ago. He was thrilled to be recognized. "That's one of the things about kids' books," Mr. Korman said. "No one over the age of 14 knows who you are."
 Among literary luminaries on the list that will become part of the library's permanent collection were Herman Wouk, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Oscar Hammerstein and children's writers Margaret Wise Brown, Johanna Hurwitz and Esphyr Slobdkina. "This is a library," Ms. Turk said. "If there weren't authors and writers, what would we put on our shelves?"
