HEADLINE: Feeding the Fans 

BYLINE:  By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER, a former restaurant critic for The Times, is restaurant editor for Citysearch.com.

 BODY:
IF the world's major athletic spectacle is to invade a small American town -- and needs to be fed around the clock -- it might as well be Park City. This well-preserved former mining settlement, now a wealthy year-round resort, appears well braced for the challenge. With more than 100 restaurants, a dynamic business district (Main Street will be a pedestrian mall during the games) and well-regimented civic planning, this giant communal meal may well come off, if not seamlessly, at least with minimal broken china.
 As for getting reservations in the next few weeks, the situation, while very competitive, is not nearly as difficult as had been expected. More than half the corporations that booked entire restaurants for part or all of the Olympics for their hospitality suites have canceled or scaled back since Sept. 11, according to nearly a dozen restaurateurs interviewed. 
 "Companies have drastically cut back on their entertainment costs," said Steve Solomon, general manager of Zoom, a contemporary American restaurant in downtown Park City. "We all hoped that we'd have these million-dollar buyouts, but it didn't happen. We're sort of back to business as usual." But business as usual during ski season means very busy, so early reservations are essential. 
While Salt Lake City, about 30 miles west, is larger and has an emerging restaurant scene, it is surpassed in quality and variety by this affluent seasonal community.
But first, a word about Utah's complex liquor laws. Bars that do not serve food and certain restaurants are designated "private clubs." A modest admission fee, typically $5 to $10, grants you access for one to two weeks. Other than that, the vast majority of full-service restaurants have no such restrictions, and in fact some have substantial wine lists.
Here is a fall sampling of Park City's Olympic buffet.

Glitretind
Norwegian-born Stein Eriksen is to Park City what Jimmy Buffett is to Key Largo. A gold medalist in the giant slalom in the 1952 Olympics, Mr. Eriksen was involved in developing the luxurious 170-room lodge named after him (a condominium hotel). The restaurant there, named Glitretind, after a mountain in Norway, is considered by some as the highest gastronomic peak in town. 
The spacious L-shaped room is shadowy and romantic, with two stone fireplaces, deep comfy chairs, flattering candlelight and colorful Norwegian-style tapestries. From some of the tables there is a striking view of the snow-capped Wasatch Range, part of the Rockies.
Like most menus in this tourist town, Glitretind's is an ambitious melange of cuisines, in this case American, Italian and Asian. For the most part, the kitchen pulls it off. 
My companion and I started with nutty pumpkin and butternut squash soup tinged with cinnamon oil, perfect for a chilly fall evening. Our other choice was the ubiquitous tuna tartar, in this case called a tuna parfait. It didn't look very dessertlike, a squat cylinder of minced tuna supporting a buttery seared scallop, all garnished with caviar and wasabi oil. Best of all was a duo of intensely smoked, gamy little quails that were tender yet crisp-skinned, and slathered with a sweetish-hot barbecue sauce. 
Servers are fittingly reserved and vigilant in this hushed setting. The wine selection is exceptionally well chosen, focusing primarily on France, the West Coast and Australia. Somebody here likes sauvignon blanc, for the selection is copious and the prices are very low. We enjoyed a pleasingly citric 2000 Villa Maria from New Zealand ($24).
For the main course, a delicate and firm-fleshed wild salmon reminded me of how inferior the farm-raised variety is. The filets arrived wrapped with a thin sheet of smoked veal, almost like bacon, which sounds bizarre but was lovely, served with potato puree, beet greens and a rather bland ginger-and-beet infusion. 
Sichuan peppers and an aromatic tea glaze worked wonders for a seared duck breast, along with a wonton cone filled with fried rice and duck confit (why didn't my neighborhood Chinese place think of this?).
And as incongruous as it may seem after that alluring creation, Key lime pie was a fine finale.

Zoom
Chances are slim that you'll see Robert Redford, the proprietor of Zoom, slouched over the bar sipping spiced hot cider; nonetheless, this stylish and serious restaurant is worth a visit on its own merits.
Housed in a former Union Pacific depot, the handsomely renovated space features the well-worn original wood floor, cast-iron sconces, soft leather chairs and, on the walls, photos galore of Mr. Redford's contemporaries in the movie business, from a boyish Francis Ford Coppola to Julianne Moore.
The contemporary American cooking is clean and unambiguous, with well-assembled dishes like pecan-crusted trout and collard greens, herbed halibut with seared spinach, and barbecued buffalo kebabs with baked beans. One of the better starters is the excellent house-smoked salmon served with a thick potato pancake and a lemony dill cream sauce. Since these are chuck wagon portions, you might want to share. Macaroni and cheese was appropriately crusty and lumpy and as smooth as a toboggan run. 
Zoom draws a rakish apres-ski crowd, and it's a good place to drop in for a drink before or after dinner.

Riverhorse Cafe
A short walk up Main Street is Riverhorse, a big, stagy second-floor expanse with theatrical lighting, oversized nature paintings and a dining deck overlooking town and mountains. On the contemporary menu you'll find familiar dishes like seared ahi tuna with a very peppery ginger-soy sauce, a smoky rack of lamb bolstered by a viscous red wine sauce, and a thyme-scented rib steak. One of the specials, macadamia-encrusted halibut, was delightfully crusty and perfectly cooked, although it did not need the cloying Chinese hot-sweet sauce.
Service was slow and unobservant, even on a weeknight, but you have to love a waiter who, upon presenting the menu, confides: "The duck's not very good, so you don't have to worry about that." 
The menu touts the Riverhorse pot stickers, filled with shrimp and mixed vegetables, but what arrived were unremarkable deep-fried triangles of stuffed wonton skins. Tuna sashimi, though cut much too thick, was top quality. The most intriguing starter was called "spicy chicken and white onion pancake" embellished with "Texas ruby grapefruit salsa." Similar to a buttery rosti potato, it was golden and crisp, but it needed some salt and a lot of black pepper. 
Among desserts, you might go with the deep crock of mixed berry cobbler and the apple tart with cinnamon ice cream.
There are few bargains on the mostly American wine list. One good choice was the mellow and full-bodied 1999 Fetzer Merlot ($36.50).

Wasatch Brew Pub
The microbrewery and brew-pub phenomenon of the late 1980's got its start in the Rocky Mountain region, and today this is suds heaven for the visitor. Park City's major contribution is called Wasatch, made here by the Schirf Brewing Company. Inside the brewery, which is right in the middle of town, is the festive Wasatch Brew Pub. You can sample from 10 or more featured brews, everything from St. Provo Girl Pilsner (light and refreshing with a nice hoppy bite) to Hefe-Weizen (a yeasty unfiltered German-style wheat beer). Beer samplings are served daily by the good-humored staff.
The restaurant is a bright and casual place with pine booths and a crowded bar decorated overhead with beer mugs of regular imbibers. The publike fare is pleasing, copious and inexpensive: light, golden fish and chips, sauteed trout with garlic herb butter, salmon encrusted with pine nuts, and wintry homemade soups and stews. Only the ribs were disappointing, dry and overly sweet. A fitting dessert, gingerbread stout cake, was first-rate.

Chimayo
If you are looking for an indigenous adobe-and-tile Southwestern sort of place, try this upscale restaurant on Main Street. The food cannot be described as bona fide Mexican -- at least I've never happened upon calamari and mango salad in my south-of-the-border travels -- but it is generally flavorful and attractive. 
The dining room is an explosion of desert colors and textures -- rough brick, beautiful tiles, cascading dried flowers, wreaths strung with Christmas lights, orange and rust fabrics. 
Such an exhilarating setting cries out for margaritas, and they arrived filling giant frosted glasses. On tasting them we assumed there was some mistake -- they resembled limeade more than a cocktail. Utah law, it turns out, allows only a measured shot glass per drink, no matter how big the glass. We asked for the limited and overpriced wine list, finding the best deal in a 1999 Sanford sauvignon blanc ($38).
Almost every restaurant in Park City seems to serve some form of toasted corn chowder. This version was the best of our trip: earthy, sweet, lumpy with corn kernels and thickened with potatoes. 
While the most anticipated entree, roasted elk loin, was a dud -- underseasoned and paired with a feeble "spicy" bearnaise -- the barbecued duck enchiladas with a spicy tomatillo salsa were zesty and nicely balanced. Also good, when they have it, is the sauteed mountain trout and grilled lamb sirloin with a roasted corn pozole. 

Grappa
At the top of Main Street, in an imposing turn-of-the-century former miner's lodge, is the most romantic restaurant in Park City. Inside, the renovated-to-look-old interior is all brick and wood and stenciled stucco, with dangling copper pots and a copper hooded hearth. The staff could not be more welcoming -- three times they offered to change our table because there was a noisy large group nearby.
One of the more inventive items sampled was a napoleon of layers of polenta, spinach, cheese and dried tomatoes. Another fine starter was the woodsy wild mushroom ravioli in a mushroom and leek broth fricasee. Figs, minced pears and diced pecans made a terrific stuffing for grilled pork chops, which were served with mashed potatoes laced with pancetta. Osso buco was unconventional -- the meaty veal shank surrounded by a brothlike sauce with vegetables -- but savory and tender. Next to dishes like those, you might pass on the lackluster salmon in a horseradish crust, and the overorchestrated and underseasoned seafood linguine. 
The wine list here is substantial, as are prices. The most reasonable bottle we could find was a white, 1999 Ruffino Libaio ($38). . None of the dessert samples are worth recommending. 

The Stew Pot
This is the place to go when you really don't feel like going out to eat. It's a laid-back place of knotty pine tables facing the mountains -- you could probably clunk in with your ski boots and they wouldn't mind -- serving restorative dishes like chunky beef stew with freshly baked bread, hefty sandwiches and an authentic Cobb salad -- and for lunch nothing costs more than $10. The Stew Pot is a good place to take kids.

Lakota
While many Park City restaurants are close to ski slopes, Lakota, a vaguely Southwestern-style restaurant in the center of town, is literally on a ski slope. Patrons can slide down the mountain into a wooden bridge that connects with the entrance. Great fun; too bad most of the food is so mediocre. One exception is the sweet and golden crab cakes , so you might order some at the bar and take in the show.

Plus six in and around Salt Lake
All price estimates are based on the cost of a three-course dinner for two, with a glass of wine each, but not including tax and tip. Major credit cards are accepted unless otherwise noted. 
Metropolitan, 173 West Broadway, at 173 West and 300 South, (801) 364-3472, fax (801) 364-8671.
Dinner is served Monday through Saturday. With its striking modern design and solidly executed contemporary American food, this is the top restaurant in town for sophisticated diners. Among the best winter dishes are oxtail braised in red wine and the roasted baby chicken with an onion-apple stuffing. The bar area is called The Met "Bistro," with a less expensive menu of burgers, fried chicken and the like. (Diner's Club not accepted.) 
Dinner for two $100 to $120.
Fresco Italian Cafe, 1513 South, at 1500 East, (801) 486-1300, fax (801) 487-5379. 
Dinner daily. A 10-minute cab ride from downtown but well worth it, this snug little cottage has a congenial staff and a menu featuring bright, flavorful pastas and risottos, as well as savory meat and poultry classics. Menu highlights include spaghettini alla siena (with tomatoes, basil, olives, aged ricotta and artichokes), and grilled pork tenderloin with a dried cherry and Madeira sauce. 
Dinner for two $70 to $90.
Red Iguana, 736 West on North Temple, (801) 322-1489, fax (801) 322-4834. 
Lunch and dinner daily. A small, color-splashed cafe near downtown, this is the best Mexican spot in the city. Try one of the famous moles -- or all seven of them -- or the chili verde (pork cubes in a piquant tomatillo sauce). Carryout is popular, so you might want to take one of the hefty burritos or enchiladas to the Games. (No Diner's Club.) 
Dinner for two $40 to $50.
Market Street Grill, 48 West Market Street, at 340 South, (801) 322-4668, fax (801) 531-0730. 
Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily. A big old fish house with a long black dining bar and old-fashioned stools, this is a good bet for grilled fish of the day, fresh oysters and seafood chowders. A contiguous restaurant under the same ownership, Market Street Oyster Bar, is equally good (although it is technically a private club and charges a $10 temporary membership fee good for two weeks and up to seven people -- and smoking is allowed). 
Dinner at the Market Street Grill for two about $70.
Log Haven Restaurant, 6451 East Mill Creek Canyon, (801) 272-8255, fax (801) 272-6315. 
Dinner daily. Nestled deep in the Wasatch Mountains, this romantic 80-year-old log cabin, with two fireplaces and candlelit tables, is worth the 15-to-20-minute ride from downtown. The food is pleasing, if sometimes overworked, so stick with the simple dishes like green-tea-smoked duck breast with spicy sesame stir-fried long beans or steaks and game specialties. 
Dinner for two about $100.
W. H. Brumby's, 224 South 1300 East, near 200 South, (801) 581-0888, fax (801) 581-0889. 
Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily. If you want to escape from the downtown Olympic crowds, this delightful little bistro-bakery near the University of Utah (a five-minute ride from downtown), offers all kinds of wintry specials like cassoulet or braised lamb shank, and a wide selection of desserts and pastries. 
Dinner for two about $60. BRYAN MILLER

An article on Jan. 6 about Park City, Utah, the site of many events in the 2002 Winter Olympics, and a listing of dining places there, referred incompletely to the availability of two restaurants. HEADLINE: Diva Among the Divas 

BYLINE:  By Frank Bruni; Frank Bruni is a staff writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
'I should be dead by now," groans Beverly Sills as she rises from her desk at Lincoln Center with a comical roll of her eyes and heads to a meeting in the conference room across the hall. She walks slowly -- maybe because she had knee-replacement surgery over the summer, maybe because she knows that the meeting won't be a lark. Lately, not a lot in the center's offices has been. "I should have dates beneath my name," she continues, and although she means the comment as shtick, it has a more serious undercurrent.
 At 72, the diva could easily be resting on her laurels. Instead, she is standing at the helm of Lincoln Center, the premier performing arts organization in the country, as it navigates the roughest water it has encountered in a while. Against its bow crashes wave after wave of difficulties: cuts in city financing, slower ticket sales since Sept. 11 and the resignation in late September of Gordon Davis, the center's relatively new president, a disorienting development that has forced Sills, the center's chairman, to pick up much of the slack. 
 But that's not the worst of it. For several months now, Lincoln Center has come across more as a stage for petty resentments and persnickety feuds than as the city's temple of high culture. A billion-dollar-plus redevelopment plan set many of the center's 12 constituent groups to dreaming, but not in harmony. So New York City Ballet now feels put out by New York City Opera, which is nursing a grudge against the Metropolitan Opera, which is looking askance at the New York Philharmonic. And Sills is feeling slightly mortified. Can't they all just get along?
When she sits down on this morning in mid-December with senior executives of Lincoln Center Inc., or "Linc Inc.," which is a sort of umbrella group for the constituents, she almost immediately begins tearing the bagel on the plate in front of her into misshapen, doughy clumps. And when the executives discuss an idea for a concert that would require special coordination among the constituents, Sills says she shudders at the thought of creating another centerwide committee -- which would of course provide one more opportunity for constituents to squabble.
One executive enumerates for Sills and the others the ways in which the city's financial support for cultural institutions has tightened since Sept. 11; Linc Inc., the executive calculates, could lose $400,000 this fiscal year. ("Goody," Sills drolly interjects.) Another executive lists current and imminent repairs, which will cost nearly $40 million. The city is supposed to pick up that tab, but center executives worry that the city's budget woes could leave them on the hook. Still, Sills tries to remain hopeful; when the executive is about to finish his presentation, she asks him, "Are you going to end on an upper?"
The same question applies to Sills herself, who would like to go out on a high note, as she always has. She cut off her career as a singer at the age of 50, before the breadth and beauty of her coloratura soprano was diminished. She relinquished her subsequent role as the general director of City Opera only after she had turned around what had been a financially beleaguered company. She wants to leave Lincoln Center, the site of some of her greatest vocal triumphs, in steady, sturdy shape. And, she says, she wants to leave sooner rather than later.
But circumstances will not oblige. Neither, perhaps, will the facets of her personality and private life that keep driving her, long after any other prima donna would have faded away.
As a performer, Beverly Sills never contained herself. In her eagerness to please a mass audience, she refused to heed artistic conventions or obey traditional boundaries. When she wasn't playing Cleopatra in Handel's "Julius Caesar" or Queen Elizabeth in Donizetti's "Roberto Devereux," she was tap dancing with Kermit the Frog or filling in as a guest host for Johnny Carson. All of this was a measure of not only her energy but also her appetite for adoration, and it was one reason that she was more of a household name than any other opera singer of her era.
Born Belle Silverman and nicknamed Bubbles, she was simultaneously refined and earthy, the classical superstar with Brooklyn in her speaking voice, the sophisticated lady who could tell a bawdy joke. When Sills ran City Opera in the 1980's, she initiated bold changes that put the audience ahead of the aesthetes, including the use of supertitles, which translate lyrics into English, and a marketing campaign that was pure fun. ("Feel like hell?" asked one advertisement. "Come see 'Faust."')
People outside the opera world took note of her ingenuity and intelligence. Sills accepted invitations to sit on prestigious corporate boards: Macy's, Warner Communications, American Express. She grew chummy with New York City's mayors, chummier still with its news media luminaries. Her Rolodex was unrivaled, as was her ability to raise the philanthropic dollars on which arts organizations survive.
Small wonder that Linc Inc. came calling in 1994, choosing her to be the first woman and the first artist ever to head the group, which is both a constituent of the center and, crucially, the landlord of other constituents. Sills was told the job might consume 15 hours a week. She has more often spent double, triple or quadruple that amount of time on it.
And she has reigned supreme. "She is an empire unto herself," says Mayor Ed Koch, a longtime friend. "Nobody questions her." That is not, Koch says, because she makes them tremble, but because she tames them with her stature, good humor and disarming effervescence. "Everybody accedes -- willingly, not morosely -- to her requests, which are really not requests at all. They're orders from above." 
Sills and Nathan Leventhal, the center's president when she arrived, sparred at first. But they worked out their differences, and Sills's tenure was shaping up to be a charmed one. In the boom economy of the late 1990's, contributions to Lincoln Center rose steadily; since 1994, the separate endowments of Linc Inc., the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic each increased by 100 to 150 percent. 
But that growing wealth wasn't the genesis of the redevelopment initiative. As Sills tells the story, the plan originated in an idle thought she had about the electricity running behind the walls of her Central Park West apartment. "I thought, There's a lot of wiring going on here," she recalls. She realized that her sockets might not be in tune with today's technology -- and then realized that the same might be true of Lincoln Center. 
In late 1998, almost nonchalantly, she proposed that all of the center's constituents assess their physical needs. She expected to receive reports on erratic heating units and cracked travertine. She ended up with a request from the philharmonic to have Avery Fisher Hall entirely reconstructed and one from City Opera, which shares the State Theater with City Ballet, to leave the theater altogether for a home of its own. Before long, there was a tentative plan for a total overhaul, with a price tag, over the 10 years the project was expected to take, of $1.5 billion, including $100 million for a giant glass dome to be floated above the center's Upper West Side campus.
But the fun was only beginning.
To her surprise, Sills says, she learned that "a lot of the constituents were unhappy," and perhaps none more so than City Opera, which felt that it was trapped in an acoustical prison. The State Theater had been built for dance, and the stage that muffled the sounds of dancers' feet so effectively also muffled the sounds of singers' voices, or so officials with City Opera contended. They wanted their own opera house on the Lincoln Center campus, which meant a new building in Damrosch Park, a corner of green snug against one flank of the Metropolitan Opera.
Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met, wouldn't hear of it. "We would have no sunlight," he complains when I pay him a visit in December. Volpe had other qualms. He thought that City Opera's complaints about acoustics were partly camouflage for an inferiority complex about not having its own theater. Volpe also knew that if City Opera tried to raise an extra-large sum of money for an opera house at the same time that the philharmonic tried to raise an extra-large sum of money to improve Avery Fisher Hall, the Met might have more trouble raising its own extra-large sum of money if it were so inclined.
The Met, the most prosperous of Lincoln Center's constituents, saw little need for the fanciful, expensive aspects of the redevelopment plan, and Volpe threw up more roadblocks than anyone else. The other constituents kept an eye on Sills to see if she would fight him. She didn't.
Volpe decided that the dome was an extravagant and ill-conceived indulgence -- and so did Sills. "I said, 'A glass dome?"' she recalls. "We're going to have to heat it and air-condition it and clean the pigeon poop! Let me see a show of hands -- which constituent would like to pay for that?' Not a hand went up." 
Volpe decided that City Opera should not be encouraged to move into Damrosch Park -- and so did Sills. She argues that the park, which is owned by the city, isn't Lincoln Center's to take over and change.
Irwin Schneiderman, the chairman of City Opera, suggests that there was a "psychological aspect" to Sills's position, that she simply could not bring herself to believe that there were significant acoustical problems at the State Theater. After all, she had built her career and achieved her fame there; when she made the cover of Newsweek in 1969, she had yet to sing at the Met, next door. (At the time, the Met's general manager, Rudolf Bing, who tended to look down his nose at City Opera, said, "I have heard her sing, but not lately, and I can't remember in just what.")
Sills does seem to have strong opinions about the State Theater's sound quality. She says that when she and Placido Domingo performed in the State Theater, "there were never any complaints about the acoustics. I never got a review that said, 'Too bad we can't hear her in a decent opera house' or 'Gee, I couldn't hear Mr. Domingo sing at all."' There is now a system of tiny microphones scattered around the stage, and it clearly offends Sills. "The very art of opera singing," she tells me, "is unenhanced sound."
In the midst of all of this friction, Davis, who took over from Leventhal as the center's president at the start of 2001, abruptly resigned -- or was shown the door, depending on whom you talk to. His defenders say that he was exasperated by Sills's meddlesomeness -- she presided over meetings usually handled by the center's president, they say, even when knee surgery forced her to do so from home, by speakerphone. Her defenders say that Davis paid insufficient attention to the nitty-gritty of his job. Sills and Davis merely say that the arrangement wasn't working.
In early October, there was a meeting at which "all hell broke loose," according to someone knowledgeable about the details. Some center constituents accused Volpe, who was not there, of being a bullheaded obstructionist, while Sills defended him and made it clear that she shared his scaled-back vision of redevelopment. According to one news report, Marshall Rose, the real-estate developer who was then in charge of the project, was angry with Sills. (Though Rose has since resigned, he and Sills adamantly deny reports of tension between them. "I love Marshall," Sills says. "I wrote him a poem the other day!")
Several weeks later, a specially created redevelopment board, on which almost all of the center's constituents were represented, met to decide on a quasi-final redevelopment plan to submit to the city for approval. The board held separate votes on each proposed aspect of the plan; unanimity was necessary for approval of each point.
The dome died, although more than half of the board voted at least to preserve the option of building it. Sills's opposition to the dome clearly miffed a few other center officials who were involved in the process. One grouses that Sills has no visual sense and thus shouldn't be making design decisions; this official remarks that her apartment, which is filled with naive art, "looks like a Mexican flea market."
What City Opera ultimately got was an agreement that it could look for an appropriate location off-campus to build a $240 million opera house. The board decided that $326 million was in order for the reconstruction of Avery Fisher Hall and that even the Met needed about $179 million in improvements. 
Complications persist. If City Opera leaves the State Theater, City Ballet, now responsible for only 26 weeks of programming there, may have to figure out how to fill the missing weeks. If City Opera doesn't leave, it stands to lose $50 million, which its largest donor, the philanthropist Robert W. Wilson, has promised only if it moves into a new house.
Sills had only one vote on the redevelopment board, but in her way she had more moral force and influence than anybody else. When she weighed in, it was for keeping things relatively modest -- for trying to make sure the project was doable. Perhaps that was because she wanted to leave behind something certain. She says that as soon as a new president is found -- the position has been vacant since Davis left -- and brought up to speed, she will probably retire. That could be as soon as 3 months from now, or as long as 12.
For 10 minutes, Sills has been on the telephone, trying to placate a screechy donor who is worried about a plaque at the center, her reward for giving $100,000. Apparently, it is not shiny enough. Sills, sitting behind the desk in her office, promises to look into it and begs the woman to stop yelling. Finally, she holds the phone at arm's length for half a minute. The woman, ceaselessly talking, has no idea.
Why does Sills subject herself to this? People who have worked with her cite her passionate commitment to the arts and to Lincoln Center. But there is another reason for her devotion to her work. Barbara Walters, a close friend, hints at it when she asks me, "How much do you know about her private life?" She is referring to Sills's two children, a daughter, Muffy, 42, and a son, Bucky, 40, neither of whom has ever heard Sills sing. Muffy, who was born with a severe hearing impairment, was discovered to have multiple sclerosis 11 years ago and now lives at home with Sills. Bucky is autistic and has spent most of his time in institutions. Sills's husband, Peter Greenough, is also ill, physically debilitated by a stroke.
"I've had all the embroidered pillows that say, 'God gives the biggest challenges to those he loves the most,"' Sills says, "and there were days when I felt I could do with a little less love." She punctuates the remark with one of her sunny, dependable laughs, but friends aren't fooled. Some suggest that her role at Lincoln Center gives her an escape from her grief. "Lincoln Center is a tangible series of problems she can do something about," says Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's cultural affairs commissioner under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, adding that the center "keeps Beverly sane."
Finally, there is this: Sills long ago grew accustomed to being the center of attention, the cynosure of a colorful and melodramatic whirl. But when her vehicle was a real opera, there were flowers and shouts of "Brava!" at the curtain call. When she finally leaves the soap opera at Lincoln Center, that may not be the case, and some of the people around her think that she is only now coming to painful terms with that.
"She's a diva, you know," says one top official at Lincoln Center in an affectionate and even sympathetic tone. "She wants everybody to love her and everything that's said about her to be positive." Her current situation has made that impossible, and there are times when she seems beaten down by it. "Not being loved," the official says, "does more harm to a diva than anything else."
One night toward the end of December, I visit Sills in a dressing room at Avery Fisher Hall, where she is about to appear as host of a broadcast of the television series "Live From Lincoln Center." She has a sore throat and a fever and sits lifelessly in front of a mirror as a makeup artist adds color to her cheeks. She allows herself a reminiscence: of the late 1960's, when the area around Lincoln Center was rough enough that she warned Muffy away from it. "All of that has changed, because of Lincoln Center," she says proudly. "Its tentacles just spread."
But what of its future? The city's budget woes could force the new mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, to rethink a pledge of more than $150 million in aid to the redevelopment project that Giuliani made. When I ask Bloomberg if that promise is solid, his answer stops short of a guarantee. "Subject to whatever finance problems the city has," he says, "it is certainly a commitment I will do everything possible to keep."
There is also no assurance, in the wake of Sept. 11, that Lincoln Center can find the private money for a project of this scale. The reports of infighting at the center won't make things easier. Martin E. Segal, a former chairman of Linc Inc., says that at dinner parties, he is constantly asked why center officials are "at each other's throats," as he puts it. "If you are a wealthy donor and you read one story after another that gives the impression of a chaotic situation -- which, in my opinion, there isn't -- then that gives you pause," he says. 
As she prepares to face the camera, Sills says, "Boy, I'm tired," and adds, with a cough, that "nothing is functioning." She means her body and her brain, but it's hard not to wonder if, at some level, she also means the grand plans for Lincoln Center. This time there are no eye rolls and there is no shtick -- just an aura of genuine exhaustion. When I see her a few minutes later on a television screen, she looks surprisingly radiant. But the hour is getting late, and she cannot hide the creeping hoarseness in her voice.

HEADLINE: Theater; 
Downtown Theaters Enter a New World

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN FIFE; Stephen Fife is a playwright and screenwriter. His play "New Day" recently completed a run in the East Village.

 BODY:
AS most people in the downtown theater world know only too well, reverberations from the World Trade Center attacks can still be felt in the less traveled streets of Lower Manhattan and the smaller audiences that make their way to the area's theaters.
 The Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York, a service and advocacy group for the city's more than 400 nonprofit theaters and related organizations, recently estimated an income loss for its member companies of $5 million for 2001 (lost ticket, space rental and concession income as well as postponed benefit performances) and a projected loss for 2002 of $16.3 million (reduced contributions and ticket sales). Despite the cooling of the national economy, A.R.T./New York tied the losses explicitly to Sept. 11, where, the group reported, "for theaters operating on tight margins, without the safety net of cash reserves and endowments, two days to two weeks of lost income can make the paying of staff and rent difficult." 
 This has certainly been true for theaters below Union Square and extending south toward ground zero. The city's decision to pump funds into Broadway -- recently buying millions of dollars worth of tickets to a variety of shows, like "The Phantom of the Opera" and "Beauty and the Beast" -- has not been matched by an equivalent plan for downtown theaters. 
One response has been the formation of Downtown NYC, a coalition of theater owners, dance and theater companies, producers, art galleries, restaurants and other small businesses "to address the challenges confronting our extended community," said the group's founder, Scott Morfee, a commercial theater producer.
Some philanthropic groups have come forward, led by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, which announced that it was establishing a $50 million fund to help support cultural and performing arts organizations affected by repercussions from Sept. 11. 
Artistic directors of a number of nonprofit theaters below Union Square, as well as Mr. Morfee and another commercial producer, responded to questions recently about their experiences after Sept. 11 and their hopes for the New Year. Here are excerpts from their replies. 

VIRGINIA P. LOULOUDES
Executive director, Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York
 What happened at the World Trade Center is similar to what Sophocles was writing about. I think that dealing with subject matter like this is why theater began. It's a place where people convene and tell stories. Those stories used to be about the things most important to us -- catastrophes, the power of the gods, myths. And if there was ever a time when we need to be focused on primal things, it is now. Our values were completely reoriented after Sept. 11 -- to some extent in a good way.
I don't think any company is going to go under. There's a difference between saying things are bad and locking the doors. If the recession deepens and downtown businesses continue to fail, then we could be looking at something worse. But the bigger danger is that theaters will exist in a substandard way. They will work without pay and health insurance, their potential will go unrealized, and the next Arthur Miller or Tony Kushner will never write that great play for them.

KRISTIN MARTING
Executive director, Here Arts Center
The events of that morning caused us to cancel 14 performances of three different shows. In addition, several other shows just canceled outright. In all we lost around $60,000 in income. Then our insurance company -- to whom we pay astronomical rates -- denied our claim on a technicality.
I went about trying to uncover other sources of revenue for nonprofit arts organizations, only to find they don't exist. It was a very frustrating time. Our building didn't fall down, none of our staff was injured, but do we need to apologize for trying to stay in business? I mean, the for-profit businesses were given help, while the nonprofits generate all this revenue for the city.
It raises the old issues about our having second-class-citizen status. I deal with this all the time, but I've never had it so reinforced. At the same time, the night we re-opened was just so meaningful. Our friends in the community came back to let us know how important Here was to them. This just made me aware of why we do what we do.
We cut $100,000 from our budget, almost all from productions we canceled or postponed. A few foundations helped us raise most of the money we'd lost, and the audience is now down only about 10 percent to 20 percent from usual. I'm no longer worrying that my payroll checks will bounce.

DAVID FULLER
Producing artistic director, Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater
When the attacks happened, we were in the middle of rehearsals for "Oedipus the King" and were performing Tennessee Williams's "Small Craft Warnings," which was a hit for us, often selling out. The immediate effect was to cut our box office in half. New subscriptions dropped off to almost nothing.
Because we don't just produce show to show, but employ a repertory format, I think that saved us psychologically. We got back on our feet right away. And the good news is that our audience has largely come back. We are poised for a major move forward, looking for a larger theater space.
But I have to say that around noontime on Sept. 11, I was worried about whether we even had a theater anymore. Those were some pretty anxious moments, and it's heartening to see where we are now.

PETER MEINECK
Artistic director, Aquila Theater
Before Sept. 11, we were selling out a 300-seat theater. Then, for contractual reasons, we had to move to a 148-seat space nearby. Suddenly, no one was coming. Then every time we'd build up attendance Attorney General John Ashcroft would announce another unspecified warning, and the audience would vanish again. It made me really angry. I'm British, but I'm also a big fan of America, and I'm going through my citizenship process right now. But in this case, I felt like my government was working against me.
I'm certainly not antiwar. I was a Green Beret myself, with the Royal Marine commandos. I think Americans have to realize that fighting terrorists has been a part of the world since World War II. All of us have to tough it out together. When people call up our box office and say, "I'm too scared to come to the theater," I think that's unpatriotic.
It reminds me of what Winston Churchill once said, when asked to close the theaters because of dangers from the Nazi blitz. He turned to an Air Force marshal and asked, "Good God, man, what are we fighting for then?"

ANGELINA FIORDELLISI
Artistic director, Cherry Lane Theater
For our show "Havana Is Waiting," we just found it so difficult to get the word out. We had a 100,000-piece mailing that went down the drain, lost in the anthrax scare. People seemed afraid to come downtown. That was a big issue.
I think our potential ticket-buying audience is still in shock. I'm sure they'll come out of it soon, and that gives me hope. But if I think about how January and February are usually the worst times to open new shows, then it could be a dark time, literally, for theaters downtown.

DOUGLAS AIBEL
Artistic director, Vineyard Theater
The situation after 9/11 was very tough for us. Our Laura Nyro musical, "Eli's Coming," was on its way to a commercial run, which got derailed. The scenery for our next show was stuck in New Jersey, with the tunnels and bridges closed down. Our massive mailing had gone out two days before, and was completely a bust. Our new subscriptions were down 80 percent. Our phones and e-mail were down.
The night it was announced that Tom Brokaw's assistant had anthrax, we had 40 cancellations. We were also grieving for our local firehouse, which lost half its men. We did manage to raise $16,000 for them from audience donations.
The loss for us this season is around $300,000. There was a lot of talk after 9/11 about what was going to be palatable for audiences, that people were looking for the theatrical equivalent of comfort food. I felt that way too.
But in the end, we decided to go forward with "Brutal Imagination," a dark play. We were absolutely adamant that we would not adjust our programming. We're hoping and praying that there is still a serious theater audience out there that will come back to Off Broadway.

ELLEN STEWART
Artistic Director, La Mama E.T.C.
We did not have an audience problem after the attacks. And we're not that far away: we did get that bad air. But the restaurants are filled down here in the East Village . People are in the streets. You would not know anything had happened, and I don't know if that's good or bad.
We always have people coming from all over the world, and so far no one has said they are not coming except one group: a theater troupe in Istanbul called the Fifth Street Theater that refer to themselves as Mama's Boys. But they were frightened to come because there were incidents on CNN of Arab-looking people being attacked in the United States. They were the only ones to cancel.
This year, La Mama is 40 years old, so we're accustomed to rolling with the punches. If we have something people want to see, they come. And if we get a review in The New York Times and it's good, we're packed. Many times we have a beautiful show and we don't have a review -- which requires word of mouth and takes a while. We've learned to deal with not getting full houses. 
From the end of December through early February we are having a teensy-weensy festival from Israel: Arabs who live in Tel Aviv; black Jews from Ethiopia; and a Yemenite dance troupe. In the December part of the festival we had two Arabs and two Israelis doing a play together.

DANIEL AUKIN
Artistic director, Soho Rep
I remember saying to the cast of the play we were working on: "This event is too much for us to process right now, but it's important to remain available to how it will inflect everything we do." And it has.
It has made us more conscious of how close we could come to closing down. This energized and provoked us and our board into more urgency, in terms of our long-term planning.
And maybe it has made people more receptive to unconventional subject matter now, as in our current play, " sic " about three young, artistically inclined neighbors living in a limbo of their own devising, consciously or not . Perhaps the events in some way helped to create an atmosphere of openness.

MARK RUSSELL
Executive director, Performance Space 122
 The ecology of these places that develop artists was really threatened by 9/11, because losing $10,000 to $15,000 can make the whole thing stumble: it can close you. We lost $80,000 in canceled rentals. I'm just lucky I have a staff that is pretty creative about making do with less.
The other thing that is hard to quantify is the psychic damage and stress. Everyone on our staff was going through this re-evaluation, where you ask: "What am I doing with my life? Making entertainment? When people are dying 20 blocks downtown?" I went through a huge crisis. I usually feel like the center of a community, but without e-mail or phones, I couldn't fulfill this.
I think we've come back in a stronger way, and our audiences have shown that we're a part of their lives too. But I feel like the millennium really began on 9/11. And it's a whole different world now.

WOODIE KING
Producing director, Henry Street Settlement
The attack on the World Trade Center has changed the nature of philanthropy in New York. It's going to impact the large cultural institutions, and if that happens the way we think, it will almost certainly destroy the small cultural institutions like us. 
We've weathered a lot of storms because we deal with sweat-equity people who work for nothing because they're young and just entering the business. But corporate giving, foundation giving, has become very, very slow. We're retrenching in order to survive.

JIM NICOLA
Artistic director, New York Theater Workshop
 We had a meeting on Oct. 1 to share our experiences about 9/11. People wanted to discuss: "What should we do as artists? How is this going to make its way into our work?"
But I thought that first we needed to talk about how we felt about this as people. And then once we had gotten through that, we could go on to the second part.
In the end, we went well into the night. People cried, got angry. We tried to rebuild in an emotional way, putting one foot in front of the other, and just being happy that we were alive, in the same room together.
We never got to Part 2.

SCOTT MORFEE
A producer of "Underneath the Lintel" at the SoHo Playhouse
 I'm a small-time independent commercial producer. A month and a half or so after Sept. 11, our show was growing daily, really picking up steam at a clip of almost 20 percent a day. Then Mr. Ridge Tom Ridge, head of the Office of Homeland Security announced that the holidays were going to be a time of increased danger. Our sales dropped 800 percent in one day.
I started calling other producers, expecting people to put on this false front, this positive face. Instead, there wasn't a single person I spoke with who wasn't forthcoming, who didn't start talking hard numbers.
That became the impetus for Downtown NYC www.DowntownNYC.info a community of people who actually care about each other, and who share ideas and promotions. Boosting business and boosting the city of New York -- that is the essence of our group. Beyond that, it remains to be defined.

GEORGE C. WOLFE
Producer, Joseph Papp Public Theater
Almost 30 acts coming into Joe's Pub canceled right away. We lost close to $50,000. Our endowment was affected and we had to lay off more than 20 staff people.
We've been using this time to re-examine what we do here, and to figure out how we can be more efficient. Everyone was overworked before; now they're really overworked. Every nonprofit group is going to have to deal with this new economic reality we find ourselves in.
In times of plenty, one can afford to be indifferent and selfish. In times of need, there exists the possibility of rediscovering community. We've all got to be smart and tough and try to support each other.

JIM SIMPSON
Artistic director, Bat Theater Company at the Flea Theater
Before the attacks, we had five shows running in rep and two dance concerts, all playing to 95 percent capacity. When we reopened a month later, our box office went down to 5 percent. I closed three of the shows and the dance concerts. "Closing show to survive" -- very bizarre.
I have a company of 35 actors, and some felt strongly that we had to deal with the tragedy. I went looking for a journalist who could instruct us in gathering interviews. I found Anne Nelson, a journalism professor at Columbia University. She told me she had been writing eulogies for a fire captain she knew. I encouraged her to turn these into a two-hander play. Eight days later, I received the script, called "The Guys." We immediately did a reading with Bill Murray and my wife, Sigourney Weaver. We decided to do a workshop to see what we had. The brief run ended last month. 
I feel like I've rediscovered theater's ability to turn on a dime and to respond in real and immediate ways. It's a great advantage to being down here. We don't have any subscribers. I'm looking to renew the theater, and that means a younger audience, who don't subscribe. We have an artists-driven agenda. I hope we can stay around, because the cultural life of downtown is very important.

JEFF COHEN
Artistic director, Worth Street Theater
On Sept. 10, we were in the process of transferring a successful production to a commercial run, and our theater was rented solid through March. Then, in a matter of days, everything canceled, and I had to give all the money back.
All of a sudden we had this empty 80-seat theater just a few blocks from ground zero. We didn't know if downtown would ever come back. In the middle of it all, I had this idea: "What about doing an old-fashioned free U.S.O. show for the workers?" 
My producer and I handed out fliers every Monday to firemen, policemen, construction workers, sanitation workers and the volunteers who care for them and feed them. 
The performers at "Stage Door Canteen" have been incredible -- many were Tony Award winners or nominees, others were headlining comics. They showed up at 5 o'clock, rehearsed with our three-piece band, and by 7 p.m. it came together. Everyone donated their services. It put smiles on people's faces and I could feel a weight lifting from them. 
It has filled me with tremendous optimism. And good things have started to happen. Philip Morris and New York Community Trust have come forward with emergency grants. And I have rentals again. We're going to be using the space for our next show, "Tartuffe," beginning this Saturday, and free tickets will be available at every performance for ground zero workers and volunteers.
I think we're going to be all right. I think downtown is coming back.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A symposium on Jan. 6 about the effects of the Sept. 11 attacks on theaters in Lower Manhattan misstated the affiliation of one contributor, Woodie King. He is producing director of the New Federal Theater, not the Henry Street Settlement.

HEADLINE: And the Winner Is: West Haven, for Now 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WEST HAVEN and neighboring Orange have been embroiled for years in what both sides agree has become a David vs. Goliath battle for a new Metro North train station.
 But both sides are convinced they are David. 
 The estimated $25 to $30 million station would be built right in the middle of the nine-mile stretch of track from Milford to New Haven. That stretch is the longest from New York City to New Haven without a stop -- a ride that can take as long as 18 minutes. It would also be the first new station built along the main line in Connecticut since the route was established about a century ago. 
But last month's long-awaited decision by the South Central Regional Council of Governments after months of debate to recommend the West Haven site off Interstate 95 at Saw Mill Road, rather than at a nearby location in Orange, only confirmed what Mitchell Goldblatt, the first selectman of Orange, was worried about all along.
"We're just a small suburban town fighting a larger city that has the support of New Haven," Mr. Goldblatt said. "I said from the beginning and still believe if the issue is improving the transportation needs of the region and getting cars off the roads then Orange is clearly the better site."
But now that the council, which is made up of 15 mayors and first selectmen has chosen West Haven, Mr. Goldblatt said he has appealed to Gov. John G. Rowland, the commissioner of transportation, John Sullivan, and the State Legislature to intervene before it's too late.
"I just cannot accept the decision by the council of governments because I truly believe Orange is the better site for the region," Mr. Goldblatt said.
But, as Mr. Goldblatt has said all along, "if the main issue is helping an urban center then of course we don't stand a chance."
Indeed, the 9 to 6 vote by the council in favor of West Haven was apparently motivated by a desire by the region's mayors and first selectmen to address the greater economic needs of West Haven, which they indicated was a major factor in their decision.
"Why shouldn't it have been a factor?" Richard Borer, the mayor of West Haven, asked. "If the station is going to have about the same impact on the region and you can also help thousands of people in an urban area, it seems clear to me that that is the way to go." Mr. Borer also pointed out that while there are just under four miles of train tracks that run through his city, only a few thousand feet runs through Orange.
"Our citizens have all the inconveniences of train tracks -- noise, pollution and danger -- and none of the benefits," Mr. Borer said. "Our residents deserve to have the station and have fought hard for it. Where is the support in Orange other than in the first selectmen's office and at Bayer?"
The Bayer Pharmaceutical Corporation, with a campus that straddles the border of both communities and with 2,000 employees, has strongly supported and lobbied for the Orange site. Bayer employees, some of whom ride a shuttle to and from the New Haven train station, would be able to walk to and from an Orange station.
"We were extremely disappointed by the council of government's decision to build the station in West Haven," said Laura Malis, a spokeswoman for Bayer. "We believe the station should be built in Orange and still support Orange's efforts to accomplish that."
Mr. Borer said he was surprised by Mr. Goldblatt's plans to appeal the council's decision and suggested that the Orange first selectmen accept a West Haven station. "I don't know what the governor or State Legislature can do," Mr. Borer said. "This a decision that needed to be made by the region and it has been made by the region. Now we should just move ahead and do whatever it takes to get the station built as quickly as we can."
But Mr. Goldblatt is angry that the council's decision came just a week after a council transportation committee comprised of transportation experts recommended the Orange site and just a few months after a major state study also chose Orange as the preferred site. As the battle has heated up, so have the tensions between the two communities. Hundreds of West Haven residents, spurred by an active grass-roots movement, packed recent hearings and made emotional pleas urging the station be built in their community.
"This is something West Haven has been waiting 50 years for," said Paul Frosolone, a lifelong resident. "It would change the city overnight by providing rail service for thousands of people who could use the train to get to better jobs in Fairfield County and New York." 
In Orange, a special train station committee was appointed several months ago by the first selectman to lobby for an Orange station.
"The Orange site is far better and I literally walked the tracks to figure that out," said the co-chairman of the Orange Railroad Committee, Richard Slawsky, former economic development director in West Haven who became convinced Orange was the better site while still in his West Haven post.
Mr. Goldblatt, armed by a state study, said an Orange station would be cheaper, could be built at least a year faster and would be more accessible to commuters who would use the station in greater numbers, which means getting more cars off the roads than a West Haven station.
"This was a major decision by the Council of Governments, there's no doubt about that and right now it very much looks like it's going to be in West Haven," said Harry Harris, transportation bureau chief of the State Department of Transportation. "But nothing can happen until the D.O.T. and the Council of Governments reach agreement on where the station should go." Mr. Harris said that won't happen until completion of the in-depth environmental study, which could cost in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Orange is not giving up.
"It may not look good right now," Mr. Goldblatt said. "But the ball seems to keep bouncing back and forth on this and I still believe in the end the station will be built here."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Small-Town Atmosphere of 'Burys' Attracts Growth

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
DEVELOPMENT is accelerating along the Interstate 84 corridor in the semirural towns of Southbury and Middlebury. Land that is priced lower than in the more-expensive Fairfield County next door, including 1,500 acres of excess holdings for sale by I.B.M., has been attracting businesses; home builders are submitting proposals for subdivisions to accommodate expected population growth; and home buyers thirsting for small-town life away from expensive suburbs are willing to make longer commutes to work.
 "Over the next few years we'll see a lot more development in the 'burys,' " said Joanne Carroll, president of the Fairfield County Home Builders Association, referring to Danbury in Fairfield County, Southbury and Middlebury in New Haven County and Roxbury and Woodbury in Litchfield County. "The region has that remoteness that all of a sudden people are looking for," she said, "and the demand for high-end homes is bringing in developers from the Farmington Valley to Westchester." 
 Southbury and Middlebury, straddling I-84 at exits 14 and 16, are not exactly overjoyed at being invaded. "This is a little Currier & Ives community of 6,100 people living in 18 square miles," said Middlebury's first selectman, Edward St. John. "We feel very strongly about controlling growth. Nothing much has changed since we were incorporated in 1807." 
But it has. Recent years have brought million-dollar lakeside homes, the price of building lots has climbed to as much as $600,000, and more change is on the way as businesses expand or move into town. The Crompton Corporation, a specialty chemical company, is transferring its Greenwich operations to an expansion of its existing Middlebury operations. Local real estate agents are expecting sales to some of the 200 employees now in Greenwich.
Henry Paparazzo, the award-winning builder of Heritage Village in Southbury, paid a little more than $1 million for 60 acres on Route 188 in Middlebury four years ago, where he is building Avalon Farms, named after the farm it is replacing. Five of a planned 48 Cotswold-cum-Normandy-style homes have been built and are priced at $500,000 to $700,000, but only one house has been sold since the opening early last year. Mr. Paparazzo attributes the slow sales in part to indecision in the immediate aftermath of the terrorist attacks. "Our market is Fairfield County and Westchester, the people most affected by Sept. 11," he said. "It has caused some hesitancy."
According to Mary Ann Hebert, co-owner of Bannon & Hebert Properties, sales agent for Avalon Farms, "we have had some of Crompton's midrange executives looking at the model house." Sales are restricted to people older than 40 with no children younger than 18.
TRADITIONS, a 150-home New England shingle-style development on 90 acres in Southbury, is having more success. It has sold 17 homes since early November and has taken down payments of 10 percent on five more. Nothing has been built except a sales office, where people are buying from floor plans and virtual video tours of the homes, which range in price from $324,900 to $464,900. 
The success of Traditions could be attributed to its appeal to a variety of buyers -- childless couples, families, active empty nesters, single people and retirees. Twelve two- to four-bedroom models, each with three different elevations, range in size from 1,950 to 3,057 square feet and range in price from $324,000 to $444,900.
The houses, designed by William Devereaux & Associates of McLean, Va., have porches, lofts, two-story foyers and family rooms. Other features on some homes include master bedrooms on the ground floor, walkout basements, one- and two-car garages, libraries and upstairs sitting rooms. 
Construction of 150 houses is expected within three years. During that time, several amenities will be added, including a village green and gazebo, an amphitheater, a children's playground and a community meeting house with a stage, fitness center, outdoor pool and children's pool.
Seven models at Avalon Farms, from 2,700 to 4,355 square feet, designed by Richard Moisan, head of Moisan Architects in Woodbury, "are deliberately different from the early New England reproductions that everyone else is doing," he said. Faux stonework exteriors, master bedrooms and baths on the ground floor, two or three additional bedrooms and one or two additional baths on the second floor are featured. Some homes have lofts, walkout basements, two-story foyers and family rooms; all models have mudrooms, laundries, two half-baths, decks or patios and two- or three-car garages.
Avalon Farms will customize homes to the extent that room sizes can be changed, walls can be eliminated and the footprint of the house expanded. Traditions will customize only interior decorating and will upgrade appliances, plumbing and lighting fixtures, floors and carpeting.
Both projects are being developed in clustered enclaves of four or five homes surrounding mini-greens. The driveways empty onto a road that encircles the mini-green and exits onto the subdivision road. Ten percent or more of the land is dedicated to open space.
Traditions' developer is Spectrum Skanska, a five-year-old company formed when the Spectrum Group Ltd. of Westchester, whose president and chief executive was Mitchell C. Hochberg, became a wholly owned subsidiary of Skanska U.S.A. 
Skanska U.S.A.'s parent, Skanska of Stockholm, has $16 billion in annual revenue, owns about 25 companies worldwide and is one of the largest international builders of highways, bridges, tunnels, offices, stadiums, airports and housing. "Our emphasis is on the United States," said Stuart Graham, executive vice president for American operations, "because it's the largest construction market in the world."
"In order to continue to grow, Skanska had to expand outside the Swedish borders -- it's always been the culture of Scandinavia to export services, going back to the Vikings," he said.
Mr. Hochberg, who now reports to Mr. Graham, has switched his focus from building multimillion-dollar homes in Westchester and Fairfield to what he calls "lifestyle communities." 
"To support the amenities we provide, we need a large number of units," he said, "and Skanska has the financial and construction capabilities to do larger and more numerous projects at more competitive prices." 
Housing is also to be built by the Timex Corporation, a longtime resident of Middlebury. The company is not going into the housing business, according to John Pollard, whom Timex hired as development consultant. It is merely using 94 acres of the site that it bought for a new headquarters but does not need for the building. The 79 homes will be age restricted -- at least one occupant must be over 55 -- and will be sold on the open market in the low $300,000 range. Timex obtained a zoning change and will submit final site plans within 60 days.
According to Jean Donegan, Middlebury's zoning enforcement officer, Omega Technologies, which is based in Stamford, will erect a satellite building on 101.8 acres that it owns in Middlebury. The property is approved for 11 commercial buildings, including Omega's, and it will be the town's first business park. 
Ms. Donegan noted that Forest Walk L.L.C. had submitted a proposal for 286 housing units on 17 acres requiring a zone change. Hearings are scheduled on Jan. 29 and 30. A proposal for 126 single-family homes by Baker Residential of Pleasantville, N.Y., was recently rejected. "We are likely to appeal," said John Horton, director of project development for Baker. A zoning change from industrial to residential was granted by the planning and zoning commission last February, he said, and specific reasons for the rejection were not disclosed.
Roads throughout the open part of Transitions include one that is a quarter of a mile long and extends into the adjacent property: Mr. Paparazzo's Heritage Village. The road, which will cost Spectrum Skanska $250,000, will be gated and locked and will be for the sole use of emergency vehicles that require access to Heritage Village and would otherwise be blocked by Traditions.
Mr. Paparazzo owned the Traditions property at one time and planned it as an addition to Heritage Village. But when threatened with foreclosure in the recession of the early 1990's, he sold it to Summit Residential of Monroe. Summit sought approval of the Papparazzo plans for 150 homes in 1998 but was unable to begin work within the town's one-year limit from approval to construction. "That's when Skanska stepped in," said DeLoris Curtis, Southbury's planning administrator. Skanska paid $9.5 million for the property last June. 
Mark Cooper, Southbury's first selectman, worries about maintaining the town's rural character, noting the attraction of the highly rated Southbury-Middlebury regional public school system and the availability of land -- only 18,000 people live within the town's 40.9 square miles.
"There used to be more cows than people," he said. "Now we have million-dollar houses; companies like I.B.M., Comsat Corporation, Kmart Corporation, the Gap, AT&T Global Network; and big housing developments."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Connecticut and Westchester copies on Jan. 6 about housing construction in Middlebury and Southbury, Conn., misstated the policy of the Avalon Farms development on the age of purchasers. The development has no age restrictions; it does not require that purchasers be older than 40, with no children younger than 18.

HEADLINE: Start-Ups Tailored to the Times Thrive 

BYLINE:  By MARCI ALBOHER NUSBAUM 

 BODY:
The double whammy of terrorist attacks and recession has hurt or destroyed untold small businesses in the New York metropolitan area, from restaurants and shops near ground zero to travel agencies and financial printers. But some have thrived and are even hiring workers.
 Consider Lexolution, the brainchild of three executive recruiters. They left an established firm to start their own company on Oct. 1 to provide contract and temporary lawyers to law firms. 
 "With layoffs and slowdowns in permanent hiring, many firms are turning to us to fill the gaps," said Nora Plesent, one founder. And in a recession, when even highly qualified lawyers can get the ax, the pool of talent for Lexolution to choose from has widened. "With resumes that read Harvard undergrad, Harvard law, major law firm, it's a kick," Ms. Plesent said.
In its first month, Lexolution has had meetings with over 20 law firms and placed more than 10 contract lawyers. The company, which began its life in the basement of one partner's home, signed an agreement to lease office space near Grand Central Terminal, starting Jan. 1. "Because the market is so soft, we found ourselves with a lot of options," Ms. Plesent said.
A substantial number of industries and professions are either flourishing in, or at least weathering, the post-Sept. 11 recession, economists say. These include pharmaceutical companies, mobile-phone makers, munitions suppliers, security specialists, bankruptcy-related services, secondary education, fast food, public transportation, health care, home entertainment, social workers and physical therapists.
The Garden City Group, a legal-administration company in Melville, N.Y., for example, has just opened a reorganization unit to capitalize on the surge in bankruptcies that has taken filings nationwide to a record 1,437,000 in the year ended Sept. 30.
The company's bread-and-butter is administering claims for large class-action cases, but it quickly realized that providing Chapter 11 services for law firms and debtors was a natural business extension. So it recruited Karen Shaer, the general counsel of a client company that had been through the class action and Chapter 11 process itself, to run the new unit.
As a result of its expansion, Garden City has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in new technology, redeployed several people, cross-trained others and moved into an office with double the space.
In its first two months, the new unit has been retained by two clients, and hopes to add 10 to 15 new cases this year. 
Another sector that usually gets a lift when the economy dips is education, particularly in those fields that job applicants can use to enhance their marketability. This year, applications to law schools and business schools are up, and Princeton Review Inc., a New York-based test-preparation outfit, says its enrollment has skyrocketed. "Prior to Sept. 11, our G.M.A.T. and LSAT growth were almost double what they were last year, and since Sept. 11, our growth has doubled again," said Jaime Bederman, the company's national director for graduate program marketing.
Fuller classrooms mean the company has stepped up hiring. Amy Smith, who runs the Long Island office, says the recession has improved the quality of job candidates. "We've seen people who were running their own businesses, reporters, graduate students and even some high-level people laid off by major corporations," she said.
Therapists and other calmers of the soul have also enjoyed a surge of business, too. Jonathan Fields opened his Sonic Yoga NYC in Manhattan on Nov. 12 with the slogan, "Taking back the holiday." By the end of the month, he had signed up 100 customers, triple his projection, for 10-session packages costing $150. "So far so good," he said.
Another specialty niche that is thriving is the fight against chemical or biological weapons. The anthrax scare created a sudden and intense demand for the services of Sylkworks Inc., a North Haledon, N.J., medical surveillance start-up, according to Brad J. Blaschak, the chief executive. Two potential but cautious investors suddenly committed money to the venture, he said. Soon after, Sylkworks sent a team to hospitals in Trenton, where postal workers were being treated for anthrax exposure, and established a method to help medical professionals diagnose and treat anthrax.
Today, its systems are in place in 16 hospitals in New Jersey, and the company expects that number to jump to 50 nationwide by the end of January. 
Then there is the personal-security profession. Tom Patire, founder of CDT Training Inc., an Elmwood Park, N.J., company that gives self-defense courses, says that business has soared at the company's 900 training centers nationwide. "Prior to 9/11, we had about 1,500 people a week coming in," he said. "Two weeks after the attacks, we had 12,000. Now, it's settled down to 8,000."

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Loss of Storage Space

 BODY:
 Q. I am a rent-controlled tenant in a building with 48 apartments. Ever since I first occupied my apartment more than 30 years ago, I and other tenants have had the use of storage space in the basement. The landlord has now notified us that we must vacate the storage space. This represents the elimination of a service I have enjoyed since moving into the building. Can the landlord do this without giving a rent reduction or other compensation? . . . George Fenmore, Manhattan.

A. Colleen F. McGuire, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants, said that on Dec. 20, 2000, the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency charged with administering the rent laws, adopted amendments to the regulations governing rent-controlled and rent-stabilized tenants. One of the amendments, Ms. McGuire said, included a roster of conditions the agency considers "de minimis."
 "The removal or reduction of storage space is now considered to be a de minimis condition unless the storage space service was provided for in a rider to a lease," she said, adding that the loss of a de minimis service would not result in the landlord being required to reduce the rent or provide other compensation.
Ms. McGuire added, however, that the agency's characterization of the loss of storage space as de minimis is not necessarily set in stone but could be subject to interpretation or modification by the agency itself or the courts.
"There may be circumstances where a condition, although included in the D.H.C.R.'s roster, will nevertheless be found to constitute a decrease in a required service," she said. "So I would advise these tenants to file a decrease-in-services complaint with the D.H.C.R. and vigorously protest the elimination of the storage."
The tenants should emphasize that the service has been provided for at least three decades, that it is important to the tenants who use it, that it will be quite expensive for the tenants to find replacement storage space outside the building and that, as a result, the termination of the use of the space will constitute a real and severe hardship for the tenants.
"In other words," she said, "the tenants should file a complaint that demonstrates that the service is not de minimis, but is important and integral to the tenancy."

Taking a Mattress Up in the Elevator

Q. I own and live in an apartment in Rego Park, Queens. A few days ago, late in the evening, I took in a twin-size mattress to accommodate an unexpected overnight guest. Two days later I was shocked when I got a letter from the management company saying that I had violated the "moving rule" and was being fined $500.
I know that the rule is that moving must be done between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, but that is for tenants who are moving in or out of their apartments. I have been living here and just took an item in. Is this a violation? . . . Hardy Zhang, Rego Park, N.Y.

A. Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that without knowing the details of the moving rule, it is impossible to determine whether the letter writer violated it.
However, he said, co-op and condominium boards generally have the power to establish rules and regulations pertaining to the use of common areas and common elements -- like elevators -- in the building. 
"Rules governing moving usually apply to any use of the common areas for moving bulky items, not just to moving the entire contents of an apartment," Mr. Luxemburg said.
At the same time, he said, fines imposed for violating the rules should bear some relationship to the amount of damage the move might cause.
"A fine of $500 for moving a mattress may be out of proportion to the potential damage the building might suffer," he said, adding that the letter writer might want to contest the amount of the fine by writing a letter to the managing agent or the board explaining the circumstances. If the board insists on imposing the $500 fine, Mr. Luxemburg said, the letter writer would then have no recourse but to resolve the matter in the courts.
