HEADLINE: A Resort Replaces a Mental Hospital in Maryland 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES BELFOURE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Md. 

 BODY:
A $155 million resort that is expected to bolster the economy of this lower Eastern Shore city is nearing completion on a site once occupied by a mental hospital overlooking the Choptank River. The Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Resort, Spa and Marina is scheduled to open in March with 400 rooms, a golf course and a 150-slip marina. A subsequent development around the golf course is expected to add 800 houses and condominiums.
 In the mid-1990's, Maryland decided to replace the aging 300-bed Eastern Shore Hospital with an 80-bed facility for the mentally ill on a site two miles away. The Maryland Economic Development Corporation recognized the development potential of the hospital's 364-acre grounds, one of the last undeveloped tracts along the Choptank, with stands of virgin forest, open fields and an untouched riverfront. 
 The state agency declared the land surplus property and issued a request for redevelopment proposals.
The Hyatt Hotel Corporation of Chicago joined with Quadrangle Development Inc. of Washington and Clark Enterprises, a development and construction company based in Bethesda, Md., to form Chesapeake Resorts L.L.C., which won the project in 1996.
Chesapeake Resorts bought the land for $5 million from the state, whose development corporation then provided $134 million of the project's cost by issuing tax-exempt revenue bonds, said Robert J. Knopf, senior vice president of Quadrangle Development, a real estate development concern that manages more than seven million square feet nationwide. The project will be responsible for paying back the bonds with revenue from the resort.
The state development corporation, which owns the improvements on the site and shares in the resort's revenue, will pay rent under the terms of a 35-year lease. After the lease expires, the physical improvements will revert to Chesapeake Resorts.
The six-story hotel is a U-shaped building anchored by an indoor pool complex and arboretum called the Wintergarden that opens out to the river's edge. Next to the hotel is an 18,000-square-foot spa and fitness center with six tennis courts and an outdoor multilevel pool. 
Inside the main complex are 15 fireplaces and 32,000 square feet of meeting space, including two ballrooms and three restaurants. The hotel, designed by the Washington office of RTKL Associates Inc., has a nautical theme, including red brick detailing that recalls the traditional architecture of the Virginia-Maryland tidewater region. 
The grounds of the old hospital now have an 18-hole golf course designed by Keith Foster, a 5,000-square-foot open-air pavilion and a seafood restaurant on a boardwalk along the river. An 18-acre portion of the site has been set aside as a nature preserve that will have walking trails and wildlife observation. 
Because of the importance of recreational boating in the Chesapeake Bay, a central part of the resort is its marina, which is expected to draw day visitors and vacationers. "Boaters can come in and rent a slip for a day or a week or a month," said Michael T. Walsh, the general manager of the resort. "We'll have all the utility hookups, fuel and a dockside marina store."
Quadrangle has also agreed to build 800 residential units throughout the golf course. That phase, which is being designed, will consist of single family homes, town houses and time-share units in mid-rise buildings. Construction is expected to begin sometime this year, Mr. Knopf said. 
Cambridge, 75 miles southeast of Baltimore, is where the Choptank meets the Chesapeake Bay. Every summer, thousands of visitors pass by the city on their way to Ocean City, the state's most popular resort, but rarely stop to visit. 
Now, government officials hope that the addition of the Hyatt resort, which can be seen from the highway, will draw more tourists to Cambridge. "We'll become a destination," Mayor Cleveland L. Rippons said. "People will see how many things there are to do here."
The city, which borders the Hyatt site on the west, has a downtown historic district with many unaltered examples of late 19th-century architecture and a maritime museum. Another attraction is the Blackwater Wildlife Refuge, an 11,000-acre sanctuary about 12 miles to the south, created in 1931 to protect migratory water fowl. 
In addition to attracting the Ocean City-bound vacationer, the resort hopes to bring in weekend visitors. "The location is perfect with Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia each only about an hour and a half drive away," Mr. Walsh said. Room rates will run $150 to $200 a night, depending on the season.
Officials hope that the Hyatt resort will become an economic catalyst for Dorchester County, whose unemployment rate was as high as 12 percent during the boom economy of the late 1990's. Although there are a few small industrial concerns, the county, with a population of about 30,000, does not have a strong economic base.
Cambridge, the county seat, remains an important center of the state's seafood industry, with Chesapeake Bay watermen traveling from its harbor to harvest crabs and oysters. But with the lowest crab harvest in almost 30 years, that industry is in trouble. 
"There could be several hundred direct jobs from the resort," Mayor Rippons said. "But more importantly, the presence of the Hyatt will accentuate an entrepreneurial spirit that will generate ancillary jobs in the area as well."
One of the resort's main efforts will be to attract conferences and social functions, Mr. Walsh said. He already has 46 gatherings booked for 2002, including eight weddings, several events for Johns Hopkins University, a nursing association and an electric power trade group.
But with all the amenities of the resort, the developers say its real draw is the location, with its views of the Choptank and beautiful country-like setting. 
The site is the result of the planning of the original 1915 Eastern Shore Hospital, which continued the philosophy of the late 19th century that asylums should be built in rural, pastoral settings so patients could enjoy fresh air and a park-like setting. The complex of more than 20 buildings, built in the Tudor Revival style, was demolished in 2000.
"You can't find land like this anymore," Mr. Walsh said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Resort, opening in March, is to have 400 rooms, a golf course, a 150-slip marina and, later, 800 homes. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) Map of Maryland highlighting Cambridge.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
A Plan to Revitalize a Historic Enclave in Camden

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BY the standards of Camden, the state's poorest city, the historic neighborhood of Fairview has held up fairly well, but holes are now poking through the armor of this area.
 About 200 of its 2,400 homes are boarded up, reminders of the families, some of whom had been in the neighborhood for generations, that in the last decade have fled from high taxes and meager services. Worries about safety have increased with the rise in the number of empty buildings that overlook the area's central green, where drug deals go down as day turns to night. 
 Fairview -- a World War I era planned community of American Federal style homes built for shipyard workers by the federal government -- may seem to be sliding, but it is still one of Camden's last viable neighborhoods. Now there is a $40 million plan in place aimed at stabilizing and ensuring the long-term health of the 225-acre enclave at the city's southernmost tip and surrounded on three sides by Newton Creek. 
The plan calls for 320 new and renovated rental and for-sale housing units for people with a mix of incomes, as well as the hiring of a manager to coordinate efforts to bring back businesses to the central square, which will be cleaned and secured. The plan also includes the creation of a 3,000-square-foot community center and a recreational area as well as the introduction of programs for youngsters in the neighborhood, which was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974. 
"It's a holistic approach, the key to which is the revitalization of Yorkship Square as a center of commerce and community," said Anthony M. Cancro, acting commissioner of the state's Department of Community Affairs, adding that it also involves community input. Those two factors make this plan different from past efforts, which "slowed but didn't stop the deterioration," he said. 
Over the last two years his department devised the plan together with the designated developer, RPM Development Group of Montclair; the Fairview Historic Society; and other community groups. Among them are the area's seven churches and the Senator Walter Rand Institute for Public Affairs at Rutgers University in Camden. 
Al Rose, president of the historic society, praised the plan's determination to preserve not only the neighborhood's bricks and mortar but also its spirit. Mr. Rose has run a pharmacy for 28 years in the neighborhood; today it is the only business still operating from an otherwise shuttered building.
FELIPE GOROSTIZA, executive director of the Rand Institute, said Fairview's "real or perceived image" of a lack of safety also needed to be addressed. "People must be given a reason to want to come back," he said. 
The Rev. Kenneth Hallahan, pastor of St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church stressed, however, that the aim is not "to gentrify the area or drive out long-time residents."
Last month the city signed off on the plan, which requires RPM to acquire existing buildings as well as land from various owners. It is to be carried out in three phases over the next three years. 
The acquisition process has begun for the first 120-unit phase, which includes acquiring four vacant buildings along the square and renovating them to create 50 mostly one-bedroom rentals and acquiring several parcels along Collings Avenue, a main entryway to the area, to build 70 new apartments. Work is to begin in late spring. 
The $40 million plan is to be financed mostly through state as well as federal funds. The city is providing a 30-year tax abatement.
In the last eight years the state has invested $80 million to produce 780 new and renovated housing units in other Camden neighborhoods as well as $20 million more in commercial redevelopment. "We had to show private developers Camden was worth investing in," Mr. Cancro said.
That commitment helped to persuade RPM, known mainly for its work in northern New Jersey, to respond to the state's call for developers. Other factors included Fairview's location and physical appeal, said Ed Martoglio, RPM's principal. 
"Beyond the blight and boarded-up buildings, you can still see a charming neighborhood," he said.
The federal government created Fairview in 1917 to house workers of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which churned out ships for World War I. Originally called Yorkship Village, it was carved from farmland along Newton Creek near the shipyard. 
But, like 54 other such wartime neighborhoods nationwide, it was designed to be more than a barrackslike compound. The designer of Fairview, Electus Darwin Litchfield, modeled the community after the Garden City developments popular in England at that time and gave it a central village square, from which stretch narrow winding residential streets and broad green commercial boulevards like spokes on a wheel. 
The architect also lined the streets with trees and row houses, duplexes and detached homes made of red brick and graced with porches and small front and back yards. Having the creek on three sides also makes Fairview seem more suburban than urban, and residents with homes overlooking the creek say they can spot egrets and blue herons.
FROM 1923, when the government auctioned off the homes, to the start of the last decade, Fairview remained an stable enclave. Then a 1992 tax revaluation that doubled homeowner's property taxes, an aging population and white flight conspired against the neighborhood and left behind a trail of vacant houses, many of them sold to investors. Over the last decade the number of such units rose and property values fell. 
In that time the neighborhood's population dropped to 4,877 from 5,353 and its complexion changed. In 1990, 90 percent of the residents were white; today estimates put the population at one-third to one-half white and the rest black and Hispanic. 
Michael H. Lang, a professor of urban studies at Rutgers in Camden and a Fairview resident, credits the neighborhood's survival over the decades to the quality of its design. He said it is often cited as a model of the "New Urbanism" school of planning, which advocates see as the answer to suburban sprawl.
While the community's response to the revitalization effort generally is positive, there are concerns. Among them are the relocation of businesses along Collings Avenue and the loss of undeveloped county-owned land along the creek to make way for the new rentals.
Some also think that the 320 residences planned are too much for the neighborhood and that too many of them, 220, are to be rentals affordable to people earning $25,000 to $38,000 a year, depending on family size. The 50 renovated rentals in the buildings edging the square and the 170 new rentals planned in up to eight structures will have one to three bedrooms with 650 to 1,100 square feet. They will rent for $400 to $600 a month.
Mr. Martoglio said the density "is needed to support area businesses." The new rentals make the plan economically viable and allow his company to provide the community center and recreational area, he said, adding that the goal of the 100 market-rate houses "is to attract people with higher incomes."
Those now-vacant houses, with 1,000 to 1,600 square feet, will be renovated and sold to buyers at initial prices of $40,000 to $55,000. Work on the first 35 homes is to begin in midspring. 
Still, old-time residents like James Viall, 80, who has lived in Fairview for 32 years, are weary of promises of a new beginning. "Sure I would like to see improved buildings," he said, but he added that an increase in neighborhood pride is also needed. 
Last month, within days after the announcement of the Fairview project, the New Jersey State Legislature rejected a separate state aid package to turn around Camden, whose finances were taken over by the state in 2000. But state housing officials stress that the Fairview money will come from the sale of bonds and from real estate transfer taxes, not the state Treasury. 
Mr. Rose, who described himself as an optimist, said the Fairview plan would be realized, "because we are all working together." Michael Devlin, a former city councilman and Fairview resident, added that "the will and resources" are there to get it done. "But," he said, "it will take work that requires rolling up shirtsleeves."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fairview was created to house workers who built World War I ships. (Sal DiMarco Jr. for The New York Times) Map of New Jersey highlighting Fairview.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
Newcomers Join Ranks of the Familiar

BYLINE:  By M. H. REED 

 BODY:
THINGS have changed. 
 Despite a competitive industry and a shaky economy, several brave new restaurants carved out a notable niche for themselves in the county last year. These innovative newcomers have attracted a loyal clientele almost from the day they opened their doors. Excitement, pizzazz, menus and decor Manhattan style echo in sleek, roomy bars. But the new spots haven't replaced the established favorites -- old-guard dining rooms with old-world elegance. 
 Here are restaurants, new and old, that deserve special note for their exceptional food, ambience or service. 

American
Few places are more Manhattan than two of Steven Palm's eating spots: Orchard Street Oyster Bar and Grill and Harrys of Hartsdale. Both stock a large selection of shellfish -- most notably oysters -- at their splendid raw bars. While the stylish ambience at Harrys outshines that at tiny Orchard Street, Orchard Street's kitchen keeps up. Look for terrine of chicken, duck with pappardelle, ginger sea scallops, and for dessert, chocolate sack, chocolate tear or refreshing green apple granita. 
New, too, is the Road House. This pretty and informal redo of space last occupied by Maxime's includes a snug bar and lounge areas and a warming fireplace in the dining room. Tyler Merson knows how to balance flavors, and he uses vegetables galore to add zip to his dishes. Delectable surprises hide in unlikely-sounding offerings, like fricassee of spaghetti squash and vegetables, bread pudding with mushroom ragout and roasted tomato salad. 
Across the river, Lu Shane's has quickly become a popular destination. Expert design has turned a long, unwieldy room into an asset. A tub of glistening iced oysters weighs down one end of a copper-topped bar. Most dishes like pork chop, salmon and quail come showered with wild mushrooms, sweet leeks or exotic oils. And, oh, those lavish desserts. 
Also just west of the Hudson River are Peter Kelly's restaurants; this culinary Mozart never runs out of fresh harmonies of flavors and variations on old favorites. Bright dining areas at Restaurant X and Bully Boy Bar are in keeping with the dazzling food. Some rooms have fireplaces or views of gardens or a pretty, romantic pond. The big complaint about the tiny, convivial Freelance Cafe & Wine Bar is that it's always crowded and takes no reservations. Many diners like to make a meal of several appetizers accompanied by good wine by the glass. Reservations are taken next door at Xaviar's at Piermont, as elegant a place as the Freelance Cafe is casual (the restaurants share a kitchen), although seating is becoming a bit tight. Xaviar's at Garrison, Mr. Kelly's first success, is open for prix-fixe tasting dinners on weekends and a fabulous Sunday brunch.
A crackling hearth warms the cellar Tack Room of Peter Pratt's Inn, which dates to Revolutionary times, and although the kitchen sometimes stumbles, its soups make a case for forgiveness. Delicious pumpkin and chestnut soup and spicy Thai-style lemon grass soup are the hits of the moment. 
A few parts of Crabtree's Kittle House creak with age, not peculiar for their beginnings as a barn more than two centuries ago. Over the years it has expanded with a rabbit warren of additions. Gregory Gilbert's oxtail ravioli in chanterelle broth or a dainty little stuffed quail or mustard-crusted lamb are extraordinary, as is everything else. Anibal Romero creates light, not-to-be-missed desserts. Service is outstanding, as it is at Iron Horse Grill, set in an old train station house. Philip McGrath (the chef and owner) and his vigilant staff are concerned with the diner's total happiness, further ensured by dishes like venison with juniper, brandade (cod with potato) and apple galette with ice cream. 
A few other small restaurants serve food notably big on flavor. Bistro Twenty-Two is a little jewel, polished by Brian Galvin's honey-glazed chicken, roasted cod and fragrant bread pudding. Maureen and Charles Steppe have taken over the old Box Tree and renamed it Purdys Homestead. The wide polished old floorboards and huge fireplaces of the old farmhouse have been retained, and the kitchen given a fresh attitude, with baking that is nothing short of splendid. Roasted oysters, rainbow trout and chicken Purdys are fine bets, as are all desserts. At Cafe Meze Mark Filippo always has something interesting on the stove such as salmon tartare, grilled octopus, skate, lamb and pork chop. These and more are embellished with creative garnishes worth a special trip. Fruity desserts are gorgeous. Marco is informal, an unlikely setting for the interesting fare Mark Donelli cooks, generous plates of spicy shrimp, grilled ostrich and other game meats. 
Then there are dining kitchens that make a specialty of one main ingredient. Fish is king at Eastchester Fish Gourmet. This kitchen knows how to cook it plain and how to cook it fancy. Lobster and seafood from the raw bar are always on hand. Creative, seasonal entrees might be roasted cod with risotto and mushrooms, Dover sole wrapped in pastry or pancetta-wrapped monkfish. At The Fish Cellar the best call is at the roomy raw bar at the entrance. Here's the spot to have a glass of beer or wine and to munch on shrimp or a selection of seasonal oysters. The shuckers are knowledgeable and can talk about the provenance of every mollusk they crack. 
Tables are small and the noise level high at Ye Olde Tollgate Steakhouse, but it would be hard to find more succulent, smooth-textured porterhouse steaks than those served here.

Chinese
There's much good news about Chinese food in Westchester. Long in the forefront of what true Chinese cuisine is about -- fresh ingredients and innovation -- Hunan Village has reinvented itself. Paul Chou, the owner, has shortened his menu to concentrate on his seasonal best. Diners should consult him or anyone on his well-trained staff about the freshest seafood or vegetable buys, which might not be on the menu. Triple-cooked pork ribs, sole in laurel wine-lees, "silk" squash with shrimp -- everything is worth a try. Soups and vegetables are beyond praise.
David Ng has moved his Jade Palace up the street and into the old Tung Sing. Now called David's Jade Palace, this new, bigger restaurant includes a wall of live-fish tanks, a tea bar with an outstanding selection and a dining porch, which is packed at lunch with patrons hungry for dim sum. Dinner is terrific too, with its fresh fish and vegetables. 
Green Symphony is a strictly vegetarian restaurant that cooks up healthful food that will satisfy even carnivores. Based on Buddhist culinary tradition, dishes are miracles of soybean and vegetable combinations that look and taste like chicken, squid, duck, shrimp and beef. No alcohol is served. Meats and fish are the real McCoy at K. Fung's, but it makes a point of offering healthful fare by adding loads of interesting vegetables to the mix, as well as noodle, dumpling and tofu dishes.

French
"French" restaurants, like "American" restaurants, have borrowed ingredients from all over the globe to enhance their already complex dishes. These are formal restaurants, and jackets are preferred.
The elegant, intimate dining areas of Chef George Seitz's Arch make a fitting backdrop for carefully made food. Butternut squash soup with roasted pecans and game dishes are among the memorable. The cheese selection is first rate, as is old-fashioned apple pie. Service is top-notch.
Cool weather seems to demand hearty fare, and for many, duck is the top choice. Several versions, all expertly contrived, are always on hand at Auberge Maxime, in its old-fashioned country-French dining rooms. Long the restaurant's specialty, pressed duck is no longer on the menu but is available with 48 hours' notice. Service? Wonderful, of course.
La Cremaillere has been around for decades and maintains its French roots. The menu is still written in French, with subtitles in English. The dining rooms are small and stuffy. But while chefs come and go -- some bright lights and some lesser -- the place perseveres, perhaps because there are no surprises, no fireworks. Consistency has its comforts. The current chef, William Savages, sees to it that dishes remain classic and as rich as ever in cream and foie gras. Goat cheese with beets "gateam," roasted squab and mustard-crusted salmon make lovely choices. 
Pretty La Panetiere is the most formal among these restaurants. Although service can be shaky and the cooking occasionally uneven, it would be hard to go wrong ordering magnificently fresh seafood, duck terrine and coquilles Saint-Jacques. Desserts are often works of art.
Harralds, like La Cremaillere, has been thriving for more than 30 years in the tradition of old-world correctness. Little changes, and why should it? The Tudor-style cottage with a cluster of small, elegantly appointed dining rooms looks like a house out of a fairy tale. The owners, Harrald Boerger and Eva Durrschmidt, the chef, have culled the best from their years of experience; every detail of the ambience and the menu has been well thought out long ago. If there's one dish that stands out from the rest, it's simply prepared truite au bleu. 

Indian
With prices generally easy on the wallet, Indian restaurants are particular bargains for lunch and brunch, when an elaborate selection of varied and delectable dishes lines their buffet tables. A few places offer buffet dinners as well, another bargain, but only on certain nights of the week. Call first. 
Discuss what you would like and your tolerance for spicy heat with wait staff, who aim to please. Here are just a few of many Indian spots. 
Coromandel, the new kid in town, bursts with color, and the food is the fiery cuisine of Southwest India. Indian art hangs on the walls of Bengal Tiger, which has 25 years of experience to bring to diners. A few new dishes are usually on the boards and add excitement to the menu. At times, service can be wobbly at India House, but little is amiss with its tasty dishes. Crowds have discovered the generous Sunday buffet dinner at Jaipore. And conveniently situated next to a movie theater, Royal Palace has a dinner buffet from Monday through Thursday.

Italian
Producing fine Italian food takes skill to balance flavors, and the artistry to deal with ever-changing new products and seasonal markets. Not many kitchens make the effort. When they do, they shine. 
In a pretty Colonial house, Emilio has the knack, from the spectacular antipasto assortment to a variety of homemade pasta to seafood. Service is excellent and the welcome, warm. At Il Cigno the ambience here is nothing much and service could be more agreeable, but diners tolerate closely packed tables and, at times, deafening noise for pappardelle with wild boar, risotto, grilled chicken or calf's liver Semifreddo is a happy ending. 
Popular, laid-back and fun, Valentino's serves good, basic, fresh food -- basins of it -- in storefront digs embellished with glass chandeliers and mirrors. New dishes join the lusty favorites: tripe, osso buco, braciole. If you don't see what you want on the menu, ask. Come with companions; the atmosphere is carnival. 

Japanese
A number of Japanese restaurants have opened in the past few years, a testament to the popularity of sushi. Cooked dishes here are less consistent. If cooking oil isn't fresh enough and hot enough, tempura can arrive heavy and sodden. Much depends upon who is watching the wok. 
One-pot soups and casseroles are best right now, when the weather's cold and when post-holiday resolutions to avoid further dining excess are still firm. These vegetable-stocked broths -- called nabeyaki udon, nabemono or yosenabe, depending upon ingredients -- are tasty, low in calories and nourishing. Try Gyosai, Hanada, Kira Sushi, Sushi Man or Sushi Raku. Any of these has fine examples of both sushi and soups. 

Latin American
In his bright and airy dining rooms, Rafael Palomina, the chef and owner of Sonora, inspired by cooking from various regions of South America, gives seafood in particular a new, winning persona. One of the ceviche appetizers or a shrimp and avocado salad or lobster quesadilla will show diners what this kitchen is about. 

Portuguese/Brazilian
Patrons who wait for tables on busy weekend nights complain that Caravela is too small. This cozy storefront space, however, is clearly just the right size. For six years people have come for Fernando Cabral's savory food, dependable cooking and warm personal service. Good olive oil, melted onions and garlic put a Mediterranean stamp on shrimp, scallops and squid, as well as on chicken, pork and fish dishes. A dash of port wine binds flavors. Port by the glass and cheeses or succulent fruit tarts finish a meal nicely. 

Good Eating Around the County
RESERVATIONS are essential for most of these restaurants. Hours and days of operation change, and some places close in January. It's a good idea to call. Prices are not as high as in Manhattan, but especially at the finer restaurants, dining out can be expensive.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 888 words

HEADLINE: LOVE & MONEY; 
When The Big Paycheck Is Hers

BYLINE:  By ELLYN SPRAGINS; Ellyn Spragins is a freelance writer in Maplewood, N.J. Her column about money's influence on relationships appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: loveandmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN I told a married friend that I would be writing a column about wives who make more money than their husbands, he snorted out a laugh. Then he said, "I wish we had that problem," using his fingers to scratch quotation marks in the air as he uttered the word "problem." 
 As it turns out, the quotation marks weren't necessary. To many men, a wife rolling in dough sounds like a fantasy come true. But earning significantly more money than your husband is more than a potential relationship problem -- it's shrouded in more secrecy than any other money issue I've written about here. 
 One successful, outspoken woman after another told me that she could not really talk about it -- or at least not with her name attached. An entrepreneur in New York City chatted happily for a half-hour about financial conflicts and then called back the next day to say that after talking to her husband she wanted to retract what she said. Husbands were offered as interview subjects but never returned calls. I felt as if I were covering a drug-trafficking story. 
Do husbands really need all this protection? Many of their wives think so. "The guy's ego is all caught up in being the breadwinner and if you take that away from him you take away a lot of his self-confidence," said a public relations executive in Boston who earns more than her husband.
A business owner from New York City, who has been married for 20 years, added: "I would never want people we know socially to know. I think it would be a real blow to his ego."
Not all high-earning wives feel that they need to tiptoe around their husbands' fragile masculinity. Women in their 20's and 30's are much more comfortable than older women with the Chief Breadwinner designation, said Ellen Perry, founder of Family Office Solutions, a wealth management consulting firm in Washington. And women whose husbands are in low-paying professions -- the arts or social work, for example -- rarely feel the need to keep secret their income disparity.
No, concealment seems most necessary when a couple's W-2 forms don't follow the apparent script handed to each partner on the wedding day. Ah, you don't remember receiving it? Of course not. A couple's earnings premise, as I think of it, is rarely articulated. But it's there all the same, embedded in the couple's career choices. He is going into investment banking and she is going to teach? The pact is that he will make the serious money and she will have a family-friendly work schedule.
If either partner deviates from the script, trouble tends to come knocking. But when a wife ad-libs by hitting a career jackpot, the strain can be enormous. Barbara Corcoran, founder of the Corcoran Group, a large Manhattan real estate firm that was acquired last fall by the Cendant Corporation and Apollo Management, remembers the year after her brokerage company's growth far outpaced that of her husband's real estate business, in New Jersey. She and her husband, Bill Higgins, survived the strain, but not without some fears.
"I actually sat down and thought, 'I better not do this,' " she said. "I valued my marriage and was fearful of losing my husband's love. I wasn't sure if he would love me as much if I was going to seem stronger than him." 
Many relationships don't outlast the stress, psychologists and wealth management consultants say. And many couples that succeed often work hard to preserve the myth, even within the marriage, that the husband is the Chief Breadwinner. 
"We don't talk about it," said the Boston public relations executive. "He'll tell me I'm beautiful but he'll never compliment me about the end-of-year tax return. He puts it in front of my face, asks me to sign it and not a word passes our lips."
Steven Axelrod, a clinical psychologist in Manhattan who specializes in work issues, says there is "a veil of silence around this kind of thing, even in many good marriages."
A sad collection of unanswered questions and lonely moments accompany that silence. Many wives feel chained to their earning power and angry that they have somehow engineered a life without an exit clause. "I worked since I was 13, but still somewhere in the back reaches of my mind I was dreaming about being rescued like Cinderella," Ms. Corcoran, 52, said. "I was resentful that I didn't have the option that all the other girls had."
WORSE, though, are the nagging questions that eat away at mutual respect. Why isn't my husband more successful? "Unless there is some emotional contract, some way of feeling that the man is being productive, there can be a real loss of status in the woman's eyes," Mr. Axelrod said. "Then the man will internalize that." 
You'd probably like to hear how husbands feel. So would I. If high-earning wives sometimes feel lonely and enslaved, imagine what their spouses are experiencing. Without their voices, this story is only Part One.
So how about it, guys? Speak up. You may have more company than you realize. The biggest secret about this secret society of fiscally unequal couples is that they are common at high-income levels. Among all married couples, about 22 percent of the wives earn more than their husbands, according to the government's Current Population Survey. But among couples in which the wife earned $100,000 or more, 68 percent of the wives outearned the husbands. 
I'm listening.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Robert Van Nutt)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
In Office Market, a Time of Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
LAYOFFS at financial services companies and related businesses combined with the collapse of many dot-com businesses were already pushing the metropolitan area's real estate sector downward before the events of Sept. 11. The attacks on the World Trade Center removed 13.4 million square feet of office space for at least several years and temporarily rendered an additional 12.1 million square feet unusable.
 But rather than causing the market to tighten, as might have been expected when 25 percent of the downtown submarket suddenly vanished, the attack released a flood of sublet space, as if by magic. According to a report by Grubb & Ellis, the brokerage and services company, 10.1 million square feet was offered for sublet in the three months after the attack, as companies that had been holding excess space put it on the market in hopes of attracting tenants who had been displaced from downtown buildings. 
 "After Sept. 11, there was an overnight land rush to anything that was built and operable next day," said Mitchell Steir, vice chairman of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that specializes in representing tenants. "It lasted 7 to 10 days." 
But once the rush to relocate had passed, the market slowed, with tenants who did not have to make decisions deferring them until market conditions become clearer. As the year ended, a high degree of confusion seemed to grip the market, with both buyers and sellers unsure about pricing.
"There is a disconnect between bid and asked in both sales and leasing," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company. "Twenty-nine percent of the direct space was on the market with no asking rent as of the end of the year," she said. "Forty-two percent of the sublease space had no asking rent."
And the lack of transactions is only adding to the uncertainty, Ms. Tighe added. "Landlords are saying, 'Make a bid.' Tenants say, 'What are the comparables?' And there are not enough comparables to tell them much."
Others in the industry agree. "The degree of uncertainty is the greatest in my entire career," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate, a brokerage and services company."People are glum, and in real estate that is a self-fulfilling prophesy."
Most real estate executives say they expect the pricing issue to work itself out in the form of lower rents this year as the amount of available space increases as a result of a continuing softening of the economy. Midtown should suffer the least, they say, because much of the available space has been taken by tenants from downtown.
Some of the space that was placed on the market after Sept. 11 was driven more by a desire to clean up financial statements than to satisfy the needs of displaced tenants, according to Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, an investment and management company.
"A lot of people dumped space so that they could take the financial hit in 2001," he said. "It was going to be a terrible year anyway, so why not get it all done at once?" By packing a lot of losses in one year, publicly held companies can lay the groundwork for rosier financial statements in the future.
Mr. Malkin said 1999 and 2000 were such good years for the real estate business that even if a recovery begins later this year it may seem unsatisfying. "People have got to get used to the idea that things will be more normal before they become incredible again," he said.
With the investment sales market having slowed sharply because building owners think their properties are still worth what they were before Sept. 11, while buyers are expecting discounts, real estate executives say owners may turn to refinancing as a way of turning part of a building's value into cash. With interest rates at unusually low levels, this appears to be an attractive alternative.
The Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street did a $230 million refinancing late in the year, said Howard L. Michaels, chairman of the Carlton Group, which helped arrange the financing. He said the West Side structure, large parts of which have been converted from industrial to office use, gained additional tenants after Sept. 11 from government agencies displaced from downtown.
He said the events of Sept. 11 had made it harder to develop financing packages for properties downtown and hotels anywhere in the city. "Before Sept. 11, you could refinance a property with one lender," he said. "Afterward, you might need as many as three lenders to get a deal done downtown."
The capital markets had already noticed the deteriorating fundamentals of the real estate market earlier in the year and had begun tightening underwriting standards, according to John Lyons, chairman of Granite Partners, a real estate investment-banking company. "As the economy softened in the spring and summer, lenders began to modify such things as projected rental growth and occupancy levels in a way that lowered the value of properties," he said.
Although a gap remains between the bid and asked prices for properties, there are forces at work that will increase pressure to complete transactions this year, Mr. Lyons said. "There are opportunity funds who have a certain stated rate of return and the longer they hold property, the lower the returns typically become," he said. "They are not in a position where they have to sell immediately, but the limited life of these funds will begin to force their hands to sell in 2002."
Douglas Durst, president of the Durst Organization, a family company that owns 10 major office buildings in Manhattan, said Sept. 11 had posed some questions to which the answers are unclear. "Normally, recessions creep up on you as the space gradually is added to the market," he said. "After Sept. 11, everybody dumped space on the market and created a situation different than anything I have ever seen."
He said tenants housed in temporary quarters may wait until the middle of this year before deciding whether they want to remain in Manhattan or increase security by spreading out to several locations.
Typical of the short-term alternatives that companies have sought is the 146,000 square feet that Morgan Stanley, an investment banking company that had 840,000 square feet in Tower Two of the World Trade Center, sublet in the One Hudson Square building at Canal and Varick Streets, said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a tenant's broker. Morgan Stanley relocated other operations to 825 Third Avenue and 1633 Broadway. 
"A lot of companies are doing short-term renewals and sublets," he said. "Rents are headed down, and the longer a tenant can wait to make a decision the better they will do."
Although this year may not be a big one for new development because of the soft office market, Mr. Durst said he might go ahead with a 2 million square foot building on the eastern end of the block bounded by 42nd and 43rd Streets and the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. Late last year he was able to buy a key parcel of land in the middle of the block to largely complete the assemblage of the site.
Mr. Durst said he hoped to start demolishing the buildings on the site in the summer to make way for the structure he plans to call One Bryant Park. The new building would share the block with the Conde Nast building at 4 Times Square, which Mr. Durst completed in 1998. 
The downtown area continues to suffer a variety of problems, including excavation operations near ground zero, transportation snarls caused by the closing of several subway stations and the PATH line to New Jersey and blocked-off streets. As a result, while asking rental rates for Class A space in Midtown have fallen about 10 percent since Sept. 11, rates downtown are off 20 percent, according to Bruce Mosler, president of United States operations for Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company.
Like many other real estate executives, Mr. Mosler was critical of the city and state for what they characterized as having been too slow to develop a package of incentives to give companies a financial reason to return to downtown or to stay there. "The city and state have failed to communicate to companies what the plan will be," he said.
In addition to financial incentives, public officials have to lay out a timetable for getting the transportation system fixed and possibly improved by bringing rail lines that now terminate in Midtown closer to the southern tip of Manhattan. "The transportation issue has got to be addressed," Mr. Mosler said. "New York businesses will withstand hardship as long as they know when it is going to be fixed."
According to Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, rather then focus on the complex and difficult job of deciding what will happen at the 16-acre Trade Center site, city officials should move swiftly to make life in lower Manhattan more normal.
"They need to improve the entire circulation system in downtown," Professor Moss said. "The frozen zone is too large. There are too many streets closed off. There has been excessive delay in building a bridge across West Street. We have to address the ecology of lower Manhattan."
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the land under the Trade Center and operates the PATH trains, has declared that it will build a temporary PATH station in Lower Manhattan. This would re-establish a direct link to Jersey City and relieve pressure on the line that runs from Hoboken to 33rd Street. Officials of the agency said the new station could be in operation in about two years.
One downtown deal that was apparently killed by the events of Sept. 11 was a plan to build a new home for the New York Stock Exchange. Under a city-sponsored plan, the exchange was to have its trading floor in the first 10 stories of a 50-story tower on the block bounded by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place.
With the exchange one of the most prominent symbols of American capitalism, its officials worried that a tall building housing the trading floors would be a target for terror. "A 900-foot tower post-Sept. 11 is not a salable transaction," Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the exchange, said at a securities industry meeting in November.
At a subsequent news conference, Mr. Grasso said the exchange still wanted to move its trading to the site at 23 Wall Street, but with far less office space above it. Referring to the trading operation as a box, he said the new location "could be a box, or a box with space above it, but not a box with 1.5 million square feet of space above it."
The exchange said it had also developed and tested an alternate trading floor at an undisclosed site in the city that could be used if another incident interrupted its telephones, power and other utilities at its primary location.
As the year ended, the exchange and the city still could not agree on the scope of the project. Instead, both parties signed a general agreement to build a 10-story trading complex with the remaining details to be worked out with the new Bloomberg administration.
One institution that was not deterred by the problems facing downtown was Deutsche Bank, which closed its $610 million purchase of the 47-story building at 60 Wall Street, the former headquarters of the J. P. Morgan banking company, as scheduled on Nov. 1. "The transaction relocated Deutsche Bank to downtown at a time when it would have been easy not to close and rationalize the decision," said Robert Alexander, a vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, who helped broker the deal. And it was done without extracting an incentive package from the city, noted David Maurer-Hollaender, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG.
Despite what is expected to be a lackluster year in 2002, real estate executives say the office market could recover quickly if the national recession ends, as expected, in the third quarter and businesses start hiring people instead of laying them off.
"It is clear to me that most of the major corporations in Manhattan have slimmed down to the least amount of real estate they can have and still function," Ms. Tighe said. "If business were to improve, they would have to add real estate. This means there will be a very direct connection between the economy and demand for real estate."
In the past, she said, there has typically been an 18-month lag between an economic upturn and a recovery of the office market.
Following are accounts of how some specialized market sectors performed and their prospects.

Retail Space
Many Rents Drop, By Varying Degrees
Like other businesses at least partially dependent on tourists and business travelers, retailers, including restaurants, were hurt by the reluctance of many people to visit the city after Sept. 11. Some were hurt worse than others. The shopping mall under the trade center, which sold to both visitors and the tens of thousands of people working in the buildings above, was wiped out.
Other retail stores that were physically little disturbed by the disaster found that a large part of their customer base had been forced to relocate to other parts of Manhattan or the suburbs.
But stores operating in prime retail locations on Madison and Fifth Avenues and on 57th Street still had sizable foot traffic and few sites were vacant, brokers specializing in retail real estate reported.
Still, the lack of visitors, particularly the free-spending international travelers, hurt overall sales. The city's convention and visitors bureau estimated that visitors spent $2.1 billion less in 2001 than they did a year earlier, a decline of 12 percent.
The outlook for this year is not particularly encouraging, with the bureau estimating that the number of visits will increase about 1 percent but that visitor spending will decline about 1 percent because most of the additional visitors will be lower-spending Americans.
The downtown retail market has been changed by the destruction of the buildings and the interruption of subway and PATH links, said C. Bradley Mendelson, who manages retail operations of Insignia/ESG. One reason, he said, is that corporations will be careful not to put all their operations in one large building like the towers at the Trade Center.
"We put Borders Books into the Trade Center," he said, but without the traffic supplied both by the workers in the Trade Center and the tourists that were drawn to the area, "I doubt Borders will take another store downtown now." And without the tourist traffic the Trade Center drew, he said, the downtown market is a five-day-a-week office market.
Elsewhere in the city, he said, sales in restaurants have been off about 15 percent from 2000, a good year, and sales at other stores have been about flat. A key indicator, he said, is that receipts at parking garages are off 40 to 50 percent since Sept. 15, indicating that nearby residents, the most likely to drive, are avoiding coming into the city.
Although overall asking rental rates for retail space is down 25 to 30 percent compared with last year, actual rentals vary widely with location, cautioned Benjamin Fox, an executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail, a brokerage specializing in retail space.
"If you are talking about a 700-square-foot store in the prime areas of Madison and Fifth Avenues, there is very little available and the prices remain high," he said. "But if you are talking 4,000 square feet to 8,000 square feet in lesser areas, there has clearly been an adjustment."
Mr. Fox said lower rental rates for stores can be good for consumers because the lower rents reduce the cost of opening a new type of store in the city. "If you look back to the mid-1970's and the '89-'91 period," he said, "that's when new retail concepts came into the city -- retailers take advantage of lower rents to come into Manhattan."

Hotels
An Abrupt Change In Tourism Industry
The terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center probably did not have the city's hotels in mind, but their timing could not have been worse, according to Thomas McConnell, director of the hotel practice at Insignia/ESG. "Retailers make their money near Christmas," he said. "For hotels, the time between Labor Day and Thanksgiving is Christmas."
Both tourist and business visits dropped abruptly after the attack, particularly from international travelers suddenly wary of coming to the city. According to the Convention and Visitors Bureau, 5.4 million fewer people came to New York in 2001 than in the previous year, a decline of 14 percent.
The decline hurt all segments of the lodging industry, including companies that rent apartments for relatively short periods as an alternative to hotels. "Our business is about 50 percent domestic and about 50 percent overseas," said Howard Pitter, general manager of AHS, which has about 300 apartments in various parts of Manhattan. After the attack, he said, "we had hundreds of cancellations." He added, "Our European business went away, both business and tourist."
Since then, he said, the domestic business has improved somewhat, partially because residents driven out of buildings in Battery Park City have sought other locations in Manhattan. But the international business remains all but dead, he said.
Many luxury hotels in the city reacted to the falloff in traffic by sharply cutting their rates. This helped fill up rooms during the Christmas season, but many in the industry expect vacancies to soar in the early months of the year, traditionally a slow time in the hotel business.
According to Mr. McConnell, the average daily rate in September last year was $179 a night, compared with an average rate of $226 for September 2000. Since the overall economy was weakening, he said, 2001 would have finished with a 76 percent occupancy rate and a $200 a night average room charge. Because of the attack, the occupancy rate fell to 72 percent, with an average nightly charge of $177.

Suburban Space
A Surge of Interest In New Jersey Space
New Jersey was the principal beneficiary among the suburban markets of the dislocation in lower Manhattan. According to a report by CB Richard Ellis, nearly 2 million square feet of space was signed for by financial services companies like Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs. Much of the space taken was along the Hudson River waterfront, but interior parts of the state benefited as well.
Most of the attention has focused on Jersey City, but activity is spreading north to Hoboken and Weehawken. SJP Properties is building a 550,000-square-foot office building at Waterfront Corporate Park in Hoboken on speculation, having filled the first phase of the project with tenants largely lured from Manhattan before Sept. 11, including the venerable publisher John Wiley & Sons.
Farther north, in Weehawken, Hartz Mountain Industries is prepared to move ahead with the final phase of the Lincoln Harbor project, which first began in 1982. But Emanuel Stern, Hartz's president, said work would not commence until tenants are signed.
Stamford, in Fairfield County, Conn., lured two major tenants displaced from lower Manhattan. Citigroup agreed to lease 235,000 square feet at 100-300 Stamford Place, while American Express (which announced plans last month to reoccupy its headquarters in downtown Manhattan in the spring) took 175,000 square feet at 400 Atlantic Avenue, according to a report by Colliers ABR, the real estate services company. Both leases were for 10-year terms.
In Westchester County, the vacancy rate remained stubbornly high as few tenants appeared to be attracted to the former corporate headquarters buildings that dominate the office-building landscape immediately north of the city.

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS; 
When Europe's Flora Flourished on Porcelain

BYLINE:  By MARTY ROSS

 BODY:
IN 1790, the Royal Danish Porcelain Factory received a commission to create a magnificent set of china -- 80 place settings and accompanying serving pieces -- apparently as a royal gift from the king of Denmark to Catherine the Great of Russia. The service was to be painstakingly decorated with paintings of flowers and plants drawn from one of Denmark's great scientific works, Flora Danica (1762-1883), a superbly illustrated catalog of the Danish flora.
 Working with the hand-colored copper engravings on folio sheets on easels before them, a respected botanical illustrator, Johann Christoph Bayer (and probably several assistants), rendered the drawings onto cups, saucers, dinner plates, serving platters, soup tureens, sauce boats and teapots. They painted the flowers, grasses, mosses and mushrooms of the realm with scientific exactitude, lavishing leaves, buds, flowers, roots, stems and seed pods on the fragile contours of every piece of the dinner service. Denmark's plant kingdom was to be laid out on damask tablecloths in glittering, candlelit halls, before lords and ladies of the utmost sophistication and discernment. It was an extraordinary royal gesture: This was the glory of creation being served up for dinner. 
 Before the 18th century, Europeans imported their fine porcelain from China, and Oriental themes predominated in their decoration. The first porcelain dinner service produced in Europe, made in Meissen in 1729, was decorated with tigers and bamboo.
As knowledge of the art of making porcelain spread across Europe, the science of botany also was flourishing. The great Swedish natural historian Carolus Linnaeus published his treatise on systematic plant classification in 1753. There was intense interest in botany among the ruling classes. Botanical gardens were being established, and the economic uses of plants were being discussed in the distinguished circles of newly formed and highly prestigious natural history societies.
Social, intellectual and administrative elites were closely knit. In Copenhagen, the porcelain factory's director, a mycologist, was also in charge of the botanical garden.
When Catherine the Great died, in 1796, about 1,000 pieces of the dinner service had been made. Hundreds remained unfinished. Instead of canceling the order, the Danish regent increased it to 100 place settings, and in January 1803, on the king's birthday, the royal pastry cook received the first tantalizing pieces of the china: the dessert service.
The complete service numbered nearly 2,000 pieces, painted with delicacy and accuracy, and edged with gold. The artists had matched the scale of the plants to each cup, saucer and plate. Wispy members of the willow family and trailing hops decorated soup tureens; lichens and mushrooms were depicted on butter dishes; milkweeds, elderberries, hawthorns and lady's mantles were reserved for the larger dishes. The lush leaves of valerian were judged appropriate for the voluptuous shape of a sauce boat.
Botanical illustrations began to appear on dinner and tea sets all over Europe. A founder of the Horticulture Society of London was John Wedgwood, whose family firm in 1810 began manufacturing a series based on illustrations in William Curtis's authoritative Botanical Magazine. French porcelain from Sevres was decorated with asters, calendulas and iris. The fern-leaf peony, P. tenuifolia, appeared on plates made in Russia. Tulip poplar flowers bloomed on a black background on a Viennese tea service. Napoleon commissioned a set of plates decorated with copies of Redoute's paintings of the roses at Malmaison.
In 1863, a new Flora Danica dinner service was ordered for the Danish princess Alexandra, who was engaged to marry Albert Edward (Edward VII), heir to the English throne. The princess's service -- 60 place-settings, almost 800 individual pieces -- is now in the collection of Queen Elizabeth II, at Windsor Castle..
Nearly 1,500 pieces of the original Flora Danica service survive. Many can be seen at Rosenborg, the Rose Castle, in Copenhagen. The service is still brought out for royal birthdays and other occasions of state.
Flora Danica is still being made by hand at Royal Copenhagen's factory, but it is hard to buy on a budget. The dinner plates cost $1,000 each, and a soup tureen a small fortune. I grew up in more modest circumstances, eating meatloaf on Thistle plates, a wonderful old Stangl pottery pattern my mother still uses. My grandmother's fancy china, decorated with fat grapes, hydrangea blossoms, ivy, full-blown roses, pansies, and other flowers and fruit, was always too good to use. When my grandmother died, my mother instinctively wrapped the plates in newspaper and packed them away forever.
Anyone who has ever plucked a bit of lichen from a tree trunk or picked a wildflower at the edge of a woodland path is aware of the delicacy and astonishing complexity of nature. These little specimens seem to spring to life again when you discover them tucked in the pages of a notebook or novel. Two hundred years ago, the pleasure must have been as sweet when a botanist and a prince -- and possibly they were the same man -- conceived the idea and accordingly decreed that, no matter how dark the night or how troubled and complex the political situation, on the dinner table, at least, it thenceforth might as well be spring. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: In the 18th century, European porcelain began moving away from Oriental themes to depict local flora. A Flora Danica ice dome, above, and a plate, left. (Royal Copenhagen)

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE; 
In Atlantic City, a Matter of Town vs. Gown

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
WHEN Robert M. Renneisen Jr. took over as chief executive of the Miss America Organization a little more than two years ago, he was greeted in Atlantic City as a hero, a savior and, most of all, a one-of-us kind of guy.
 The truth is, Mr. Renneisen did not have a hard act to follow. He was replacing a neophyte in the form of Robert Beck, a lawyer from Chicago who had embarrassed the pageant during his yearlong tenure by decreeing that women who had been divorced or who had had abortions should be allowed to enter the annual contest that searched for "all-American face and form." 
 It is not that simple. Atlantic City has a one-year lease on life in terms of keeping the 80-year-old pageant in its hometown. It was the last thing that this faded resort needed in a time of economic weakness when New York State is inching closer to legalized gambling in the Catskills -- a prospect that frightens the gaming industry in Atlantic City despite protestations to the contrary. 
The concern is that New Yorkers and others -- who make up 15 percent to 20 percent of the gamblers in Atlantic City -- will head for a modern resort in the mountains rather than a glitzy casino on the Boardwalk facing a less-than-inviting stretch of beach and surrounded by urban decay.
Against such a forbidding backdrop, Mr. Renneisen -- who worked his way up in the world of casinos over the past 20 years in marketing and management -- last week accused Atlantic City's civic leaders of not doing their best to keep the pageant in the place it was born and threatened to take it on the road if they did not come up with an additional $1 million a year.
Almost two weeks ago the board of the Miss America Organization voted unanimously to remain in Atlantic City for at least one more year despite the refusal of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Bureau to agree to the pageant's request for more money.
It made residents of this beleaguered city yearn for a simpler time.
"It was a bit surprising," said Cathy Burke, who owns the Irish Pub, a longtime local watering hole. "Miss America is the thing that gives Atlantic City an identity. It shows us as more an attraction than just the casinos. You wouldn't think it, but I love these people who come in for Miss America. They are so real. It's like a family reunion every year when they come into town."
While many people in Atlantic City deride the anachronistic notion of a beauty pageant in the 21st century, they do not want to see it ride out of town on the old Reading Railroad -- or any other conveyance on the Monopoly board.
"Yes, someone must be against it, I guess," said Pinky Kravitz, who has had a radio call-in talk show in the Atlantic City area for 40 years. "There are people who get upset when the sun shines, too. Realistically, though, it is part of this community. Miss Universe, the teen pageants, they are all a copy of Miss America.
"It may be hokey," Mr. Kravitz added, "but ultimately it's fun. For two weeks out of the year, it gets Atlantic City good publicity in newspapers all over the country. How can anyone here really want it to leave?"
While Mr. Renneisen's threats certainly aroused anger, at least some observers were willing to admit that he had a point. In addition, places like the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn., the MGM Grand in Las Vegas; and Anaheim, Calif., said they were willing to pay top dollar to lure the pageant from Atlantic City.
"To sell it out to the Mohegan Sun so they can promote their property to the nation would have been a slap in the face," said James Carney, an Atlantic County freeholder. "There was some suspicion on why it was moving where. The checkbook was there to go higher. But money wasn't the total issue and the board saw it. It has been an 81-year-old marriage. It went beyond the money."
But for Mr. Renneisen's part, it is about the money. He said that the pageant lost money last year -- even though it received $5.8 million from ABC for television rights -- and that he hoped with state subsidies, upgrades to production facilities and other in-kind services worth about $1 million, Atlantic City could make the pageant profitable.
To that end Mark Juliano, director of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority, has organized a task force of business and community leaders to figure out how to keep the pageant in town.
"It's definitely an Atlantic City event that should stay in Atlantic City," said Andrew Latz, the third generation of his family to run the Knife and Fork restaurant in the Chelsea section of the city -- a place where a first-place prize from the original 1921 Miss America parade is on display. "The Knife and Fork won it, and we want to display it to show how tradition still means something in Atlantic City, that the city is multidimensional, not just a bunch of casinos."
This is not the first time that officials have threatened to move the annual pageant. Leonard Horn -- predecessor to the reviled Mr. Beck -- had discussions with Disney about taking on the event, and for several years even had the contestants gather at Disney World in Orlando before the pageant in Atlantic City. But no one took seriously the threat by Mr. Horn, a lawyer who grew up in the area, to move the pageant.
"The most important thing was that he wanted it here, and now we know most people in Atlantic City want it here, too," said Mr. Kravitz. "Maybe we took it for granted and this is a good thing. But you know, you can't beat the publicity. Say a girl from Tuscaloosa is in the pageant. Well, her paper covers it for a couple of weeks. Then she gets in the finals and all of the papers in the state do it, too. We couldn't buy that type of thing."
Nor is it likely that Mr. Renneisen can buy the type of local support he gets in Atlantic City. Dozens of volunteers chaperone and drive and do all sorts of tasks to make sure the pageant operates smoothly and pleasantly in Atlantic City.
"People have taken off two, three weeks of their vacation for 25 or 27 years to work on Miss America," said Mr. Carney.
Uncasville, for example, where the the Mohegan Sun Casino is situated, has a population of only 9,909, probably not enough for a good volunteer base.
And in Las Vegas and Anaheim, the pageant would be no more than an afterthought among so many other local events.
"Here we get the people who work for the event or love the event to come back and enjoy themselves," said Ms. Burke of the Irish Pub. "There are hockey people or golf people, right? So there are Miss America people, too, and for whatever anyone thinks, they embody the true spirit of the country. They are of all races and ethnicities and they love coming here for this pageant."
She added: "For a couple of weeks a year, Atlantic City becomes a wholesome place, which is hardly a bad thing. Maybe this is what we needed to appreciate that."

Robert M. Renneisen Jr., who now runs the contest, says the city must ante up more money or it will leave. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times); (Photographs by Chris Polk for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Spare the Children

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH V. DORIA Jr.; Joseph V. Doria Jr., who represents Bayonne and part of Jersey City in the Assembly, will be chairman of the Education Committee.

 BODY:
ABRAHAM LINCOLN, a man who revered the value of education, once gave this sage advice: "Leave nothing for tomorrow which can be done today."
 It's always been a good maxim to live by, but I have found Lincoln's words to be profoundly applicable in recent weeks as state policymakers consider ways to address a multibillion-dollar revenue shortfall in the state budget. New Jersey's "financial problem" has already prompted a state government hiring freeze. There also have been discussions about such austerity measures as making no increases in municipal aid and paring down a scheduled increase in the NJSaver property tax rebate program. 
 Only time will tell the extent and severity of the spending reductions the state will need to keep its budget balanced and its fiscal house in order. But as lawmakers weigh their options, they would be wise to keep Lincoln's words in mind and repel any temptation to cut back financing for the fledgling early childhood education programs that have been created to address long-ignored inequities in the state's public schools.
Preschool programs are a mandatory investment, not a frivolous expenditure. Early education should be considered sacrosanct because the kind of future we create for our children and ourselves will depend on what we do for our children today.
Continuing to finance preschool programs ensures more than personal growth opportunities for children. In the long run, these programs help to protect this state's long-term economic stability while averting further counterproductive court fights over the state's system of financing public schools.
When governments invest in educating children at ages 3 and 4, there are significant dividends down the road. Numerous studies have demonstrated that a first-class preschool experience has a direct relation to how children learn and how they get along with others. Children who have taken part in such programs exhibit a greater level of social adjustment, have less chance of being left back or of being placed in special education, and have a greater probability of graduating from high school.
In a series of landmark decisions in the Abbott v. Burke school lawsuit, New Jersey's Supreme Court has ruled that all 3- and 4-year-old children in the state's 30 "special needs" districts, called Abbott districts, must receive "high quality" preschool programs. After years of procrastination and posturing, the state has finally reached a point where it might move in earnest to meet the court's mandate.
Under New Jersey's Early Childhood Program Aid initiative, more than $329 million in state aid was distributed in fiscal year 2001-02 to the Abbott districts and to 98 non-Abbott districts that have a substantial number of low-income families. The money is specifically earmarked for providing full-day kindergarten and half-day preschool programs for 3 and-4-year olds. 
Currently, the formula for determining a school district's eligibility for these funds is based on the total percentage of lower-income children in a district. But the state's budget problems could force a dramatic change in the way this financing is determined. State education officials have already sent letters in which they hint at spending reductions for some districts. Their approach would drastically reduce the number of school districts eligible for the financing.
In the short term, the state would save itself some money. The long-term outcome, however, may be an expense worth avoiding: a whole generation of young people could be deprived of what many researchers consider the foundation upon which future academic success is built.
New Jersey faces numerous fiscal challenges -- financing vital highway and mass transportation projects, providing for our elderly citizens and meeting the security challenges following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, to name just a few. But we cannot afford to siphon precious dollars away from early education.
Throwing money blindly at a problem is never an answer, but adequately investing in our children at a tender age produces a dividend for us all. When all children are properly educated from the start, all of society reaps the benefits -- now and in the future.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Retirement Shares You Keep Paying For

BYLINE:  By ERIC BAUM

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund fees, never easy to decipher, are becoming even more complex. Several big fund companies have introduced a class of retirement shares recently that may be appealing in the short run but that lift an investor's long-term expenses.
 The shares have different names, and while they generally promise lower expenses at the outset, they often result in higher overall costs for investors by increasing the annual fees paid to brokers. First introduced in smaller 401(k) retirement plans, the shares are now being offered to investors who hold mutual funds in individual retirement accounts. 
 In some cases, the shares will raise fees for investors who have held funds in employer-sponsored 401(k) plans for years and will roll them over into I.R.A.'s when they change jobs or retire.
The advent of the shares troubles some experts. John Rekenthaler, president of online advice at Morningstar Inc., said the retirement shares would confuse many people.
"I'm confused," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "I don't think it's good for the fund industry.
"It would be nice if they could find a way to sell the product rather than add to the proliferation of product," he added. "This just adds to the level of distrust between the client and the adviser."
Fund companies offering retirement shares include Franklin Templeton Investments, OppenheimerFunds, Invesco Funds and Putnam Investments. American Funds is also considering retirement shares, according to Chuck Freadhoff, a spokesman for Capital Research and Management, which owns the American Funds Group.
"I think there's a sense that the retirement plan business, especially the 401(k) plan market, is such a large part of every mutual fund company that it needs to be treated in a different way," Mr. Freadhoff said. "We are certainly looking at the concept of a share class for retirement."
But the shares have not yet swept the industry. Vanguard and Fidelity Investments are not planning to introduce the shares in their own funds, nor will they sell them through their fund supermarkets.
"We don't have a retirement share class, and have no plans to offer one," said Dan Flaherty, a spokesman for Fidelity.
Brian Mattes, a Vanguard spokesman, said: "We do not have one of these programs because we are committed to selling directly to the investor. Everyone wants to get paid for distribution, but that is not part of our philosophy."
Fund companies are positioning themselves for the anticipated roll-over of trillions of dollars of baby-boomer retirement assets from 401(k)'s and other defined-contribution retirement plans into I.R.A.'s. Such roll-overs are expected to reach $467 billion a year by 2010, according to Cerulli Associates, a consulting firm in Boston.
For brokers and financial advisers who sell funds to investors, the retirement shares provide increased service fees over the long haul. Ordinary fund shares that charge an upfront commission customarily provide brokers with fees of 0.25 percent of assets annually, while the retirement shares raise the fees to a minimum of 0.35 percent and to as much as 0.75 percent, fund companies and brokers said.
BECAUSE the retirement shares often waive commissions, they are useful for some investors, while giving brokers an effective sales tool, said Douglas Rentschler, an OppenheimerFunds vice president in Grosse Pointe, Mich.
"It's another pricing arrangement that will allow the financial adviser to diversify their clients' portfolios in the proper funds at an appropriate expense ratio," he said.
Some brokers acknowledge that the shares benefit them more than their clients. John Diaz, president of Premier Financial Advisors in New York, said he was motivated to consider selling OppenheimerFunds' retirement shares because they paid a higher commission in the long term. Still, he said, the typical alternative, known as a Class A share, represents a better value for customers. The A class is the standard share category on which an upfront commission, often 5 to 6 percent, is charged.
"Usually, the A share wins out in the long term because you have a lower expense ratio," he said. "But there was a lot of hand-holding over the last year. Clients expect some kind of service that requires time, and advisers should get paid by either fees or commissions."
Steve Mattar, president of Mattar Financial in Farmington Hills, Mich., used software to provide a hypothetical example of how a long-term investor would be better off with A shares, although retirement shares might seem more appealing at first glance.
A person investing $500,000 in Putnam's Voyager fund in an I.R.A. using Class A shares in November 1991, would have qualified for a reduced commission of 2 percent, or $10,000. The remaining sum, invested at annual expenses of 0.86 percent, would have grown to $1.81 million in 10 years without withdrawals, he said. In the same situation, an investor using retirement shares, which Putnam calls M shares, would incur no initial commission but would pay annual expenses of 1.36 percent. The investor would have accumulated $1.76 million had the share class existed for all 10 years. (It was created in December 1994.) 
In that illustration, the A shares outperformed the M shares after the eighth year. Hypothetical situations also show that the A shares would have earned $2.5 million more than the M shares over 25 years.
While some investors feel confident choosing from multiple share class options, others say they need help.
Don Lewis, 48, the former director of government sales at Dictaphone, lost his job in a recent round of layoffs and has a balance of roughly $60,000 in his 401(k), which he plans to roll over into an I.R.A.
He is investigating investment options with his wife, Lynne Mersfelder-Lewis, 36, but finds the array of funds and fund classes off-putting.
"It's not intimidating; it's annoying," he said. "It's information overload." To avoid the mistake of choosing an unsuitable share class, he has decided to invest with Vanguard, the largest strictly no-load fund family. 
Commissions, however, are ultimately a means of paying for professional guidance, and picking a mutual fund is a decision that involves trust as well as cost, Mrs. Mersfelder-Lewis said.
"Are they doing something that's better for your stock portfolio or for their pocketbook?" she asked of the investment advisers. "That was one of the reasons why we picked Vanguard."
