HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NONFICTION; 
Thrift Amid the Squalor, Ego in the Skyline

 BODY:
FIVE POINTS
By Tyler Anbinder
The Free Press
($30, hardcover)
 Some observers nonetheless questioned the wisdom of emigrating, given that the Irish faced discrimination and were virtually forced into low-paying manual labor. Reading such charges in The Irish-American, Five Pointer Michael Coogan felt compelled to reply. Although it was true that Irish Americans worked primarily as laborers, he wrote, the Irish were especially well suited for the work. Besides, the County Wicklow native argued, manual labor paid well compared to the options available in Ireland. 
 "Don't they get good value for their time and labor," Coogan asked. "They can eat good beef, and pork, and butter, and eggs, and bread -- not so at home in the old country," even though "an Irish laborer had to work harder there than here."
Those familiar with the standard version of Irish-American history might be surprised by these letters. A deep pessimism pervades this literature, assuming that the famine immigrants were a kind of lost generation fated to be victims of disease, nativism and overcrowded tenements in America.
If any group of Five Pointers was going to fit this stereotype, it ought to be the Lansdowne immigrants. A full 90 percent of the Lansdowne men toiled as lowly paid menial laborers, and they lived with their families in the most filthy and overcrowded tenements. But account ledgers from the Emigrant Savings Bank suggest that these immigrants did far better than we have previously imagined. Lansdowne immigrants living in Five Points opened 153 accounts in the bank's first six years of operation (through August 1856). 
In fact, about half of the Lansdowne families living there had opened accounts by mid-1855. The bank records provide a rare glimpse into the economic fortunes of a very significant number of the Lansdowne immigrants.
The bank ledgers suggest that even while living in Five Points, the Lansdowne immigrants were able to save far more than one might have imagined.

EMPIRE:
A Tale of Obsession,
Betrayal, and the Battle for an American Icon
By Mitchell Pacelle
John Wiley & Sons
($27.95, hardcover)
As the real estate gold rush of the 1980's was fading into bust, and financial pressure on the insurance company mounted, Prudential had decided to sell the Empire State Building, and Kurt A. Reich was waiting to meet the mysterious couple who had bid more than anyone else.
The ego buyers had indeed been out in force, because the world's most famous skyscraper, curiously enough, was likely to sell for a price that -- in the lofty world of Manhattan real estate -- was little more than a song.
Thirty years earlier, Prudential had gutted the building's profit potential. It had leased the entire building -- for 114 years, an eternity in real estate -- to an investment company controlled by a pair of Manhattan real estate titans. Each year, the two moguls paid Prudential a paltry $1.9 million in rent for the 2.5-million-square-foot building, giving them both a motive to cling to their lease with the tenacity of Park Avenue millionaires in rent-controlled apartments.
Whoever bought the Empire State Building now would face the prospect of wrangling with two of Manhattan's most difficult real estate titans: Peter Malkin, an iron-willed Harvard-educated lawyer who was exacting to the point of annoyance, and Leona Helmsley, a notoriously volatile woman who was sowing terror through the billion-dollar real estate empire assembled by her ailing husband, Harry. What Prudential was selling, in truth, was little more than sizzle: the right to boast, "I own the Empire State Building."

UNEARTHING GOTHAM:
The Archaeology
of New York City
By Anne-Marie Cantwell
and Diana diZerega Wall
Yale University Press
($39.95, hardcover)
The African Burial Ground has become an enormously important site for modern-day Africans, African-Americans and all New Yorkers. This sacred site underscores and commemorates the deep historical presence of Africans in New York and their contribution in building the nation. 
As David Dinkins eloquently put it, "Millions of Americans celebrate Ellis Island as the symbol of their communal identity in this land. Others celebrate Plymouth Rock. Until a few years ago, African-American New Yorkers had no site to call our own. There was no place which said, we were here, we contributed, we played a significant role in New York's history right from the beginning. Now we -- their descendants -- have the symbol of our heritage embodied in Lower Manhattan's African Burial Ground. The African Burial Ground is the irrefutable testimony to the contributions and suffering of our ancestors."

THE EMPIRE STATE:
A History of New York
Edited by Milton M. Klein
Cornell University Press
($45, hardcover)
 World War II had transformed New York City. . . . The lively arts, blacked out in Europe, lit up New York City. . . .
What resulted was an astonishing outpouring of Americana. In 1943 came Aaron Copland's "Fanfare for the Common Man," a paean to wartime patriotism; and the following year saw Martha Graham's performance of Copland's masterful "Appalachian Spring." 
The musical "Oklahoma!" made history on Broadway in 1943. It not only featured Richard Rodgers's lilting tunes and Oscar Hammerstein II's apple-pie lyrics, but set a new standard for the musical stage by making Agnes de Mille's "dream ballet" and Oliver Smith's haunting scenic designs an integral part of the drama. Further highlights in 1944 included Leonard Bernstein's "On the Town," with book by Betty Comden and Adolph Green . . . 
During the war, Broadway mounted patriotic shows like Irving Berlin's revue "This Is the Army" (1942), and sponsored the Service Canteen, which hosted visiting soldiers and sailors. Drama was largely escapist fare, notably "Life With Father," which ran throughout the war, and "Harvey" (1945), the whimsical account of a man and his imaginary friend, a seven-foot rabbit, which beat out Tennessee Williams's brooding, sexually ambivalent "Glass Menagerie" for the Pulitzer Prize. 
Several Shakespearean productions marked social breakthroughs, notably the black actor Paul Robeson's lead in "Othello," and "The Tempest," which starred Canada Lee, another African-American, as Caliban. In 1941 the Group Theater, run by Harold Clurman and Lee Strasberg, put on Thornton Wilder's sentimental tale of humankind's progress, "The Skin of Our Teeth," worth of note for Elia Kazan's direction of Montgomery Clift's Broadway debut.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Melissa Telzer, Alexander Milne-Pott

 BODY:
Melissa Hope Telzer, the daughter of Dr. Ellen G. Telzer and Mark N. Telzer, both of Brooklyn, was married on Wednesday to Alexander Thomas Gideon Milne-Pott, a son of Judith B. and S. Ross Milne-Pott of Melbourne, Australia. Johnnie M. Johnson, the deputy city clerk in Brooklyn, performed a civil ceremony there at Borough Hall. Last Sunday, at Bridgewaters, a restaurant in Manhattan, Kathryn Boeschenstein, who is studying to become an Episcopal priest and is a friend of the bride's mother, performed a nondenominational celebration. 
 Mrs. Milne-Pott, 32, and Mr. Milne-Pott, 29, work in Melbourne. The bride is the Web-infrastructure manager at KPMG Australia, the accounting and consulting firm. The bridegroom is a portfolio manager for JM Financial Group, a fund management firm. 
 The bride graduated from Brandeis. Her father is a caterer in Brooklyn. Her mother is a child psychologist in Brooklyn.
The bridegroom graduated with honors from the University of Melbourne. His mother is a Ph.D. candidate and an economics tutor there. His father is a director of corporate finance in the Melbourne office of HTM Wilson, a stock brokerage firm.
The couple met at a dance club in New York in December 1999, when Mr. Milne-Pott was visiting from Australia and Ms. Telzer was working as a management consultant at PricewaterhouseCoopers L.L.P.
"I gave him my number, saying, 'this guy is in from Australia?' " Ms. Telzer said, emphasizing the name of the continent as if to remind herself of the romantic futility the word seemed to promise. "I said to everyone at Christmas, 'Oh, I met this really cute Australian,' and they said, 'Can't you meet someone in New York?' "
But that first meeting led to a long phone call a few days later, followed by a movie date. Two weeks remained before Mr. Milne-Pott had to leave New York, and in that time, they became inseparable.
So began a long-distance relationship. Their phone calls crossed 16 time zones, and they made the flight between New York and Melbourne a dizzying number of times.
"When you go, you arrive two days later," the bride said. "And you can just imagine us calling each other. I don't think I got any sleep." Mr. Milne-Pott said he took traveling halfway around the world for love in stride.
"From an Australian perspective, it isn't such a big thing," he said. "The nearest country is eight hours away. New York is just a lot longer trip."
Even so, after seven months, they lost patience.
"We decided that someone had to move somewhere," Ms. Telzer said. "My job was better at the moment, and so he quit his job and moved to New York in September."
Visa restrictions, however, made finding work difficult, so in February Mr. Milne-Pott went back to Australia. In April, Ms. Telzer moved there, too.
Last month, they made the 22-hour trip to New York to marry in the city where they met. His parents also made the trip, and he gave them credit for his transglobal romance.
"Our family has always encouraged us to go out and find the person of our dreams," Mr. Milne-Pott said. "Where that person comes from is second to that."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
The Ups, Downs and Fine Print of Sector Rotation

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE bear market of the last two years has been painful for many mutual fund investors. But it has been relatively good to those who rotate through sectors.
 How good? Consider the performance of newsletters that advocate such rotation. The Hulbert Financial Digest has ranked the newsletters as if they were money managers carrying out these strategies. 
 At the peak of the bull market in late 1999, barely a handful of these newsletters were ahead of the stock market itself. Today, nearly two-thirds of them are.
It is rare for more than one-fourth of money managers to beat a buy-and-hold strategy over the long term. To be sure, the proportion grows somewhat during bear markets, to the extent that managers invest any of their portfolios in cash or bonds. Nevertheless, the percentage of sector-rotation newsletters that are now outperforming the market is surprising -- and is well above the percentage of other newsletters doing so..
Though there are many variations, sector-rotation strategies switch among sector funds -- those that specialize in particular industries -- in the hope of always being in the best-performing sectors. Many investors pursue the strategy through Fidelity Investments, which offers 41 sector funds, designated by the word "Select" in their names, as in Fidelity Select Energy. Other fund families that offer sector funds include Vanguard, Rydex Funds and ProFunds. There is also a growing list of exchange-traded funds -- securities built from baskets of stocks grouped by a particular sector or index.
The allure of sector rotation is easy to understand. Many investors view it as a middle path between a buy-and-hold strategy, which loses money during a bear market, and market timing, whose potential looks great on paper but which rarely works in practice. An additional attraction is that even in a bear market, some sectors do well. So investors who pursue these strategies can sidestep intractable questions about whether a bear market will continue.
Theoretically, at least, the payout can be big. Investors lucky enough to have been in the best-performing Fidelity Select fund in each of the last 10 calendar years would have made an average of 66 percent a year, annualized, versus 12.3 percent for the stock market as a whole, as measured by the Wilshire 5000 index. During the bear market of the last two years, someone who invested in the top-performing Select fund each year would have had an annualized return of 46.3 percent, versus a loss of 10.9 percent for the market. 
Of course, few investors are lucky enough to be invested in the top-performing sector fund in any given year, much less for 10 consecutive years. Nevertheless, every January, many investors are sorely tempted to try their hand at sector rotation.
Most of them end up regretting the decision, because few have the self-discipline to follow the precise dictates of sector-rotation strategies or the willingness to pay the almost-daily attention they typically demand. On balance, the sector-rotation strategies monitored by The Hulbert Financial Digest have beaten those odds. Of the 41 now being followed, 27, or 66 percent, are ahead of the Wilshire on a risk-adjusted basis over the monitored periods. Because that market-beating percentage is so much higher than for other newsletters, the sector-rotation newsletters' success is unlikely to be a chance occurrence.
Using the Sharpe Ratio, named for the Nobel laureate William Sharpe, each newsletter's performance was divided by its risk, as measured by the volatility of its returns. That was to ensure that newsletters that were willing to incur above-average amounts of risk were not given an unfair advantage.
The Fidelity Select model portfolio of Timer Digest provides a good illustration of how the Sharpe Ratio can deflate what otherwise appears to be impressive performance. Between the beginning of 1988 and Nov. 30, the portfolio outperformed the Wilshire, 16 percent to 13.7 percent, annualized. At the same time, the portfolio was 73 percent riskier than the Wilshire. As a result, the portfolio's Sharpe Ratio was below that of the Wilshire -- which means that it owes its market-beating performance to its riskiness.
Comparing strategies on a risk-adjusted basis is important in any context, but it is especially so for sector-rotation strategies because of their riskiness. On average, based on their Sharpe ratio, the 41 sector-rotation strategies now being monitored have been 14 percent riskier than the overall stock market. The 27 strategies that beat the market were even riskier, averaging 21 percent more risk than the market. That such a high percentage of strategies outperform the market even after such adjustment means that they genuinely added value.
WHY has the average sector-rotation newsletter performed so much better? Part of the explanation lies in the short-term momentum strategies that almost all the sector-rotation newsletters pursue. Many academic studies have shown that stocks do exhibit short-term momentum, which means that the average stock that has outperformed the market in the recent past continues to do so, at least for a while longer. Sector-rotation strategies appear to be just another way of exploiting momentum in the market.
And momentum manifests itself more reliably among sector funds than individual stocks. Say a particular stock has a 55 percent probability of rising in price because of its short-term momentum. Now imagine a portfolio that owns many such stocks. It can be shown mathematically that this portfolio's odds of rising are much higher -- closer to 75 percent, in fact.
The key to this upside potential is that a sector fund's portfolio is homogenous. Its stocks sometimes move in tandem because they come from the same industry.
The downside, of course, is that a sector fund's heightened probabilities will work against it once its momentum heads south. That is why a sector-rotation strategy demands daily attention of investors: they may have to get in or out of a fund on a moment's notice.
These newsletters are indeed active traders; as of Nov. 30, for example, their recommended funds had been held for an average of only two months. As a result, their strategies are more appropriate for tax-deferred accounts, in which frequent transactions will not have adverse tax consequences.
Because of their frequent trades, sector-rotation investors should aim to avoid transaction costs. Many sector-rotation strategies have begun to favor non-Fidelity sector funds, because Fidelity levies a 0.75 percent redemption fee if a Select fund is sold within 30 days of purchase. Exchange-traded funds may also become a preferred alternative, provided that they are traded through a deep-discount brokerage firm.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Payoffs in Fleet-Footed Investing"Seven of nine portfolios based on sector-rotation strategies recommended by investment newsletters for at least five years have beaten the overall stock market on a risk-adjusted basis. Graph shows newsletters, portfolios, tracking, and the annualized gains.(Source: The Hulbert Financial Digest)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Corporate Profits: Is the Worst Over?

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A DUBIOUS anniversary will be played out over the next few weeks, as American corporations release their results for the final quarter of 2001. 
 Corporate earnings started to deteriorate a year ago, and they haven't stopped since. Investors are likely to be disappointed if they buy shares expecting that the profit picture will improve quickly. The positive spin, if you can call it that, is that the outlook for some sectors is not as bad as for others. 
 Chuck Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial/First Call, which tracks earnings estimates, took some time last week to talk about what he sees ahead. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. What is the best thing you can say about fourth-quarter earnings?

A. Compared to the year-ago quarter, when the seasonal patterns were the same, it appears that profit warnings are starting to decelerate, and until you start to see that, you can't talk about an imminent upturn in earnings. You don't just throw a switch and go from record earnings levels to down and then back up to record levels again. Also, there is a reasonable chance that technology may do better than expected.
Back in July, tech companies in the S.& P. 500 index were expected to have an earnings decline of 24 percent. Just before Sept. 11, they were expected to be down by 43 percent. Now the drop is forecast to be 64 percent. I think they will beat those numbers. But that doesn't mean much.

Q. What impact will Sept. 11 have on profits?

A.There will be more effect in the fourth quarter than there was in the third. Prior to the attacks, we had expected third-quarter earnings would be down 17 percent. They ended down 21.6 percent. The bulk of the difference was in insurance company earnings. That hit is essentially over.
Before Sept. 11, we had thought fourth-quarter earnings would be down 12 percent. Now we think the decline will be 22 percent. That number looks about the same from the third quarter, but in reality the fourth-quarter numbers are a lot worse. On a seasonally adjusted basis, profits are probably down 15 percent from the third quarter. 

Q. Was 2001 the worst year for corporate profits?

A. For the year, earnings will be down 16.7 percent. In 2000, they were up 16.2 percent. I don't know about ever, but you could make a case this is the worst earnings year since World War II at least, if you look at the length and breadth of the downturn.
There were two recessions where earnings declines were as deep or deeper, and two when the length of declines was as long or longer. But they were not the same two.

Q. Has the decline in earnings ended?

A. We will end up with five down earnings quarters at least. Analysts are already forecasting declines of 6 percent. I am confident the first-quarter number will get taken down more than the normal trimming.
The second quarter could be anywhere from flat to up a few percent. Then, for the third and fourth quarter, profits will be up a fair amount, partly because the comparisons get a fair bit easier and also as a result of all the stimulus taking hold and helping the economy. At this point we think earnings will be up 1 percent in the second quarter, up 15 percent in the third quarter and up 32 percent in the fourth.

Q. Which sectors are expected to produce the biggest profit gains and declines in 2002?

A. Right now, analysts are saying the biggest gainers will be technology, basic industries like chemicals and papers, and financials. Both tech and basic industries are forecast to see profits increase by more than 40 percent. Profit growth in financials is projected at 27 percent. Transportation, which will probably lose money, and oil companies, which are projected to see profits fall 25 percent, are the worst categories.

Q. Do you agree with analysts' numbers?

A. The mistake analysts are making is looking at how we bounced back from other recessions. In technology, there are still some demand and supply problems. I will believe the upturn in technology profitability when I see it.

Q. Are you concerned about the run we have had in stocks since late September?

A. Theoretically, you should pay more on trough earnings than on peak or normal earnings, but valuations in technology stocks are excessive in many cases. If you look out to 2003, when you are back closer to what normalized earnings should be, you are talking about prices that are two times the growth rate for many of these companies. In my mind, that is a bit rich.
But I don't think valuations are necessarily ahead of themselves in virtually every other sector. 
Still, I would feel better if the Fed, which in the past has said it does not react to asset valuations, started to tighten monetary policy if the market started to gallop.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING; 
Olympic Group's Dream Is Environmentalists' Nightmare

BYLINE:  By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
To get to most points along Willow Lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, you have to hack through a 12-foot wall of phragmites stalks. To uproot those plants and turn the lake and its environs into a rowing site, as proposed by a group that wants to hold the 2012 Summer Olympics in New York, you have to go through a wall of indignant citizens called the Flushing Meadows-Corona Park Conservancy. 
 "What they call an improvement, I call a disaster," said Paul Graziano, a member of the new group, as he hiked around Willow Lake with a dozen fellow members on a recent cloudy Sunday afternoon. 
 The improvements he finds disastrous include dredging and connecting the 48-acre Willow Lake to the nearby 84-acre Meadow Lake, and raising Jewel Avenue onto a bridge that would cross the rowing site. The plan also calls for ball fields and wildlife habitats in the park. 
Daniel L. Doctoroff, who served as president of NYC2012, the private group that is backing the Olympics in New York, until named by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as deputy mayor for economic development, has said such changes would improve Willow Lake.
"It is not a natural lake," Mr. Doctoroff said. "It was bulldozed into existence for the 1939 World's Fair to accept rainwater from the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway. It is filled with sediment, which is itself filled with chemicals like copper sulfate." But Mr. Graziano said the plan would turn the lake into "a giant bathtub" by smoothing out its idiosyncrasies.
The Bloomberg administration will continue the push to bring the 2012 Olympics to New York.
On the hike, the members found the area squishy and overgrown. It yielded wild irises and berry-bearing sumac vines, as well as bottles, a broken kite and some underwear. 
Richard P. Murphy, the Queens parks commissioner, guided the group. He stopped before a burned, unstable wooden bridge, which is one reason the lake is now fenced off from the public. Conservancy members say the park should be modestly renovated, routinely patrolled and open during the day. But they say no to the Olympics. 
NYC2012 had a big success in October when the United States Olympic Committee put New York on its list of four cities as possible host of the Games. The committee plans to choose one city by fall 2002. Should New York be chosen, it would go against foreign cities, with the 2012 host to be chosen in fall 2005. If New York is picked, the city's land-use approval process would begin. 
In December, , Mr. Doctoroff said Willow Lake is so polluted even eels have trouble surviving, "and they can survive almost anything."
With the proposed improvements, he predicted, its water would become clean and swimmable. "Even drinkable," he said. JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Managers Say This Decade Belongs to Health Care

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN

 BODY:
HEALTH care funds have outperformed the overall market over the last decade, and despite a disappointing run last year, some of the funds' managers declare that the future is theirs.
 "We believe this decade belongs to us," said Samuel Isaly, manager of the Eaton Vance Worldwide Health Sciences fund, the top-performing health care sector fund over the last 10 years, according to Morningstar. "In my opinion, health and biotech stocks can dominate the market over the next decade, just as technology stocks did in the 1990's," he said. 
 The last 12 months, however, have not been impressive for the sector. After a spectacular run in 2000, because of investments in companies generating steady earnings, the funds were hurt when nervous investors dumped high-priced stocks in early 2001, said Emily Hall, a Morningstar analyst. 
Moreover, pharmaceutical stocks, the biggest chunk of health care sector funds in general, had a tough year as drug company earnings were hit by patent expirations and an unexpected slowdown in government approvals of new drugs. Partly as a result, health care sector funds fell an average of 10.9 percent last year.
The long-term figures are better. Over the last 10 years, health care sector funds have returned 13.8 percent a year, on average, versus 12.9 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
Fidelity Select Health Care has handily beaten both the S.& P. 500 and another sector fund, Fidelity Select Technology, in the 20 years since its inception, returning a cumulative 4,071 percent, versus 1,613 percent for the index and 1,792 percent for the technology fund. "Over the long term, consistent earnings really do matter," said Eric Kobren, executive editor of Fidelity Insight.
Factors that have allowed health care funds to post such solid numbers are still in place, including steady demand for services and new treatments. In addition, new medical devices and developments in biotechnology are likely to spur growth, money managers and analysts said. 
The aging population of the United States and other developed countries is expected to spend more on health care products and services. And an expanding middle class in many developing countries should help global companies, because the richer a country becomes, the more it tends to spend on health care. In the United States, health care spending's share of gross domestic product has almost doubled in the last 30 years, to 13 percent from 7 percent. 
The pace of innovation is accelerating, said Dr. Kris Jenner, manager of the T. Rowe Price Health Sciences fund. Not only are investments made by biotechnology companies in the last 10 years bearing fruit, he said, but the mapping of the human genome promises to speed the development of more effective treatments. 
One effect is likely to be an increasing number of biotechnology companies that actually generate earnings; about 100 are expected to be profitable in 2005, up from about 30 now, Mr. Isaly said. "It's harvest time," he said. 
Over all, earnings of health care companies are expected to grow 16 percent a year over the next five years -- three percentage points faster than the S.& P. 500, according to analysts' estimates compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
Health care stocks, however, have a problem: their future promise is hardly unrecognized. "This is not exactly a contrarian play," said Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor. The average price-to-earnings ratio of the stocks in health care funds is 40, according to Morningstar, compared with a multiple of 26 for the S.& P. 500. Even more expensive are biotech stocks, which have average multiples of 47, according to Mr. Jacobs's figures.
"You're talking pretty big risk here," he said. When such companies fail to deliver on investor expectations, their stocks fall hard.
Equally daunting for big drug-company stocks is the prospect of increased government involvement in the market. A prescription drug benefit under Medicare could depress drug prices and drug company profits, given the large role the government would play, Dr. Jenner said. Moreover, state governments have become more aggressive in pressing drug companies to lower prices. Just last month, 29 attorneys general filed suit against Bristol-Myers Squibb in an effort to break the company's exclusive hold over Buspar, its anti-anxiety drug, and open the market to generic versions. 
ULTIMATELY, however, the key to profit at drug companies is their ability to come up with effective new drugs quickly, Dr. Jenner said. That process has faltered of late, as shown in flat earnings expectations for companies like Eli Lilly and Merck for 2002. But later this year, drug introductions are expected to rebound. "I think people will look back on this year as an attractive time to buy," he said. 
An easy way for individual investors to play the long-term growth in health care is to buy shares of a relatively diversified sector fund. Some funds focus on volatile niches like biotechnology or medical devices. But a broader health care fund may invest in large pharmaceutical companies and small biotechs, upstart medical device companies and established hospitals and health maintenance organizations in the United States and abroad.
Over the long term, the Vanguard Health Care fund, with $17.2 billion in assets, has been among the best-performing broad-based health care funds. Run by Edward Owens, it has returned 19.8 percent a year, on average, over the last 10 years. In 2001, the fund was down 6.9 percent, five percentage points better than the S.& P. 500.
"Ed has been doing this a long time," said Daniel P. Wiener, editor of The Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, a newsletter. "He's proven he can be very consistent." Among Mr. Owens's top holdings now are the pharmaceutical giants Pharmacia and American Home Products.
Pharmaceuticals also play a big role at Eaton Vance Worldwide Health Sciences, which Mr. Isaly has managed for more than a dozen years. The fund invests only in drug stocks and biotechs, but those holdings cover both American and foreign companies, big and small. Among Mr. Isaly's favorite holdings are Eli Lilly, Novartis and Genentech.
ONE fund that did well last year was the Hartford Global Health fund, a relative newcomer. It is run by four managers at Wellington Management, which also employs Mr. Owens. The managers -- Joseph Schwartz, Ann Gallo, Jean Hynes and Kirk Mayer -- went into 2001 with an underweighting in drug stocks, relative to the Goldman Sachs Health Care Index, because of their big run-up in 2000. They also held disproportionately more health care service and medical devices stocks. Such companies had been beaten down the previous two years. Last year, health service stocks soared as pricing pressures on the industry eased, while drug stocks languished. 
Generally, investors are advised not to allocate more than 10 percent of their portfolio to a sector fund. "No matter how big the sector, these funds are going to trade with the vagaries of the industry," Ms. Hall warned. 
Some fund analysts, however, say the sector is broad enough and solid enough to warrant a bigger weighting. "We would have as much as 20 percent in a fund like Vanguard Health Care," Mr. Wiener said. "This is a well-diversified fund in a major sector of the economy that is recession-resistant, profitable and growing," he said. 
Before leaping into the sector, investors may want to check their exposure to health care stocks. Many growth stock funds loaded up on health care last year, and investors may have more than enough exposure already, Ms. Hall said.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOSEPH F. COATES; 
A Practiced Eye on the Future

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
 TALKING sweaters. A cure for schizophrenia. Cars that drive themselves to school to pick up your children. These are some of the things that Joseph F. Coates sees in the next 10 years. Mr. Coates, a futurist, analyzes technological, economic, political, social, cultural and demographic trends for businesses and government and industry organizations, and predicts what may happen in the next 5 to 50 years. 
 Mr. Coates is the retired president of Coates & Jarratt, a 22-year-old consulting company in Washington that gazes into its crystal ball for the likes of Coca-Cola, Ford Motor, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Coates, who now has his own consulting company, Joseph F. Coates Consulting Futurist, offered a few prognostications on Thursday. Here are excerpts. LYNNLEY BROWNING

Q. After Sept. 11, people predicted that business and government would change forever. Have they? How?

A. The main change affecting business and government is that you can no longer give casual acknowledgment that you are part of a larger system. Business and government are going to be forced to acknowledge this. They haven't been attendant to vulnerabilities. Business, in particular, tends to give little attention to the rare, the unusual, the unexpected and the offbeat.

Q. In what areas do you forecast the biggest changes?

A. The most interesting thing that's beginning to unfold at an increasing pace is molecular biology, molecular genetics. We're going to find pressure on people -- family members, friends, employers -- if there's a disease in the family to go and get a test. Prevention and treatment will follow much more slowly. But diagnostics will be quick, cheap and very important, and out of that will come the growth of genetic counseling.
Also, we are on the edge of the earliest forms of brain technology. All the things you'd say about your car or gas stove, you'll say about the brain. Fix it, take it apart, add to it, modify it. Within the decade, schizophrenia and psychotic depression will be history. That's how rapidly this knowledge is unfolding. We will have a cure and prevention of these within the decade. It doesn't mean we won't see schizophrenia in 2011, but the means of treating it will be there.
In the next couple of years, you're going to see overwhelming public and political acknowledgment that greenhouse warming is real. And we'll see massive programs that will affect home building and industrial processes -- and with that, a movement to massive conservation.
We're going to see much more work at home. Companies will see that people going to work is a tremendous waste of resources. Your grandfather on the farm probably saw one person a week, and he didn't go crazy. It's just a social accident that in an urban world, you see people so often. Videoconference screens will be fine enough so that you can read people's body language.

Q. How else will life at home change?

A. You will see the "electronic home work-study center." You're going to have to have something set aside as a designated workplace -- bigger homes. By the end of the decade, the typical home will have seven to eight flat-panel screens. Your cousin will be getting married in California, and you'll stick out your hand and touch the screen. It's not an alternative, either-or way of living. It's a substitution.
And who needs a $25,000 automobile to drive 5,000 miles a year? Are you going to travel three miles to a McDonald's? You'll see the redistribution of the service sector. You'll see fast-food people coming into the neighborhood with kiosks selling 15 items.
Regarding the education of children, with the dreadful condition of K-12, several things will happen. Parents will protest, but it won't be very effective. Home schooling will grow. Some parents will augment what the school does; others will replace it.
Distance learning has become very popular. College will eventually be the thing you go to only for hands-on experience or to find a mate. I see this rolling back into high school.

Q. Do you see any breakthroughs in how we consume energy, what we drive, what we wear?

A. We may see a significant number of fuel-cell automobile models over the next five years. I don't see hydrogen as a big factor in less than a dozen years. The people who wage war against nuclear power, that generation is aging and dying off. A new generation more favorable to nuclear energy will emerge.
You're going to have technology that provides "total body confirmation" -- shapes, colors, size, style preferences -- and all of this will be available to vendors. You will see a picture of yourself on the screen in the outfit, and can have the picture rotate so that you can see how the back looks. Say you're dealing with Nordstrom, and you want a warm-weather suit: 'No. 12, that's great, do you have that in yellow?'

Q. What technologies give you the most confidence?

A. The overall introduction of more information technology, in the form of sensors, "actuators" and detectors. For example, by the end of the decade we will have automobiles that are totally robotic. You'll say: "Car, it's getting close to 3 -- go pick up the kids. Then go pick up Harriet and go to Safeway."
Also, we're moving into an area of total body improvement. We'll have sweaters that tell you you're hunched over and won't stop until you stand up straight. If you're a diabetic, you'll have something buried in your belly or leg or other fat place that tells you: "Hey, Carol, you overdid it this time. Better take some more insulin." You'll be able to change your voice, your attitude, your interpersonal relations. No aspect will elude you.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Emerging Markets Test the Faithful

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
AS a pioneer of emerging-markets investment, Mark Mobius attained guru status among investors who had an appetite for risk and a taste for exotica. 
 In the 1980's, when holding stock in anything but I.B.M. or AT&T was considered a walk on the wild side for many investors, Mr. Mobius, president of Templeton Emerging Markets Funds, led shareholders into places like Mexico, Turkey and Korea. Later, when capitalism was establishing beachheads in Russia and Vietnam, he was one of the point men. 
 Those who signed up for his global journey were well rewarded, at first. His funds typically produced double-digit percentage returns -- until the middle of the 1990's. Then they began to sink, a result of seemingly endless emerging-markets problems including the Thai currency devaluation in 1997, the Russian debt default the next year and, most recently, the economic crisis in Argentina. 
The Templeton Developing Markets fund, for example, has had a spotty record. It rose an average of 12.26 percent a year from its inception in October 1991 through the end of 1994, according to Morningstar Inc., compared with a gain of 8.19 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Since then, the fund has lost 1.72 percent annually, on average, while the S.& P. has risen 15.98 percent, a difference of 17.7 percentage points.
There have been periods of respite for the markets, like 1999, yet even then the funds performed poorly because they did not invest in technology stocks. Those shares were the strongest performers in emerging markets just as they were elsewhere. 
The source of the funds' strength in the early 1990's proved to be their Achilles' heel later: Mr. Mobius's penchant for value.
As the decade was ending, buying stocks that were cheap relative to the worth of their earnings or assets was just as ineffective in emerging markets as it was in the United States. So after suffering a decline in absolute performance during the 1997-98 crisis, Templeton was hurt by a decline in relative performance during the subsequent recovery.
"We consistently avoided the expensive, exciting areas, to our chagrin," Mr. Mobius said in a telephone interview from Australia. "That hurt our performance for a while. The big emerging markets are dominated by tech issues, and they were affected by the run-up in Nasdaq."
Illustrating the global contagion from the bubble, he noted that for a brief period, the stock with the biggest market valuation in Brazil was "some crazy thing called Globo Cabo," a money-losing dot-com and cable television entity spun off by Organizacoes Globo, a media company. As with so many Northern Hemisphere counterparts, Globo Cabo's stock plummeted, declining 62 percent for the year. 
Despite the setbacks for emerging markets and for his funds, Mr. Mobius is cautiously predicting a new growth phase.
"I sense a reawakening," he said. "Investors have lost money in the U.S., and they have begun to realize they have to diversify. Also, private equity has not done well, and some investors are taking knocks in hedge funds. Korea and Taiwan did a tremendous reappearance act. That has aroused some interest."
Mr. Mobius says other emerging-markets countries will be in the vanguard of the revival he is counting on this year. South Africa, where stocks are "so cheap, it's quite unbelievable," is a favorite.
So are Poland, Russia, China and Austria. Austria is not an emerging market, but its status as a gateway to Eastern Europe, one of his preferred regions, allows him to count it as one.
DEMONSTRATING a nature that allows him to see silver linings in the darkest clouds, he added: "Look at Argentina. It's a big disaster, but there are opportunities there. All of Argentina is not going to sink into the sea. We've nibbled at some stocks in Argentina and some have moved up nicely."
Among the stocks he regards highly are four in South Africa, all of which are also listed on United States markets: Sasol Ltd., a chemical concern; Sappi Ltd., a paper producer; Sa Breweries; and Anglo American Gold, a large mining company.
Others in his portfolios include Pliva, a Croatian drug maker; Beijing Batang, a Chinese power company; and Quilmes, an Argentine brewer. Two favorites in Austria are Erstebank and the oil company OMV.
Mr. Mobius likes oil companies throughout the developing world, including Perez Companc in Argentina, PKN in Poland and PetroChina.
In addition to the South African companies, Quilmes, OMV, Perez and PetroChina have United States listings.

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS: NEW YORK BY THE NUMBERS; 
Where the Men Aren't

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
THE resident of Apartment 4N at 790 Concourse Village West may be a man or a woman. But the odds are she's a woman, because Concourse Village, the seventh most female neighborhood in the city, has 1.45 women for every man. And the odds prove right: The resident's name is Paulette Gay-Mack, and she has lived there for 15 years. 
 Figures from the 2000 census for nearly 300 neighborhoods show that the most heavily female areas, for people age 18 to 64, are economically diverse, vary in size and are scattered throughout the city. But there is one markedly common feature: They are dominated by large housing complexes with formal application processes and long waiting lists. 
 Seven of the 10 most heavily female neighborhoods contain large low-income public housing projects, like Edenwald in the Bronx. With 1.6 women for every man -- compared with a citywide average of 1.1 -- Edenwald is the city's most female neighborhood. The other public-housing neighborhoods are Brownsville (1.53), Red Hook (1.46) and New Lots (1.42) in Brooklyn, in Claremont Village (1.46) and Soundview (1.42) in the Bronx, and Arverne and Edgemere (1.42) in the Rockaways.
But 2 of the top 10 areas -- Starrett City in Brooklyn (1.51) and Concourse Village (1.45) -- are middle- or mixed-income areas with subsidized high-rises, low turnover, private security and, residents say, a real sense of community. 
Gramercy Park, an upscale area of just 3,000 people that ranked second in the city with 1.57 women to each man, fits neither mold. Its rank is due mostly to the Salvation Army's Evangeline Residence, a home for about 300 young professional women that has low rents, a friendly atmosphere and a long waiting list, much like Concourse Village and Starrett City.
Women end up in these neighborhoods for many reasons. In the mid-80's, pregnant with her son Shakir, Ms. Gay-Mack moved from Greenwich Village to the Concourse Village co-op of her fiance. "We decided we were going to get married, and Eighth Street was not conducive to raising a child," said Ms. Gay-Mack, noting that she had lived near the theater playing "The Rocky Horror Picture Show."
Concourse Village, she said, provided community like the kind she had grown up with in Virginia. When Shakir was born, she had already found a baby sitter, a trusted older neighbor that the family still calls Nana.
"Once I get into the complex, once I walk up that ramp, I feel safe," said Ms. Gay-Mack, who remained there after her marriage ended. In the relatively high-crime neighborhood, security guards watch the outdoor areas and watch building entrances.
Starrett City is a subsidized rental community, not a co-op, but it has a family-oriented feel like Concourse Village. 
Rosie Battle, who arranges meetings at New York Life, has lived in Starrett with her sister for 11 years and has noticed there are few men on the express bus she takes into Manhattan every morning. Like others, she theorized that the stable setting, many families, 24-hour security and reliable maintenance attract single women.
"In the middle of the night they'll come if you have a stopped-up sink," Ms. Battle said. "You don't need a man around if you have somebody to fix your sink."
THE preponderance of women in areas with low-income projects did not surprise Elijah Anderson, a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania. "Many of these places are just full of women," he said.
Mr. Anderson argued that some inner-city men shy away from relationships because of social pressure and fear of failing as providers: "These men are much more marginal to such situations," he said. "They do go off to the military. They do go off to prison. They do go off to be free to consort with other women."
Shanekwa, a single mother in Edenwald, calls them "1-2-3 men" meaning they come and go quickly. She added that some men also live in the project surreptitiously, so their families can avoid rent increases. 
Kenneth Mercer, the executive director of the Edenwald Gun Hill Neighborhood Center, agreed. "I know for sure that there are men not on the leases," he said. 
But these shadow men are unlikely to account for all the imbalance in neighborhoods with many women. What then makes Edenwald the city's most female area?
The answer is not entirely clear, but Mr. Mercer suspected that the lack of local jobs encouraged men to move toward the city. Others join the military.
"It's not an embracing environment for a young man who wants to succeed in life," Mr. Mercer said. Women face similar pressures, he said, but those who are raising children have more incentive to stay.
The scarcity of recent immigrants in public or subsidized housing may also raise the relative numbers of women in those places. Immigrant families may not know the system well enough or may not have been in the city long enough to have risen through a waiting list for such housing. If they had, they might change the imbalance between the sexes, because they often maintain an integral family structure. In heavily immigrant neighborhoods like Washington Heights and Flushing the male-female ratio is approximately one to one.
On the borough level, immigrants' choice of neighborhood can also affect male-female numbers, according to Joe Salvo of the Department of City Planning. The Bronx has a large female population, for instance. One reason is that male-heavy immigrant groups like Bangladeshis tend to wind up in Queens, while Dominicans and West Indians, who send a more balanced mix of the sexes to this country, gravitate to the Bronx. 
Jail also plays a role in the sex ratio in the Bronx, according to numbers, adjusted for population, from the city's Correction Department. About three times as many inmates in city jails list their residence as the Bronx as list Queens and about twice as many as list Brooklyn. 
All told, the Bronx is the state's most female county. And if you drop "group quarters," a large part of which are jails, the Bronx, home of Rikers Island, becomes the seventh most female county in the United States, with more than five women for every four men. 
Of course, statistics generalize. In a Red Hook laundromat last week, a bank employee named Augie said he was raising three children alone in private housing. "You don't know how many are out there like me," he said. "The guy who lives above me, he's got a daughter and lives alone, too."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
The Last Act Didn't Save the Play

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund investors closed out a sour year with a soupcon of sweetness.
 Reflecting the upturn in major market indexes from October through December, equity mutual funds had their best quarterly gain in two years. But the rebound, which encompassed all but two fund groups, only narrowed big losses for a year that many investors would rather forget. 
 After the steep declines prompted by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the average diversified stock fund gained 13.7 percent in the fourth quarter, according to Morningstar Inc. Still, much damage had already been done. 
For the year, more than 8 of every 10 stock mutual funds lost money, the worst annual performance in nearly 30 years. Two sectors that fared well were gold funds and, more significantly, small-cap stock funds. 
"It was a year in which I hope investors were diversified," said Robin Thurston, director of research at Lipper Inc., the fund research company.
With stock prices crumbling for most of the year, investors indeed chose to put their money into different asset classes. 
Based on figures from AMG Data Services, the flows represent a string of superlatives: 
* Net inflows into equity mutual funds were the smallest on record.
* Money market funds and taxable bond funds saw their biggest-ever annual increases.
* Tax-exempt municipal bond funds had the highest net inflows since 1993.
"The reallocation to bonds that began in August of 2000 has continued," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data.
It was a good quarter -- and a great year -- to be invested in taxable bond funds.
In fact, during the last 18 months, bond prices have staged their biggest rally since the Depression. They inched higher in the fourth quarter, powered by additional reductions in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve and continued weakness in the economy.
According to Morningstar, taxable bond funds rose 1.3 percent in the quarter, for their ninth consecutive quarterly advance.
With yields on Treasury notes and bonds at very low levels, Mr. Adler said, investors are now piling money into corporate and high-yield bond funds, which carry much higher interest rates but also much more risk.
For the year, more than $84 billion flowed into taxable bond funds, according to AMG, the biggest increase ever. By contrast, equity funds attracted net inflows of $35.5 billion in 2001, down sharply from the $169 billion committed in 2000.
The stock market's losses over the last two years have also prompted risk-averse investors to stampede into another fund category: money markets.
More than $412 billion moved into money market funds last year, Mr. Adler said. By year-end, $2.3 trillion was on deposit in these accounts, according to AMG, compared with $1.85 trillion at the end of 2000.
"A huge amount of money went to the sidelines," Mr. Adler said. "A lot of that would never have gone into the bond or equity markets, but some would have."
In fact, even professionals who invest money for a living seemed reluctant to commit capital to the stock market as the fourth quarter began. Reeling from the previous three months, the worst period since the fourth quarter of 1987, many apparently did not recognize the post-attack sell-off as a buying opportunity.
"One of the interesting things is that fund managers were a little defensive at the beginning of the quarter," said Thomas McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities.
"They seemed to underperform the bounce off the bottom," he added. "But by mid-December, they were outperforming."
Mutual fund investors were not much different. Mr. Adler said November was the biggest month of the quarter for equity fund inflows, at $10.6 billion.
At one big fund company, the Vanguard Group, net inflows into stock funds for the quarter were about $5 billion, said Brian Mattes, a spokesman. An additional $3.8 billion went into its bond funds, and $2.2 billion into its money market accounts, he said.
The stock-fund inflows at Vanguard were up sharply from $1 billion in the third quarter. 
WILLIAM H. MILLER III, who manages the $12 billion Legg Mason Value Trust, was one professional who did not dawdle.
During the last week of the third quarter, Mr. Miller trimmed positions in companies then selling at very depressed levels and sank all of the fund's available cash reserves into the market.
"We believe the market bottomed in the third quarter," he said. Value Trust rose 9 percent in the last three months of the year, and outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the year for the 11th consecutive time.
Edward B. Jamieson, chief investment officer for domestic equities at Franklin Advisers, said his group invested more than $1 billion between the reopening of the markets after the Sept. 11 attacks and mid-October.
"To see the Nasdaq below 1,500 was an opportunity we didn't know we would see again," he said.
The big bounce in the Nasdaq helped to turn a truly disastrous year for technology funds into one that was merely miserable.
Technology funds surged 37 percent in the fourth quarter, according to Morningstar. But that still left technology funds down 38 percent for the year.
And many analysts are wondering whether the fourth-quarter technology gains are sustainable, given the currently shaky earnings prospects for many companies in the sector.
"There is a lot of anticipation in this rally," said Kevin Landis, portfolio manager of Firsthand Funds in San Jose, Calif.
"If the economic turnaround turns out to be vapor, then the rally will make a U-turn. I had a heck of a rally in January and again in the mid-April to early May period," he said of his experience in 2001. "They were both head fakes."
For the quarter, Firsthand's six technology funds rose an average of 43.2 percent. But for the year they were down 45 percent, on average. 
It was a good quarter and a good year for small stocks and small-cap stock mutual funds. Of the major market indexes, the Russell 2000, the small-cap barometer, was the only one that ended the year higher. But the gain is somewhat misleading, because the group was a laggard for years.
Still, small-cap value funds were the second-best performing group last year, rising 16.6 percent, according to Lipper. The best performers were gold funds, up more than 19 percent, though they are not as widely held and do not encompass as large a universe of companies. 
The best performer among small-cap value funds was the Fidelity Low Priced Stock fund, up nearly 27 percent for the year.
"There are some pockets that did well, but the reality is that the average investor has most of his or her money in large-cap stock funds, and most of those fell 10 percent to 15 percent," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar.
The collapse of Enron and a drop in energy prices during the quarter were bad news for utility funds. The Lipper utility fund index fell about 1 percent in the quarter and was down more than 20 percent for the year. Only one other fund group was down for the quarter: funds invested exclusively in Japanese stocks. They fell 1.9 percent for the quarter.
Many money managers and analysts were cautiously optimistic about the new year.
"Underlying demand and economic trends are still valid" in support of technology stocks, said Mr. Landis at Firsthand, "but we needed to go through this," he said of the sell-off.
"A greater percentage of my companies are giving us good news than they were last January or last spring," he said. "If we get more waves of bad news, then we could get another haircut. But I would be surprised if we go below the September lows."
MR. MILLER at Legg Mason said he expected 2002 to be a "pretty solid year, but one that is unlikely to be called a gangbuster year."
"It is not likely to be one like what happened following the big market bottom in 1982 or 1990, because overall valuations are a lot higher," he said. "But we do believe corporate profits are likely to expand nicely."
Mr. McManus at Banc of America was more guarded.
The first quarter, traditionally a time when fund inflows are strong, will be a disappointment, he said.
"We are forecasting the worst first quarter in quite some time" for fund flows, he said.
He said that last year was "the second year where equities did not perform as well as expected, and the amount of additional money people have to invest will be down."
Because he regards many stocks as richly priced, he said that "the market doesn't owe us as much in 2002 as some people expect."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Late-Inning Heroics In a Wild, Wild Year

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
STOCK mutual funds rebounded smartly in the fourth quarter from their post-Sept. 11 dive, with domestic diversified equity funds gaining 13.7 percent, on average, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rising 10.3 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. Despite their strong finish, however, most stock funds lost money in 2001. 
Managers of some of the best-performing diversified stock funds talked about the end of a difficult year and about their expectations for the market.

Opposite Extremes
The top performers for the quarter, the $390 million Van Wagoner Emerging Growth fund, with a return of 87.8 percent and the $180 million Van Wagoner Post-Venture fund, up 81.2 percent, were also among the worst 10 funds for the year. Despite their exceptional close, both funds lost about 60 percent of their value in 2001.
"Our stocks were killed post-Sept. 11, and the fourth-quarter story is a rebound of what we think are leadership companies," said Garrett R. Van Wagoner, the firm's founder and the funds' manager. "But our year-to-date numbers don't reflect that. We're not popping Champagne corks here."
For both funds, Mr. Van Wagoner, 46, seeks rapidly growing companies in new and emerging industries, although those in Post-Venture must have received venture capital financing during the last five years.
The quarter's performance of Emerging Growth was driven by fourth-quarter gains in three stocks that fell more than 40 percent for the year. Mr. Van Wagoner added all three in the market sell-off after Sept. 11 and said he planned to hold onto them because he thought they were leaders in attractive niches.
The first is Embarcadero Technologies, a San Francisco company that provides database management software. The share price, which started 2001 in the low $40's, fell below $7 in October but closed on Dec. 31 at $24.20, down 46. percent for the year. "If you push a beach ball underwater far enough, it eventually bounces back," he said. 
The second stock was Stellent Inc., a maker of Web content-management software in Eden Prairie, Minn. Its price more than doubled for the quarter but was down 42 percent for the year. Stellent's programs "let you manage everything from documents to PDF files to e-mail, and they let you present all the content in a nice, easy-to-read format," Mr. Van Wagoner said, referring to Adobe's widely used Acrobat Portable Document Format. 
A third winner for the period was Interwoven Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., another content management company. It rose 152 percent in the quarter but was down 70 percent for the year.
"The industry niche is in its infancy and has maintained its growth rate better than industries like telecommunications or semiconductors," Mr. Van Wagoner said.
Looking ahead, he expects technology companies to improve this year, but very slowly. "It will be a pretty subdued year," he said.

A Bet on the Internet
Technology companies also drove the performance of the $103 million Baron iOpportunity fund, which returned 43.3 percent in the quarter, ranking fifth among diversified funds and ninth over all. It fell 3.6 percent for the year. "Our goal is to buy businesses where the predominant driver of value and profitability is the addition of the Internet and technology to the company's business," said Mitchell J. Rubin, the fund manager.
Mr. Rubin, 35, made money on Overture Services, an Internet advertising company in Pasadena, Calif. Its price almost tripled in the fourth quarter. "It's a low-cost, high-profit-margin business, and management has cut beneficial deals for themselves and their affiliated partners like AOL and Yahoo," Mr. Rubin said.
Also up sharply in the fourth quarter was Hotel Reservations Network of Dallas, the operator of an Internet travel agency specializing in the hotel industry. Its price doubled. . "Even though it's been a difficult year for the hotel industry," Mr. Rubin said, "the company benefited from the shift in people booking hotels over the telephone or through bricks-and-mortar travel agents to using the Internet."
Accenture, formally Andersen Consulting, was another gainer, up 111 percent for the quarter. Mr. Rubin said, "Every company has to understand and evaluate its business based on changes in technology," a field in which Accenture is a leading consultant. 
While he would not forecast trends, he said he thought that "our companies have done extremely well in very difficult economic times, and they will have an easier economic backdrop in the next 12 at 24 months that will translate into expanded profitability."

Anticipating a Recovery
By contrast, the $245 million CGM Focus fund owns no technology stocks, said its manager, G. Kenneth Heebner. It rose 38.5 percent in the quarter, finishing No. 13 among diversified stock funds and 18th over all. It rose 47.7 percent for the year.
Mr. Heebner, 61, says he has invested in companies poised to profit from what he thinks will be a strong economic recovery in 2002, led by consumer spending. Home builders account for 26 percent of its assets, followed by makers and sellers of recreational vehicles, 17 percent; airlines, 12 percent, and trucking companies, 10 percent.
One fourth-quarter winner was Winnebago Industries, the maker of recreational vehicles, which rose 72 percent. "Expectations were low following Sept. 11 and business was weak in September and into October," Mr. Heebner said. "But the business outlook has improved a lot during the quarter."
He also made money on Beazer Homes USA, based in Atlanta, up 51 percent for the quarter. Beazer, which designs, builds and sells single-family homes, serves the low-price market, he said, a niche that is more sensitive to interest rates than to overall economic activity.
 Frontier Airlines, which has its hub in Denver, more than doubled in price in the quarter. "It's one of the few airlines that has better prospects for 2002 than it did pre-Sept. 11," Mr. Heebner said, "because their big competitor, United, cut capacity more than 25 percent in the Denver market." Frontier is low-cost and profitable, he added.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Investing on Autopilot? There's a World of Choices

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
SINCE the Vanguard Group created the first mutual fund tracking the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index more than 25 years ago, the logic behind the idea has been so compelling that investments in index funds have grown to over $300 billion.
 Most of that money is held in funds tracking American markets, but for cost-conscious and globally minded investors, many index funds focus on foreign markets. Some specialize in individual countries, while others track regional, worldwide and broad-based emerging-markets indexes. 
 Vanguard shares dominance of the market in foreign index funds with State Street Global Advisors, a unit of the State Street Corporation in Boston, and Barclays Global Investors in San Francisco, a unit of Barclays P.L.C. The aim of these funds is the same as that of their domestic counterparts: to offer low-cost competition to actively managed funds. 
The pros and cons of index funds that invest abroad are similar to those of domestic index funds. But active managers of foreign funds contend that inefficiencies, like poor research in many foreign markets, give their funds advantages.
Indexers, meanwhile, rely on mathematics to support their cause. "In aggregate, all investment holdings equal the market," said George U. Sauter, managing director of Vanguard's quantitative equity group, the division that runs index funds. "Investors can only get the market rate of return, only less because they incur costs trying to get the market rate of return."
All else being equal, their argument goes, investors who pay the lowest price will receive the highest returns in the long run. And Mr. Sauter said the costs of operating in foreign stock markets were greater than in the United States.
For one thing, it costs money to have analysts and fund managers stationed in exotic locales. And then there can be high costs for routine services like settlement of trades, safekeeping of shares and accounting and record-keeping in a mix of markets that may have greatly different regulations. The average actively managed foreign equity fund costs 1.8 percent a year to run, plus transaction costs, versus 1.4 percent, excluding transaction costs, for domestic equity funds, according to Morningstar Inc.
Vanguard's three foreign index funds have expense ratios ranging from 0.29 percent to 0.57 percent. The funds track indexes of European, Pacific and emerging markets as compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International, a leader in the arcane and precise science of index construction.
Vanguard offers two other portfolios. The Vanguard Developed Markets Index fund combines shares in its Europe and Pacific funds in appropriate measures to replicate the performance of the MSCI Europe, Australasia and Far East, or EAFE, index. The Vanguard Total International fund mixes shares in all three funds to replicate the MSCI EAFE Plus Emerging Markets Index. This index represents the whole world, except the United States and some markets that limit participation by foreigners or else are just too small.
BARCLAYS has 33 funds, called iShares, focusing on foreign and global indexes, including many single-country funds and some that tracking global industry indexes. 
Unlike conventional mutual funds, like Vanguard's, iShares are exchange-traded funds; they trade in the same way as stocks and have expense ratios ranging from 0.25 percent to 0.89 percent. One drawback of iShares and other exchange-traded funds is they incur brokerage commissions. An advantage is that they can be bought and sold throughout the trading day, while mutual funds are transacted only at the close.
State Street offers exchange-traded funds, too, although just a few, as well as mutual funds.
Active managers say that while index funds might indeed be better if all else were equal, when it comes to investing in foreign markets, all else is seldom equal.
Hugh Young, managing director in Singapore for Aberdeen Asset Management Asia, said stocks in foreign markets, especially in his region, were not as well researched as those in the United States. That, he said, gives active managers a better chance of beating the indexes.
Much research in Asia consists of "flattering brokerage reports of large stocks in need of financing," Mr. Young said. 
"I would argue there is lots of scope for outperforming, which over time we have done," he added.
The way to do that, he said, is to avoid some very large stocks that dominate indexes in some countries, especially in emerging markets. These are often the shares of poorly run, government-controlled telephone and energy companies -- or government-supported conglomerates, as in Korea.
Stephen Watson, chief investment officer at Gartmore Global Partners in Conshohocken, Pa., agreed that "the less things are researched, the more there is the chance of finding out an angle" that allows managers to beat the market. An angle that has worked over the last decade, he said, is for Japan managers to avoid banks and for broadly focused international managers to avoid Japan.
Mr. Watson invoked some math of his own to support active management. Passively run index funds must have larger investments in the priciest stocks and markets. In the late 1980's, he said, before its stock market bubble burst, Japan accounted for 65 percent of the EAFE index; lately, it has been barely more than 20 percent.
"If you had been passively exposed to EAFE, you would have seen massive damage to the value of your fund" in the 1990's from its heavy ownership of Japanese stocks, he said. Nevertheless, he acknowledged that "it's not an easy thing to do, to beat indexes consistently, because of fees and costs."
But a look at the numbers suggests that it is also not easy to beat active management. Over the last 1, 3, 5 and 10 years, only European index funds have consistently outperformed the average actively managed fund focusing on their regions. Funds tracking other regional and international indexes have tended to lag behind equivalent actively managed funds.
Gus Fleites, director of exchange-traded funds at State Street, said the strong performance of many actively managed funds resulted from their decision to persistently shun Japan.
"Any fund that made a less-than- benchmark-weighted investment in Japan would have outperformed," he said.
Indexers dismiss that argument, however, saying active funds were just as underweight in Japan on the way up as on the way down. "They have underperformed over the combined 20-year time frame," Mr. Sauter said. "They didn't all of a sudden become smart. They were on the right side of it in the 1990's and the wrong side in the 1980's."
STEVEN SCHOENFELD, who leads international equities for Barclays, was just as skeptical, saying, "Nothing shows active managers can pick these turns" in markets. He also rejected the argument that market inefficiencies offer them an edge in certain countries. "The same fundamental arithmetic of active management applies whether it's U.S. large companies or Asian emerging markets," he said.
All the same, Mr. Schoenfeld was prepared to be magnanimous. He suggested investing 10 to 25 percent of an equity portfolio internationally, with half of that amount indexed and the rest actively managed.
"We think a low-cost, broad-based, indexed core should be the base for any investment portfolio," he said, "whether domestic only or developed international markets or even emerging markets."
