HEADLINE: For Clothing Makers, It's Cutor Be Cut 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
THE dawn of 2002 brought no happy new year to clothing makers. For them, the squeeze is on.
 The recession, economic reverberations from Sept. 11 and unseasonably warm weather leading up to Christmas combined to clobber apparel sales last year. December was particularly gruesome. With sweaters and winter coats piling up at the pinnacle of the shopping season, desperate retailers dropped prices by as much as 70 percent. Someone must pay the price of that discounting, though, and the time of reckoning is at hand. 
 The pain of sharp markdowns will be felt all the way down the retail food chain, though the brunt will be borne not by the stores, but by the apparel manufacturers and wholesalers that supply them with everything from designer denim to cashmere overcoats. 
The ranks of these businesses are expected to shrink sharply in the coming months, according to bankers, other creditors and many manufacturers themselves. Donna, Tommy, Ralph and Calvin are all expected to suffer some, but the real trouble will be felt by the thousands of midsize and small companies, those with sales of less than $100 million -- companies like Bisou Bisou, the maker of a trendy women's line. Many, like Bisou Bisou, which is on the verge of filing for bankruptcy for its retail operations, could seek court protection, following in the recent footsteps of many American textile manufacturers, including Burlington Industries and Malden Mills Industries.
"The domestic fabric suppliers are all already almost out of business," said Adam D. Winters, a senior vice president at the Merchant Factors Corporation, one of the industry's largest suppliers of credit, "and now the apparel manufacturers must consolidate or go out of business."
Trouble among apparel makers, of course, is hardly headline news. Low-cost competition from overseas has been driving apparel manufacturing offshore, and retailers have been extracting steep concessions from their suppliers for years -- especially since the late 1980's, when bankruptcies and consolidations among retailers left fewer, but more powerful chains to buy the goods. For about a decade, department stores in particular have been using this strength to elicit concessions like "markdown money" -- the payments that retailers demand from manufacturers, after the season, to make up for whatever profits they lost by putting goods on sale.
But 2001 was different. Apparel sales were soft all year; so were prices. As the economy weakened, credit tightened, leaving many manufacturers and wholesalers in a vise.
"There is very little margin for error in this environment," said Paul Charron, the chairman and chief executive of Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the few companies that saw third-quarter revenue and profits improve from last year. "Large, sophisticated retailers are looking to do business with large, sophisticated suppliers. Management that has not executed with precision is in big trouble."
THE exact damage to the sector will not be known for a few weeks -- it is in January that retailers sit down with suppliers and demand cash back for those goods sold at discount prices or delivered late or in imperfect condition. The omens, however, began to emerge in late October and November, when the largest apparel makers reported discouraging third-quarter results and hinted that there was far more more bad news to come.
The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler jeans and Vanity Fair lingerie, is laying off 13,000 employees, or 18 percent of its work force. Kellwood, the maker of Sag Harbor, Sierra Designs and Kathie Lee Gifford's line for Wal-Mart, said its net earnings for the quarter would decline nearly 50 percent, compared with the period a year earlier, partly because its margins were being squeezed at retail.
For the quarter ended in September, Donna Karan International, owned by LVMH Moet-Hennesy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury conglomerate, had a net loss of $53.7 million, down from a profit of $14 million in the quarter a year earlier. And in October, the Jones Apparel Group, parent of Jones New York, whose blazers and pants are popular with working women, substantially cut earnings expectations for 2002, to $2.60 a share from $3.29, in part because of an expected "heavily promotional environment" at retail.
Those numbers, however, do not tell the full story. The largest apparel makers are actually in the best shape. The middle tier -- companies with $5 million to $100 million in annual sales -- is feeling more pain. One such company, BCBG Max Azria, based in Los Angeles, is short on cash and has been slow to pay its own suppliers; the company is now instituting 10 to 15 percent across-the-board cuts in expenses. Mad Engine, a San Diego company that sells T-shirts embellished with designs and sequins to department stores and to larger manufacturers like Levi and Polo Ralph Lauren, has laid off 50 percent of its headquarters staff. And Michael Kors, a designer whose company is partly owned by LVMH, was on the verge of a multistore rollout of his mid-priced line with Bloomingdale's when the deal collapsed, he said, after he refused to guarantee profit margins. Bloomingdale's, a unit of Federated Department Stores, denies that it asked Mr. Kors to guarantee margins.
BECAUSE most domestic apparel makers are middle-tier private businesses, often family affairs, they lack the resources and the muscle to fight back when retailers knock them about.
Princess Knitwear, for example, a small company based in the Bronx that still has manufacturing operations in New York City, has survived by producing only high-end goods to order. In the fall, it took on a sizable order for plus-size separates from an upscale department store chain that George Wolf, Princess's owner, declined to name. For four years, it had been a good client, paying in full and on time, according to Mr. Wolf. But, he said, he received a call two weeks before the order was due to be delivered in October from the store's buyer, saying that if he did not cut the price by 33 percent, the store would cancel the order. 
Mr. Wolf said he protested that such a cut would wipe out its profit margin. The buyer apologized, Mr. Wolf recalled, but insisted that extraordinary times called for extraordinary measures.
With no choice but to discount or to let the made-to-order knitwear sit in his warehouse, Mr. Wolf swallowed the costs. "We should all be in this together," he fumes now. "Instead, department stores want to maintain their profit margin and have us shoulder the whole sacrifice."
Such hardball tactics, while not new, have been spreading. Some manufacturers report that Kmart, the giant discount chain, has been dodging payments lately. At Thanksgiving, Kmart owed Playtex, a division of Sara Lee, $90 million on already-shipped inventory, some $50 million of which was long overdue, according to executives close to the situation. When Sara Lee stopping shipping Playtex products, the executives said, Kmart paid $15 million, but as of three weeks ago was still in arrears for the rest.
Kmart denies that it is having trouble with Sara Lee. "Today we have a normal account balance," said Jack Ferry, a company spokesman, "and we made regular payments during the time in question."
A spokeswoman for Sara Lee declined to comment.
Vendors also complain that J. C. Penney, which in late 2000 hired Allen Questrom, formerly of Barneys New York and Federated, as chief executive, has been aggressively stepping up demands for cash support in areas like advertising and markdown money. "It is the new hierarchy over there," said Alby Amato, the chief executive of Mad Engine. "They want guaranteed margins on everything."
A spokeswoman for Penney said: "We are more competitive in ways we weren't before. Our vendors know it is a war out there."
THE trend even affects Wal-Mart Stores, where sales for stores open at least a year rose by an estimated 6 percent this past holiday season. The chain, which has a reputation for negotiating thin margins up front but then sticking with them, has been asking for cash back after this season of sales, according to many factors and vendors who asked not to be identified.
Jessica Moser, a company spokeswoman, said, "We work to make our business agreements mutually beneficial for both us and our suppliers."
Hal J. Upbin, the chief executive of Kellwood, confirmed the epidemic: "My client list is the top 20 vendors in the country," he said, "and I can't think of one who is not doing it at some level."
As retailers become more demanding, creditors -- usually factoring companies, the financial middlemen that finance manufacturers and collect payment directly from retailers -- have become less forgiving, too. "The factors are becoming extremely tight," said Marc Bohbot, the chief executive of Bisou Bisou, which sells $40 million of apparel a year to department stores. "They are looking over the shoulder of every management, and they want 10 times the guarantees of last year to loan money. They investigate any asset outside the corporation in order to get liens on buildings, homes and even cars to guarantee the loans." (Creditors look at personal assets for family-owned companies.) 
MACROECONOMIC conditions, meanwhile, are worsening. Prices paid to producers of apparel have been spiraling downward since 1999; since November alone, the index of those prices has declined almost 1 percent, according to the Labor Department. "The success of discount retailers like Wal-Mart, Kohl's and Target has helped drive prices down," said Carl Steidtmann, chief economist at Deloitte Research. "It means if you are a midlevel manufacturer, life is not very fun. Because you can't take advantage of economies of scale, you must compete on something other than price, and in today's market that is a difficult challenge."
Midlevel manufacturers who are feeling such pressure, of course, have the option of trying to sell out to larger companies, and many are doing just that. But will they find buyers? "A lot more companies are willing to be acquired," said Mr. Upbin, of Kellwood. "We are seeing more deals than we have ever seen before, but how many deals can you do?"
In 1999, the latest year for which figures were available, there were almost 17,000 apparel manufacturers and wholesalers in the United States, according to the American Apparel and Footwear Association.
Daniel A. Greene, a senior vice president of FleetBoston Financial, one of the most active banks in the retail industry, said he anticipated "more consolidation in the coming year, but there are many more sellers than buyers."
The recession is separating big companies from small companies in obvious ways -- like which have more cash -- and also in less obvious ways, as in which are more technologically current. Usually, only big manufacturers can afford the most advanced computer systems that help identify sales trends early and predict buying patterns, helping to control inventory.
"We have invested heavily in technology," said Mackey J. McDonald, the chairman and chief executive of VF. "We think it is critical to servicing the retailer and in forecasting trends and needs."
Plenty of companies will survive. Yet for everyone but the large and powerful and the small-but-hot fashion houses, the game is now much less fun. "Anything with production in the United States is a dying breed," lamented Mr. Amato of Mad Engine. "I look at what is happening and I say, 'I've got to get out of the manufacturing end of it.' "

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Satisfying 2 Cravings: Yield and Safety

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS

 BODY:
AS anyone in a money market fund knows, even security has its risks.
 The interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve Board last year have sliced into returns of money market funds, certificates of deposit and savings accounts. Taxable money market funds paid just 1.59 percent, on average, last week, according to iMoneyNet, a money-market fund tracker, while a three-month C.D. provided an average yield of 1.73 percent, according to Bankrate.com, a financial site. 
 But there are other choices. Stable value funds may offer what investors crave these days: yield and safety, not to mention higher returns. 
"Most of us have clients who are cautious or conservative or older, and we want to keep money in cash -- in a no-risk investment," said Malcolm H. Gissen, who runs his own investment firm in San Francisco. "This is a very attractive alternative."
At their best, stable value funds try to marry higher yields with price stability. The funds typically hold a diversified fixed-income portfolio of bonds with three- to five-year maturities. They add insurance guarantees, known as wrappers, to try to fix the funds' share price, or net asset value, at $10, which preserves both capital and accumulated income.
While the funds' yields still reflect changes in interest rates, the insurance guarantees aim to even out the bonds' price fluctuations. Investors benefit because the value of the funds should not decline even when interest rates rise and bond prices fall. But the same insurance mechanism that stabilizes prices from a decline makes investors miss bond price rallies.
"It's not for everybody because it is so sophisticated," said Norman M. Boone, a financial planner at Boone Financial Advisors in San Francisco. "But this is providing a pretty attractive combination of higher yields, stability and liquidity."
Stable value mutual funds fall into a broader category called stable value investments, which also include insurance products like guaranteed investment contracts. Together, these instruments had $233 billion in assets at the end of 2000, the most recent data available, with the bulk held in defined-contribution accounts like 401(k)'s.
Stable value mutual funds were first sold outside of retirement plans in 1998; as of Nov. 30 last year, their assets amounted to $1.2 billion, according to the Stable Value Investment Association. The funds are offered by a number of firms, including OppenheimerFunds, Morley Capital Management, ICMA Retirement and United Asset Management.
Deutsche Asset Management has the longest track record in this field, and its mutual funds hold the most -- $600 million -- in assets. The Deutsche PreservationPlus fund was introduced in 1997 by Bankers Trust, which Deutsche Bank acquired. The portfolio is available in defined-contribution plans. In 1998, the firm added the Deutsche PreservationPlus Income fund, which is intended for investors opening individual retirement accounts.
The fund has no sales charge but is sold mainly by investment advisers who may charge a fee for managing their clients' portfolios. Investors can also open an account directly at Deutsche with a $2,500 minimum.
THE portfolio of bonds resembles other intermediate-duration bond funds, with maturities averaging about three years. Holdings include a mix of high-quality corporate, government and asset- and mortgage-backed bonds. High-yield, or lower quality, bonds, make up about 7 percent of the portfolio. 
The fund is distinguished from a typical intermediate-duration portfolio by the insurance wrappers. Contracts from insurers or banks including Bank of America; TransAmerica Life, a unit of Aegon Insurance; and Caisse des Depots et Consignations of France try to buffer the bonds' prices from market fluctuation.
Managers try to make sure that the insurers and banks are highly rated, said Eric M. Kirsch, managing director and head of North American fixed income at Deutsche who helps manage the fund. If managers are concerned about an insurer's credit quality, they can choose a different insurer.
Although Mr. Kirsch buys intermediate-term bonds, the insurance guarantees make duration a moot point to some fund analysts.
"These funds, because of the insurance wrappers, are completely insensitive to interest rates," said Eric M. Jacobson, a senior bond fund analyst at Morningstar Inc. 
As a result, an investor wanting to buy or sell shares should be able to do so at any time at a steady rate of $10 each. As with any other security, the value of the bonds shifts with market conditions, but if a shareholder sold after the bonds' prices fell, the insurance wrapper agreement would make up the difference. 
"The yield is not very volatile -- it will change and track interest rates but it does that on a gradual basis," Mr. Kirsch said.
The cost for that peace of mind is missing out on an uptick in bond prices. The investors also bear the expense of the wrappers. Mr. Kirsch estimates that the wrapper agreements cost 0.23 percent of the total 1 percent expense ratio of the PreservationPlus Income fund. The wrapper ensures that investors can cash out at $10 a share when bond prices fall, but under some circumstances, involving extreme fluctuations in interest rates, investors could be charged a 2 percent fee if they redeemed their shares.
The portfolio's returns have held up well, compared with the average taxable intermediate-term bond fund. Over the three years through Dec. 31, PreservationPlus Income gained 6.17 percent, on average, topping the 5.10 percent return of the average taxable intermediate-term bond fund, according to Morningstar.
SUCH returns were attractive to John and Erika Ammirati of Los Altos, Calif., whose investments Mr. Gissen oversees. The couple are conservative in their investments and were drawn to the stability the fund offers, Mr. Ammirati said. About six months ago, they shifted 5 percent of their retirement assets into Deutsche's stable value portfolio. "We are being insulated from the volatility that's taking place," Mr. Ammirati said.
Investors should educate themselves about how such funds differ from more traditional intermediate-term bond funds, Mr. Jacobson advised, since these funds are not federally guaranteed. "It's a fairly new, very complex strategy," he said, "and that's what raises the caution level a little bit."
Sean McKeon, a registered investment adviser at DAL Investment in San Francisco, is not troubled that the insurance is not an absolute guarantee.
"It is not a government-guaranteed bank account, and it still is subject to the creditworthiness of the institutions that issue the wrappers," Mr. McKeon said. "But that being said, anyone who wants this fixed-income portion to remain stable in value, it's worth forgoing some potential higher return and allows you take a little more risk with the other portions of your fixed income."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Education as an Investment. Really.

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
WITH tuition rising faster than inflation, and returns on many investments still in reverse, parents of prospective college students are facing some serious choices. Should they cash in their mutual funds now? Seek loans or grants? Ask a wealthy relative for help in paying? 
 Now a Manhattan company, Iempower, which started two years ago, has developed an alternative method of paying for college. Through its Web site, www.MyRichUncle.com, Iempower is working to match students with a network of well-heeled investors -- sort of like wealthy relatives. The investors provide money to pay for undergraduate or graduate degrees; the students agree to pay a fixed percentage of income for a set period after graduation. 
 But are people willing to invest in authority-questioning, baggy-pants-wearing college students, whom they don't even know? So far they have, said Raza Khan, who founded Iempower with Vishal Garg. The men attended Stuyvesant High School and New York University together.
In the last year, Mr. Khan said, Iempower has received $750,000 from investors, while 1,000 students have applied for aid and 65 have received it.
Mr. Khan says Iempower decides whether to offer assistance, and at what rate, based on students' grade-point averages, standardized test scores, employment experience and career goals. The company analyzes the data using actuarial principles that it calls an evaluation engine. 
The repayment rates vary. For undergraduates, they start at 0.2 percent for each $1,000 of earnings for a period of up to 15 years. Rates for graduate students start at 0.1 percent per $1,000 for up to 10 years. The maximum repayment rate is 0.4 percent per $1,000. All students also pay a one-time service fee to the company of 2.5 percent. It is deducted from the amount borrowed.
The company says it caps the aid amounts so that no one pays more than 15 percent of his or her future earnings. Once the students graduate and are employed, Iempower asks them for monthly income filings and for tax returns.
So are these loans better than conventional student loans available through banks or from the federal government? It is a judgment call for each student, because the actual repayment will not be known until graduates are well into their careers. In theory, students using MyRichUncle could fall victim to their own success -- the more they earn, the more they will have to pay back. For students, the most widely used loan right now is the federal Stafford Loan program; the interest rate is currently 5.39 percent.
Mr. Khan says his business tries to provide both a good return for its investors and a financial aid option to students who cannot afford to pay for college. 
"What's incredibly exciting about this," he said, "is that it is one of the few occasions where social ambitions and business ambitions are pursuing the same goal."
But Mukund Krishnaswami, a managing partner of Revolution Capital, a venture capital fund in Philadelphia and New York, has doubts about the program. 
"For every 10 students, you have two or three who decide they're not going to work, two who become social workers or priests, and you're not going to make any money on them," he said. "But maybe you get one person who becomes Bill Gates."
Mr. Krishnaswami said he considered starting a similar business after graduating three years ago from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, but abandoned the plans because he did not think the return would be good enough.
MR. KHAN would not disclose what investors could expect to earn, except to say that "it's fairly competitive" with other investment options.
Mr. Krishnaswami said the students most prized by Iempower -- those with the greatest earning potential -- may be the ones least likely to apply. "Anyone who intends to make a lot of money," he said, "is probably going to take out a student loan instead."
But Mr. Khan said students did not always have a clear picture of their future earnings. "It's funny how many poets become investment bankers," he said. "If you can spot value, the capital will move there."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Still Alive and Growing Online, Without Fanfare

BYLINE:  By MIGUEL HELFT 

 BODY:
THE court-ordered auction of the assets of Webvan was something of a spectator sport, Silicon Valley style. Dozens of former employees, reporters, television crews and gawkers, many of them unemployed technology workers, gathered in late October at the company's shuttered headquarters near San Francisco for a sell-off of computer and office equipment. 
 It was as much a chance to witness the final chapter in one of the most spectacular failures of the Internet bubble as to gaze at piles of some of the most sophisticated technology gear anywhere. 
 But for Leo Hopper, a manager in the technology department of Global Sports, the e-commerce company, Webvan's auction was serious business. Sitting near the back of a packed room and armed with an inventory list of more than 3,000 products, he repeatedly flashed his auction card to bid up an item -- a Sun Microsystems server, some networking gear from Cisco Systems, a data storage system. By the end of his buying spree, Mr. Hopper had snapped up several million dollars' worth of equipment at 10 cents to 15 cents on the dollar. "We have our eye out for bargains," he said. 
It is the kind of frugality that has kept expansion costs down at Global Sports, one of the few e-commerce companies that is still growing as if it were 1999. 
Less than three years after it began running Internet stores -- including the Web sites, warehouses and customer service centers -- for sporting goods retailers, Global Sports has become one of the largest and most successful e-commerce survivors. 
Unknown to many consumers, Global Sports, based in King of Prussia, Pa., runs online stores for the Sports Authority, Sport Chalet, the Athlete's Foot and more than 20 other retailers, media companies and professional sports organizations.
Investors are noticing. Its 2001 sales are expected to be $100 million, up from $43 million in 2000. It has virtually no debt and had more than $92 million in cash at the end of the third quarter. (Results for the fourth quarter will not be released until Feb. 6.) Global Sports shares, which began 2001 at less than $6, are now trading at $20.33.
YET its business did not always elicit admiration. When Global Sports ventured onto the Internet during the peak of the dot-com boom in early 1999, its business model was shrugged off. Wall Street and the media reserved praise for eToys, Amazon.com and other online stores that were trying to create brands and hoping to displace conventional retailers.
As most "pure play" e-commerce companies were perishing, the outsourcing model of Global Sports started gaining proponents. Now, none other than Amazon is aggressively chasing after the same business.
"We created this business years ago, when people said it didn't make any sense," said Michael G. Rubin, the chief executive of Global Sports. "We have proven what an opportunity this is."
Mr. Rubin and his team still face significant hurdles. Global Sports must prove it can make money on the Internet. The company hopes that the tally of 2001 holiday sales will help show its first pro forma quarterly profit and that it will be profitable this year. Global Sports has bet that much of its future growth will come from areas where it has little experience, like luxury goods and general merchandise. And even with $100 million in sales, Global Sports remains small enough that it could face challenges from well-financed rivals. 
"As it becomes more lucrative, it will attract more competition," said Evie Black Dykema, a senior retail analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
For now, the aftermath of the dot-com collapse is playing in Global Sports' favor. 
While scores of e-commerce companies have vanished, online retailing continues to grow, and shoppers increasingly expect off-line stores to have online branches. Yet for many traditional retailers, the Internet has been little more than a costly headache. In recent months, traditional chains -- including Target, Wal-Mart and Macy's and Bloomingdale's, the Federated Department Stores units -- have scaled back, restructured or canceled online efforts. 
That has made Global Sports' offer of low-cost, low-risk Internet stores more attractive to retailers. Last year, it signed up Kmart, adding a general merchandiser to its stable of sporting goods companies. 
Despite spending more than $100 million on its own e-commerce effort, Kmart's Internet subsidiary, BlueLight.com, had consistently missed sales targets, according to Richard Blunck, chief executive of the Kmart unit. After becoming chief in May, Mr. Blunck said he considered several potential partners, including Amazon, before settling on Global Sports.
"This business has been in an absolute turnaround situation," Mr. Blunck said. Through November, BlueLight had reduced operating costs 75 percent while increasing sales 45 percent and improving on-time shipments and customer satisfaction, he said. (BlueLight has not yet released total holiday season sales but has said they exceeded expectations.)
Amazon declined to talk about its competition with Global Sports, but over the last year, as growth in Amazon's core retail operations has stalled, the company has emphasized the importance of its outsourcing business. Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, has described it as a "very meaningful driver of growth in the long term."
After Global Sports signed up Kmart, Amazon added Target to a list of partners that includes powerhouses like Toys "R" Us, Borders and Circuit City Stores. 
For businesses seeking to outsource e-commerce operations, "the two biggest options are Amazon and Global Sports," said Lauren Cooks Levitan, an analyst at Robertson Stephens. With 38 million shoppers, Amazon can bring significant traffic to its partners, Ms. Levitan said. But Global Sports has a better history of having its partners' stores ready in record time, she said. And Amazon competes with several of its partners in categories like books, consumer electronics and appliances, while Global Sports does not, Ms. Levitan added. 
Mr. Blunck said, "I wanted to have a partner that wasn't in the business of competing with me." 
Having Amazon as a rival does not seem to trouble Mr. Rubin, who at 29 has a 16-year track record as a successful businessman. 
Mr. Rubin opened his first business, a ski shop in his parents' basement, when he was 13. By the time he finished high school, he owned five retail ski shops in New York and Pennsylvania. After a semester at Villanova University, Mr. Rubin dropped out to start KPR Sports International, which sold off-price sporting goods. In 1997, KPR merged with Ryka Inc., a publicly traded maker of athletic footwear for women; the company later became Global Sports. 
By late 1998, the company was profitable, with $130 million in sales. Yet like many entrepreneurs, Mr. Rubin decided he could not ignore e-commerce opportunities. 
He considered starting an online sporting goods store but felt that he could not compete with established brands. So he decided to join with as many sporting goods retailers as were willing to sign up. 
"People believed we couldn't get competitors to partner," said Michael Conn, Global Sports' senior vice president for business development. Mr. Rubin, however, was so confident he sold all of Global Sports' existing business to focus on the Internet. 
By May 1999, Mr. Rubin had signed up 5 of the top 10 sporting goods retailers. Nearly two dozen have since followed. 
"They are the sporting goods industry online," said John Horan, publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, a newsletter. 
MR. RUBIN'S success hinged on an offer that presented little risk for retailers. Global Sports would assume all costs associated with running the online business, including inventory risks. It would pay a portion of sales -- between 5 percent and 10 percent -- to its partners. All the retailer had to do was advertise the online business in its stores. (The arrangement with Kmart is different. Kmart owns the inventory, held in Global Sports warehouses. Kmart pays fees and commissions to Global Sports to run the online operations.)
The economics made sense for Global Sports. Payments to its retail partners were much smaller than what pure-play Internet stores were spending in marketing to acquire customers -- the kinds of costs that had sunk Fogdog.com and MVP.com. 
In October 2000, Global Sports bought Fogdog for $38.4 million in stock, mostly to retain its well-regarded technology team. In September, Global Sports announced it would acquire Ashford.com, a troubled online luxury goods retailer. Mr. Rubin hopes to use Ashford's distribution sites, merchandising team and business relationships to solicit the online business of off-line luxury goods retailers, just as he has done with sporting goods companies.
"I think this can be a multibillion-dollar business that generates terrific cash flow," Mr. Rubin said of Global Sports. 
His boast is reminiscent of the Internet bubble. Yet Wall Street appears to like it. Of five analysts who follow the company, three rate it a strong buy and two rate it a buy, according to Thomson Financial Network, which tracks analysts' ratings.

PERSON: Helmut Panke 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
A Loyal Survivor Rises at BMW

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
IT is not clear whether Helmut Panke was surprised, but almost everybody else at Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. was.
 At what was supposed to be a routine supervisory board meeting on Dec. 3, Joachim Milberg announced that he would retire a year early as chief executive of BMW, the automaker based in Munich. A day later, the company said Mr. Panke would take over as chief executive when Mr. Milberg stepped down in May. A man whose gaunt face and steely manner belie a more extroverted personality, Mr. Panke, 55, is a corporate survivor who had risen to chief financial officer and was Mr. Milberg's preferred successor. 
 On the surface, Mr. Panke, who speaks fluent English and who led BMW's manufacturing foray into the United States 10 years ago, landed one of the best jobs in the industrial world. While bigger rivals are reeling from the global recession and internal problems, BMW is thriving.
Under Mr. Milberg, BMW sold Rover, the money-losing British carmaker, shedding a disastrous acquisition.
Last year, BMW re-established itself as one of the most profitable automakers. Sales rose 11 percent in the first nine months. Thanks largely to its popular X5 sport utility vehicle, which Mr. Panke helped push the company into building, nine-month sales in the United States surged 19 percent.
Unlike most rivals in the United States, BMW did not increase sales with interest-free loans and other incentives that hurt profits. Nine-month operating profit rose 7.5 percent, and net profit rose 64 percent, although the 2000 results were hurt by Rover write-offs.
The stock market value of BMW is higher than that of Volkswagen, even though BMW sells one-fourth as many cars. The once-rampant speculation that BMW would be swallowed by a bigger company like Volkswagen or Ford Motor is gone.
But Mr. Panke will face some difficult and immediate tests. If the global economy remains stagnant, even BMW will be hurt. And Mr. Panke risks a major embarrassment if the 7 Series, BMW's new $70,000 line of cars, is a flop. The 7 Series, billed as BMW's most prestigious, has just gone on sale in America, but the automotive press has already criticized its styling as radical.
And the company is again trying to extend its reach into the lower end of the market. It is producing a new version of the Mini, one of the only Rover lines BMW kept, and a new 1 Series of small BMW's. Even if those succeed, their profit margins are lower than for luxury cars.
Mr. Panke is keeping a low profile until he formally takes the top job; he declined requests for an interview. The day after he was named Mr. Milberg's successor, he told reporters in Munich that he wanted to emphasize "continuity."
His rising influence has been apparent at BMW for some time. A former consultant in Germany at McKinsey & Company, he joined BMW as a senior corporate planner in 1982.
He is a veteran of management turmoil, having navigated two boardroom shake-ups since 1999 and one of BMW's biggest crises -- the problems at Rover. But part of his rise in the company stems from loyalty. While other executives disagreed with Mr. Milberg, Mr. Panke became a trusted lieutenant.
He first attained visibility in the early 1990's, overseeing site selection of BMW's first factory in the United States. He toured the South, talking to people at churches and truck stops and asking about the quality of the schools and whether there was a good work ethic. In 1992, BMW decided to build in Spartanburg, S.C., and Mr. Panke became president of American operations. He is admired by many people in South Carolina.
"I worked with him a long time; he's just a straight-up guy, a very good businessman," said Carroll Campbell, who was governor of South Carolina when BMW was deciding where to build. 
Mr. Campbell, now retired, says that he remained friends with Mr. Panke and that "when he was elevated, he gave me a call."
The Spartanburg plant was a turning point for BMW's American presence. The United States now accounts for nearly one-quarter of BMW's sales and is its biggest foreign market.
Mr. Panke's reputation has also been burnished by his role in persuading BMW to build the X5, aimed at the one in four BMW owners who also has an S.U.V. in the garage. "He clearly recognized that BMW's dependence on car models would be a barrier, as it tried to expand its lineup," said Wesley Brown, an auto industry analyst at Nextrend., of Thousand Oaks, Calif. 
Whatever his virtues, Mr. Panke's career has benefited in part from being out of the line of fire. He had no involvement when BMW's former chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, acquired Rover in the early 1990's and embarked on an ultimately catastrophic plan to expand into mass-market cars.
Mr. Pischetsrieder became locked in internal warfare over strategy and was forced out in 1999 by the board, dominated by Germany's Quandt family.
BMW's top post went to Mr. Milberg, a quiet, onetime professor of industrial organization who had joined the company only six years earlier. Mr. Milberg quickly elevated Mr. Panke to chief financial officer, and both men gradually became convinced that they had to abandon Rover.
Other top executives disagreed and began to undermine Mr. Milberg by making their views known outside the boardroom. That was when Mr. Milberg forced out three members of the management board. Among them was Carl-Peter Forster, the production chief, who is now president of Adam Opel A.G., the German subsidiary of General Motors.
Through the upheavals, Mr. Panke radiated confidence. He defended Rover as long as that was official policy, contending that management could solve the problems.
But when Mr. Milberg went public with plans essentially to give Rover away, writing off billions of dollars, Mr. Panke was on the dais alongside Mr. Milberg, fielding questions. And when BMW began booming again, Mr. Panke behaved as though it had been planned.
In an interview in 2000, Mr. Panke recalled rebutting speculation that BMW was too small to compete against Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler, Ford and General Motors. "You see?," he said. "Didn't I tell you we would stay independent?"

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Class Consciousness Comes to Airport Security

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
THE velvet rope separating the V.I.P.'s from the hoi polloi has arrived at the airport security gate.
 Deeply concerned that egalitarian pile-ups at crowded checkpoints have caused many formerly frequent fliers to curtail travel since Sept. 11, the nation's airlines have begun setting up special-access security lanes for their most elite customers -- those who fly first-class or who belong to the highest levels of carriers' frequent-flier programs. 
 The airlines defend the new stratification as a necessary nod to customer relations. "As a company that is in a customer-service business we'll continue to look for ways that we can shorten security lines for all of our customers, and to provide customers who pay more to fly with us more with additional benefits and services," said Kurt Ebenhoch, a spokesman for Northwest Airlines. 
All airlines are adding security lanes for everyone's use. But four of the top five domestic airlines -- Northwest, United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines -- have installed special lanes to put elite passengers in shorter lines. Only Continental Airlines has not done so, opting instead for additional checkpoints "for all of our customers," said Rahsaan Johnson, a company spokesman.
Flying, of course, has long been socially stratified. For obvious economic reasons, airlines give special treatment to customers who buy expensive first-class or business-class seats. Usually, these passengers are business travelers who pay the highest fares, even for seats in coach. Most business travelers belong to frequent-flier programs, which offer different levels of benefits depending on how many annual miles passengers accrue.
In airports themselves, however, class distinctions have traditionally been muted. Most carriers, for example, keep their membership-only club lounges behind closed doors, marked only with discreet signs.
But with the overall plunge in air travel after Sept. 11, economic catastrophe loomed for the airlines, which depend on business travelers for as much as two-thirds of their revenue. In surveys, airlines discovered that about 25 percent of that core market was cutting back on travel -- not because of fear of flying, but because of the delays and annoyances at crowded, often tense airport security checkpoints.
"The airlines have an obvious and understandable interest in serving their most valued customers," said David S. Stempler, president of the Air Travelers Association, a leading passengers' advocacy group.
V.I.P. lanes are just the beginning, Mr. Stempler and other industry experts say, as airlines scramble to find ways to balance the demands of law enforcement and customer service in a new era of increased airport security. Soon, they say, travelers will have the option of enrolling in a national identification program that will expedite check-ins using a high-technology system to essentially vouch for one's trustworthiness as a security risk.
Several airlines have been working separately on such systems. But with responsibility for airport security scheduled to shift on Feb. 18 from the airlines to the federal government, it's now considered likely that a unified system will emerge. The Air Transport Association, a trade group that represents the airline industry, has told the federal government that it supports such a plan.
One thing is certain: in the future, to get through to the gate faster, you'll need to be on "the list" -- a database of travelers who have applied for and received (most likely by paying a fee) a "smart card" I.D. that can be used for expedited airport security processing. Basically, said Mr. Stempler, the system would "separate airline passengers into two groups: the known and the not-known."
No matter what form such a system eventually takes, most proponents agree that it will have to be voluntary. Using a kind of "reverse profiling" technology, travelers will swipe their I.D. cards through A.T.M.-like devices at security checkpoints. As a guard against counterfeiting, encoded biometrics on the card would enable the device to verify a person's identity through fingerprints, handprints, iris-identification or facial recognition scanning. Then the system would check with a central database to verify that the user was designated an acceptable security risk.
The I.D. system would "separate the people we know -- the ones who are not high-risk -- from the people we don't know," Mr. Stempler said. "You get to go to a shorter line for your security check if you're in the known category. We'd still need to inspect what you're carrying, just as we do with everybody else. But everyone else who we don't know, you spend a little more time on, find out where they're going, what they're doing, where they've been."
Though anyone could enroll in such a system, in practice it would be used mostly by frequent fliers who would be willing to go to the expense and trouble of applying. But in granting more convenience to users, even a voluntary system would exert pressure on regular fliers to join, critics say.
And the idea raises ticklish privacy issues, since both the government and commercial interests, which may be linked to the card as a way of offsetting its cost, may have access to the database. 
There also are questions about the reliability of the technology itself, according to critics. Such equipment often doesn't work, the American Civil Liberties Union said in a study released last week. For one thing, it maintains, facial-recognition systems used by police departments for urban anticrime surveillance are flawed by an unacceptably large number of so-called false positives, which inaccurately match innocent passersby with wanted criminals.
All these questions need to be addressed, Mr. Stempler and others say. Right now, snarled security lines and angry passengers -- no matter how much they pay for their tickets -- pose one of the biggest customer-relations problems in the airline industry's history.
The main goal, Mr. Stempler said, is to enhance security by focusing resources more on high-risk passengers and less on those fliers who are willing to share personal information with security agents. "If you're looking for a needle in a haystack, which is what this is, it's good to try to get rid of as much of the hay as you possibly can," he said.

HEADLINE: The World; 
The Danger Of Doing Good Deeds

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
DURING the Afghanistan air war, the top military officer of the United States regularly briefed reporters not only on the areas bombed overnight, but also on the number of individual food packets dropped by military cargo planes.
 In a typical briefing on Oct. 22, 2001, Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that "U.S. forces struck in six planned target areas that included airfields and air defenses, command and control facilities, and terrorist forces and camps." Then, barely missing a beat, he added, "We continued our humanitarian airdrop mission Saturday, with four C-17s delivering approximately 52,000 rations." 
 By giving such prominence to the military's airdrop of individual food rations, General Myers left the distinct impression that they played a critical role in the relief effort. But that notion was turned on its head by Andrew S. Natsios, the head of the Agency for International Development, which oversaw the American relief effort during the war.
"There was a symbolic importance to those food drops," said Mr. Natsios at a news conference last week describing the herculean efforts made to transport 200,000 tons of wheat into Afghanistan by December to prevent famine.
But symbolism aside, noted Mr. Natsios, the 2.5 million food rations that were dropped by the American military represented just one quarter of 1 percent of the food needed to feed the Afghan people.
In a country where the people were barely surviving even before Sept. 11 -- after three years of drought and 20 years of war -- the military's individual food rations of peanut butter, Pop-Tarts and lentil stew, spread very thinly across a few remote areas, made little difference, according to relief officials.
But to Pentagon officials, the airdrops were a success on two scores. First, at least some food was delivered to the most desperate Afghans as winter approached. This was important, said Joseph J. Collins, a deputy assistant secretary of defense, because this was the first time the United States had begun fighting a war in a country already suffering from a humanitarian crisis. "This has made humanitarian assistance to distressed populations an integral part of our overall policy, " Mr. Collins said.
Second, the food aid also gave the White House a powerful weapon in the propaganda campaign to convince Afghans that the United States wanted to help them. 
But many private relief agencies have complained that the food drops also caused a dangerous problem by blurring the distinction between humanitarian relief workers and the people fighting the war.
The strongest weapon in the arsenal of relief agencies is their neutrality -- their pledge that they will work to relieve the suffering of all, and not try to help or harm any particular group in a conflict. 
When those food packets started fluttering down from the same people who were bombing the country, it called the neutrality of relief workers into question.
"Those airdrops of ration packets were at the forefront of our concern," said Nicolas DeTorrente, director of Doctors Without Borders, a private charity that takes no government money to ensure its neutral status.
"The packets were quite ineffective in reaching the people in need -- really just a drop in the bucket -- but they presented a real problem by blurring the line drawn between the military and us," he added.
Something similar happened during the Kosovo campaign, when, as American planes delivered bombs, NATO forces built refugee camps in Albania and Macedonia. There, too, relief agencies discovered that a red cross or a red crescent sometimes wasn't enough to maintain their neutrality in the eyes of the people the United States was bombing.
Since the end of the cold war, relief agencies have struggled to capture what they call "the humanitarian space" where they can minister safely to civilians in a war zone. Arguably, this space is more critical than ever, given the character of modern warfare, in which many armies intentionally attack civilians. Today civilians make up 80 percent of wartime casualties. 
"The whole topic is hugely sensitive, much more even than in Kosovo," said Oliver Uhlrich of the United Nations office of humanitarian coordination. "The U.N. is very concerned about maintaining its neutrality."
The U.N., whose World Food Program transports food to people in conflicts and whose refugee organization is charged with caring for those who flee the fighting, is acutely aware of the potential problems created when military forces simultaneously fight and engage in humanitarian activities.
"Civilians are now at the heart of war and it is important that we do all we can to protect them, and to do that we have to be allowed to remain neutral and to be seen as impartial," said Urs Boegli of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Building With Attitude; 
The 'Look at Me' Strut of a Swagger Building

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL J. LEWIS; Michael J. Lewis, chairman of the art department at Williams College, is the author of "Frank Furness: Architecture and the Violent Mind."

 BODY:
NEW YORK is the only city in the world where the decision to build a cluster of 50- or 60-story buildings could seem an act of modesty. But such is the plan to rebuild the World Trade Center at close to half its 110-story height, as laid out by John C. Whitehead, head of the downtown redevelopment project. This is understandable. Who would duplicate a monument that had already been attacked twice, and expect tenants to move into the world's largest bull's eye? Thus the World Trade Center may well be reborn, in name and in rental capacity, but without the swagger.
 It is not only at Wall Street that monumental gestures have fallen from favor. On the East River, Frank Gehry proposed a new Guggenheim Museum that would have forever altered the city's skyline, a writhing tempest of metal, billowing like a full-rigged ship in a gale. It would have rivaled the nearby Brooklyn Bridge, though it now seems unlikely to happen. Meanwhile, in Chicago, Donald Trump's project for the city's tallest building has been shelved. There, too, swagger is on hold. 
 Each of these might be termed swagger buildings -- arrogant, proud and strutting objects that are the physical manifestations of America's competitive culture. Swagger buildings are distinguished either by exceptional size (the Woolworth Building and the Empire State Building), novel or arresting shape (Frank Lloyd Wright's original Guggenheim Museum), or by some dazzling but purely symbolic gesture (as with Wright's dream of a mile-high skyscraper). They are what happens when the financial power of a corporation is brought to bear on a small speck of urban real estate, and given permission to roar. They are high-spirited, narcissistic and supremely confident; they free inert metal and masonry to dance and caper in the air; they show what should be impossible to show: an earthbound building in the act of having fun.
THE swagger building has but one objective -- to rivet public attention. It is the loud and fascinating stranger who enters the room and instantly changes the tone and direction of conversation. And it is central to the experience of the American city. For all its spirited high jinks, it is engaged in the deadly serious business of making fortunes and casting its rivals into the shadow -- literally, if possible. Swagger buildings herald the entrance of a brash upstart, or anyone who can contrive a splash of color and a bit of architectural turbulence, hoist it against the sky, and trumpet, "I have arrived." They come in successive waves, and their ebb and flow is the visible pulse of the city. 
For swagger buildings can certainly fail. Fashions in architecture can be as fickle as those in clothing -- and these failures are far more difficult to hide in the back of the closet. Not much is needed -- an untimely economic lurch, a shift in the cultural winds, an unfortunate but indelible psychological association -- for a gesture of authority to look like bombastic flailing. When this happens, a swagger building can turn into something like the universally mocked Edsel -- something not merely dated, but whose form is deafeningly and magnificently wrong.
At times swagger itself becomes wrong. Too much agitation on the skyline does not communicate authority but a St. Vitus's dance of gesticulation. And when everyone is shouting, it is the whisperer who gets the attention. Such was the case with the Victorian era. The flamboyant Second Empire style failed so wretchedly after the Civil War that it still looks ridiculous a century and a half later. This style was created in France under Emperor Louis Napoleon, and its jaunty pavilioned towers and bulbous mansard roofs proclaimed affluence and sophistication with a fashionable French accent.
America embraced the style in a collective frenzy after the Civil War. The Old Executive Office Building in Washington is the most conspicuous relic of the style. Typically, though, New York built the most lavish example in its post office, a plump, florid leviathan that transposed the Louvre onto lower Broadway. 
After the Civil War, this festive, haughty style struck a welcome note: cathartic exuberance after the carnage. But in 1870, the vain French emperor blundered into a foolish quarrel with Prussia and was deposed, along with the style that had become his trademark. The prosperous mansard, which once looked voluptuous and vigorous, now looked puffed up and arrogant. New York, ever alert to the vagaries of fashion, jettisoned the style. The enormous Second Empire state capitol in Albany was already half built, but its offending mansard was lopped off. Throughout the country the mansard slunk into disfavor, further tainted by the Panic of 1873.
America is notoriously unforgiving to failed swagger buildings. The nation has never liked being associated with failure, whatever the cause. For Americans, the Second Empire lingers in the collective imagination as something either comical -- the gloomy turreted mansion in Charles Addams's cartoons -- or vaguely sinister -- the looming house of Norman Bates in "Psycho." It is the embodiment of failed ambition and decay. The odium of Louis Napoleon's fall even came to rest, quite unfairly, on the lackluster presidency of Ulysses S. Grant, as the style was incongruously dubbed the General Grant style. 
But swagger cannot be checked for long -- especially for buildings conceived during a period of economic prosperity like the Roaring 20's. This era produced the nation's finest swagger buildings, those Art Deco whimsies with their crisply chiseled walls and tapered shafts that rose to make great swaggering sculptural gestures at their crowns: the helmeted spire of the Chrysler Building or the fantastic Zeppelin mooring mast atop the Empire State Building. Their forms communicated vibrant economic health, the architectural equivalent of flushed cheeks and sparkling eyes.
Modernist architects may have mocked these forms, but their popularity was unassailable. Not until the Depression began were these cheeky and bold gestures regarded as grotesque and inappropriate. It was not the mooring mast that discredited the Empire State building; it was the investors leaping from windows and the apple sellers huddled around its base.
Much the same happened to the swagger buildings of the 1980's. At the start of that restless decade the Trump Tower and the AT&T Building -- with their jolly postmodern rooflines, colored bands of polished granite and sleek glass walls of Darth Vader-like opacity -- were first associated with unbridled economic expansion, later with junk bonds and looming recession. Once again, the psychological connections turned a gesture of confidence into a vulgar and boastful contortion. It will be some time before colored granite stripes are fully rehabilitated.
Now the events of Sept. 11 have again changed the nation's perception of the swagger building, which had recently returned to glory. Every indication suggests that there will now be a distinct moratorium on swagger buildings. But it is certain that they will return. They are, after all, basic to the American vernacular, like the advertising jingle and the billboard. Americans may often resent them and envy them and, sometimes, take malicious glee when their financing fails, but the nation will, nonetheless, find itself wishing for their return -- those cocky and amiable ruffians on the skyline.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Housecleaning at Ailing Funds Is Light, So Far

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
AFTER two years of shabby performance for America's growth-stock funds, the housecleaning has begun.
 Some managers with subpar records have been swept out, and some of the worst-performing funds have been shut down or merged into better ones. But the widespread disappointment among investors in hundreds of sagging growth funds has spurred far less change than fund analysts had anticipated. 
 "If it turns out that this is all there is, I would be shocked," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar Inc. in Chicago.
More managers were shown the door in 2001 than in most years, he added, "but it hasn't been tremendous." 
The losses suffered by growth funds certainly have been. In 2001, growth funds -- those that concentrate on buying stocks of large companies expected to grow fast -- lost 23.56 percent of their value, on average, according to Morningstar. That came after a loss of 14.5 percent in 2000.
"There's a paucity of strong managers," said Burton Greenwald, a mutual fund consultant and independent fund director in Philadelphia. "The bull market carried a lot of average, or perhaps mediocre, fund managers to heights that did not reflect their abilities."
Many growth funds soared during the technology stock boom of the late 1990's, so investors who sold them two years ago should have racked up big gains. But those who held on may be finding that all of their paper gains have been wiped out and that their investments are now worth less than when they made them -- even after the stock market's rebound gave most growth funds a boost toward the end of 2001.
The fallout from the growth-fund plunge varies greatly from one company to another. At the money management unit of Merrill Lynch, the two most prominent growth managers, James D. McCall and Paul G. Meeks, have recently been replaced. At Putnam Investments in Boston, which has several underperforming growth funds, managers have been shuffled, and the process of picking stocks and balancing potential risks and rewards is being overhauled.
But some fund companies are sticking by their gunslingers. Consider the Invesco Growth fund, run by the Invesco Funds Group in Denver, which was popular with growth fund investors during the boom. The 2001 performance of Invesco Growth was so poor that even its long-term record turned dismal. On Morningstar's five-star rating scale, it now rates just one star, down from three a year ago and five just two years ago.
By increasing its stake in the technology sector early last year, Invesco Growth's managers compounded their troubles. The fund lost 49.1 percent of its value last year -- more than double the loss for its peer group -- and its assets dipped below $1 billion, about half of what they once were.
At the end of November, according to Lipper, another fund-tracking company, only three large-cap growth funds had bigger one-year losses than Invesco Growth, only five had worse three-year records and only 14 had worse five-year records. Taking into account the taxes its shareholders have had to pay on past gains, the fund's average annual return over the last five years has been a loss of almost 6 percent, according to Morningstar. 
Through the good and the bad, Trent E. May has managed the fund. He and Molly Cisneros, a spokeswoman for Invesco, said they did not expect that to change.
"Our process, I think, is not broken," Ms. Cisneros said. "Our style works well, and investors like it. We are not going to abandon that style."
Mr. May, who is also the lead manager of the Invesco Endeavor fund and helps manage the Invesco Growth and Income fund, said Invesco Growth's long-term record painted too bleak a picture. (All three of Mr. May's funds fell more than 43 percent in 2001.)
"It's been a very disappointing year," he said in an interview from his home in Colorado. "I don't want to underemphasize how disappointing it's been."
But under his management, he said, the fund had performed well through early December 2000. At that point, it was on its way to a sixth consecutive annual gain, he said. But an end-of-the-year swoon sank its return for that year to a loss of 23.9 percent.
In the first quarter of 2001, it lost an additional 40 percent of its value. After rebounding 11 percent in the second quarter, it sank 43 percent in the third.
The wild ride did not end there. As Ms. Cisneros was quick to point out, Invesco Growth had one of the biggest gains of all funds in October and November.
Still, the fund gained about 40 percent in each of its best years, 1997 and 1998. It would have to match that performance in the next two years to make up for last year's loss.
To do that, Mr. May would need a lasting resurgence in the technology stocks that account for more than half of the fund's assets. Despite having dug the fund into a deep hole with an even bigger bet on tech stocks early last year, Mr. May has not looked elsewhere for growth.
HE acknowledged that he and his co-manager, Douglas J. McEldowney, miscalculated in February and March. Thinking that the interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve would spur a quick economic recovery that would benefit technology companies, they raised the fund's stake in tech stocks to as much as 60 percent. 
"We underestimated how much downside there was left in technology," Mr. May said. He and his management team, he added, "didn't cut the numbers enough."
"We became too focused on a company-by-company basis and lost sight of some of the broader portfolio implications," he said. The independent directors of Invesco's funds, most of whom are paid more than $80,000 a year to oversee management of the company's 30 funds, did not call for Mr. May to be replaced, he said, but they did demand improvement in the company's risk controls.
As a result, he said, he tried to reduce the growth fund's risk level by putting more of its assets into companies with stronger balance sheets that would help them withstand a prolonged economic downturn. Invesco's managers also started holding quarterly meetings to discuss the bets they were making and why they were making them, he said.
Firing growth-fund managers because their funds are down in a weak market would not be fair and could prove to be a mistake when the inevitable rebound occurs, Mr. May said. "Had we underperformed when growth was in favor and underperformed when growth was out of favor, that would be a catalyst for change, and I wouldn't expect to survive that," he said.
Some fund companies are not as patient as Invesco.
Harbor Capital Advisors replaced Howard Moss and Blair Boyer of Jennison Associates as the managers of the Harbor International Growth fund in December. The fund lost 38.5 percent of its value in 2001, compared with a loss of 20.65 percent for the typical foreign stock fund. Much worse, for the last three years, its average annual return was a loss of 17.84 percent, more than 14 times the loss recorded by its typical peer.
According to Morningstar, more than 350 funds with at least $100 million in assets have underperformed their peer groups for the last one and three years under the same lead manager. That list includes some of the biggest names in fund management, like Gary L. Pilgrim of Pilgrim Baxter & Associates, Garrett R. Van Wagoner of Van Wagoner Capital Management, Scott W. Schoelzel of Janus Capital and Louis G. Navellier of Navellier Associates.
More than 50 of the funds on that list lost at least 30 percent of their value last year. Four of those belonged to Invesco and five to Putnam.
One standout laggard is Putnam OTC Emerging Growth, which still had more than $3 billion in assets after losing more than 46 percent of its value last year, according to Morningstar. Over the last three years under the management of Michael J. Mufson and Steve Kirson, the fund has lost 15.33 percent a year, on average, compared with a gain of 5.23 percent for the typical mid-cap growth fund.
That means that an investor who gave $10,000 to Mr. Mufson and Mr. Kirson to manage three years ago would have about $6,000 left. In contrast, an investor in the typical mid-cap growth fund would have more than $11,500.
Mr. Mufson and Mr. Kirson still have their jobs, but other managers and analysts at Putnam have lost theirs in a reassessment the company undertook this year, said Stephen M. Oristaglio, senior managing director at Putnam. He said Putnam tried to determine what skills its employees would need in the post-bubble market and whether they had them or would be willing and able to acquire them. 
"When we do all of that, a number of people fall out," Mr. Oristaglio said. "They're no longer with us. The people that aren't up to snuff have been let go."
WHILE most lead managers have kept their funds, he said, some co-managers with different specialties have been added to some Putnam funds. Roland W. Gillis was named co-manager with Mr. Mufson and Mr. Kirson in September, for example.
Dismissing an underperforming manager may be the easy answer, but it is not always the right one, Mr. Oristaglio said.
"There's good turnover, and there's bad turnover," he said. "You've got to be very thoughtful about change."
Mr. Kinnel of Morningstar said he expected that directors of many fund companies would be full of thoughts about change when they met this month and next to review 2001 results.
"My guess," he said, "is the first quarter is going to see a fair amount more turnover."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
An Obscure Bond Manager Caters to Big Clients

BYLINE:  By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
WESTERN ASSET MANAGEMENT may be the most obscure big bond manager in the United States. 
 The firm is a subsidiary of Legg Mason, the Baltimore financial services company, which is better known for its stock mutual funds. William H. Miller III, the chief executive of Legg Mason's fund group and the manager of the flagship Value Trust fund, is widely recognized for outperforming the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for more than a decade. 
 But Western, in Pasadena, Calif., has quietly built a strong reputation among institutional money managers whose fixed-income assets it handles. These include directors of the pension funds of the Connecticut Retirement Plans and Trust Funds, the Illinois State Universities Retirement System, and the California Public Employees' Retirement System, known as Calpers. It ranks as the fourth-biggest bond fund manager for institutional, tax-exempt investors in the United States, according to Pensions & Investments, a trade magazine. 
All told, Western manages nearly $100 billion -- almost two-thirds of all the assets under management by Legg Mason and its subsidiaries, the parent company said. Bonds, however, bring in relatively low fees: the management fee for Western Asset Core, a bond fund sold to institutions, is 0.40 percent, while the fee for Legg Mason Value Institutional is 0.66 percent, according to Morningstar. 
Western's focus has been big accounts, but the firm manages more than $5 billion in bond mutual funds for individual investors, either under its own name or that of Legg Mason, according to the parent company. Western is also making a big push in the business of 401(k) plans, adding $1 billion in such assets in the last year. 
The firm's increasingly high profile is awkward for Western executives who prefer to discuss its investment views directly with their clients instead of in newspaper or television interviews. Western's strategy is to be "low key, to focus on investments and client service and get on with it," said Deepak Chowdhury, managing director for asset management at Legg Mason. The subsidiary's executives, including James W. Hirschmann, the chief executive, and S. Kenneth Leech, its chief investment officer, rarely give interviews. Mr. Leech speaks in public only at occasional gatherings organized by the parent company.
Raymond A. Mason, the chief executive of Legg Mason, says he is comfortable with the subsidiary's relative inaccessibility because of Western's institutional orientation. "In that business, publicity doesn't have a whole lot of value," Mr. Mason said.
Western, which had $3.5 billion in assets when Legg Mason bought it in 1986, caught on with institutional investors because of its performance. The Illinois State Universities Retirement System recently hired Western to manage a $75 million fixed-income portfolio because "they had a long track record that was just outstanding," said John Krimmel, chief investment officer of the Illinois system, with $10.5 billion in assets.
WESTERN'S recent performance, as reflected in its institutional mutual funds, has also been good. Western Asset Core, an investment grade intermediate-term bond portfolio with $630 million in assets as of Sept. 30, according to Morningstar, returned 10.1 percent in 2001, or 1.6 percentage points better than the Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond Index and 2.7 percentage points better than other funds in its category, according to Morningstar, which gives the fund its top, five-star rating.
Although Western Asset Core and Western Asset Core Plus, a similar fund that holds more mortgage-backed securities, are principally institutional funds, small investors can buy shares in them through Schwab and Fidelity brokerage accounts with minimum initial investments of $2,500, far less than the $1 million required of institutions. 
Legg Mason, however, considers Schwab and Fidelity institutional clients and does not deal directly with retail investors who invest through them, said Thomas J. Hirschmann, manager of Western's institutional funds. Availability through Schwab and Fidelity is useful for financial advisers who want to put clients in funds offered by Western, Mr. Hirschmann said.
Retail investors can also put money into Legg Mason's taxable bond funds or money market accounts. The funds, totaling $3.6 billion in assets as of Sept. 30, have higher expenses and lower returns, however, than the institutional funds. Legg Mason Investment Grade, which returned 6.8 percent in 2001, has an expense ratio of 1 percent, compared with half a percent for Western Asset Core.
"That's a huge difference," said Scott Berry, an analyst at Morningstar.
Mark Fetting, who runs Legg Mason's mutual fund group, attributed the difference primarily to the higher costs involved in pricing a retail product distributed through financial advisers. "The retail funds also have a bit more of a conservative charter," Mr. Fetting said. 
Western uses a team approach, relying on specialists in each bond sector. The firm also uses multiple investment strategies simultaneously, he added, on the theory that if one or two fail, the others will keep the portfolio ahead.
One of Western's goals is to manage interest-rate risk by managing the duration of bonds in the fund's portfolio. The success of Western Asset Core in 2001 had much to do with a bet that the Treasury market would continue to rally, said Mr. Berry of Morningstar.
EXACTLY how Western will manage the portfolio in coming months is unclear. In a meeting organized by Legg Mason last month, Mr. Leech gave some hints of his views. He said the economy was likely to brighten, but that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to be worried about inflation and so was unlikely to raise interest rates. In his opinion, most bond market participants mistakenly believe that the Fed will raise rates by two percentage points by the end of 2002. At most, he said, the climb would be one-half of a percentage point. "Since we're at a cyclical low point right now, monetary policy will err toward an ease," he said.
To achieve higher returns in Western's portfolios, Mr. Leech is likely to look toward bonds like mortgage-backed securities and corporate bonds that yield more than Treasuries. The greatest opportunities will be in junk bonds, because their prices are now deeply depressed, and because the economy is expected to improve, he said.
"We think this has the potential of being the best-performing sector of the U.S. fixed-income markets next year," Mr. Leech said.
