HEADLINE: All That Easy Credit Haunts Detroit Now 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
WHEN the North American International Auto Show, the Cannes Film Festival of the auto industry, opens here today, the Ford Motor Company will put on a display of its new vehicles. The company hopes to make its mark with a redesigned version of its Expedition S.U.V. and a station wagon from its Volvo unit that looks like it wants to be an S.U.V.
 But the big news will come at the end of the week, after the show ends. That is when Ford is expected to announce a plan to return to profitability by reversing the company's declining quality, cutting costs and perhaps closing plants to ease overcapacity. 
 This year, even during a week when product has always been king, financial matters are front and center. Concerns are growing on Wall Street about the health of the multibillion-dollar credit operations of Ford and, to a lesser extent, General Motors. 
In 2001, total auto sales stayed at a near-record level, especially after Sept. 11, largely because G.M. and Ford leaned heavily on their financing businesses to pump up sales. But that burst of interest-free financing deals was just the latest in a string of deal making that led to swelled portfolios of leases and car loans taken on by Ford Motor Credit and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, known as G.M.A.C., in the last five years.
Unlike their foreign rivals, which have developed stables of models that buyers actually will pay more for, Ford and G.M. have relied more on incentives like low-interest loans and cheap leases to attract customers. The automakers have ponied up billions of dollars to their financing units to make up the difference on the below-market financing.
In good times, their credit businesses provided either a large part of their earnings or covered operating losses in the automaking business.
Now, with the economy slowing and unemployment rising, the question is whether the credit business will aggravate the effects of the recession instead of cushioning carmakers' bottom lines.
"More of these loans have been going bad, which is why Ford ran into trouble," said Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley.
"The fact that G.M.A.C.'s loan losses are lower than Ford's, and the fact that their reserve ratios are higher, suggest they have more cushion," he added. "Does that mean it's not going to go bad at G.M.A.C.? No. I think G.M.A.C.'s earnings are going to go down this year. But I don't think it will be as bad as Ford."
Consider Ford Motor Credit. In the first nine months of 2001, it made nearly $1.2 billion, while Ford as a whole lost about $385 million.
G.M.A.C. is expected to have $1.2 billion in earnings in the first nine months of this year, down slightly from $1.3 billion in the first nine months of last year. That means G.M.A.C. is accounting for almost all of G.M.'s operating profits.
Many analysts worry about the potential for even more write-offs as the rate of bankruptcies rises during the recession, leading to more defaults, and as the value of vehicles coming off leases falls because the demand for used cars has flagged.
In the third quarter of last year, Ford Motor Credit's loan losses rose to 1.36 percent of its total loans and leases, up from 0.87 percent in the year-earlier quarter. G.M.A.C.'s loan losses were 0.69 percent in the third quarter, up from 0.6 percent. Both companies have recently bolstered their reserves for future losses, indicating that loan loss rates are continuing to rise.
On one level, the nation's two independent automakers are moving in opposite directions. Ford, previously Wall Street's consensus pick among the Big Three, is coming off a dreadful year that brought more disputes with Firestone and the ouster of its chief executive. The company is expected to report its first annual loss since 1992.
General Motors, whose market share has fallen to less than 30 percent today from 60 percent in 1960, actually gained a sliver of share last year, for the first time since 1988. Its share rose to 28.3 percent, a 0.03 percent increase over 2000, and G.M. will be the only one of the Big Three to record an annual profit.
BUT both G.M. and Ford continue to have problems competing with imports without resorting to heavy subsidies. Banks, in turn, have been fleeing the auto financing business because it is hard to compete with subsidized rates. As a result, Ford Motor Credit financed more than half of the vehicles Ford Motor sold last year, according to the company, up from 37.6 percent in 1996. G.M.A.C. financed more than 40 percent of G.M. sales, up from about 25 percent in 1995.
At G.M.A.C., 85 percent of loans made in 2000 had some subsidy. That compares with about 50 percent in 1996, according to a Morgan Stanley report.
While offering credit to more people has been shown to improve customer loyalty and increase opportunities for marketing to a captive audience, Wall Street analysts debate the extent of risk now inherent in the financing businesses.
Ford's and G.M.'s credit ratings were downgraded two notches last year by Standard & Poor's and Moody's, largely forcing the automakers out of commercial paper and into other, more expensive forms of funding, like turning pools of auto loans into securities. Credit spreads between their borrowing rates and their lending rates have narrowed greatly, further compressing how much they make by financing car purchases.
"They have been a drain this time around," Mr. Girsky said, referring to the credit businesses.
Both Ford and G.M. must set aside capital to shore up the balance sheets of the credit businesses as they make more loans. At the end of 2000, for example, G.M. contributed almost $2.5 billion of its capital to G.M.A.C.'s balance sheet.
"Ford Credit will probably need capital" soon, Mr. Girsky said.
"If you're growing your business, it's one thing to put capital in a company and get a return," he added. "If you're not growing, it's a different story."
Ford and G.M. both acknowledge the diminishing returns of their credit businesses in the contracting economy, but they say that no surprise write-offs are in store.
"Leasing has been a negative for us; I'm not trying to paint it as any kind of positive story," said Bill Muir, the chief financial officer of G.M.A.C. He quickly added that "we have adequately accounted for it and aren't facing any kind of a blowup over it."
Car loans are not the only problem. Leases have become less profitable, too.
Automakers like G.M. give themselves a cushion when valuing leased vehicles. In 1998, Mr. Muir said, G.M.A.C. could take a car returned at the end of a lease and sell it for an average of $1,000 more than what they had estimated when they calculated the lease terms. That gain fell to just $200 last year because many people who might have considered a used car chose instead to use no-interest loans to buy new cars.
Some analysts believe that there is a risk that carmakers could actually start losing money on each leased car. Ford Motor Credit is particularly at risk, they say, because of its more aggressive lending practices.
Another problem for the financing units is the rising number of bankruptcies and defaults.
"We are in a deteriorating economic environment and we are dealing, as all others in the industry are, with a very, very high level of bankruptcies of our customers," said Greg C. Smith, the president and chief operating officer of Ford Motor Credit.
Mr. Smith was installed last month after his predecessor, Donald Winkler, was ousted. Mr. Winkler's resignation came after Ford said it would need to pump several hundred million dollars into Ford Motor Credit because the financing unit had underestimated the amount it would need for reserves, resulting in a $900 million fourth-quarter loss for Ford Motor -- about five times greater than analysts had expected.
Mr. Smith said Ford had tightened its standards as the economy deteriorated, and would benefit from a rebound in the used-car market.
Some analysts said they were surprised that Ford appeared to be suffering more than G.M. "Traditionally, we've considered them as stronger, because they only had one business," said David Andrews, a credit analyst at UBS Warburg.
Ford Motor Credit sticks to auto lending, while G.M.A.C. is diversified into other businesses, like mortgages. In the past, analysts worried that these other businesses came with their own sets of risks that G.M. might not be prepared to handle, although last year mortgages actually cushioned G.M.'s losses on car loans. Some analysts worry that the outlook for mortgage lending and some of G.M.A.C.'s other businesses are still concerns this year.
"They're really pretty much in the same boat," said John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "They have the same set of problems, but Ford Credit's are more acute right now." 
He pointed to the deteriorating credit ratings of the two companies. 
"Both companies are seeing their borrowing costs increase; that's the main difficulty," he added. If the credit rating is cut enough, "the availability of credit diminishes."
All these issues underlie the fundamental problem for Ford and G.M.: their vehicles' overall lack of appeal has been such that they have not been able to compete with imports.
Last year, through November, incentive costs, including subsidized loans, rebates and warranties, rose to $2,291 a vehicle for the Big Three, compared with $1,146 for Asian automakers, according to the AutoData Corporation, a research firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Despite that additional spending, G.M. managed to increase its market share just 0.03 percent last year, while Ford's share fell to 21.9 percent from 23 percent in 2000.
The costs of those incentives add up. In 2000, Ford Motor Credit reported pretax earnings of $2.97 billion. But that same year, Ford Motor spent $3.4 billion to make up for those cheap loans -- a huge expense that reflects more on the health of the auto business than the financing business.
Ford and G.M. are likely to see their market share shrink again this year, when overall sales are expected to fall sharply, analysts say. The companies have little room to maneuver further on pricing while their Japanese competitors benefit from a weaker yen, which declined by 14.6 percent against the dollar last year.
Last week, G.M. said it would change from interest-free financing to offering rebates of $2,002 a vehicle. The new wrinkle, meant to energize consumers again with a deal that seems different, will not lower incentive costs significantly. But at least it should lower the number of deals G.M.A.C. finances.
"We haven't been a drain on resources," Mr. Muir of G.M.A.C. said. "If you go over the past five years, G.M. has still gotten more cash dividends out of us than equity they have put into us."
Mr. Muir believes that as rebates are used and as sales decline, the amount of financing will slow and the need for capital will lessen.
"As the business cools off, we can still maintain our leverage and return a lot of capital to G.M.," he said.
Still, General Motors has other problems, principally rising health care costs and a potential multibillion-dollar deficit in its pension fund.
THE best way to fix these problems is to make vehicles that people will want to buy without any help. For Ford, it means striking the right balance between cost cutting and product planning, and getting the new products right.
G.M. has developed more momentum on the product side, but only very recently. Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of the company, appears to have re-energized G.M.'s design department by hiring Robert A. Lutz, the former president of Chrysler, last year.
Mr. Lutz, the champion of vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the PT Cruiser, often compares Detroit to Hollywood. Companies spend a tremendous amount of money each year to develop a few new products, whether movies or car models. If people like enough of them, the production executives are heroes. If they don't, the executives are in trouble.
And that appears to be a fact that no amount of financing, ultimately, can make disappear.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
New S.E.C. Rule Starts a Name Game

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
AS if it weren't hard enough to tell one mutual fund from another, many sponsors have decided that certain names just don't work anymore.
 So the Safeco Ginnie Mae fund is about to become the Safeco U.S. Government Securities fund, Strong American Utilities has recently morphed into Strong Dividend Income, and Invesco Blue Chip Growth has been renamed Invesco Growth. 
 A new rule by the Securities and Exchange Commission is motivating many of the name changes. The rule requires that by July 31, 2002, funds focusing on particular types of investments put at least 80 percent of their assets in the type of security their names imply. The previous standard was 65 percent, but it was vaguely worded and not an official commission rule. 
"This is more a commission position," said Paul F. Roye, director of the agency's division of investment management. 
In early 2001, when it approved the rule, the S.E.C. estimated that 504 funds did not meet the 80 percent threshold. Some 30 percent of them had large and presumably temporary cash positions, the commission said, but the rest would need to change either their names or their policies.
A sampling of fund families and consultants generally supports the tougher standard. They say that the cost of compliance is relatively small and that funds will still have considerable leeway -- being free to use terms like "growth" or "small capitalization," for example, that refer more to strategies of investment than to types of securities. 
William H. Miller III, a portfolio manager whose Legg Mason Value Trust has beaten the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for 11 consecutive years, would be unaffected, even though his definition of "value" embraces AOL Time Warner, hardly a value stock by traditional standards. On a price-to-earnings basis, the company's shares are about three times as expensive as the average stock in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Burton J. Greenwald, a consultant in Philadelphia, was pleased with the S.E.C. rule change. "The name will be more descriptive, and I think the investor will benefit" over all, he said. Mr. Greenwald added, however, that in some cases, funds investing in narrowly defined sectors could become more volatile.
"If you're going to make a bet on telecommunications, it's going to be 80 percent telecom," instead of 65 percent, he said.
TYPICALLY, fund sponsors said in interviews, the new rule was only part of the motivation for name changes.
Safeco, for example, increasingly found Ginnie Mae bonds too confining an investment niche -- one that excluded even the obligations of the company's cousins, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
"It needed to be broadened anyway to make a better product," said Victoria Martinsen, a spokeswoman for the fund. It will be renamed this spring in the normal cycle of shareholder votes.
Similarly, the Growth Fund of the Northwest, already more than 90 percent invested in five of the region's states, is using the occasion of the new requirement to change its name to the West Coast Stock fund, adding California to its investment possibilities. The move gives it "a larger universe to ply our trade," said Randall L. Yoakum, chief investment officer for WM Advisors, the fund's adviser, which is based in Seattle.
The impending bite of the new rule figured in the decision by Southeast Asset Management to close and then last month liquidate Longleaf Partners Realty, a six-year-old, $500 million fund based in Memphis. Because of mergers, conversions to investment trust status and few new public offerings, suitable investment opportunities in its sector shrank severely.
"You might have to force yourself into a company not normally qualifying, just to maintain the 80 percent," said Lee Harper, marketing vice president.
Rule 35d-1, as the S.E.C.'s policy on fund names is now formally known, prohibits names that use terms like "guaranteed" or "insured" in a way that implies federal backing. Even if a fund meets the 80 percent test, the rule says, its name may be misleading if it implies an even higher commitment. Index funds and tax-exempt funds are two examples.
The commission considered but rejected doing away with its policy of requiring bond funds with names that include "short term," "intermediate term" or "long term" to have certain dollar-weighted average maturities -- less than three years for short-term funds, 3 to 10 years for intermediate term and more than 10 years for long term. It said the policy provides "reasonable constraints" against their misuse.
But the rule permits sponsors leeway in various, less definable realms. "The rule does not apply to fund names that incorporate terms such as 'growth' and 'value' that connote types of investment strategies as opposed to types of investments," the commission decided. Nor does the rule cover terms like "balanced," "international," "global" or those describing the capitalization of portfolio companies as small, medium or large.
That means "you can still be 90 percent domestic and call yourself global," said Russel Kinnel, an analyst at Morningstar. But he said that including these terms would have been unnecessarily restrictive. 
For one thing, stocks can migrate between categories. A company that was mid-cap in 1996 might have become a large cap three years later, said Geoffrey H. Bobroff, a consultant in East Greenwich, R.I. The Stratton Growth fund, for example, began life in 1972 by investing in growth stocks but has mutated over the decades to become classified as a value fund. 
Mr. Roye of the S.E.C. said funds needed to maintain flexibility. "There are different ways to achieve an investment strategy," he said. "If we tried to be very specific, we could be out of date five years from now."
Moreover, Mr. Bobroff said fund managers were increasingly sensitive to accusations of style drift -- when portfolios are allowed to stray outside specified parameters. "Buyers have become much more demanding that people stick to a disclosed style," he said.
Nevertheless, while the new rule may help investors make decisions, there is no substitute for looking at what portfolio managers actually buy and sell. 
"Even with added enforcement, the name still doesn't tell you very much," Mr. Kinnel said, pointing to funds that are simply named "Janus" and "Fidelity." "You still have to go by the portfolio."

HEADLINE: Huge Decline Seen In Budget Surplus Over Next Decade 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 

 BODY:
Analysts from both parties say the budget surplus for the next decade has shrunk to less than a third of what was projected a year ago, setting up an especially intense partisan battle over taxes and spending in the midst of an election-year recession.
 As the Bush administration and Congress prepare to debate a new round of budget proposals, the analysts said the government's $2 trillion annual budget was likely to end up tens of billions of dollars or more in the red for each of the next several years before returning to surpluses for the rest of the decade. 
 The government will end up in deficit for at least the next few years, they predicted, despite pressure from the White House for budget cuts or freezes in many areas outside the campaign against terrorism.
"We're a world away from where we were at this time last year," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee. "I'm not sure how you solve this equation, arithmetically or politically." 
The new figures, developed separately by the Democratic staff of the House Budget Committee and the Republican staff of the Senate Budget Committee, are an effort to predict official figures to be released by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office this month and the White House's Office of Management and Budget next month. 
The numbers developed by the two staffs are very similar. They provide a clear sense of the scale of the reversal in the nation's fiscal fortunes in the wake of the economic downturn, the Sept. 11 attacks and the $1.35 trillion tax cut President Bush pushed through last year over opposition from most Democrats.
With the money drying up and Democrats and Republicans facing painful choices between cutting the budget and abandoning any pretense of fiscal responsibility, the political and economic considerations are complex. 
Democrats have attacked the Bush tax cut, arguing that it has sliced deeply into the surplus, and they are trying to link it to the recession by suggesting that the resulting budget problems are keeping long-term interest rates higher than they would normally be during a downturn. 
Mr. Bush and Republicans on Capitol Hill are defending the tax cut as appropriate medicine for the weak economy and using the figures to increase pressure on Democrats to hold down spending increases.
In his weekly radio address, President Bush said he would meet with his economic advisers when he returned on Monday from a trip to California and Oregon, "to discuss the latest economic data and work for a quick recovery for our economy." He urged Congress to act on his proposals, which include further tax cuts and provisions to benefit unemployed workers, ideas that would further increase the deficit.
With surpluses apparently having given way to deficits in the short run, and with the long-term surplus a fraction of what was anticipated a year ago, both parties are being forced to scale back plans for initiatives like providing retirees with help buying prescription medicine.
They also seem to have little chance of making good on their pledges to use the part of the budget surplus generated by Social Security to pay off most of the $3.3 trillion national debt in the next decade.
In a report completed on Friday, the Democratic staff of the House Budget Committee estimated that the surplus for the 10 years ending in 2011 would be $1.79 trillion, compared with a projection by the Congressional Budget Office a year ago of $5.61 trillion for the same period. The 10-year outlook is likely to be slightly brighter in the forecast the Congressional Budget Office will release this month, because that projection will add the estimated surplus for 2012 and drop the presumed deficit for this year.
The Democratic analysts said the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, was on track to run a deficit of at least $3 billion. That figure, though, rests on the assumption that Congress and the administration do not increase spending on the war, domestic security and programs like aid to farmers. 
More likely, the Democrats said, the deficit this year will be a minimum of $15 billion once those issues are addressed, and much more if the two parties agree on an economic recovery package. Just a month ago, the two parties were considering economic stimulus plans that would have cost as much as $90 billion this year.
For next year, the Democratic analysis said, the deficit would be at least $43 billion and more likely would be $70 billion or above.
In a report completed last week, the Republican staff of the Senate Budget Committee estimated that the surplus for this fiscal year through 2011 would be $1.86 trillion. 
The Republican analysis showed the government eking out a $1 billion surplus this year and next year. But because that projection did not account for the near certainty that Congress would approve more money for fighting the war and for other issues, Republicans said they assumed the budget would end up tens of billions of dollars in deficit for those years, especially given the election-year pressure on both parties to increase spending.
"It puts a lot of things in a tight box," said G. William Hoagland, the Republican staff director for the Senate Budget Committee. 
Both the Democratic and Republican figures show the government dipping into the Social Security surplus to pay for general government operations for most of the decade, significantly reducing the amount of money available for debt reduction. 
"If we had one agreement that was bipartisan and bicameral, it was that we would save the Social Security surpluses by buying up the national debt," Mr. Spratt said. "As you go through these numbers, you see any hope of accomplishing that dashed."
The worsened fiscal outlook has created a bind for Mr. Bush, whose team is completing the budget plan he will submit to Congress on Feb. 4, covering the fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1. Mr. Bush is scheduled to meet in the coming week with his budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., to sign off on the final numbers.
Mr. Daniels said he expected the administration's deficit and surplus projections to be similar to those of the Congressional Budget Office and those developed by analysts within the two parties. He said that the 10-year surplus projections would be scaled back substantially, and that for the next two years the budget would be roughly in balance before the costs of any new initiatives.
Mr. Daniels said the budget that Mr. Bush will submit will call for overall growth in spending, primarily by increasing financing for the Pentagon and for domestic security programs.
"You can look for the rest of government to grow, but much more slowly," he said. "
Administration officials said that programs like the National Science Foundation and the Women, Infants and Children program, which provides healthy food to poor children and pregnant women, would get more money under their plan.
But Congressional aides from both parties said the administration has signaled that it intends to freeze or cut many other programs, including the Smithsonian Institution and the Army Corps of Engineers, all of which have powerful patrons inside and outside Congress.
Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said the budget squeeze was a direct result of Mr. Bush's tax cut, which he said was sold on the basis that last year's surplus projections were, if anything, too pessimistic.
"Now we're seeing real consequences, in terms of seeing a flood of red ink facing us not just this year but for years to come," Mr. Conrad said.

HEADLINE: BUSH, ON OFFENSE, SAYS HE WILL FIGHT TO KEEP TAX CUTS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 5 

 BODY:
President Bush used his first major appearance of the new year today to declare to an audience in central California that Democrats would reverse the tax cuts of last year "over my dead body."
 In a swing through two states he lost in the 2000 election, Mr. Bush tried to turn the national discussion from the war on terrorism back to strategies for ending the recession and easing unemployment, the issues his political aides believe will dominate this year's midterm elections. 
 Mr. Bush's flat declaration today, aimed at Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, echoed his father's pledge at the 1988 Republican national convention in New Orleans, "Read my lips: No new taxes." President George Bush backed away from that promise two years later, at tremendous political cost, a lesson his son is said to have taken to heart. 
While never mentioning Mr. Daschle's name today, President Bush used a "town meeting" in Ontario, Calif., to ridicule the Democratic leader's critique of the effects of the tax cut last year. He urged Americans to rally behind his economic program, stalled in the Senate, the way they rallied behind his war.
"There are going to be people who say, 'We can't have the tax cut go through anymore,' " said Mr. Bush, who appeared relaxed and to be enjoying himself after 10 days at his Texas ranch. "And I challenge their economics when they tell you raising taxes will help the country recover."
Then, after a pause, he added: "Not over my dead body will they raise your taxes." The members of crowd, which included many Latinos who have settled here in what Californians call the "Inland Empire" about an hour and a half drive east of Los Angeles, roared with approval.
Mr. Daschle, considered a potential candidate for the Democratic nomination for president in 2004, has so far avoided calling for a reversal of the 2001 tax cut. But in a speech on Friday, he accused President Bush and the Republicans of triggering the "most dramatic fiscal deterioration in our nation's history" by pushing through the cut, which will amount to $1.35 trillion over the next decade unless it is amended.
Today, in a statement issued after Mr. Bush's speech, Mr. Daschle suggested that the president had deliberately distorted Mr. Daschle's views.
"No amount of hot rhetoric will get the economy back on track," he said. "Let me be clear, I proposed short-term tax cuts to create jobs and generate investment and long-term fiscal discipline, not tax increases."
Mr. Daschle repeated his argument that the tax cuts had reversed an era of fiscal discipline and turned surpluses into deficits. "It is time they explain to the American people what they intend to do about the hole they dug," Mr. Daschle said of the Republicans.
Mr. Bush's swing through the West Coast today was intended to focus on the problem of rising unemployment, especially here in Oregon, which has the highest unemployment rate in the country, 7.4 percent. But he made no new proposals, and his aides referred reporters to legislation passed by the House, but not by the Senate, that would extend unemployment benefits and help the unemployed continue their medical insurance.
In Portland this afternoon, Mr. Bush repeated his argument to an enthusiastic crowd, but avoided repeating "over my dead body." He said simply, "The answer for those who want to raise our taxes is no."
He told the Portland audience there were already some reasons to hope economic recovery was under way, though he did not square that with his call for more stimulus. "I believe 2002 is going to be a fabulous year for America," Mr. Bush said.
In past years, political debate in Washington would center on what kind of compensating cuts would be made to avoid increasing the deficit. But neither party is talking in those terms now. Mark McClellan, a domestic policy adviser, said only "our goal is to stay out of deficits by restoring economic growth as quickly as possible."
Mr. Bush also used the Portland speech to suggest for the first time that voicing a terrorist creed would be viewed by his administration in the same terms as committing an act of terrorism. He told the crowd that anyone "who espouses a philosophy that's terrorist and bent, I assure you we will bring that person to justice." His aides did not elaborate.
In his speech in California and at a question-and-answer session today where he roamed the stage, Mr. Bush previewed his political strategy for the coming months -- a blend of counterterrorism and counter-Daschleism. He began with an account of America's military successes in Afghanistan, mentioning Osama bin Laden once in passing. Then Mr. Bush wove to the need to back up military success with the adoption of his economic strategy.
"It's time to take the spirit of unity that has been prevalent in fighting the war and bring it to Washington, D.C.," he said.
In the past few days his aides have subtly tried to merge the two issues by dropping their references to an "economic stimulus plan" in favor of a slightly different locution, calling the same legislation an "economic security plan." That puts it on the same level as an initiative stalled in the Senate, the president's "energy security plan."
It is a clear effort to blunt the Democratic strategy of backing Mr. Bush on the war and battling him on domestic issues, starting with the economy. In recent days Mr. Bush's top advisers, led by Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, and Karen P. Hughes, have mapped out a strategy that tries to capitalize on Mr. Bush's tremendous approval ratings to win early legislative victories once Congress is back in session at the end of the month.
Time may be short. The White House suspects those approval ratings are bound to drop as the shock of the Sept. 11 attacks wears off.
Today, Mr. Bush combined techniques from the campaign with the more serious demeanor he has gained since Sept. 11. "Now that I'm in California I've got to walk around like a talk show host," he joked as he took a microphone and wandered amid the friendly crowd. He preceded his economic discussion with a moment of remembrance for Sgt. First Class Nathan R. Chapman, an Army Special Forces soldier from San Antonio, who on Friday became the first American soldier killed by hostile fire in Afghanistan.
But Mr. Bush said little new about the war and offered no hint of where it would lead next, but twice he called the effort in Afghanistan "the first front," reminding his audience that he was committed to routing out terrorist groups elsewhere.
He focused his foreign policy remarks on the need to develop a middle class in Mexico, a favorite issue of his before Sept. 11, and one that fits into his economic plans.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
ForgottenIn the Boom, Hard Truths Are Relearned

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
 Here are a few lessons gathered from the recession so far.

DON'T SEND CONGRESS TO DO AN ADULT'S JOB -- Given an opportunity to take quick action to help laid-off workers and encourage companies to begin investing in equipment again, Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill failed to pass a stimulus bill. They circled each other for three months in the fall, then concluded that they would rather debate ideology in the 2002 elections than compromise and act quickly to help their constituents.
 In a closely divided government, the outcome was no surprise. But it underscored the primacy of monetary policy in responding to the business cycle. Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve began their aggressive interest rate reductions long before it was clear that the economic slowdown would become a downturn, and they eased policy four times just in the three months after Sept. 11.

IN TIME, BUTTER TRUMPS GUNS -- Asked to name the top issues for the government to address, respondents to a Harris Poll put terrorism at the top of the list in October, at 43 percent. The economy was second, at 20 percent. But by mid-December, after the recession had been made official, the economy was No. 1, at 32 percent, with terrorism at 22 percent.
Right now, Americans feel good about their government in general and about President Bush in particular. But the polling figures are a reminder that when voters go into the ballot box, they think first of their own livelihoods -- and just as they reward the party in power when times are good, they punish it when jobs are disappearing and incomes stop growing.

BUDGET PROJECTIONS ARE BUNK -- A year ago, the Congressional Budget Office forecast that the federal government would run a surplus over the next decade of $5.6 trillion. When the office releases new projections in a few weeks, the comparable figure is likely to be $1.5 trillion to $2 trillion.
Some of the swing is a result of the $1.35 trillion tax cut that President Bush signed into law in June. But most of it is a result of the weaker economy, which in a few months has altered the nation's agenda for 10 years or more by eating up the revenue that both parties had counted on to pay for favored programs.

ECONOMIC NATIONALISM IS ALIVE -- Globalization is making national borders less and less relevant to economic life. Consider Europe, where a dozen nations have put aside monetary sovereignty and cultural identity to bind themselves to a single currency and supranational institutions like the European Central Bank.
But Europe would do well, as it celebrates the successful launch of the euro, to take a look at Argentina, which is being ripped apart by a currency crisis. Argentina tried the developing-world version of what Europe is doing; it tied its currency, the peso, to the United States dollar, effectively giving up control of monetary policy in exchange for lower inflation. But when the economy went into a tailspin, Argentina had no way to respond.
The results seem likely to include not just a repudiation of the peso-dollar link, but also a backlash against the proponents of that link, primarily the United States and the International Monetary Fund. Argentina, having defaulted, is free to pursue a more protectionist, inward-looking brand of politics.

DON'T TRUST IDEAS BORN IN A BOOM -- When capital is cheap and everyone is looking for a quick score, investors and executives tend to adopt strategies built on the notion that they will succeed because everything else is succeeding. During this business cycle, the dot-coms were the first casualty of that idea, followed by much of the telecommunications industry, airlines and, most recently, the Enron Corporation.
More nasty surprises are in store for investors and employees in other industries that are now being tested by a downturn. As they emerge, so will increased pressure for tighter regulation and new standards for auditors and stock analysts.

A PRODUCTIVITY "MIRACLE" WASN'T QUITE -- The most important economic development of the last decade was the surge in the growth of productivity, the most basic measure of business efficiency and the key variable in the economy's capacity for long-term expansion. Productivity growth has held up reasonably well through the recession, suggesting that its improvement is more than a cyclical phenomenon. But the latest estimates suggest that the surge was not quite as pronounced as initially thought. When the recovery begins, the ebullient "new paradigm" optimism of the late 1990's will have to give way to a more tempered but still upbeat outlook.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Landlord Prepares For a U.S. Makeover

BYLINE:  By IRA BRESKIN 

 BODY:
MANY Canadians harbor resentment toward the enormous shadow cast by the United States on topics from beer to hockey to vowel sounds. That sweeping generalization may soon apply to commercial real estate.
 Some of the biggest commercial landlords in North America are based in Canada. But one of them has renounced its national roots, and in the next few months, if shareholders approve, it will become a naturalized American corporate citizen. 
 The company, the TrizecHahn Corporation, which already manages trophy properties like the Sears Tower in Chicago, the Grace building in New York and the new Hollywood and Highland center in Los Angeles, home of the Academy Awards, is literally moving from Toronto to New York. The move involves some workers, furniture and even its share listing, which is shifting from the Toronto Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange. 
Moreover, Trizec is moving in to New York just as some companies, rattled by the Sept. 11 attacks, are thinking of moving out.
Trizec officials said they were unaware of any company that had undertaken a similar change. Business historians said the only other remotely comparable example that came to mind was the 1986 relocation of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., a financially troubled maker of farm machinery, from Toronto to Buffalo. That company, which traced its Canadian roots back to the mid-1800's, changed its name to the Varity Corporation and was later sold in pieces to other companies.
Under Trizec's makeover, the company would sell all its properties in Canada and Europe. That would leave it focused solely on office buildings in the United States, where it owns or manages about 49 million square feet of space -- the equivalent of more than three World Trade Centers.
That would make Trizec the second-largest publicly traded real estate company in the country, behind Equity Office Properties of Chicago, controlled by the investor Sam Zell, which has 125 million square feet of office space.
The change is more than just a statement about Trizec's direction. It also reflects a broader acknowledgment that even with a slumping economy, the United States offers the kinds of tax advantages and business incentives for commercial real estate companies that Canada and other countries do not.
"We decided to create a structure that is reflective of the reality of our business," Christopher Mackenzie, Trizec's president and chief executive, said in an interview. "We decided to sell out in Canada because we didn't see the same growth opportunities as in the United States."
MR. MACKENZIE, a Briton who previously ran the European operations of GE Capital, has no second thoughts about overlooking national identities for business advantage in a global economy. His conversion strategy will qualify Trizec for significant tax breaks that it plans to share with current investors, on both sides of the United States-Canada border,and to use those breaks to attract new investors.
Trizec's change may not sit well with everyone, particularly Canadian nationalists who have lamented what they see as the growing hegemony of American companies. But so far no organized opposition has surfaced in Canada, partly because Trizec is shedding its Canadian assets.
"No one would quibble with this specific company moving," said Stephen Blank, a professor of international business and management at Pace University's Lubin Business School in New York.
But others say Trizec's move will be watched closely by other Canadian businesses. "This could be the precursor of more relocations, more similar actions because of the large investment Canadian comapanies have in U.S real estate," said Peter Morici, a professor at the University of Maryland's business school and an expert in Canada trade.
Mr. Mackenzie has been working on Trizec's makeover since he became chief executive in December 2000. Trizec's chairman, the billionaire financier Peter Munk, who also heads the Barrick Gold Corporation, hired him after Trizec had diversified, without much success, into hotels and retailing properties.
The plan to leave Canada was announced with little fanfare on Sept. 24, less than two weeks after the attack on the World Trade Center. Senior managers said the attack and its aftermath had not delayed the change, which still must be approved by American and Canadian shareholders in separate votes scheduled for late March or early April. Under the change, Trizec would convert into a real estate investment trust, or REIT, the structure adopted by its major American competitors because of significant tax advantages.
REIT's pay no federal income tax on profits distributed to shareholders. Moreover, by moving to the United States, Trizec will no longer pay a 10 percent tax on dividends distributed to its United States shareholders, as currently required under federal tax law.
"I think the reorganization is terrific for investors," said Lee Schalop, an analyst at Banc of America Securities in New York. "It gives them a security that's comparable to other competing companies."
The company's recent share performance, however, does not necessarily show enthusiasm. They traded in the $18 range after the plan was announced but closed on Friday at $16.05.
While Trizec's move to the United States is unusual, the company is taking extraordinary steps to accommodate shareholders in Canada.
After the change, Trizec's remaining non-office properties will be owned and packaged for sale by Canco, a new sister Canadian company owned by Trizec's Canadian shareholders. Canco will maintain a shareholder dividend equivalent to that of the Trizec REIT. It will also have a roughly 40 percent stake in the REIT, the same percentage that Canadian investors now hold in Trizec.
Those conditions are meant to satisfy regulators in both countries, which require that each company is majority owned by local taxpayers in order to minimize their tax liability.
REGARDLESS whether Trizec's reorganization benefits the company's shareholders, its United States tenants should expect to pay higher rents.
Mr. Mackenzie said the company's strategy is to continually upgrade properties to justify higher rents at lease expiration. And, he added, Trizec's office properties are currently almost fully booked -- at rents about 27 percent below average market rates.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Fixing Argentina: Whose Job Is It?

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
ON the day he was designated Argentina's fifth president in two weeks, Eduardo Duhalde cautioned his countrymen not to try to fix blame for the country's chaos. Then he did just that. 
 "It's time to tell the truth," he told the Argentine Congress last week. "Argentina is bankrupt. Argentina is destroyed. This model has destroyed everything." 
 Many Argentines had expected him to announce the end of their unique decade-old plan that pegged their peso to the dollar -- a plan that shrank Argentina's hyperinflation to single digits before turning into a drag on the economy during the last four years of recession.
Mr. Duhalde still is expected to dump the peso peg. But his speech could also be read as a condemnation of a much broader economic model, the one sold by Washington all over Latin America that consists of deregulated markets, privatized state businesses and liberalized trade rules for once-closed economies.
Regardless of how long he lasts in office, Mr. Duhalde has already raised questions sure to complicate American relations with Argentina and, perhaps, other Latin countries: What is the responsibility of the United States for the economic meltdown and the shadow it casts on Argentina's political future? And what responsibility does it have for getting the problems fixed before they spread to other Latin countries?
Many developing countries bought Washington's economic model in the 1990's, but none more wholeheartedly than Argentina, which for a few years became a symbol of the model's success. Certainly, no other country went so far as to adopt its exchange rate plan.
President Bush sent Mr. Duhalde an encouraging note last week, but his underlying message was the same one he gave all the players in Argentina's recent game of presidential musical chairs: "You got yourselves into this mess, so get yourselves out. Then we'll talk about help."
In fact, the Bush administration has been distancing itself from Argentina for a year, calculating that the country's financial troubles will not spill over to other countries, as happened when Mexico's currency collapsed in 1994-1995. In that case, President Clinton hammered together a $50 billion rescue plan -- the kind of bailout that the Bush administration now rules out.
There is an important distinction to be made between the United States's closest and most distant Latin neighbors. "Historically, in the south, the most important relationship has been with the United Kingdom," rather than with the United States, said Guillermo O'Donnell, a professor of government at the University of Notre Dame. This is true even for resentments. Professor O'Donnell, an Argentine, said Mexicans still pine for Texas and California the way Argentines gaze at Britain's Falkland Islands. Mexico sends 85 percent of its exports to the United States, but less than 12 percent of Argentina's trade is with the United States.
But that is not to say that the United States, as the hemisphere's dominant power, has exerted no influence on Argentina. President Jimmy Carter's focus on human rights put pressure on Argentina's military regimes in the 70's. Later, Argentina's generals were gravely disappointed when the Reagan administration opposed their disastrous effort to seize the Falklands, then backed the country's return to democracy.
WHAT followed was something of a honeymoon. Argentina freed itself of economic chaos by hitching its future to Washington's broad economic vision of free, competitive global markets. Under Carlos Menem and Fernando de la Rua, it drew close enough to the United States to be accused by Fidel Castro of "licking the Yankee boot." The crowning touch, the currency peg, was adopted in 1991 as the brainchild not of Washington, but of Economics Minister Domingo Cavallo. 
"It's true that the United States didn't cause Argentina's problems in the direct sense of imposing a particular mechanism," said Manuel Pastor, professor of Latin American and Latino studies at the University of California, Santa Cruz, referring to the currency peg. "But we have been going through most of Latin America offering advice and pushing people toward liberalization and privatization." So, he says, Washington does share responsibility for the current chaos. "Having prescribed the tonic for all these countries," he said, "we should be willing to help when the tonic proves toxic."
Others insist that it is not the economic model that is at fault in Argentina but the specific mechanism of the currency peg. "It is an absolutely fundamental error for someone to conclude that Argentina is in a mess because it embraced market economics," said John O'Leary, a former ambassador to Chile from 1998 to 2001. If market economics were at fault, he said, Chile could not have achieved the solid economic base it now has.
Chile can place its debt on the international markets at competitive rates. It has lowered tariffs and may sign a free trade deal with the United States this year. Most important, it has shown a restraint unknown in Argentina. Its public debt is about $5 billion. Argentina's, with twice the population, exceeds $130 billion. 
But the arguments for the United States taking greater responsibility in the Argentine crisis go beyond mere economics. Argentina is a big player in the neighborhood that the Bush administration insists is closely linked to the United States' future. The democracies Washington has supported in the region are fragile to some degree. As the open market model has sputtered from country to country, democracy itself has become less popular, paving the way for populists like Venezuela's Hugo Chavez to hoard power. 
Given his early comments, and his history as a free-spending, crowd-pleasing governor, Mr. Duhalde worries those who feel him capable of a similar course.
Latin America as a whole remains plagued by deep inequality and unemployment, and with few exceptions -- Mexico and Chile are the major ones -- free-market reform plans have disappointed those who expected them to solve those deeper problems. An overt repudiation of the open market in a frantic Argentina would reverberate across the region, challenging uncertain democracies like those in Ecuador and Peru, while fanning the embers of anti-Americanism.
And then there is the fact that a default on its debt by Argentina would be the largest in history. Outsiders have had the chance to safeguard savings, but these are somewhat uncharted waters. Some of the economic analysts who have confidently predicted there will be no contagion effect on other countries are the same ones who denied that Mexico was in trouble in 1994.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Seeing Is Believing; 
America as Reflected in Its Leader

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IS it him, or is it us?
In the four months since Sept. 11, President Bush has seemed transformed from a casually educated son of privilege into a mature leader of a nation at war. Gone are the jokes about his I.Q. and his attention span. The president himself has appeared to rise to his new mission against terror time after time, from his tough-minded speech to Congress on Sept. 20 to his eloquent peroration about "the struggle of memory against forgetting" that marked the three-month anniversary of the attacks on Dec. 11.
 But the United States has changed, too, perhaps far more than its leader. The deadliest terrorist assault in the nation's history has left Americans feeling vulnerable and unambiguously patriotic. "All of this was brought upon us in a single day," Mr. Bush reminded the nation on Sept. 20. "And night fell on a different world." Americans quickly rallied around the president, as historically has happened at times of national crisis. 
 And yet events since Sept. 11, not least Mr. Bush's stratospheric approval ratings, suggest that something more unusual has happened to the nation's perception of its president.
In the days since the attacks, historians explain, Americans have projected on to Mr. Bush the qualities they desperately want him to have. That projection has worked, historians say, because Mr. Bush has managed to display those qualities -- strength, compassion, a mastery of a complex war on many fronts. It is significant that the attacks on Sept. 11, on two symbols of American financial and military might, might also have hit the White House, or so those terrified staffers who evacuated it believed. But when the White House was spared, Americans seemed to turn even more toward it and the president as symbols of hope and calm and security. The man had merged with the office.
Bruce J. Schulman, the director of American Studies at Boston University, argued that Mr. Bush "was never as silly or shallow as many people depicted him before." Nonetheless, he said, "It may be that certain of his qualities that seemed less than presidential before -- the inarticulateness, the folksiness, the seeming lack of sophistication -- now have become badges of things that are distinctive and appealing about American society at a time it seems under attack."
In a culture that has demonstrated marked suspicion of the intellectual and always admired the frontier, with its images of eternal promise, Mr. Bush's language of the wild West, of wanting Osama bin Laden "dead or alive," has been derided by academics even as it was embraced by the public. Mr. Bush's first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, in November, was similarly direct, free of the usual diplomatic niceties and was praised at home, even as leaders of other nations called it blunt and U.S.-centric. 
"He is someone who views the world in reductionist terms, who sees life as a clash between good and evil," said Robert Dallek, a presidential historian and the author of a two-volume biography of Lyndon B. Johnson. "It may not be entirely wrong, but the point is, this is something that caters to the public's interest right now."
In the same way, people now seem willing to indulge Mr. Bush's real forays to the West. Last summer, as the president was beginning a month-long break at his Texas ranch, polls showed that 55 percent of Americans thought that Mr. Bush was spending too much time away from Washington. He was taking it so easy, why should he need a vacation? But Mr. Bush will have spent 10 days of vacation at his ranch when he returns to Washington tomorrow, all without a single word of criticism suggesting that he didn't need the rest.
Other historians say that it is the unique nature of the American presidency that causes Americans to turn to Washington at a time of crisis, and that the horrific quality of the attacks simply intensified the reaction to Mr. Bush. Unlike prime ministers in the parliamentary democracies of Europe, the American president is head of state as well as head of government -- the embodiment of the nation.
"We want presidents to symbolize the country," said Michael Kazin, a history professor at Georgetown University and the co-author of "America Divided: The Civil War of the 1960's." "That's what presidents are for."
THE attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon were in that sense attacks on Mr. Bush, with the result that there was far less public discussion about the massive security failure of his government and far more sympathy about the burdens he must now bear in office. 
"If he does well, that means we're safer, and we want that to happen," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster. Mr. Bush's performance in the first weeks after the attacks generated his high approval ratings, Mr. McInturff said, but that initial performance does not explain why a Republican president currently has a 75 percent approval rating among African-Americans, most of whom did not support him when he ran for office. But now, Mr. McInturff said, Mr. Bush has come to represent American stability.
"They're investing not only in him personally, but as a way to express their hope for the country," Mr. McInturff said. "The presidency is the extension of the American public and how we feel about our country."
The vote for the president is certainly the most personal vote the public casts. The relationship between president and citizen is unique among all other elected officials.
Psychoanalysts say that there is nothing surprising about projecting qualities on to those in positions of leadership, and that it fulfills a basic need. "We always project qualities onto our presidents," said Peter Wolson, a Beverly Hills psychoanalyst and the past president of the Los Angeles Institute and Society for Psychoanalytic Studies. "The public has a need for an idealized hero. The public wants the president to succeed, even though there may be envy and lots of other conflicted feelings. There's a wish that the president will be a strong, powerful father figure."
Though Mr. Bush did not seem such a figure at first, the crisis has given him a chance to transform himself in the eyes of the public. His story can be seen as that of a particular kind of mythic hero dear to the American imagination.
"What do Prince Hal, Moses and Frodo have in common?" asked Jonathan Lear, a psychoanalyst and philosophy professor at the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago. "None of them seek power, yet they're able to rise to the challenges that history, God or sheer chance deals them." 
Prince Hal, the wastrel son of King Henry IV, surprised everyone by becoming a courageous soldier. Moses didn't want to lead the Jews, but God forced it upon him. Frodo Baggins, the sweet-tempered hobbit of "The Lord of the Rings," was given a ring by his uncle, then told he had to save the world by returning it to its source. President Bush, Mr. Lear argued, is seen as the recipient of a similar kind of tragic luck.
Has Mr. Bush changed? Of course he has, even if the line from his White House underlings is that the public is now seeing in the man what they always saw. Anyone who has watched Mr. Bush for the past four months can see how confident and assured he has become in speeches and in unscripted question-and-answer sessions with reporters, how he has command of the issues at hand.
But the public has changed, too. The question is whether it will stay changed for the next chapter of the Bush presidency, when Prince Hal makes the push to revive his domestic agenda.
"When they look to Bush, they say, 'Well, he surprised me on the international front,' " said Mark Penn, a Democratic pollster, " 'but that doesn't mean I think he can run the economy.' "

HEADLINE: A Gesture by Pakistan's President Is Not Enough for India 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER

DATELINE: KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 5 

 BODY:
In a theatrical gesture delivered with a flourish onstage, Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, strode up to Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India today and thrust out his hand.
 Mr. Vajpayee shook it, and the audience erupted in applause, relieved that there was at least some sign of contact between two nations that are engaged in a volatile conflict that threatens to turn into a war. 
 But to Mr. Vajpayee, the general's gesture was not simply "a hand of genuine and sincere friendship," as the general had described it. When Mr. Vajpayee rose to give his own speech, he used the moment to say he had had enough of symbolic gestures from Pakistan.
He told General Musharraf, in front of all the heads of state in the region, that he expected a halt to terrorist acts against India carried out by groups operating from Pakistan. India has blamed Islamic groups that have been backed by Pakistan for an Oct. 1 suicide bomb attack on a state legislative assembly and a Dec. 13 assault on Parliament.
"I invited President Musharraf to Agra," Mr. Vajpayee said, alluding to talks the two leaders held during the summer in that Indian city. "We were rewarded with a terrorist attack on the Jammu and Kashmir assembly and, last month, on the Parliament of India."
When all the speeches by South Asian leaders participating in the summit meeting here finished, Mr. Vajpayee, 77, walked creakily on his bad knees past the vigorous general with nary a sidewise glance, ignoring another opportunity to shake hands.
Those glimpses of two leaders onstage captured India's festering anger and suggested why it has been so difficult for India and Pakistan to find enough common ground even to sit down formally to look for a peaceful resolution of their conflict. Though senior leaders from both sides have had private discussions, it became clear today in India's public comments that Pakistan has not yet done enough to satisfy its demands for action.
The United States, Britain and other nations had hoped that the two countries would use the meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation as an opportunity to reduce tensions, especially since leaders of India and Pakistan are conveniently staying in the same hotel.
But by late this evening, it had still not happened, and the conference is to end on Sunday. The Pakistani reaction to the day's events was murky. Pakistani officials canceled a news conference this evening.
General Musharraf's speech today did not say what the Indians had hoped. He condemned terrorism without qualification, but he did not claim any responsibility on Pakistan's part for the Islamic groups that had been waging a "holy war" against India in Kashmir.
Instead, alluding to the insurgency in Kashmir, India's only majority Muslim state, the general said the world had to draw a distinction "between acts of legitimate resistance and freedom struggles on the one hand, and acts of terrorism on the other."
The general has defined the violence in Kashmir as part of a freedom struggle, while India sees it as terrorism.
Since the Dec. 13 attack on Parliament, there has been a huge military buildup along India and Pakistan's common border, and the countries have downgraded diplomatic relations with each other. India also cut bus, rail and air links with Pakistan.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain is in India now on a long-planned tour and is expected to meet with Mr. Vajpayee on Sunday, and then go on to the Pakistani capital, Islamabad, on Monday, where he is to meet with General Musharraf.
In another indication of international concern about the current crisis, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today gave an interview to BBC -- available on every television in the hotel where the Indian and Pakistani delegations were staying. He said the United States was seriously considering sending an envoy to the region to try to calm the tensions.
Secretary Powell praised General Musharraf for the steps he has taken to arrest the leaders of the two Islamic fundamentalist groups that India has blamed for the attack on Parliament -- comments that Indian officials seemed to find galling, since they still do not think the general has done enough.
Jaswant Singh, India's minister of external affairs, said India wanted a public declaration from Pakistan saying it would stop sponsoring terrorism against India. And it has demanded that Pakistan hand over 20 suspects wanted on terrorism and criminal charges in India, contending they have found sanctuary in Pakistan.
Mr. Singh, who has talked repeatedly with Secretary Powell through the crisis, said the possibility of an envoy had not been discussed, and he reacted coolly to the idea. "The United States of America has missions in New Delhi and Islamabad," he said. "Unless the missions are not up to the task, I don't see the need for a special envoy."
In barbed references to what many Indian officials see as the United States' double standard on terrorism -- that the United States can crush it militarily in Afghanistan, but that India must be restrained -- Mr. Singh said terrorism east of Pakistan, in India, is just as bad as terrorism west of Pakistan, in Afghanistan.
"Pakistan is an ally of the United States of America," Mr. Singh said. "Good luck to the United States of America."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LESSONS; 
If Saddam Hussein Is Next, Experts Say, Do It Fast

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
If Saddam Hussein is to be taken out, experts agree, much of the reaction in the Arab world and elsewhere could be mitigated if the operation were quick.
 That, at least, is the apparent lesson of Afghanistan, where the rapidity with which the Taliban collapsed and the swift installation of a home-grown interim government seem to have muted the feared anger in Arab streets or opprobrium elsewhere in the world. 
 Few Arab leaders would regret to see President Hussein's government ended in Iraq, experts say, but as with Afghanistan, many have feared the reaction. "If it went quickly and smoothly, like Afghanistan and the Taliban, there would be no place for a public uproar," said Rolf Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat who was the chief United Nations arms inspector in Iraq from 1991 to 1997. 
But if it dragged on, or failed, Arab and Islamic militants would have a powerful weapon to incite the masses against the pro-Western governments of countries like Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
Ousting Mr. Hussein, said James R. Schlesinger, defense secretary in the Nixon and Ford administrations and a senior adviser to Lehman Brothers, "would transform the strategic map of the Middle East."
"But for that to occur we would have to achieve the outcome with efficiency and high confidence," he added.
There is little question that the Bush administration would like to take on Mr. Hussein next.
If there is a moment to get him, proponents contend, it is now. The war on terrorism has generated a global momentum against purveyors of terror. Further, if Mr. Hussein is not crushed now, he may never be.
Yet even in the wake of the Afghan operations, any talk in Washington of "getting" Mr. Hussein runs up against a wall of resistance and anxiety, at home and abroad.
There is a fear that the overwhelming international support for the American operation against Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda organization and the Taliban, which bestowed an international legitimacy on the war against terrorism, would fall apart if the United States took unilateral action to topple Mr. Hussein, especially since there is no evidence linking him to the attacks of Sept. 11.
Going after him now would revive accusations of unilateralism against the United States. It would also revive suspicions of a vendetta by veterans of the first Bush administration, which stopped short of deposing Mr. Hussein in the Persian Gulf war a decade ago.
"There were 500,000 troops on the ground in 1991, and they didn't do it," said Madeleine K. Albright, who dealt extensively with Iraq as secretary of state and as ambassador to the United Nations before that. "I think at this time, given the amount of work the administration has laid out for itself in terms of finishing the job in Afghanistan, it's hard to see that this is feasible."
The sentiment is widespread. Even Britain, America's most consistent ally, has urged caution, and so has Kofi Annan, secretary general of the United Nations. A common thread in their arguments is that it is better to stick with the devil you know. Mr. Hussein is basically being contained, the argument goes.
To move against him, by contrast, would be to plunge dangerously into the unknown -- an unstable or dismembered Iraq, a more powerful Iran, a suspension of oil supplies from one of the world's largest suppliers, dangerous shock waves through the Arab world.
Just getting to him, moreover, would be a far more dangerous undertaking than the hunt for Al Qaeda and the Taliban. The Iraqi Army is a far larger and more potent force than the Taliban. There are no proxy armies on the ground ready to advance, and however unpopular Mr. Hussein may be, there is no guarantee that his armies would quickly give up.
"If we're after evil, he's evil," said Graham Allison, director of the Belfer Center at Harvard University. "The only argument against getting rid of Saddam is nobody knows how to do it, or the cost of doing it."
Options under consideration in the administration are believed to focus on operations not involving a full-fledged invasion, but starting a conflict that internal opponents would complete. But that raises the question of whether any opposition group has the organization, leadership or capacity to overthrow Mr. Hussein. He has crushed all previous efforts.
Further, pitting the southern Shiites or the northern Kurds against the ruling Sunnis in Iraq's center could arouse angers beyond the borders of Iraq and could fracture Iraq into ethnic and religious camps, creating a new source of instability in a chronically unstable region.
Proponents of going after Mr. Hussein argue that there is no reason to assume that a successor government would necessarily fail. They contend that he is so unpopular that a determined nudge should be enough to set his own people against him.
If the United States supported the opposition, they say, it would be perceived not as an invader but as the ally of the Iraqi people fighting to liberate them, as with the Afghans.
The advocates of action argue that most Arab leaders would be glad to see Mr. Hussein go, but that they need a plausible case to make to their people -- concrete evidence of wrongdoing, perhaps, or some tangible American economic assistance.
"Some weeks ago the common wisdom was that going after Saddam would undermine our position in the Muslim world," said Richard Perle, of the American Enterprise Institute, who is an adviser to the Pentagon and a vocal advocate of action against Mr. Hussein. "Almost nobody argues that anymore, because similar things were said of the consequences of going after Taliban."
Beyond the Middle East, Washington's longing to unseat Mr. Hussein is generally resisted in Russia and Europe. Iraq owes a huge debt to Russia and is one of the few nations where Russia can exert its influence in the Middle East. France has large potential contracts in Iraq, and all European economies would be affected by the loss of 2.5 million barrels of oil a day, even for a limited period.
Even Britain has expressed reservations, worrying that extending the antiterrorism campaign to Mr. Hussein would convey the image of Americans reverting to unilateral actions.
There are those who agree with Dr. Albright that, however attractive and proper the ouster of Mr. Hussein, this is simply not the time. The hunt for international terrorists is entering a broad new phase in which international support will be even more critical, and there is no opposition ready to take power in Baghdad.
"Even those who argue that he is dangerous because of weapons of mass destruction have nothing to say about our lack of preparation," said Leon Fuerth, who was the national security adviser to Vice President Al Gore and now teaches international relations at George Washington University. "There are other ways to really, really increase the pressure on Saddam Hussein without making this the next top order of business."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Critical Path appears tobe limping back from the brink.

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
ONLY three months ago, Critical Path appeared close to collapse. With its reputation in ruin after an accounting scandal, its shares trading as low as 24 cents, and a debt of $300 million, the once highflying provider of corporate e-mail systems appeared ready to join the many remains of failed companies strewn along the Internet's trail of busted dreams.
 But Critical Path may be on the comeback path. Under a new management team, the company has quietly settled more than 50 shareholder lawsuits, brought in well-respected financiers and nursed its balance sheet closer to health. 
 The leaders of the revival are David Hayden, the founder and executive chairman, and William E. McGlashan Jr., a venture capitalist and turnaround specialist who accepted an interim executive role shortly after the scandal broke in February 2001. Mr. McGlashan is to shed the term "interim" from his title today, when the company plans to announce that it has named him full-time chief executive. 
"We made it through the valley of the shadow of death," Mr. McGlashan, 38, said in a recent interview at the company's headquarters in the South of Market neighborhood of San Francisco, which was once filled with dot-coms.
Critical Path's quarters, a four-story converted warehouse with exposed brick walls and wood beams -- will soon be part of the company's dark history. The company leased the building -- for $47 a square foot -- only a month before the accounting irregularities became known. Now, as part of its efforts to reduce operating costs to less than $30 million a quarter, half the rate of last spring, Critical Path will soon move to the sixth floor of a more staid corporate building nearby -- for $35 a square foot, reducing its rent by $1.6 million a year.
The move is just one of many ways the company's executives have tried to correct the management mistakes of the last two years. Since March, Critical Path has shed half its work force as it has withdrawn from weak businesses, most of which the company entered through a dozen acquisitions that pulled it farther and farther from its original vision: running e-mail systems and large data directories for corporations.
"What 2001 was about was re-establishing the company's financial credibility and balance sheet," said William E. Ford, a new member of the Critical Path board. "This coming year is going to be about growth and market leadership."
But before that happens, Critical Path must continue to persuade customers and investors that its business model is strong. More important, it must win back the trust it so badly damaged.
Once a Wall Street darling, with its stock soaring as high as $119.50 in March 2000, Critical Path screeched to a halt last January when it widely missed its earnings projections. Instead of the profit long promised by the company's management, Critical Path posted a loss of 16 cents a share.
But the bombshell hit two weeks later. On Feb. 2, the company suspended two top executives and started an internal investigation into its financial practices after questions arose about the way executives reported revenue from several sales contracts. The Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation, the stock plunged, and Wall Street analysts and investors began accusing Critical Path of deliberately cooking its books under heavy pressure to turn a profit.
Critical Path was eventually forced to restate its financial results from the third and fourth quarters of 2000, lowering its annual revenue 13 percent and widening its loss more than a third. The board forced out the chief executive, the president and the vice president for worldwide sales, then dismissed eight members of the sales team.
Citing the S.E.C. investigation, the company would not describe the questionable transactions. But Mr. McGlashan said they were limited to three deals. Referring to the previous management, he said: "For three deals, you went through this as a company? You cheated for three lousy deals?"
The accounting debacle struck as the economy worsened, leaving Critical Path scrambling to reassure existing and potential customers that it would survive. Mr. Hayden -- who said he was on a yearlong sabbatical from the company when the scandal occurred -- and Mr. McGlashan spent much of last summer visiting customers in the United States, Europe and Asia. During the tour they offered confidential information about the company's prospects for financing in exchange for agreements not to trade Critical Path's stock on the insider information.
Some companies balked at the sales pitch, unwilling to become involved with a company sitting under a black cloud. But others, including Morgan Stanley, DuPont and the national postal services of Italy and Germany, signed on.
DuPont uses Lotus Notes for its corporate Web-based e-mail, but hired Critical Path to operate a less sophisticated, and less expensive system for 7,000 workers in some factories and remote offices. "Obviously, one of the concerns we had was, 'Will they still be here tomorrow?' " said Irvin Lipp, a spokesman for DuPont. "They answered that question, which is why we went with them."
While software sales for the first nine months of 2001 fell 40 percent, to about $22 million, from the year before, Critical Path alleviated some doubts about its survival in November. First it announced that it would pay $17.5 million and issue warrants on 850,000 shares to settle shareholder lawsuits. The next day, the company said that investors led by General Atlantic Partners, a venture capital firm, had retired $65 million in Critical Path's debt and invested $30 million for a 26 percent stake, bringing the debt down to $38 million.
Mr. Ford, a partner with General Atlantic, and Raul J. Fernandez, chief executive of Dimension Data North America, joined the Critical Path board, restoring more credibility to the turnaround efforts. The stock price has increased moderately with the company's fortunes, closing up 20 cents, to $3.80, on Friday.
Critical Path has "done a remarkable pullback from the abyss," said Matt Cain, an analyst with the Meta Group, a research firm. "It's not necessarily out of danger, but it has been, over all, a remarkable comeback."
But the sting of betrayal will not go away easily for many investors. All 17 Wall Street analysts who followed the company early last year have dropped their coverage. One mutual fund manager who was burned by the falling stock price said he had no confidence in the company; he plans to sell his shares as soon as they rebound enough to offset some of his losses.
"In the end, everything they said about what they had appeared to be false," said the manager, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "Every once in a while you get skunked in a fraud, and we got skunked."
Critical Path executives acknowledged that they must win back Wall Street to improve a tarnished reputation. They intend to resume issuing forecasts for their quarterly results, a practice they stopped after the accounting irregularities. And Mr. McGlashan said he would revive a classic mandate of the old economy -- underpromise, overperform, be predictable -- to gradually restore investors' faith in a company that followed new economy excesses off a cliff.
"Particularly with the history of this company," Mr. McGlashan said, "you can't mess up twice."
